fields.headline: Tigana steamroller demolishes Palace
fields.trailText: Fulham 3 - 1 Crystal Palace
fields.body:
Like lambs to the slaughter, Crystal Palace became the 11th consecutive victims of Fulham's league season, one that looks increasingly likely to lead to a succession of smashed records and celebrations.

The last time Alan Smith brought a Crystal Palace side to Craven Cottage, in 1994, Chris Coleman was playing in his defence. Now he is Fulham's club captain. At the end of that season, Palace were promoted to the Premiership as champions and Fulham were relegated.

Fortunes can change rapidly in football, but already this season it appears too late for Palace to be dreaming of anything more than mid-table consolidation and for Fulham to worry themselves over anything other than automatic promotion.

It was immediately apparent that the gulf in class was not merely statistical. It is not often that a goal scored after nine minutes can be described as overdue, but when Louis Saha rose to head home Fabrice Fernandes's free-kick it was no more than the home side deserved.

Saha should have scored after two minutes when set up by Luis Boa Morte; after 10 minutes Fulham's delirious fans were cheering every successful pass, of which there were many.

But if Fulham were tempted into complacency, they were punished after 16 minutes, when Palace scored a goal that told a great deal about the difference between the sides. A second corner in quick succession led to an unsightly scrap that ended only when Neil Ruddock thumped the ball home left-footed.

Fulham took only six minutes to regain the lead, when Lee Clark capped another quick incisive move with a fine first-time finish from 15 yards.

Palace changed their shape for the second half, replacing Ruddock with the Latvian international winger Andrey Rubins, signed from Skonto Riga on Tuesday and, apparently, the quickest player Arsène Wenger has ever seen.

Briefly their increased attacking vigour hinted at redemption but Fulham's third crushed their hopes. Barry Hayles, having arrived as substitute three minutes earlier, outmuscled his marker on the right touchline and centred for Clark to score easily.

Palace at least proved that Jean Tigana's all-conquering side are not quite as strong in defence as they are in attack. They were still, though, strong enough.

fields.headline: Souness starts to make Blackburn tick
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 0 - 2 Blackburn Rovers
fields.body:
The battle of the fallen giants ended with Blackburn reprising their role of top dogs to move into the top half of the First Division last night. Two first-half goals and a compact, organised performance from the former Premiership champions were rightly rewarded with victory over a Wimbledon side also finding it hard to recapture former glories.

The reduction in Blackburn's circumstances is particularly noticeable on European weeks such as these. Five years ago they were in the Champions League where their surroundings were a lot more glamourous than this wet evening here in front of an echoing crowd of just over 6,000.

But having run Fulham close on Sunday, the signs were already there that Graeme Souness may be finally getting it together at Blackburn. After a cautious opening 20 minutes, in which each side could only muster one shot at the keeper, Rovers took the lead in embarrassing circumstances.

Stig Bjornebye, about 20 yards out on the right, curled in a free-kick and as Rovers' Craig Short went for the ball, Wimbledon's Trond Andersen tried to intervene but only managed to divert the ball into his own net.

Rovers had taken the lead at Fulham before surrendering it. And Wimbledon almost hit back when a great move involving Chris Willmott and John Hartson ended with the Rovers keeper John Filan's instinctive one-handed save to deny Jonathan Hunt.

But then Blackburn took control. Kelvin Davis saved from Garry Flitcroft before Rovers extended their lead. Just before half-time a Wimbledon clearance fell to Flitcroft about 25 yards out and the Rovers captain unleashed a stunning first-time volley into the back of the net.

Blackburn were clearly not missing their two injured strikers Matt Jansen and Nathan Blake. Wimbledon, meanwhile, were missing a lot. In an attempt to fill a few gaps, they made a double substitution at half-time, bringing on the veteran midfielder Michael Thomas and the rangy young striker Patrick Agyemang.

But the Wimbledon gang do not seem so crazy after all these years, unless one counts last Saturday's 4-4 home draw with Gillingham. The old spirit was lacking and Blackburn continued to pose the greater threat as Craig Hignett fired from close range straight at Davis then wriggled his way into the area to force a fine one-handed save from the keeper.

webTitle: Champions League: Man Utd 3 - 1 PSV Eindhoven

fields.headline: United bounce back on top
fields.standfirst:
Late rally sees Ferguson's men through after PSV threaten to snatch a point

Sheringham 9, Scholes 82, Yorke 87 | Van Bommel 76
fields.trailText: PSV threatened to snatch a point at Old Trafford before a late rally saw Man Utd to the top of the group.
fields.body:
Manchester United promised Old Trafford another feast of familiar delights last night but then lost their appetite and toyed with their food. It was a change of mood United nearly lived to regret.

For more than an hour an early goal from Teddy Sheringham promised to take United to the top of their Champions League group. PSV's attack was practically giving Fabien Barthez the evening off. But with 14 minutes remaining Mickael Silvestre headed Joonas Kolkka's centre out to Mark van Bommel, who drove the ball into the roof of the net from 25 yards.

Old Trafford feared an apparently straightforward win had been thrown away. But in the 82th minute a pass from Dwight Yorke, combined with Andy Cole's dummy, set up Paul Scholes for a chance which he took with aplomb, and in the 87th Giggs sent Yorke through for United's third. Anderlecht's 4-2 victory over Dynamo Kiev helped United go top.

United were hoping to quell the faintest tinge of doubt about their reaching the next round, PSV having won 3-1 in Eindhoven three weeks earlier. That night Sir Alex Ferguson had rotated his team to the point of breaking a thread on the screw, but last night a full-strength United sought to remind the Dutch what the English champions were made of.

The return game was not without its undercurrent of acrimony. Eric Gerets, PSV's Belgian coach, and Ferguson had accused each other of arrogance, the United manager adding a charge of diving against Gerets's players for good measure.

Pre-fight posturing apart, United knew that they needed to defeat PSV by a margin to sway any head-to-head decision should the teams finish level on points. Ideally they required an early goal. One duly arrived after eight minutes.

PSV's plan was to defend in numbers and trust that they could trap United in a web of close-covering before they came within sight of goal. Fat chance: the first time Giggs took the ball through at speed the PSV defence clearly did not have the means to cope.

Cole and Sheringham missed chances but these were merely sighters. The goal followed a corner won by Sheringham's astute through-pass to Giggs which PSV scrambled behind. Beckham swung the ball in sharply from the left and Sheringham was unmarked as he nodded the ball powerfully into the net.

PSV had to settle for a period under siege as United sought to wrap the contest up quickly. Outpassed and outmanoeuvred, the Dutch side could easily have been three down by the 20th minute.

A tendency to foul the opposition near the penalty arc was not the brightest of ideas, given Beckham's penchant for scoring in such situations. Ronald Waterreus did well to punch one of Beckham's free-kicks clear just past the quarter-hour and when, three minutes later, Beckham's swerving centre dipped dangerously into the goalmouth Ronny Johnsen chested the ball down before he was crowded out.

Having lost one of their strikers, Arnold Bruggink, who was replaced by Theo Lucius following a tackle by Gary Neville, PSV did not appear best placed to put pressure on their opponents. Yet as the fierce tempo of United's game began to ease so the Dutch champions restored some parity territorially. As Adil Ramzi began to turn Denis Irwin on the Dutch left United's defending appeared too loose and casual for comfort.

Towards half-time Manchester United remembered where their upper gears were to the extent that Sheringham might have finished the opening 45 minutes with a hat-trick. But first he saw a close-range shot deflected over the bar, after a ball from Giggs, and then in stoppage time Sheringham wafted another chance over with Giggs again the provider.

In the second half Cole was finding it hard to get past Kevin Hofland. Nevertheless the speed of Giggs on one wing and the quality of crosses from Beckham on the other continued to promise further goals.

In the 52nd minute Beckham's centre dipped teasingly into the goalmouth to be met by the head of Johnsen, only to see the ball rebound back off the underside of the bar. United badly needed one of these chances to go in, one-goal leads being what they are.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin (Brown, 81min), G Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre; Beckham (Butt, 88), Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Sheringham (Yorke, 74), Cole.

PSV Eindhoven (4-4-2): Waterreus; Van Der Weerden, Nikiforov, Hofland, Heintze; Van Der Doelen (De Jong, 73), Vogel, Van Bommel, Ramzi (Kolkka, 65); Bruggink (Lucius, 29), Kezman.

Referee : J A Fernandez Marin (Spain).

webTitle: 'He's a scorer and he wanted his first goal'

fields.headline: 'He's a scorer and he wanted his first goal'
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson reflects on a job well done at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Dwight Yorke sealed Manchester United's victory over PSV Eindhoven last night and his manager Sir Alex Ferguson conceded that it was an important goal for his Tobagan striker who has been out of favour at Old Trafford recently.

"That's his first of the season," Ferguson said. "He's had a long way to run but he's a scorer and he wanted to score his first goal."

Ferguson was a relieved man after United's ultimately comfortable win. "The number of chances we created and some of our last-third play was very good," he said. "But in the middle of the second half there was a carelessness that came into our play and PSV started to be a threat.

"[After PSV scored] there was an urgency about us and that urgency brought a better concentration in terms of our passing because it had got careless and slack in the second half.

"Overall with the chances we created we should have won by a few, but when you were 1-1 with 15 minutes to go, you've got to be happy to win 3-1. It's a great result for us and puts us top of the group. It puts us in pole position with PSV."

The PSV coach Eric Gerets was left to reflect on what was nearly a great result. "After 45 minutes it could all have been over," he said. "But little by little we played better and we scored a good goal.

"But unfortunately they scored a second goal from Scholes. We had a great dream for five or six minutes of realising something special here, but we have come away with nothing."

A defiant display by a depleted Leeds United gave David O'Leary's side a 0-0 draw with Besiktas on their return to Istanbul and kept them on top of Group H in the Champions League.

Leeds will qualify for the second phase if they beat Barcelona at Elland Road next Tuesday. O Leary said: "This is a great point for us. We were without our first-choice goalkeeper, centre-backs, a number of midfielders and our top scorer [the suspended Alan Smith] but I am delighted."

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: A quick run around the groups after matchday four.
fields.body:
Barcelona's meeting with Milan was a repeat of the 1994 European Cup final but on this occasion a hat-trick from Rivaldo denied the Italian club a victory and the chance to move above Leeds in Group H.

The Brazilian opened the scoring at the San Siro with a free-kick and though Demetrio Albertini put Milan in front with two goals in 15 first-half minutes, the first a thunderous shot, Rivaldo soon equalised. Jose Mari made it 3-2 moments later but Rivaldo levelled it again just before the hour.

"We played for a victory but it was important not to lose," Albertini said. "I am displeased with the result, but Barcelona played with great determination. Our qualification chances are unchanged."

Anderlecht, who entertain Manchester United next Tuesday, moved up to third in Group G by beating Dynamo Kiev 4-2 despite going one down after a minute. The Belgian club, who had lost 4-0 in Ukraine, hit back with four first-half goals, one an own-goal, two from the Canadian Tomasz Radzinski and the other from Alin Stoica.

Bayern Munich, finalists in 1999, secured a 2-0 victory over Paris St-Germain in Group F and moved to the top after Helsingborgs helped by beating Rosenborg 2-0.

Deportivo la Coruna missed a host of chances and were held 1-1 by Juventus in Group E, where both still hold sway as Panathinaikos could manage only a 0-0 draw with Hamburg.

fields.headline: Andras Schiff plays radical piano for Bach
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia Orchestra/Schiff
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating; ***
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia Orchestra/Schiff
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating; ***
fields.body:
It's a sign of how embedded the practices of the period instrument movement have become that the sight of a piano playing continuo in Bach's orchestral suites - as in Andras Schiff's performances with the Philharmonia - now seems bizarre, and even radical. Schiff's series of concerts features him as both pianist and conductor, and forms a further part of the celebrations of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death.

With the Philharmonia, Schiff revels in the political incorrectness of defying the stranglehold of early instrument ensembles in this repertoire. But then, as Schiff's solo piano performances have consistently revealed, there's rather more to Bach interpretation than deciding which instrument is most historically appropriate.

The third of his programmes saw him accompanying baritone Thomas Quasthoff and mezzo-soprano Monica Groop in two solo cantatas, and directing the first and third orchestral suites. Quasthoff turned the famous Cantata BWV 82, Ich Habe Genug, into a miniature opera of world-weary resignation. The central aria, Schlummert Ein, was a perfectly reposed paean to heaven's eternal slumber.

Along with the moving directness of his phrasing of the aria's main melody, Quasthoff's voice hovered thrillingly on the brink of audibility, and on the edge of consciousness, between the different sections of the piece. The grim resolve of the final aria was balanced by the meditative melancholy of the opening movement, and the dialogue between Quasthoff and oboe soloist Christopher Cowie. Unfortunately it washeard in its full richness only at the end of the work, after Cowie's mechanical problems with a temperamental instrument first time round.

Despite the vivid spareness of the accompaniment to Cantata BWV 170, reduced to a single instrument per part, Monica Groop did not register the same dramatic immediacy as had Quasthoff. Nevertheless, the extraordinary desolation of Bach's part-writing in her aria, Wie Jammern, was chillingly affecting.

Schiff's accompaniments were always sensitive, yet lacked a searching emotional power. Similarly, his direction of the orchestral suites wanted in precisely the interpretative fire for which his pianism is so renowned. There were glimpses of his brilliant musicianship, as in the tempestuous energy of the first suite's Bourée or the sonorous weight of the third suite's Gigue. But in much of the performances, the luxurious sheen of the Philharmonia's sound was a substitute for compelling musical insight.

fields.headline: Wilt
fields.standfirst:
Rating:***
Underworld, London
fields.trailText:
Rating:***
Underworld, London
fields.body:
"That's a lovely shirt you've got on, sir. Where's it from?" Not your usual rock'n'roll introduction, but then Wilt frontman Cormac Battle's individuality extends beyond his interesting name. After spending his formative years with indie band Kerbdog and watching both fan base and record company commitment ebb away, Battle went back to college. But the guitar habit proved hard to kick and, together with fellow Irishmen ex-Kerbdog drummer Darragh Butler and friend Mick Murphy on bass, Wilt was born. In a voice frighteningly reminiscent of Kurt Cobain, Battle vents his frustration and pain with tunes that are guitar heavy but melodically light, the Sub Pop sound for chart palates.

It's All Over Now has Battle staring skyward, the verses running into a razor-sharp chorus at a furious speed, punk, grunge and pop mixed up and polished to perfection. Wilt keep you guessing. Battle himself, while lyrically tormented, is on stage an odd combination of winsome indie hero and Tommy Cooper. As the drumming slows for X Pedestrian, the mood becomes darker and more in keeping with the angst-ridden lyrics. Battle's voice becomes a drone against a Happy Mondays bass-line and psychedelic guitars which crash and rage to an apocalyptic climax. Standing to one side of the stage, Battle watches Butler, before striding centre stage and bringing his guitar to punishing life once again.

Not your usual rock'n'roll introduction, but then Wilt frontman Cormac Battle's individuality extends beyond his interesting name. After spending his formative years with indie band Kerbdog and watching both fan base and record company commitment ebb away, Battle went back to college. But the guitar habit proved hard to kick and, together with fellow Irishmen ex-Kerbdog drummer Darragh Butler and friend Mick Murphy on bass, Wilt was born. In a voice frighteningly reminiscent of Kurt Cobain, Battle vents his frustration and pain with tunes that are guitar heavy but melodically light, the Sub Pop sound for chart palates. It's All Over Now has Battle staring skyward, the verses running into a razor-sharp chorus at a furious speed, punk, grunge and pop mixed up and polished to perfection. Wilt keep you guessing. fields.headline: You Are Here
fields.standfirst:
Holden Gallery, Manchester
Rating: **&#42
fields.trailText:
Holden Gallery, Manchester
Rating: **&#42
fields.body:
You Are Here, curated by artist Graham Parker for Manchester Metropolitan University's Holden Gallery, initially appears like an exhibition of texts with a few artworks interspersed. Parker has invited artists to contribute works based on an area of central Manchester with the Ordnance Survey grid reference of 84E 97N. His own Cappuccinopolis includes a list of rogue words rescued from his computer: "Shit shite shn signifiers Silesian Situationist-inspired." Cleo Broda exhibits texts sent to her in response to requests for advice on what to do in Manchester: "Going to the university bar on a Saturday night, pretending to be a student, necking on a bar stool with some long-haired engineering student from Yorkshire with an accent you could make pudding with."

Most of the texts here come in the form of cultural justifications, or documentations of past works whose moment has passed. Wry Madchester wit is hemmed in by the terribly sobering terminology of international theoretical discourse. This has something of a spoilsport effect when applied to works that are both visually engaging and conceptually intriguing, such as Ben Cook's abstract paintings in the form of do-it-yourself art kits. And I wonder if all this textual palaver is intellectually astute when it so distances the viewer from the work.

When the work is as captivating and evocative as Helen Bendon and Jo Lansley's photo-series, the accompanying text is superfluous. Bendon and Lansley have recently started making photographic tableaux that tell of delightfully perverse nocturnal rituals. Four images show glimpses of the dressed-up duo arranging fairy rings in back-street Manchester. The concept may be deliberately immature but the visual realisation sends the mind off into some pretty unusual areas of intellectual speculation.

Until December 11. Details: 0161-247 6225.

fields.headline: Markets escape meltdown
fields.standfirst:
Bad news from IBM and Chase Manhattan rattles global trading

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Global stock markets yesterday threatened a repeat of Black Monday on the eve of the anniversary of the 1987 market meltdown.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Mark Milner
fields.body:
Global stock markets yesterday threatened a repeat of Black Monday on the eve of the anniversary of the 1987 market meltdown.

The panic began on Wall Street where worse than expected figures from computer company IBM and Chase Manhattan bank sent shares into freefall. Investors were further unsettled by news that inflation is heading higher - making it harder for the US federal reserve to cut interest rates to prevent the economy slowing.

The Dow Jones fell more than 400 points to a low of 9,654 within minutes of New York's opening bell, the first time it had been below the 10,000 level for seven months. The technology heavy Nasdaq composite index was even harder hit, shedding 5% at one point.

In a move which briefly revived memories of October 19, 1987 when the London stock market lost 11% of its value - and a further 12% the following day - the FTSE 100 share index mirrored Wall Street's headlong plunge, rapidly losing almost 200 points at one stage to stand only a fraction above 6,000 points.

European markets took a hammering too, with hi-techs especially in the firing line. But as the markets plunged to some of the worst levels seen this year bargain hunters moved in and brought a measure of recovery to hard pressed markets. The Dow cuts its loses to less than 200 points, Nasdaq's recovery saw it back into positive territory and London trimmed its loss to less than a third of the original slump.

"It is still not looking terribly good. Even though we have seen some recovery I don't think it necessarily implies we have reached the bottom," said Stephen King, chief economist at HSBC in London.

Inflationary pressures have already raised the cost of borrowing in the US and are expected to hit discretionary spending on items such as computers, prompting a sell-off of computer shares.

Several of the world's largest technology companies have already warned of weaker revenues going forward and yesterday's news from IBM took 20% off its shares yesterday morning.

Ian Shepherdson, economist at High Frequency Economics, said investors would not forgive signs of weakness in the current climate. "We are in a bear market. Any piece of bad news results in a stock being hammered, while any good news is ignored."

All but the most defensive food and drug companies were hit by concerns over rising inflation. The consumer price index released by the government yesterday showed that prices for goods such as clothes and tobacco had risen at their fastest pace for six months.

The headline CPI rate, which included the rising price of oil, rose 0.5%, after dropping 0.1% in August. Clothing prices showed the biggest increase in 10 years, while housing, health care and tobacco all increased.

Investors, which have pushed the Dow and Nasdaq to record highs, this year, now fear that they have been too optimistic about future profits.

In the current climate, few analysts would predict whether shares were close to bottoming out yesterday in spite of a 40% fall in the Nasdaq and a 16% decline in the Dow.

Mr Shepherdson said he felt technology shares which had been seriously overvalued, were now back in line with the market. Intel, which sparked this latest round of selling with a profits warning last month, is trading at about 34 times forecast 2000 earnings, he said, in line with the average for the S&P 500 group of shares.

fields.headline: Dean Johnson
fields.standfirst:
12 Bar Club, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
12 Bar Club, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
"I like this rain, it's northern rain," Dean Johnson tells us, happily resting an arm on his guitar. "But it's making a mess of your pavements of gold." As an introduction to his songs, with their sweet sentiments encased in hard-edged reality, it would be hard to beat. But the cynicism is real, derived from a rage against the notion that disappointment and disillusion are romantic ideals for the aspiring bedsit poet.

When Johnson sings of bingo and the bomb, there's no irony intended. And he knows about faded dreams of glory. Johnson's latest album, Loser Friendly, has been well received, but the five albums before it sunk without trace. And then there was the song written with Wet Wet Wet just before the Marti Pellow heroin habit made front-page news, followed by the record deal that saw the label go bust before the ink was dry on the contract.

And tonight Johnson watches half his audience leave before he even takes to the stage. "Sorry, I haven't got any friends here," he shrugs as the support band pack their guitars and take their mates with them. It's no wonder he doesn't take his rain hat off. But while he's comfy in his anorak and jeans, the music he makes is powerful and unsettling.

As he tears into Kneeling Down, his hand is a blur as he violently plays his guitar. There are no half-hearted wisps of songs here, just lyrically abrupt, musically adept visions of the city. But while he attacks a lyric, a gentle melancholy is always there - Bob Dylan's passion tempered by Noel Gallagher's way with a tune. And true to form, there's a cheeky chappy Scouse persona to hide the pain.

Johnson is almost as entertaining when he's not singing as when he is. "I'm currently basking in critical acclaim," he announces. "It's the same as being under one of those sunbeds, without the little goggle things." If he chooses to abandon his guitar, a career in working men's clubs is ready and waiting. But it would be a pity if he did.

Cambridge Blues, a homage to the genius, though mad, musicians of that city ("Nick Drake, not someone you'd want to on go on holiday with," he concedes) is filled with fear and loneliness, while The Nominations Are tells of urban life in a cultural wasteland.

And while Johnson at times seems like a confident chancer who has jumped up on stage to grab five seconds of fame, he's riveting to watch, though the stage antics amount to little more than the odd kick of a leg.

But as he ends with a touching and acutely observed song detailing the life and death of Paula Yates, it's hard not to think that Johnson is something special.

fields.headline: Eileen Rose
fields.standfirst:
Spitz, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Spitz, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Another week, another female singer trying to merge Alanis Morissette's lyrical convolutions, Sheryl Crow's tuneful rock chickery and that hint of kookiness Jewel embraces with such alarming gusto. It's a while since there was a worthy pretender, but Eileen Rose Giadone comes close and, crucially, she's very much her own woman.

This Irish-Italian-American hails from the wrong side of the Boston tracks, but she has lived in Britain for a decade, bumbling along in bottom feeder bands such as Medici Slot Machine and Fledgling, who troubled themselves with neither charts nor critical acclaim. No matter: Eileen Rose's co-produced, self-written debut solo album, Shine Like It Does, is a gem and although she occasionally slips into waifdom, she has the brassy yet coy presence of her closest musical sister, Aimee Mann.

She announces that she feels "a little slutty tonight" but, as if to prove she's a woman's woman too, offers the sage advice that "a woman with a correctly fitted brassiere is a happy woman". She can cackle like Marianne Faithfull and scream like Patti Smith, but her sights are set higher. When she twists herself around the microphone and belts out the joyous, anthemic Rose, it's far from impossible to imagine entire arenas belting out the hookline, "I can hear my father talking saying, 'Rose, never learn to sing the blues' ".

Reassuringly, she has vulnerability too. She cannot pronounce the letter R properly and in the slight and unashamedly romantic Would You Marry Me? she might even have an out-of-context hit. Shining, an intricate saga of parental infidelity and separation, is more typical, but she never forgets where the melody is and it almost breaks into Sympathy for the Devil at its climax.

The closer Paper Hearts, a sad but defiant new song, a tale of "my gothic tendencies" and "throwing up on my dress", merges both feistiness and vulnerability, an ability she would do well to hone.

Backed by five men, three of whom are on loan from Alabama 3 and one who used to play with Wreckless Eric ("They bring some very average songs to life," she notes, disingenuously), Eileen Rose simply stands there and sings those splendid songs as if her life depended on them. In a sense it probably does.

webTitle: Review: The Diary of Anne Frank

fields.headline: The Diary of Anne Frank
fields.standfirst:
Lyceum, Sheffield
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Lyceum, Sheffield
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Anne Frank's story has been portrayed many times on stage, notably in a version by Bernard Kops, and the Pulitzer prize-winning adaptation of Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett on which the present production is based. None of these, however, takes into account the previously suppressed material that appeared in Mirjam Pressler's definitive edition three years ago, which did much to rescue saintly, sexless Anne from being occluded by her own cult.

In excising the more intimate passages of his daughter's diary, Otto Frank inadvertently preserved an image of a girl who seemed too old for her years and yet strangely too young for them at the same time. Wendy Kesselman's dramatic update presents the unresolved Anne in the middle - the flighty teenager who begins her secret life pinning matinee idols to the wall - and concludes it with an adult exploration of her emerging feelings for her slightly older fellow-captive, Peter.

This is the edition that had hardened, Broadway hacks drawing heart-broken conclusions; and Jonathan Church's impeccably sensitive production looks set to do the same. To a certain extent these are true events too coruscating for the theatre - a fact which seems to be acknowledged in the way the actors simply disappear after the final scene and, like their characters, never come back. A dignified gesture, which by no means suggests that the cast do not warrant their applause.

The ensemble playing is superb: one never loses the sense that there are eight individual stories being told through the lucid scrutiny of an adolescent girl. Yet the entire weight of the drama rests, as it must, on the slender shoulders of 16-year-old Anne Bedi - not only a disturbingly accurate physical match for Anne with her rosebud mouth and huge, liquid eyes, but also a young actor of sufficient re sources to suggest the incompatible extremes of Anne's personality. Despite the icon Anne Frank has become, Bedi is not afraid to show how, for the inhabitants of the annexe, she was often nothing more than an infernal nuisance.

It is extraordinary to witness how she develops from a pain in the neck to a throb in the heart.

Until Saturday (box office: 0114 249 6000) then touring.

fields.headline: Not tonight, Napoleon
fields.standfirst:
Napoleon
Shaftesbury Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Napoleon
Shaftesbury Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
In the field of musicals, it's a case of one step forward, two steps back. Just when The Witches of Eastwick and The Beautiful Game seemed to herald a return to book-shows with a biting plot, along comes this through-composed piece of historical tosh that already looks old-fashioned. Its only redeeming features are Francesca Zambello's effortlessly fluid production and Michael Yeargan's elegant designs.

John Julius Norwich expresses surprise in the programme that Napoleon has never been the subject of an opera or musical before. Discounting Prokofiev's War and Peace, in which he makes a highly dramatic appearance, he has actually been the hero of Austrian, French, Italian and even Broadway musicals. If none of them has endured, the reason is fairly obvious - how do you encompass his turbulent rise from Corsican outsider to consul and emperor, and how do you present the sea of blood through which he waded in over 40 battles? Dreams of unending conquest are hardly ideal musical matter unless you're going to do a bad-taste equivalent of Springtime for Hitler in Germany.

Andrew Sabiston (book and lyrics) and Tim Williams (book and music) get round the problem by suggesting that Napoleon was really a romantic lover at heart. They whisk us breathlessly from Paris in 1794 to Waterloo in 1815, showing Napoleon moving from idealistic revolutionary to failing conqueror all the time manipulated by Talleyrand. But, in their view, he was really driven by his passionate love for Josephine so that even at the moment of his military downfall he has time for a visionary duet with her in which they jointly sing, "I need you, I can't live without you".

The effect is simply to reduce Napoleon to a Tussaud's hero who realises too late in the day that military conquest is nothing without the love of a good woman. The one truly interesting character in the whole piece is the politically scheming Talleyrand, whom David Burt endows with a limp and a lethal smile that suggests he breakfasts off iron filings. At first brushing the arriviste Napoleon aside with a Thacherite cry of, "You're not one of us", he backs him when he wins and jettisons him when he loses. Talleyrand, you ject of the show, though he would stillfeel, should have been the sub have had to contend with Williams's unmemorable, film-score music and Sabiston's stupefyingly dull lyrics.

Zambello's production alone makes the show worth watching. As in her Covent Garden Billy Budd, she makes striking use of a tilted, rising stage in the battle scenes and, with the help of Yeargan's stylish projections, conjures up some beautiful tableaux: Napoleon's coronation at Notre Dame, with scarlet costumes set against the sun-bright cathedral, even suggests Lyceum Theatre spectacle in Irving's heyday.

But neither Paul Baker as the impassioned Bonaparte nor Anastasia Barzee as Josephine can do much to lift the characters above the level of ciphers. This is cartoon-history with permanent musical accompaniment that leaves you both emotionally and intellectually unstirred.

Booking until January 6. Box office: 020-7379 5399.

webTitle: Falling unemployment threatens to end MPC unanimity

fields.headline: Falling unemployment threatens to end MPC unanimity
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hawks on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee staged a tactical retreat earlier this month, surprising the City by voting for unchanged interest rates and encouraging speculation that the cost of borrowing has peaked at 6%.
fields.body:
Hawks on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee staged a tactical retreat earlier this month, surprising the City by voting for unchanged interest rates and encouraging speculation that the cost of borrowing has peaked at 6%.

The unanimous decision broke the pattern of the past two months when there was a five:four majority in favour of leaving rates on hold, according to the minutes of September's meeting, published yesterday.

However, analysts warned that, with unemployment continuing to fall sharply, divisions about the direction of inflation and interest rates were likely to resurface soon.

Geoffrey Dicks of the Royal Bank of Scotland said the hawks were biding their time before next month's quarterly inflation report, when the Bank will issue a new forecast.

"The labour market is the battleground with the doves prepared to take the present conjuncture on trust and the hawks suspicious that the present benign conditions are just a lull before a difficult 2001 pay round. We share the hawks' worries but it is hard to see a majority gelling in favour of a hike until next year," Mr Dicks said.

Official figures published yesterday show that the number of people out of work and claiming benefit fell by 16,400 in September to 1,035,300, putting the jobless total on course to fall below a million within the next few months.

Despite strengthening demand for labour, average earnings growth held steady at 3.9%.

"Unemployment was falling sharply, particularly amongst the short-term unemployed, and this could not persist without putting upward pressure on wages," was the view.

The other camp agreed that the labour market was a risk to the outlook but wanted clear evidence of an acceleration in earnings growth before taking action. It was worried about the downside risks to growth and inflation from the strong pound.

webTitle: IFAs seek judicial review over windfall ruling

fields.headline: IFAs seek judicial review over windfall ruling
fields.trailText: Independent financial advisers and their insurers are seeking a judicial review of the High Court's ruling that windfall shares should not be included in any compensation payouts to clients who were mis-sold endowments and pensions.
fields.body:
Independent financial advisers and their insurers are seeking a judicial review of the High Court's ruling that windfall shares should not be included in any compensation payouts to clients who were mis-sold endowments and pensions.

If they succeed, policyholders who may have received and spent windfall shares from their building society's demutualisation will have to discount the value of the shares from the shortfall in their endowment or pension policy.

Gareth Fatchett, partner at law firm Armstrong Neal which has been approached to take the case, says the issue is one of fairness. "Any financial product comes with assets and liabilities," he said. "In this case, the products' liabilities were that they might not perform. But their assets where that they led to windfall shares. It's is not right that policyholders who were more than happy to take the windfall shares are complaining that the policies which gave them the shares are under-performing."

It is understood the case is being driven by IFAs who may go out of business if they have to pay compensation and their professional indemnity insurers who will have to fork out for any claims.

If the compensation process results in big payouts, professional indemnity insurers say premiums will have to increase to cover the cost which, in turn, may make insurance too expensive and put IFAs out of business. As such, a judicial review would try to prevent a vicious circle leading to IFAs being bankrupted.

Any ruling in favour of the IFAs would be very controversial; building society members who didn't have endowments or pensions will be able to keep their windfall shares whilst those with shortfall policies will face a double whammy of under-performing pensions and endowments and missing out on bonus shares.

fields.headline: Regular Fries
fields.standfirst:
Roadhouse, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Roadhouse, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.body:
Live, Regular Fries are renowned for their drug-addled absurdity. At times, they've brightened stages with spider plants and lamp shades, band members in space suits and, occasionally, a bloke playing (and wearing) a birdcage. Tonight, such eccentricity is notably absent. Standing in front of a shiny backdrop, the eight-strong band (all, supposedly, well-connected London scenesters) look, pretty much like any bunch of lads on their way to the match, their only idiosyncrasy an Emmanuelle-style wicker chair for keyboard-player and ex-NME writer, Paul Moody.

Despite reports that there is a new purpose about their second album, War On Plastic Plants, their meandering psychedelic grooves sound as vague and as Skunk Rock as ever. Late 1980s Madchester is the Fries' spiritual home, but where the Happy Mondays and the Stone Roses were weird, original, or so sky-scrapingly melodic that punters would pimp-roll from venues feeling 10 feet tall, the Fries are a little flat.

With Dave Brothwell's deadpan chat lost in the mix, and with the beats and the bass ill-defined, guitarist Griff is often the only colour amidst the swooshing synths, flaring Hammond organ and sci-fi FX. He's good - roving through wah-wah squalls, liquid, interstellar tangles to crunchy rawk riffing, but he's no John Squire.

Regular Fries are unreconstructed rock'n'roll, their tired eyes proving that their redoubtable anthem Coke 'n' Smoke is more reportage than bravado. And everyone can join the party. They applaud the crowd, one kid gets to, "Yo! Yo! Yo!", down the mic and several Fries lead rabble-rousing shout-ins.

Ironically, when the Fries, "bring it down", they shine. Eclipse and The Drowned World - percolating bass, deftly applied synths and strings, Griff unravelling star-crossed, wistful lead guitar lines and Brothwell a doleful, ragged commentator - are sweet and melancholy as St Etienne and probably too indie-sounding to suggest a new direction for a band as keen to fit into a long lineage of frazzled musicians as the Fries.

It's a pity, that, at the moment, they're mostly proving that if you give a band enough dope, they'll hang themselves.

fields.headline: Among Unbroken Hearts
fields.standfirst:
Traverse Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Traverse Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Familiar dramatic themes run through this new play by Wick-born writer Henry Adam. A rites-of-passage tale of sorts, it features a painful homecoming, the claustrophobia of small town life and the looming responsibilities that come with adulthood. What separates it from the crowd of plays touching on such issues is its setting (Caithness) and the brutal, but never sensational, presentation of heroin addiction it includes.

Ray has returned to his childhood home with his friend Neil, having been away long enough - and emotionally far enough - to have missed the death of his father and grandmother. His one-time mentor and hero, Chaimig, is now a blind old man on the brink of senility, cared for only by his granddaughter, who has an unopened letter of acceptance from Glasgow university in her pocket.

Death hangs heavy over the play in the form of suicides, overdoses, old age and only the "ghosts" living in this remote, abandoned landscape. The writing is first-rate, managing to be poignant but not sentimental, universal but not blandly so.

The reality of their next fix is the only solace for the younger men. The bleak answer to a question Ray asks when he tried to get clean is: "What are you supposed to do when there's nothing left to do?" Similarly, Chaimig stands on the shore, looking out though he cannot see, summing up old age as waking up one day to find yourself "something you thought you would never be".

There are some uneven moments. At times the small cast's accents wander, there are a couple of scenes in which the emotional intensity seems too sudden, too forced (as when Neil trashes the cottage). But these are tiny splinters in an otherwise smoothly directed and beautifully acted drama, with an especially impressive performance from Billy Riddoch (Chaimig), the poet-crofter with fast-fading wisdom.

Everyone is clinging to life here, flailing over a precipice, without hope or community to sustain them or catch them. "Nobody has roots anymore, Ray," says Neil. "It was on the news. Did nobody tell ye?"

At the Traverse, Edinburgh (box office: 0131-228 1404) until October 28 then touring.

webTitle: Champions League: Manchester United v PSV

fields.headline: Cole fit as Ferguson goes on the attack
fields.trailText: Group G Alex Ferguson sounded confident that normal business will be resumed tonight after the 3-1 defeat in Eindhoven as he announced an early start to hostilities by taking a pot-shot at PSV's integrity.
fields.body:
Manchester United will tonight hope to confirm that the best cure for a hiccup is a shock to the system. Except that whereas United suffered the former in the Netherlands three weeks ago it is they who will attempt to inflict the latter at Old Trafford on their conquerors that night, PSV Eindhoven.

The Dutch champions' 3-1 victory over a below-strength United team in the Philips stadium has, for the moment at least, upset the anticipated course of events in Group G of the Champions League. PSV lead the group by two points from Dynamo Kiev, who are away to Anderlecht this evening, and United.

With two of their last three fixtures in the opening round at home United should finish first or second to reach the next group phase. But they can ill afford to slip against the Dutch a second time.

Thus Sir Alex Ferguson will confront Eric Gerets's side with his strongest available team, a sharp contrast to his approach in Eindhoven when David Beckham, Ryan Giggs, Teddy Sheringham and Andrew Cole started on the bench because the United manager wanted to keep them fresh for the Premiership game at Arsenal the following Sunday.

In the event United lost both matches but Ferguson is confident normal business will be resumed tonight. "The players know it's an important game in that we took a chance in Holland and it didn't work," he said yesterday. "But winning the home games is always the key issue in these group situations."

So with Beckham fit after a knee problem, Gary Neville recovered from a toe injury, Cole better after a damaged ankle and Giggs, only a substitute at Leicester on Saturday, and Paul Scholes refreshed after a weekend's rest, United will look for an emphatic win .

Just in case Old Trafford needs rousing for the occasion, Ferguson yesterday accused the opposition of arrogance and a tendency to dive. Managerial mind games are nothing new but Ferguson had been put out by PSV claims that his decision to field a weakened team in the first match smacked of conceit.

He remarked that this was strange coming from the Dutch. "I think they have an arrogance which has been well documented," he said. "But to level it at a team like Manchester United when no one else has ever done that - well, maybe some people have - isn't relevant to the facts of the case.

"Dutch teams don't play Saturday, Wednesday, Saturday every week. People who make comments like that don't understand the mechanics of our game. We didn't underestimate PSV. We knew we were going to get a hard game but I also felt I knew we could recover from that game by winning our two home matches."

Manchester United (probable): Barthez; Irwin, G Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Sheringham.

PSV Eindhoven (probable): Waterreus; Heintze, Hofland, Nikiforov, Van der Weerden; Ramzi, Van Bommel, Vogel, Van der Doelen; Bruggink, Kezman.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: How  long-running campaigns against government policy keep going

fields.headline: Goal bound
fields.standfirst: How do long-running campaigns to influence government policy keep going?  Nicola Hill reports
fields.trailText: How do long-running campaigns to influence government policy keep going? Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Angered at the prospect of a state pension increase of just £2.25 a week, linked to inflation, pensioners are planning to march on parliament next month. They will again call on the government to restore the link between the pension and average earnings. The trouble is, the campaign is now in its 20th year - with no sign of victory.

How do such campaigners keep going? Should they soldier on with idealistic aims or trim their sails and focus on more achievable goals?

At the Campaign Against Arms Trade, there is a continuing debate about whether to set practical or absolute aims. But co-ordinator Rachel Harford believes pragmatic steps can be taken to achieve what may be seen as an idealistic goal. A first step could be to increase regulation, leading to reduction and finally abolition of arms trading. Harford says: "I feel offended by accusations of not living in the real world and that banning arms trading is a utopia. Monitoring the daily activities of the arms trade, I would argue I'm very rooted in the real world."

Sarah Burton, campaigns director at Greenpeace, insists on sticking to ideals. She says: "It may take 20 years, but keep at it like a dog with a bone."

One of the environmental group's goals is to phase out fossil fuel. "Three to four years ago, people said this was idealistic. But now environment secretary John Prescott and the president of Ford are talking about it. Our timescales may be different, but at least it is on the agenda."

When something isn't even on the agenda, however, it may be difficult to stay motivated. The campaign to restore the link between pensions and average salary is led by the National Pensioners' Convention. Its organiser, Gary Kitchen says: "One of the most vital tasks must be sustaining the will among grassroots activists."

Each year the organisation holds a "pensioner parliament" that attracts 2,500 older people. Kitchen believes it is also important to hold local events throughout the year, as long as they are orchestrated to attract media attention and not just held for their own sake. "Even when there is no clear impact on policy, campaigners may receive a fillip through seeing that their efforts are having an impact on public opinion or the media."

The plight of pensioners has received unprecedented media attention in the past few months and will probably continue to do so in the run-up to the election. But the government seems determined not to restore the link. Kitchen says pensioners are still not deterred. "The government's refusal to restore the link has served overall to strengthen the pensioner movement. We believe we are fighting for justice not some pragmatic goal. We know that justice is not usually won lightly, so the fact that success may take time is only to be expected."

Of course, cynics may say that taking time could also be self-serving for those employed by a campaign. There is likely to be more job security in aiming for utopia rather than choosing a pragmatic, achievable goal. So what does happen when a goal is achieved?

When the Ottawa Convention was signed in 1998, banning anti-personnel mines in 107 countries, the campaign to ban landmines could have shut up shop. Instead it changed its name and focus. The director of the newly named Landmine Action, Richard Lloyd, says: "It was a big problem because everyone thought the campaign was over, but there are still a lot of things to do such as clearing mines and helping victims."

It took 12 months for the campaign to shift its emphasis and refocus the organisation. "Instead of asking supporters to write to their MP, we are now focusing on fundraising to help victims," says Lloyd. "We had to talk to grant-making trusts and persuade them to still fund us," he adds. Fortunately, the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund continued to support the new organisation to the tune of £90,000 a year. Landmine Action is also benefiting from three years' funding from the national lottery. Lloyd says: "This core support is essential in a period of transition, it gives us the space and ability to move into a second phase."

Lloyd thinks it is a mistake for campaigns to have too narrow a focus. He maintains that the original campaign always had a practical focus, so it is justified in continuing its work dealing with the aftermath of landmines. He advises that goals should be realistic and adds: "I would love to see the day when we make ourselves redundant."

That is exactly what staff at Jubilee 2000 will experience at the end of this year. The organisation's campaign has not achieved its goal - the cancellation of unpayable debt owed by the world's poorest countries by the year 2000. But spokesperson Nick Buxton says: "Part of the strength of the campaign was a strong focus and a deadline. People felt they could get involved. Even though it may still be a long way off, cancellation of debt is on the agenda and the principle is accepted by all sides."

The campaign has been very successful in galvanising people to demonstrate at G8 summits, forming human chains and attracting media attention. But its name is a double-edged sword, says Adrian Lovett, deputy director. "The name Jubilee and the ambition to achieve change for the new millennium resonated with people, but obviously it has an inherent lifespan."

Lovett argues that there is a strong case for trying to achieve aims in a limited space of time. He also thinks that campaigns should be rational, rather than emotional, and that organisations should shift their focus to concentrate on the economic reasons for change, rather than "helping poor people" arguments. He concludes: "You have to find a way of encompassing realism and idealism to succeed."

Monitoring the daily activities of the arms trade, I would argue I'm very rooted in the real world." Sarah Burton, campaigns director at Greenpeace, insists on sticking to ideals. She says: "It may take 20 years, but keep at it like a dog with a bone." One of the environmental group's goals is to phase out fossil fuel. "Three to four years ago, people said this was idealistic. But now environment secretary John Prescott and the president of Ford are talking about it. Our timescales may be different, but at least it is on the agenda." When something isn't even on the agenda, however, it may be difficult to stay motivated. The campaign to restore the link between pensions and average salary is led by the National Pensioners' Convention. Its organiser, Gary Kitchen says: "One of the most vital tasks must be sustaining the will among grassroots activists." Each year the organisation holds a "pensioner parliament" that attracts 2,500 older people. Kitchen believes it is also important to hold local events throughout the year, as long as they are orchestrated to attract media attention and not just held for their own sake. "Even when there is no clear impact on policy, campaigners may receive a fillip through seeing that their efforts are having an impact on public opinion or the media." The plight of pensioners has received unprecedented media attention in the past few months and will probably continue to do so in the run-up to the election. But the government seems determined not to restore the link. Kitchen says pensioners are still not deterred. "The government's refusal to restore the link has served overall to strengthen the pensioner movement. We believe we are fighting for justice not some pragmatic goal. We know that justice is not usually won lightly, so the fact that success may take time is only to be expected." Of course, cynics may say that taking time could also be self-serving for those employed by a campaign. There is likely to be more job security in aiming for utopia rather than choosing a pragmatic, achievable goal. So what does happen when a goal is achieved? When the Ottawa Convention was signed in 1998, banning anti-personnel mines in 107 countries, the campaign to ban landmines could have shut up shop. Instead it changed its name and focus. The director of the newly named Landmine Action, Richard Lloyd, says: "It was a big problem because everyone thought the campaign was over, but there are still a lot of things to do such as clearing mines and helping victims." It took 12 months for the campaign to shift its emphasis and refocus the organisation. "Instead of asking supporters to write to their MP, we are now focusing on fundraising to help victims," says Lloyd. "We had to talk to grant-making trusts and persuade them to still fund us," he adds. Fortunately, the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund continued to support the new organisation to the tune of £90,000 a year. Landmine Action is also benefiting from three years' funding from the national lottery. Lloyd says: "This core support is essential in a period of transition, it gives us the space and ability to move into a second phase." Lloyd thinks it is a mistake for campaigns to have too narrow a focus. He maintains that the original campaign always had a practical focus, so it is justified in continuing its work dealing with the aftermath of landmines. He advises that goals should be realistic and adds: "I would love to see the day when we make ourselves redundant." That is exactly what staff at Jubilee 2000 will experience at the end of this year. The organisation's campaign has not achieved its goal - the cancellation of unpayable debt owed by the world's poorest countries by the year 2000. But spokesperson Nick Buxton says: "Part of the strength of the campaign was a strong focus and a deadline. People felt they could get involved. Even though it may still be a long way off, cancellation of debt is on the agenda and the principle is accepted by all sides." The campaign has been very successful in galvanising people to demonstrate at G8 summits, forming human chains and attracting media attention. But its name is a double-edged sword, says Adrian Lovett, deputy director. "The name Jubilee and the ambition to achieve change for the new millennium resonated with people, but obviously it has an inherent lifespan." Lovett argues that there is a strong case for trying to achieve aims in a limited space of time. He also thinks that campaigns should be rational, rather than emotional, and that organisations should shift their focus to concentrate on the economic reasons for change, rather than "helping poor people" arguments. He concludes: "You have to find a way of encompassing realism and idealism to succeed."

webTitle: Charity Award 2000: Sunnnyside Community Gardens Association

fields.headline: Inner city, inner peace
fields.standfirst: Sunnnyside Community Gardens Association
fields.trailText: A green oasis in the heart of concrete-clad Islington - run by Sunnyside Community Gardens Association
fields.body:
Walk through the Elthorne Park neighbourhood in north London and you see densely populated estates where most of the flats lack a balcony, let alone a garden, and communal areas are covered in Tarmac. So it is a bit of a surprise to turn off Hazellville Road and find yourself at the entrance of a wildlife park, complete with its own ecology and horticultural therapy centre, woodland area and nature pond.

This green oasis in the heart of concrete-clad Islington is run by Sunnyside Community Gardens Association, a charity set up in 1978 to convert a then derelict site into a garden for local people. Many of the flats on local estates are small, exposing residents to overcrowding and noise. In addition, Islington's need for psychiatric services is almost double the London average and many of its wards register third highest in the UK index of deprivation.

The idea was to take a holistic approach to improving the local community's mental and physical health, creating a "healthy" building and organic gardens.

Designed by an architecture student at what is now North London University, the energy efficient ecology centre incorporates solar water heating panels and recycled paper wall insulation. As well as maintaining the gardens, the charity also operates a neighbourhood scheme, to compost green waste, and has worked with schools and under-fives playgroups on nature gardens and recycling initiatives. Sunnyside estimates that 4,000 people benefit from these activities each year.

The charity provides volunteering opportunities for the neighbourhood's residents, day centres and psychiatric hospitals. Activities include gardening, carpentry and environmental art. Much of the work is physically exerting, which project co-ordinator Rosemary Jones believes has positive benefits on mental health, enabling people to regain self-esteem, reduce dependency on statutory services and move on to further education or employment. "The association ensures people are able to re-centre themselves because of' social support or through attention-focusing practical work, which has the additional benefit of taking the edge off any shyness or lack of confidence."

In an equal opportunities framework, all those working or visiting are called "volunteers", which avoids any sort of hierarchy. Jones says the aim is a welcoming environment, where people feel a sense of community. "We're not there to do good to people; we're there to be normal."

About half of the centre's 58 volunteers have, or are recovering from, mental health problems. One, a former architect who had a breakdown 18 months ago, says working at Sunnyside has been extremely therapeutic: "It's a very friendly and inclusive place, and it's very grounding to work with the soil and as part of a team." She is now studying horticulture at college as a result of her volunteer work.

While Sunnyside claims it is a prototype for what the government now calls healthy living centres, the charity has yet to attract national lottery funding earmarked for such initiatives. However, a combination of core funding from Islington council and grants from a range of trusts and foundations supports four part-time staff, including a social worker engaged in mental health development work.

In addition, Sunnyside has been recognised by the government as one of 23 environmental charities showing good practice in neighbourhood regeneration. It regularly receives referrals from the council's social services department and local mental health charities.

Jones says Sunnyside wants to expand volunteering opportunities and training, while increasing residents' involvement in its ecological work. Another volunteer, currently on the charity's management committee, believes Sunnyside fills a gap in the psychiatric care system. "If you have mental health problems, your whole social life is brought to an end so you can't interact with people," he says. "Here you work with all sorts and become more confident, compared to day centres where you make no friends."

 Sunnyside Community Gardens Association, The Ecology & Horticultural Therapy Centre, Hazellville Road, London N19 3LX (020-7272 3522)

webTitle: Profile of   Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, at the helm of Kent council

fields.headline: How the garden grows
fields.standfirst: Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, at the helm of Kent council
fields.trailText: Profile: Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, at the helm of Kent council
fields.body:
He is probably the most powerful Tory in Britain. William Hague might dream of entering Downing Street, but Sandy Bruce-Lockhart exercises power. With an annual budget of £1bn, 30,000 employees, and European politicians knocking on his door, the man who runs England's most populous county likes to think that his administration is a template for progressive Conservatism.

After assuming the leadership of Kent county council three years ago, from a loose Lab-Lib alliance, Bruce-Lockhart cut £27m from the budget, reduced the number of chief officers from 13 to six and created 60 "business units" covering all services throughout the organisation, which serves more than 1.3m people.

But this was no slash and burn administration at County Hall, Maidstone, dedicated to minimalist government, with everything hived off bar a few essential services. On the contrary, this new Toryism combined firm financial management with an equally strong economic, moral and social agenda - and there are plenty of rough edges around the garden of England - to pull the disadvantaged into the mainstream of society.

Kent's glossy five-year plan of action set targets for raising the county's income to create more jobs; safeguarding the environment by cutting greenhouse gases; increasing school funding - while retaining grammar schools; protecting "vulnerable and disaffected young people"; and improving the level of care for the elderly and vulnerable.

In the modern Tory context, Bruce-Lockhart's ideology cannot be easily defined, although his MP, shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe, gives a clue. "Sandy is an old-style Tory, patrician yes, with a very strong social conscience ... and a great sense of humour." But there are equally strong moral undertones: no truck with Clause 28, and a strong commitment to promoting citizenship and Christian values. He believes people have lost their sense of belonging and that the disadvantaged need a hand-up as well as a hand-out. He certainly wouldn't argue with the label "Christian democrat".

The council leader, who has been president of Widdecombe's Maidstone constituency association for some time, came into politics via an unconventional route. Born into a Scots family living in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, he eventually left school for the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, and went to work in the then Rhodesia. He ran a large farm, for a South African owner, producing maize and raising cattle with 400 African workers to supervise. He speaks fondly of the experience. "I developed some very strong friendships," he says, while railing against the injustices of apartheid and racism.

From southern Africa he went briefly to Australia to test the climate for farming, decided it "wasn't as nice as Africa", and arrived in Kent in 1968. After 20 years working the land, he decided to enter politics in 1989. "Without wanting to sound too grand about it, I felt I wanted to make some kind of contribution to society." His 300-acre fruit farm, producing apples and pears, employs 15 people full-time. It is now run by a manager.

Bruce-Lockart, aged 58, admits to having had, like many, a jaundiced view of local government. "I was very cynical about it and, much to my surprise, I found an organisation which was well-run by people of great integrity who had a genuine commitment to public service," he says. "That really surprised me and I feel very strongly that these people, with a strong ethic for helping others, deeply committed to their jobs - social workers, occupational therapists, teachers - are under- valued by society."

But the past year has not been easy. Criticised for taking a firm line over asylum seekers, he has been deeply offended by some charges levelled against him. "It is a terrible insult for someone like Sandy to be accused of anything resembling racism," insists Widdecombe. "He's an old-style Tory, not at all racist."

He has pleaded for understanding, arguing that in the winter of 1996-97 there were 50 asylum seekers coming to Kent; last winter there were 10,000. The county, in short, needed bailing out. While the government's relocation strategy has eased the county's problems, Kent is still looking after 2,300 asylum seekers on its patch, plus a further 800 unaccompanied minors, while the county has the responsibility for a further 4,400 dispersed around England.

Bruce-Lockhart himself is much travelled these days as well, hopping regularly between Kent, the Nord Pas de Calais region in France, and Belgium - a designated European economic interest group, where five municipalities club together to promote trade, education links and tourism.

Largely as a result of the channel tunnel, Kent is more integrated with the rest of the European Union than any other part of Britain. Ashford, closer by Eurostar to Lille than Waterloo, has 325 French businesses registered in the town - some of them escaping a punitive tax regime across the channel. Eighty per cent of Kent schools have links with a sister school in France.

Does this, then, make Bruce-Lockhart the ultimate pro-Euro Tory? Certainly not. He sees no contradiction in promoting closer ties with Europe while preserving the nation-state and opposing the single currency. His leader would be proud of him.

webTitle: Democracy day - elected mayor campaigns gather pace

fields.headline: Democracy day
fields.standfirst: Elected mayor campaigns gather pace
fields.trailText: Elected mayor campaigns gather pace
fields.body:
Ministers pushing the case for radical reform of town and county halls think their campaign to create a network of elected executive mayors in England after the next general election is finally paying off. With some 14 councils, led by Birmingham, preparing to hold mayoral referendums - and a string of others poised to join them - all the signs now point to a "national democracy day" in 12 months' time.

The idea is to co-ordinate up to 30 mayoral referendums next October to test popular support for an elected first citizen - with full-blown mayoral polls coinciding with local elections in May 2002.

This comes as key members of the New Local Government Network, a pressure group close to Downing Street, publish the results of a lengthy research project which urges the government to be far bolder in giving councils more powers and responsibilities - and argues that policies imposed from the top without local support often fail. Significantly some of the findings of the project, Towards a New Localism, which will be discussed at a conference in London tomorrow, follow the Guardian's own agenda for local democracy, published last month in its alternative election manifesto.

The network says that the mayoral debate should light the spark for a much wider reform process, with councils developing into the champions of their areas by assuming a wider leadership role embracing the economic and social health of communities. It attacks the excessive centralism of Whitehall and calls for a new system of five-year "partnership compacts", drawn up between town halls and all local stakeholders, which would replace the panoply of government-inspired programmes. Councils selected for such compacts would get extra government cash and support.

With the network influential in parts of the government, the reaction of ministers so far has been interesting. Perhaps with an eye on the project, local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, has urged authorities to become more adventurous. "Councils don't need to wait for a lead from central government before testing new ideas," she last week told the annual conference of the Society of Local Authority Chief Executives. "I'd be very pleased to see more evidence of councils making the running with their own reform agenda."

Armstrong finally pushed through legislation paving the way for mayors and cabinet-style administrations three months ago, with her boss at the environment department, John Prescott, publicly expressing opposition to the concept.

Nevertheless, with Birmingham now on track to lead the field, it is likely that other big cities will join small authorities - such as Berwick-upon-Tweed, and several London boroughs - in quickening the pace for change. Birmingham's support rested on a knife edge. But the council's Labour leader, Albert Bore and his deputy, Andy Howell, have narrowly retained their positions after beating off opposition in the city's divided Labour group.

webTitle: Leader: The NHS is still in crisis

fields.headline: Not out of danger yet
fields.standfirst:
The NHS needs some intensive caring

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The challenge facing Labour on health reform remains daunting. What for years was Labour's strongest policy card is now a major cause of falling political support. The squeeze which New Labour applied to NHS funding in its first two years in office helped prompt this erosion.
fields.body:
The challenge facing Labour on health reform remains daunting. What for years was Labour's strongest policy card is now a major cause of falling political support. The squeeze which New Labour applied to NHS funding in its first two years in office helped prompt this erosion. Health remains the public's top priority, yet as our ICM poll published yesterday shows, only 13% of people perceive any improvement in the NHS, compared to 34% who believe it is getting worse. This is unfair, given the government's plan for the biggest and longest sustained increase in health spending since the NHS was set up in 1948 - a real-terms increase of a third to its £50bn budget over five years. But then politics is unfair.

Ministers were right to insist on the NHS embracing modernisation in return for the money. In an address celebrating the 200th anniversary of the Royal College of Surgeons yesterday, the prime minister sensibly reminded his medical audience of the many changes they had made over the last two centuries. The key to the government's modernising plan is that almost all its proposals are already operating in some part of the system. Mr Blair listed several reforms, among them North Tyneside's success in reducing accident and emergency waiting times for even minor conditions to one hour, and West Middlesex Hospital's new procedures that have cut the wait from referral to diagnosis of prostate cancer from four months to 14 days. Ministers are right to insist best practice should be spread more quickly.

But how do you get short-term benefits from a long-term plan? With difficulty; but that should not deter Labour from its path. There will be few visible benefits if election day is next May - just brighter hospital reception areas and more cheerful wards - but serious reforms will be on their way. Medics, managers and nurses are on side for the long-term goal. Front line staff were directly involved in drawing up the plan and sit on 10 new task forces pushing it through. Sensibly, an insider, Nigel Crisp, who has shown he can push through reforms, has been named as the new boss of the NHS: an outsider would have had too much to learn. But momentum will only be maintained if the dispute over working practices - particularly the perfectly legitimate reduction in consultants' private practice - is resolved quickly. That is Mr Crisp's first challenge.

fields.headline: Blair attacked over NHS 'spin'
fields.standfirst:
Repentant PM urges surgeons to embrace change

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's admission that the government should be "absolutely frank" about the time needed to improve the NHS was thrown back in his face yesterday when a senior surgeon accused him of raising unrealistic expectations by "spinning" the figures.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's admission that the government should be "absolutely frank" about the time needed to improve the NHS was thrown back in his face yesterday when a senior surgeon accused him of raising unrealistic expectations by "spinning" the figures.

Bernard Rebeiro, a consultant surgeon at Basildon hospital and member of the council of the Royal College of Surgeons, told the prime minister that by promising 7,500 new consultants, when only 1,500 of these would be new posts, or 200 new CT scanners, when all but 50 were replacements, "the government is giving the impression the health service is going to be so much better when it isn't".

He added: "One of the big problems you have here is one of expectation. I am very concerned that we need to be very frank with the public and make sure they do know what they are going to get."

The former president of the Association of Surgeons of Britain and Ireland called for an end to such "spin, double accounting and treble accounting" as Mr Blair faced the Royal College of Surgeons for the first time since the publication of the NHS Plan in July.

Doctors' leaders had been infuriated by the £19.4bn blueprint for reform's proposal to ban consultants from practising in the private sector for seven years - a move described by the BMA as "an ill-conceived, vindictive attack" - but yesterday surgeons privately decided not to grill Mr Blair on the issue.

"We are all still very concerned about it because it takes away our freedom to do what we want in our spare time but we didn't want to get sidetracked when the real issue is advising on how to deliver the right health care for the NHS," said Mr Rebeiro.

In return, the prime minister appeared placatory, stressing that the government wanted the ban so that young consultants concentrated on building their expertise within the NHS, but acknowledging the need for further discussions. "Try and understand what we're trying to deal with so we come to an arrangement that suits you and us for the long term," he added.

He urged surgeons to embrace the plans for modernisation, warning that without their support the NHS could not offer the health care needed. "In return for the money, some of the old style practices, old style demarcations between professions, uncollaborative ways of working must go," he warned. "The NHS ... needs to become better. To adapt. To be prepared to do things differently."

But he also admitted the government had misjudged the depth and scale of the problems afflicting the NHS. "I know our first two years in office were very tight, and I am sorry for that," he added.

He stressed the need to be "absolutely frank" about the time needed to improve the NHS - a pledge reiterated by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who said the government would gain more respect by being "dead straight with people about the depth of problems and the amount of time to put it right".

Speaking after such pledges, Mr Rebeiro reiterated that the government would face fierce criticism if it failed to deliver - and challenged ministers, in their accounting, to show such honesty.
