fields.headline: Easy access for all
fields.standfirst: Poster campaign encourages businesses to make changes
fields.trailText: Poster campaign encourages businesses to make changes
fields.body:
Posters are springing up on billboards across the country this week, asking business people: "What have you got to offer?" The posters variously feature a pub, a restaurant and a greengrocer's, but the aim is to put the onus on all service providers to think about how they cater for customers with disabilities.

The poster campaign, which will be matched by newspaper and magazine advertisements, has been devised by the Department for Education and Employment to raise awareness of provisions in the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA) that service providers should make "reasonable" adjustments to ensure disabled people have appropriate access. The provisions became effective a year ago.

The campaign is the first by the government on disability since last year's See the Person drive, which faced criticism from some disability activists for being patronising. It is believed that the composition of the new posters was discussed in advance, and at length, with a number of people from the disability sector.

A key theme of the campaign is that businesses very often need make only small changes to comply with the act. Many business people have been alarmed by rumours, and reports in parts of the media, that fundamental changes are required. The posters give a helpline number and a website address where further advice is available from the Disability Rights Commission (DRC).

Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, says: "There are over 8m disabled people in the UK with a spending power of over £40bn a year. And those disabled people want to use services just like everyone else.

"This campaign will help service providers understand practical and simple ways in which they can make their businesses more accessible to disabled customers. These easy-to-understand examples on the posters will help businesses think again about what they can do to help increase their access to disabled people."

Early reaction among mainstream disability groups has been favourable. They are welcoming the shift of emphasis from the pure consciousness raising of See the Person to the need for concrete measures to help disabled people.

Brian Lamb, public affairs director of the Royal National Institute for Deaf People, says: "It's a good attempt to show that a lot of the adjustments that businesses are expected to make are simple and easily do-able, so that disabled people can have the same level of service as everyone else.

"All the evidence shows that it's small and medium sized businesses that are either completely unaware of the legislation, or are not getting to grips with it. The B&Qs of this world are well aware of it already, and are making enormous strides, but a lot of everyday services don't come from them - they come from the guy round the corner."

Liz Daone, head of campaigns at Scope, the cerebral palsy charity which has itself mounted similar awareness drives, says she is "delighted that Margaret Hodge is recognising the importance of the disabled pound".

It makes no sense for businesses to exclude disabled people, says Daone. "Companies that do not become accessible will miss out on these customers - and on profits - and are potentially in breach of the DDA. The poster campaign shows that accessibility changes do not have to cost a lot.

"Businesses often complain that they cannot afford to make their premises accessible, or do not know where to go for help. Surely, with the launch of this campaign, businesses can no longer use ignorance as an excuse."

Disability groups will be looking to the government to build on the campaign. Lamb says: "Of course it's not enough on its own. What's needed is the determination to see it through. It does need to be sustained."

 The DRC helpline is on 08457-622633 and its website is at www.drc-gb.org

fields.headline: The suffering professionals
fields.trailText: If you want to understand the woes of universities in Britain, you might contemplate the "research transparency exercise". This is a bit of government snooping which asks teachers how we spend our time during the week.
fields.body:
If you want to understand the woes of universities in Britain, you might contemplate the "research transparency exercise". This is a bit of government snooping which asks teachers how we spend our time during the week. In addition to totalling the hours we spend instructing and doing research, we have to include "breaks taken from academic duties, whether spent at home or away", and we have to work out not just the time we spend at conferences but our travel time. I included the fact that I spend 13.7% of each week day-dreaming, 9.8% of which is in my office, 3.2% in my favourite armchair. The government may allow me the armchair.

Teachers aren't alone the victims of Big Brother. The bureaucratic nightmare has weighed down the health services, social work, transport, and local government - and no one is getting rich in these jobs. In my own bailiwick, senior scholars in Britain spend about twice the time on administration than they do in America, for about half the pay. The RTE joins other "exercises" like the RAE ("research assessment") and TQAE ("teaching quality assessment"). I don't know who reads this stuff; I do know that for us it is a demoralising rather than an invigorating exercise.

The assumption in the past was that people went into public service because of the intrinsic value of the work. But that is no longer realistic. Low pay, coupled with lots of bureaucracy, sends a big warning to young people: do something else! The health services are losing experienced doctors to the private sector; teachers in primary schools harassed by Ofsted are quitting; scholars are leaving the country. I've spent the last week trying to prise out of various government agencies some facts about just how gloomy this gloomy picture is. For some strange reason, among all the statistics our masters gather, I could find no one in authority who keeps records on the brain drain.

As a former American academic, what I have observed is a change among people leaving Britain for North America. Fifteen years ago, when British universities began to suffer, the people crossing the Atlantic tended to be stars with international reputations, such as the philosophers Bernard Williams and Richard Wollheim. Today the academic expatriates seem younger, in their early 40s. This is just the age when a scholar or researcher is coming into his or her own, and the time when pay differentials between Britain and America tend to widen.

New York University, where I taught, has vigorously recruited some of these talented younger people in the humanities and social sciences. They aren't dewy-eyed immigrants kneeling in prayer as the planes land in America. They have given up family and friends, and their children will go to foreign schools. Nor are they simply coming for the money. The ones I know - and used to recruit - have come for the sake of their work.

It's easy to blame Thatcherism for this sorry state of affairs, given the hatred she and her cronies nursed against the intelligentsia and the contempt her crew showed public service in general. But blaming the Tories is too easy. Though the present government has begun to address the financial distress of the public sector, it has yet to grapple with the demoralising, soul- deadening bureaucracy which makes talented people think about doing something else or going elsewhere.

The problem is simply that the government does not trust the public sector to regulate itself, at least at the professional level. Of course there were, and are, and will be, abuses in the public sector - just as in business. I imagine the present government is still in thrall to the terrible time in the 80s when local Labour councils ceased to serve the public interest well, or serve it at all. But to treat doctors, social workers or teachers like local councillors is a grave error.

A public service works well when professionals in it get respect for their work; under these conditions they will hold each other to account. That's how the health services used to operate, and it made medical care in Britain the envy of other countries. The present system is an institutionalised form of contempt: it supposes that, left to ourselves, we won't keep our own houses in order.

I have, therefore, a simple policy proposal: trust us - the most radical reform this government could undertake. Put everyone employed administering the RTE, the RAE and the TQAE to work monitoring Railtrack instead; let us govern ourselves. If the government did just this, perhaps those British academics who have been lured abroad would begin buying plane-tickets home.

Richard Sennett, author of 'The corrosion of character' (Norton £8.95) and sociology professor at LSE, will be writing a regular column.

fields.headline: Associated denies delay to femail.co.uk
fields.trailText: Associated New Media has refuted speculation that it has had to delay the launch of femail.co.uk, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Associated New Media has refuted speculation that it has had to delay the launch of femail.co.uk, its new flagship women's site.

Ted Verity, editorial director at Associated New Media, said a launch date had never been set and that the site may be up and running by Christmas. Sources at Associated claim they were told the site would launch in October.

Mr Verity said: "The whole thing has been meticulously organised and we have a clear editorial strategy." He pointed out that it was imperative to launch a "brilliant product" given that it was effectively a second-generation site that would replace CharlotteStreet.com.

"We're getting very close to launching a fantastic product and working round the clock to make it happen," he added.

Sources close to ANM have suggested that the mooted delay was due to "indecisiveness" and confusion about editorial direction, a factor vehemently denied by Mr Verity.

ANM currently has professional consultants performing functionality tests on femail.co.uk. Mr Verity said a number of "minor adjustments" had been suggested and subsequently implemented and he was awaiting further reports.

Mr Verity implied that ANM was in no hurry to launch femail.co.uk because it already had a product on the market - CharlotteStreet.com - and that ANM would launch femail.co.uk "when ready".

fields.headline: Railtrack boss resigns
fields.standfirst: Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The chief executive of Railtrack, Gerald Corbett, tendered his resignation today, as the organisation admitted that the condition of the track in the area of yesterday's Hatfield train derailment was "not good".
fields.body:
The chief executive of Railtrack, Gerald Corbett, tendered his resignation today, as the organisation admitted that the condition of the track in the area of yesterday's Hatfield train derailment was "not good".

With investigations into the crash focusing on the possibility that a broken rail caused the Great North Eastern Railways service to derail, the Railtrack board will meet at 6pm today to decide whether to accept Mr Corbett's resignation.

Railtrack, the rail infrastructure company that is responsible for maintaining tracks, said the section of the line where the accident occurred had been reassessed for re-railing in January and that work had started in May.

The balance of the work was due to have been completed in November and the crash section of track had been treated for grinding in early September to prevent cracks, Railtrack said.

As GNER resumed a full service on the line where four people died yesterday, Railtrack said that it was "investigating the possibility of a broken rail being a factor in the tragedy".

At the scene of the crash, a Railtrack director said that a broken rail had been found, but it was not yet known if it was smashed before the accident or during it.

Earlier, Mr Corbett said: "I, personally, am distraught that another tragedy has occurred on our railways.

"The families of the bereaved are foremost in my mind. As a matter of course, as chief executive of Railtrack, I have, of course, tendered my resignation to the board."

However, Pam Warren, the founder of the Paddington Survivors Group, said: "We urge Railtrack not to accept Gerald Corbett's resignation."

Speaking at a news conference at the Madejski stadium in Reading, Berks, Mrs Warren, who was badly burned in last year's rail disaster, said: "I have today spoken to Gerald Corbett and his wife. He is genuinely upset and affected with what has happened.

"The way forward now is constructive dialogue. We are beginning to have a working relationship with Railtrack."

Railtrack also today imposed a speed restriction on bends on high-speed lines. This will require drivers to knock a third off their permitted speed in such areas and will lead to inevitable delays for passengers.

Seven people were today still in hospital after Tuesday's 12.10pm GNER London to Leeds high-speed train derailed in Hertfordshire.

The four men who died in the crash have yet to be named, although the identities of two of those who died in the crash were due to be released later tonight by police. All were in the buffet car of the train which had its roof torn off after colliding with a trackside pylon.

Although they were not named, those still in hospital are six women and one man. The women were identified as a 61-year-old from Salisbury in Wiltshire, a 30-year-old from Wakefield, West Yorkshire, a 66-year-old from Harrogate, North Yorkshire, a 40-year-old from Nottingham, a 38-year-old from London and a 40-year old from Sheffield, South Yorkshire. The man, aged 41, comes from south-east London, said police.

Both Railtrack and GNER agreed today that the crash will lead to renewed anxiety among passengers.

Railtrack London and North East Region director Nicholas Pollard said: "The investigations will continue urgently throughout today."

He said he was aware that Railtrack could come under heavy fire if the crash was found to be caused by a fault with a rail.

"I am sure people will take that line and I understand that obviously a tragedy of this nature shakes confidence right across the industry in the UK as a whole."

GNER chief executive Christopher Garnett said that railways were still "incredibly safe although I do accept that what happened yesterday has shaken people's confidence".

Mr Garnett added that he did not think that the number of serious accidents in recent years was anything to do with rail privatisation.

He added: "There is a perception that rail travel is unsafe, but when you look at the statistics, it is an incredibly safe way of travel."

But Vernon Hince, of the biggest rail union the RMT, said there had been widespread concern that the privatised rail companies were not observing safety procedures.

George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies, said that he was certain that "corners were not cut".

As the search for clues continued, transport minister Lord Macdonald said that he was looking for answers "in hours and days rather than weeks".

The routes that are most likely to be affected by the Railtrack speed restrictions are the London to Scotland East Coast main line on which the accident happened, the West Coast main line, which also runs from London to Scotland and the Great Western line from London to Bristol and Cardiff.

The West Coast line, in particular, has a number of bends.

This has prompted Virgin Trains, run by Sir Richard Branson, to invest in high-speed tilting trains that can go faster around curves.

They are due to be introduced on the line in 2002 and will considerably reduce journey times from London to the Midlands, north west of England and Scotland.

After bringing down the annual number of broken rails in the network, Railtrack had to report a sharp rise in incidents in 1998-99. Although the figure was slightly down in 1999-2000, Rail Regulator Tom Winsor has told Railtrack of his unhappiness with its record on broken rails.

Publishing the latest statistics for broken rail, the Health and Safety Executive said that the number was "still significantly higher than in the mid-1990s".

Another problem, according to provisional HSE figures, is buckles in track. The number of these, which had fallen to 21 in 1998-99, more than trebled to 64 in 1999-2000.

Yesterday's accident occurred on a stretch of track that is continuously welded, which should greatly reduce the chances of a rail cracking. But rail experts agree that defects can appear even in welded areas.

In its most recent annual report, Railtrack said that the drop in the number of broken rails last year was not enough, but added that track quality was now better than at any time since the mid-1990s.

The company has also said that the growth of traffic on the network, particularly heavy freight, has had a major impact on track deterioration.

The company has been ensuring that track renewals are targeted at locations where they will have the most effect.

Railtrack has also spoken of introducing the UIC60 rail, which is the standard rail used in the rest of Europe. It is stronger than the traditional rail that is used in Britain and needs less maintenance.

The company plans to replace an extra 350 miles of rail over the next five years. A total of 68,000 tonnes of new rail has been ordered for this year - the highest amount since 1988.

In 1995-96, there were 776 broken rails and 133 track buckles on the network. The following year, broken rails dropped to 739, but provisional figures for 1999-2000 saw the figure climb to 949 from a high of 988 in the previous 12 months.

Track buckles slid to a low of 21 in 1998-99, but by last year, the provisional figures revealed 64 incidents.

In the immediate aftermath of the crash, several possible reasons for the crash were considered, including terrorism, which has since been discounted.

A broken wheel was also thought a possible cause, but GNER said today that, as they were convinced that this was not the case, they would be running a service on the route today.

Vandalism is another possibility that has not been ruled out, but that seems unlikely, as it would be expected that the front of the train would have been derailed before the middle carriages.

The assistant chief constable of the British Transport Police, Paul Nicholas, said that a criminal investigation, probing the possibility of vandalism, was underway. This needs to be concluded before the police give control of the scene over for the technical investigation _ which is expected to happen no earlier than the end of this week.

Mr Nicholas said: "20% of that [the investigation] has been conducted and there is no evidence of vandalism so far."

The overturned carriages had been partially lifted this afternoon with the use of air bags and no more casualties had been found, he said. The search would continue tomorrow and the carriages would probably not be removed from the line until Friday.

Among the Railtrack board members who will tonight decide the fate of Mr Gerald Corbett's will be Jennifer Page, the sacked chief executive of the Millennium Dome.

Ms Page, who earns £26,000 in her role as a part-time board member of Railtrack, will be one of 12 directors at the meeting, which will start after 6pm at Railtrack's head office by Euston station in London.

He is genuinely upset and affected with what has happened. "The way forward now is constructive dialogue. We are beginning to have a working relationship with Railtrack." Railtrack also today imposed a speed restriction on bends on high-speed lines. This will require drivers to knock a third off their permitted speed in such areas and will lead to inevitable delays for passengers. Seven people were today still in hospital after Tuesday's 12.10pm GNER London to Leeds high-speed train derailed in Hertfordshire. The four men who died in the crash have yet to be named, although the identities of two of those who died in the crash were due to be released later tonight by police. All were in the buffet car of the train which had its roof torn off after colliding with a trackside pylon. Although they were not named, those still in hospital are six women and one man. The women were identified as a 61-year-old from Salisbury in Wiltshire, a 30-year-old from Wakefield, West Yorkshire, a 66-year-old from Harrogate, North Yorkshire, a 40-year-old from Nottingham, a 38-year-old from London and a 40-year old from Sheffield, South Yorkshire. The man, aged 41, comes from south-east London, said police. Both Railtrack and GNER agreed today that the crash will lead to renewed anxiety among passengers. Railtrack London and North East Region director Nicholas Pollard said: "The investigations will continue urgently throughout today." He said he was aware that Railtrack could come under heavy fire if the crash was found to be caused by a fault with a rail. "I am sure people will take that line and I understand that obviously a tragedy of this nature shakes confidence right across the industry in the UK as a whole." GNER chief executive Christopher Garnett said that railways were still "incredibly safe although I do accept that what happened yesterday has shaken people's confidence". Mr Garnett added that he did not think that the number of serious accidents in recent years was anything to do with rail privatisation. He added: "There is a perception that rail travel is unsafe, but when you look at the statistics, it is an incredibly safe way of travel." But Vernon Hince, of the biggest rail union the RMT, said there had been widespread concern that the privatised rail companies were not observing safety procedures. George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies, said that he was certain that "corners were not cut". As the search for clues continued, transport minister Lord Macdonald said that he was looking for answers "in hours and days rather than weeks". The routes that are most likely to be affected by the Railtrack speed restrictions are the London to Scotland East Coast main line on which the accident happened, the West Coast main line, which also runs from London to Scotland and the Great Western line from London to Bristol and Cardiff. The West Coast line, in particular, has a number of bends. This has prompted Virgin Trains, run by Sir Richard Branson, to invest in high-speed tilting trains that can go faster around curves. They are due to be introduced on the line in 2002 and will considerably reduce journey times from London to the Midlands, north west of England and Scotland. After bringing down the annual number of broken rails in the network, Railtrack had to report a sharp rise in incidents in 1998-99. Although the figure was slightly down in 1999-2000, Rail Regulator Tom Winsor has told Railtrack of his unhappiness with its record on broken rails. Publishing the latest statistics for broken rail, the Health and Safety Executive said that the number was "still significantly higher than in the mid-1990s". Another problem, according to provisional HSE figures, is buckles in track. The number of these, which had fallen to 21 in 1998-99, more than trebled to 64 in 1999-2000. Yesterday's accident occurred on a stretch of track that is continuously welded, which should greatly reduce the chances of a rail cracking. But rail experts agree that defects can appear even in welded areas. In its most recent annual report, Railtrack said that the drop in the number of broken rails last year was not enough, but added that track quality was now better than at any time since the mid-1990s. The company has also said that the growth of traffic on the network, particularly heavy freight, has had a major impact on track deterioration. The company has been ensuring that track renewals are targeted at locations where they will have the most effect. Railtrack has also spoken of introducing the UIC60 rail, which is the standard rail used in the rest of Europe. It is stronger than the traditional rail that is used in Britain and needs less maintenance. The company plans to replace an extra 350 miles of rail over the next five years. A total of 68,000 tonnes of new rail has been ordered for this year - the highest amount since 1988. In 1995-96, there were 776 broken rails and 133 track buckles on the network. The following year, broken rails dropped to 739, but provisional figures for 1999-2000 saw the figure climb to 949 from a high of 988 in the previous 12 months. Track buckles slid to a low of 21 in 1998-99, but by last year, the provisional figures revealed 64 incidents. In the immediate aftermath of the crash, several possible reasons for the crash were considered, including terrorism, which has since been discounted. A broken wheel was also thought a possible cause, but GNER said today that, as they were convinced that this was not the case, they would be running a service on the route today. Vandalism is another possibility that has not been ruled out, but that seems unlikely, as it would be expected that the front of the train would have been derailed before the middle carriages. The assistant chief constable of the British Transport Police, Paul Nicholas, said that a criminal investigation, probing the possibility of vandalism, was underway. This needs to be concluded before the police give control of the scene over for the technical investigation _ which is expected to happen no earlier than the end of this week. Mr Nicholas said: "20% of that [the investigation] has been conducted and there is no evidence of vandalism so far." The overturned carriages had been partially lifted this afternoon with the use of air bags and no more casualties had been found, he said. The search would continue tomorrow and the carriages would probably not be removed from the line until Friday. Among the Railtrack board members who will tonight decide the fate of Mr Gerald Corbett's will be Jennifer Page, the sacked chief executive of the Millennium Dome. Ms Page, who earns £26,000 in her role as a part-time board member of Railtrack, will be one of 12 directors at the meeting, which will start after 6pm at Railtrack's head office by Euston station in London. webTitle: Benn may change election of Speaker

fields.headline: Benn may change election of Speaker
fields.standfirst: Veteran MP pushes for reform of arcane procedures
fields.trailText: Tony Benn will today make a last-minute attempt to open up the arcane          procedures for electing the 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons by          securing agreement to change the rules as soon as MPs return to          Westminster on Monday.
fields.body:
Tony Benn will today make a last-minute attempt to open up the arcane procedures for electing the 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons by securing agreement to change the rules as soon as MPs return to Westminster on Monday.

Contrary to expectation that nothing can be done despite a determined campaign by modernisers all summer, there is now a real chance for change. Instead of voting on candidates two at a time - hoping to get a consensus candidate from a crowded field - it would allow all 13 hopefuls to be voted on at once, with a second vote play-off between the top two.

That is Mr Benn's plan. The 75-year-old former Labour cabinet minister will meet Sir Edward Heath , father of the Commons and nine years his senior, to argue that the former Conservative premier has the power to let MPs choose directly from up to 13 aspirants to Betty Boothroyd's office. The two old rivals are the only survivors of the 1950 parliament and have sat as MPs under eight speakers. Sir Edward, who may retire at the coming election - as will Mr Benn - has been telling MPs he will stick to the existing rules unless strongly persuaded otherwise. Sir Edward is keen to "get it right", while Mr Benn would relish a last blow for enhanced democratic procedures.

To nudge Sir Edward along, a clutch of senior ministers and ex-ministers, including John Major and Kenneth Clarke, as well as committee chairmen are backing the changes. These include either a new voting system or the kind of hustings for candidates which younger MPs such as Labour's Peter Bradley and Gordon Prentice are organising on Monday. In meetings yesterday the clerk of the Commons, Bill McKay, a key player, told Mr Benn and Sir Edward that, as acting speaker for the day Sir Edward can change the rules if MPs agree - a crucial concession to the case many MPs have made in letters to the former prime minister.

With or without a change of rules, and barring a spectacular upset, Michael Martin, a 55-year-old Glasgow trade unionist, will be elected. Miss Boothroyd will resign as Speaker and an MP this weekend after eight years of keeping order and running the pounds 200m parliamentary budget.

Many MPs who support Mr Martin's candidacy also believe the rules should be changed. So do some on both sides who believe that he lacks the necessary grip or firmness to manage an unruly Commons and run the labyrinthine Palace of Westminster.

A high degree of consensus remains important. The past two speakers - Miss Boothroyd and Tory Bernard Weatherill - were elected by backbenchers against government-favoured runners. This time, candidates whose names have been promoted by ministerial "narks" have suffered accordingly.

Liberal Democrat Menzies Campbell has been hurt this way as has the Tory front-runner, former minister and arch-moderate Sir George Young, the most likely winner if Mr Martin stumbles.

Part of the problem lies in the timing of Miss Boothroyd's departure, designed to give the existing Commons the choice, but coming just as they began a 12-week summer break. The other problem this time is the number of would-be speakers who will not stand down though their hopes are slender.

In 1983 Margaret Thatcher hoped her former cabinet ally, Humphrey Atkins would win. When support was lacking he pulled out and backed Mr Weatherill, another Tory and ex-whip whom she disliked. In 1992 John Major backed Peter Brooke, who was popular but a recent cabinet member.

He proved the fallguy. Miss Boothroyd's name was put forward as an amendment to the Brooke motion - and carried convincingly by 372 to 238. Other Tory hopefuls melted away. If no Benn amendment is pushed through MPs expect a similar deal whereby someone, probably Alan Haselhurst, Miss Boothroyd's Tory deputy, is proposed - the fallguy - and Mr Martin's name added as the amendment.

He would probably win easily. If not, Sir George's name might be proposed. But many MPs would regard it as an affront to democractic practice that 10 candidates never had their chance.

fields.headline: Nasdaq bubble slowly deflating
fields.trailText: Robert Shiller, the Yale economics professor who earlier this year pushed a pin into the hi-tech bubble, remains a pessimist. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Robert Shiller, the Yale economics professor who pushed a pin into the hi-tech bubble earlier this year, remains a pessimist. In an interview with the Guardian yesterday, Mr Shiller said that US shares were still trading at historically high valuations in spite of a dramatic sell-off in the past six weeks.

He shrugged off the impact of individual corporate results on the overall trend. "Instead of a bubble bursting, the market is more like a ball with a leak in it. It is going down but imperceptibly."

When Mr Shiller published his book Irrational Exuberance earlier this year, the Dow Jones and Nasdaq stock indexes were close to all-time highs. Since then, both have fallen sharply with the Nasdaq down 40% in the year to date. Yesterday, the man derided as an academic naysayer, concluded: "This is kind of what I expected." He added that the Nasdaq was still "wildly overpriced".

The turmoil has hit the big names. Last week shares in Yahoo! one of the biggest names on the internet, lost 27%. On Mon day Verizon and Vodafone delayed their $5bn public offering after a series of high-profile technology companies put out profit warnings.

Investors are now raising doubts about Rupert Murdoch's ambitious plans to spin off News Corporation's satellite assets. Larry Haverty, a fund manager and analyst at State Street Research, said News Corp's plans to start an investor roadshow for Sky Global in the next few weeks were likely to be shelved. "I think right now it's unlikely that they can get a deal done," he said after recent conversations with the management.

The flotation of Sky Global, which in cludes BSkyB as well as News Corporation's digital assets around the world, will be one of the largest media company listings ever. Mr Murdoch has indicated that it would be valued at about $40bn when listed in New York.

A spokesman for New Corporation said yesterday that the planned listing was still "on track" to be completed by the end of the year. If so, a roadshow to attract new investors is likely to start some time in November.

Another big name to be hit hard by the market weakness is America Online, the world's largest internet service provider which is due to announce its latest earnings figures after markets close tonight. Shares in AOL dropped 15% yesterday morning to a year's low as concerns mounted that a downturn in the internet sector would hit the group's revenues from advertisers.

The sharp fall has prompted several analysts to question the group's proposed groundbreaking merger with Time Warner, the media conglomerate. The stock market value of AOL has halved since last December, before the merger was announced.

At the same time, shares in Time Warner fell sharply yesterday. At about $68, the shares are not far above their pre-bid levels. Mr Haverty was among several Wall Street analysts to suggest that Time Warner executives must be rethinking the value of the deal, given the sharp down turn in AOL's share price. "As the likelihood of them ending this deal goes higher, the lower these shares fall."

Two companies that have led the market downwards will report within 24 hours of each other this week. Intel, the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer, prompted the latest wave of selling last month when it warned that the third-quarter results it was due to report last night would be worse than expected. Since then, shares in the this former sure bet have more than halved. Even after this unusually sharp descent, traders yesterday were still nervous that last night's earnings would point to even greater problems.

Investors will be nervously watching for any signs of warnings from Microsoft today when it announces its third-quarter results. On Monday night, shares in the world's largest software company fell to a two-year low of $50.38.

Microsoft was the most highly valued company in the world as recently as January with a market capitalisation of more than $500bn and three of the world's four richest men sitting on its board. Yesterday, Rick Sherlund, the highly rated Goldman Sachs analyst, brought some relief to the shares by suggesting that the company could bounce back as long as today's announcement contains nothing new. In the present raging bear market, that constituted an invitation to buy. Shares in Microsoft were up $1 at midday.

webTitle: Middle East crisis: what the papers are saying

fields.headline: Middle East crisis: what the papers are saying
fields.trailText: As the Middle East teeters, Derek Brown looks at how the local press are viewing the situation.
fields.body:
The day after the Sharm el-Sheik ceasefire agreement, there is not much optimism to be found in the regional press. Predictably, Israelis now want Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to prove that he means peace, while Arab opinion wants exactly the same of Israel.

The Jordan Times gives prominence to two pictures: smiling leaders at the Sharm el-Sheik summit, and grieving women at the funeral of 13-year-old Muayyad Osama Jawarish in Bethlehem.

The paper reports King Abdullah's warning that the success of the ceasefire depends entirely upon Israel's prompt implementation of its part of the deal.

A gloomy leading article also notes that peace hopes depend on what happens on the streets.

"Palestinian president Yasser Arafat and Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak, whose mutual trust has plunged to an all-time low, will have to work hard to sell the truce to their furious populations and to ensure it stands.

"They will have to calculate their own political and diplomatic risks and see how best they could build confidence and re-engage for the benefit of the whole region.

"Clinton, who is counting his final days in the White House, has to work equally hard to ensure full implementation of the latest agreement to fulfil his promise of an honest peace broker - even if most Arabs have given up on that."

The Khaleej Times, in the United Arab Emirates, rather callously observes that the Sharm el-Sheik agreement has calmed world oil markets.

The editorial goes on to note the lurch to the right of Israeli public opinion, and the enormous task facing Palestinian president Yasser Arafat to convince his people of the need to resume peace negotiations.

"Passions are running high among the rank and file of his own organisation, Fatah, who believe that the long-winded peace process has run its course and that it is time to renew the intifada.

"It will take more than mere words from Arafat to put back their faith in negotiation."

The Palestinian Ministry of Information daily summary of headlines from the local Arabic papers is full of anger and bloodshed, with three more deaths recorded and a great deal of invective against Jewish settlers in the occupied territories.

The Arab Media Internet Network carries a reminder that it is not just those in the front line who are being harmed.

It features an appeal by the Union of Palestinian medical relief committees for international intervention. The appeal points out that many communities are running short of food and medicine, and is fiercely critical of the Israeli "closures" - the sealing off of Arab areas.

It offers the poignant example of what this meant to 10-year-old Alaa Osama Hamdan from Sawiyya village near Nablus. "Alaa became ill with a serious case of acute abdominal pain. The Israeli forces prevented her from travelling to a hospital in Nablus for nearly two days.

"Her father finally succeeded in bringing her to a clinic in the nearby village of Qabbalan. Alaa died almost immediately after she arrived at the clinic."

Another pan-Arab website, Arabia.net, carries an interesting selection of cartoons from the region's papers, on the theme of the violence in the occupied territories.

The Jerusalem Post carries news of continuing violence, and an extraordinary report that two men who were in the mob which lynched two Israeli soldiers in Ramallah last week, may have been abducted and summarily executed by Israeli secret service agents.

The hawkish paper finds President Clinton's "even-handedness" at the summit alarming. It comments: "Enough with equivocation: it is the Palestinians, not Israel, that must now prove their desire for peace. This must be immediate and comprehensive, demonstrated by the Palestinian leadership, security apparatus, and the majority of the populace.

"If not, then all that was achieved at Sharm was a temporary truce."

The Post also maintains its reputation for dull and deeply unfunny cartoons, with a crude caricature of Yasser Arafat recoiling from a boomering he has just thrown, marked "violence".

The more moderate Ha'aretz welcomes the ceasefire, but says it does not nearly enough to revive the peace process.

"The negotiation vacuum which facilitated the eruption of violence must be filled by decisive diplomatic activity. Events in recent days undermined hopes held by many Israelis and Palestinians regarding the prospect that a just reconciliation between the two peoples can be reached.

"Concrete diplomatic steps, and an agreed-upon timetable for the resumption of negotiations from the point at which they stalled at Camp David, are now crucial components needed for the process of recovery from the bloody clashes."

fields.headline: Premier League confident of finding new broadcaster
fields.trailText: 4.30pm update: Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore speaks on the collapse of the PPV deal with NTL.
fields.body:
Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore said: "We respect the fact that NTL have reached this decision. The outlook for the FA Premier League is, however, very positive."

It is believed that the Premier League was unhappy with a number of additions NTL wanted to make to the ground-breaking deal and, privately, that there was also some doubt as to whether the company could actually fulfil its commitments.

Although today's announcement causes some embarrassment to the Premier League, it does not believe it will have a problem trying to find a replacement broadcaster.

fields.headline: Press review
fields.standfirst: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow on what is occupying the Russian newspapers
fields.trailText:
Amelia Gentleman in Moscow on what is occupying the Russian newspapers
Special report: Russia
fields.body:
Kursk
With just days to go before the operation to recover the bodies of sailors from the sunken Kursk begins, Parlamentskaya Gazeta argues that the whole venture should be cancelled. The paper claims that the government's decision to try to rescue some of the corpses came as a result of extreme pressure from the media - and argues that the risks of the mission have been ignored. Its report points out the dangers to the divers who are to undertake the task and questions whether it is necessary to expose the families of the 118 dead men once again to such extreme levels of stress, unavoidable during a recovery operation which is due at best to retrieve just a small fraction of the bodies. Under a headline "Leave their bodies in peace", the report concludes: "According to a naval tradition which has existed ever the beginning of seafaring history, there is no shame in being buried at sea".

Middle East
The reasons behind Russia's non-attendance at the Sharm El-Sheikh peace summit continue for the second day to be analysed in the Russian press - with the humiliation of the perceived snub to the Kremlin gaining almost as much prominence as the agreement itself. Seeking to explain Russia's absence from such an important international summit, the tabloid Komsomolskaya Pravda argues that Russia - having proved its diplomatic prowess in the resolution of the conflict in Yugoslavia - was giving America a chance to play a key role in negotiations. The report concludes that Russia will have plenty of opportunity in the future to exert its influence in the resolution of Middle Eastern affairs, characterising the agreement reached by Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat as "fragile".

Pope
With the spy case against American citizen Edmund Pope due to begin today, the businessman's lawyer tells the Moscow Times that his prospects are bleak. Pope, a retired naval intelligence officer who travelled to Russia to buy marine technology equipment for use in the West, was arrested in Moscow on April 3 and charged with trying to buy top secret documents connected with a high-speed torpedo called the Shkval. If he is found guilty, Pope, 54, faces up to 20 years in prison. The paper quotes Pope as commenting that he has little hope of being released, stating: "I see two possible outcomes - a better one and a worse one. The worse one would be that we are all thrown in jail, including the laywers. The better one would be that I am imprisoned alone."

Gore-Chernomyrdin scandal continues
The fall out from George Bush jnr's accusation that former prime minister Victor Chernomyrdin siphoned off IMF funds continues in Russia's papers today. The remarks were made as Bush launched an attack on the Democrats' policy on Russia during last week's televised debate with Al Gore and prompted Chernomyrdin to announce this week that he planned to sue. Izvestiya reports on the latest stage of a scandal, which it believes could extinguish Gore's chances of winning the elections. The paper publishes the text of a letter from Chernomyrdin to Gore, informing him about details of Russian nuclear cooperation with Iran and urging him to keep the details secret from Congress. Explaining the power of these revelations within the context of the American election campaign, the paper comments: "The Republicans have nosed out an opportunity to attack the Democrats for having apparently led Russia from the bright world of democracy into the leaden and foggy twilight of corruption".

Bolshoi Premier
After weeks of upheaval behind scenes at the Bolshoi, great attention has been paid in the Russian press to preparations for tonight's premier of Tchaikovsky's opera Evgeny Onegin. Rather than displaying a new interpretation of the work, the producer has returned to a 1944 production - recreating costumes and sets from this classic production. Moscow's critics are, however, undecided about the value of this exercise. Komsomolskaya Pravda also reports with some scepticism on the decision to cast the popular classical star, Nikolai Baskov, in the main role as Lensky - commenting that the singer has become so used to performing to huge concert audiences that he can no longer sing well without the aid of a microphone and has clearly been struggling during rehearsals.

"This was evident from the laboured expressions he made, and his agonised articulation of every sound," the reporter comments "You got the impression that Lensky had some kind of tic or another kind of illness to the nervous system."

fields.headline: Warner/AOL deal nears regulatory 'home stretch'
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Time Warner says its merger with AOL is nearing the US regulatory "home stretch", reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Media giant Time Warner has said its planned merger with AOL is nearing the US regulatory "home stretch", while unveiling its third-quarter results.

Time Warner reported a 13% rise in operating profit, driven by increases at its publishing and cable network businesses. The company reported revenues up 3% to $6.87bn (£4.48bn). Earnings before interest, tax and amortisation rose 13% to $1.27bn, excluding charges.

The group's publishing division reported a 14% rise in earnings, driven by magazine advertising gains at Fortune, In Style, Sports Illustrated and Time.

The film division performed less well. Hits including the Perfect Storm and Space Cowboys failed to lift results, which were 6% down at $218m.

Chairman and chief executive Gerald Levin said: "Third-quarter operating profits were fuelled by 17% growth in advertising and provide exceptional momentum for our impending merger with AOL.

"The merger will have a profound effect on our businesses across the board, substantially driving our growth, profitability and free cashflow potential."

fields.headline: A game of two halves
fields.standfirst: Go-karts, activity days, sleepovers ...  Nigel Planer pulls out all the stops to keep his sons busy and happy for the half-term holiday
fields.trailText: Go-karts, activity days, sleepovers ... Nigel Planer pulls out all the stops to keep his sons busy and happy for the half-term holiday.
fields.body:
I always try to lay on something special at half-term. It's expected. And it's great to take a day or two, switch off and enjoy stuff with your kids. As I tend to know all about boys, I lean towards go-karting as a good option: I like the boy stuff. During a recent holiday in Devon we got both our older boys catapults. I had to take a serious interest in these - purely from the point of view of proper parental instruction and supervision, of course.

Arranging time off work should be easy because Frankie and I are both self-employed, but it never works out that way. In practice, it's a nightmare. The nature of the business is more that you go along to a reading and they say, "Right, we want you: we start tomorrow and it's nine night shoots in North Wales. Can you do it?"

I have been in the situation where you just can't cancel work. I've had my son sitting in the dressing-room, letting him wander around and sending him secret winks while he's watching from the wings. As in any workplace, people crowd around and say "How sweet!", but they've got their jobs and they aren't going to be able to entertain your kid. If I'd been the stage manager, I might have been quite concerned because there are quite a lot of hazards backstage in a theatre.

At least it's one way children can see something of your life. But he didn't always like it - he scratched "BORING" in Biro deep into the wood on the desk in my dressing-room. Which was annoying, because it is a rather good piece of furniture I'd specially brought from home.

If you are stuck at work, the school-based sports activity days are a good bet. Our two boys always loved those. I remember my son doing a long stint of a sort of tennis-and-obstacle-course combination. He was raring to go at the beginning of each day. This year I've been waving the booking form at our 10-year-old for the past three weeks and he just goes "Uh" and won't choose any activities. I suspect it's because it's run at the school and so involves being bossed around. He'd rather hang out.

Having your mates round is another staple of half-term week. It was something I always did with my son's friends on the houseboat I had. It seems to be happening when they're much younger: I didn't sleep over at a friend's until I was 12 or 13. Now it's all the rage when you're six. You have to keep them occupied and talk them through it when they're younger, because children often get second thoughts when it's teeth-brushing and pyjamas and wee-wees - and suddenly they decide they need their mummy and want to go home. The trick is to keep them occupied right up to bedtime story. Once they've stayed over the first time, you can't keep them away.

Now, of course, we hardly see them. They disappear upstairs and we just hear the Crash Bandicoot playstation music. Frankie and I try to add up the time and hope it comes to less than two hours solid per day. We used to have a rule: no computers at getting-up time. But now we've got a baby it's not so easy to uphold that rule since it gets us off the hook in the mornings.

Really I'm quite old-fashioned: I think it's a pity that they aren't making assembly-kit models. But I do see with boys how they use computer games for a lot of the social stuff: building a team; congratulating each other; working out pecking-order (who's best at which bit); and co-operation (sharing the controls to get through) - all of which is good. Men always use games of any kind that way, to try and form themselves into a pack.

Half-term is just as much about growing-up as school-time is.

Nigel Planer and his wife, comedy writer and actor Frankie Park, write a weekly column for the website www.AllAboutParents.com.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Sixty per cent of girls aged 14 and 15 believe they are too fat, according to a recent survey. Can parents do anything to help?
fields.trailText: The Question: Sixty per cent of girls aged 14 and 15 believe they are too fat, according to a recent survey. Can parents do anything to help?
fields.body:
Andrew Hill Psychologist Leeds University

I've got two adolescent daughters, and I think as parents we've got to believe we can always do something to help our children. There's plenty of research about the link between maternal weight concerns and dieting among young people. I think it is important for parents not to be weight-obsessed themselves, because it is passing on a model of behaviour to their children. If parents can show their children by example that you can accept your shape and your body, it definitely takes the pressure off. Don't underestimate your influence: it does make a difference.
Verdict: Yes

John Balding Schools Health Education Unit

When you ask young people about the pressure to be slim, they talk about thin models and media images, but I don't think it's the whole story. I think peer pressure is the crucial element, and it's difficult to know what you can do about that. 0ur survey found that 18% of Year 10 girls aren't having anything for breakfast, and another 18% are only having a drink. Parents could try to encourage their teenagers to have breakfast. If family breakfasts are out, at least try to make sure your youngster gets some cereal or a piece of toast.
Verdict: Not a lot

Leslie Sinoway Features editor, Mizz magazine

It's too easily forgotten that worry over body-shape is a natural thing: at puberty your body changes, and you notice it and worry about it. We get sackfuls of mail from young girls worried about how they look. And we strive to do everything we can to bolster self-image: we encourage healthy eating and exercise; and although we obviously use models, we also feature lots of our readers in our photographs. I don't think parents can really help: when you're 13, the last people you want to listen to are your parents. Parents should give teenagers some space to sort themselves out.
Verdict: No

Deborah Mills Planner with an advertising agency

Many people lay the blame for poor self-image on advertising, but I think that's unfair. The Spice Girls were targeted at five and six year-olds, and what were they saying to them? I have children myself and I believe the message we give them as parents is vital. We need to reinforce that there's no right or wrong shape, and we also have to be aware of our own behaviour. As with so much of parenting, it's common sense: we don't want them to sit on the couch eating crisps all day, but we need to make clear that there's no need to be as thin as a rake either.
Verdict: Yes

Jill Wellbourne Eating Disorders Association

By the time they're teenagers, there isn't a lot you can do; it was ten or more years ago that you could have done something. What young children see around them is that adults get to choose whether to eat or not. When you're a child, you have to eat up what you're told to. So is it any wonder that when little children grow older, they want to eat less and skip meals? One way parents can help is by encouraging children to celebrate their bodies. You should encourage exercise and sport. If you believe in your body, you're more likely to enjoy the shape you are.
Verdict: Not a lot

webTitle: Parents: Helen Carter after her conviction for infanticide

fields.headline: 'It was just one shake'
fields.standfirst: A depressed, exhausted mother shook her crying baby. The baby died. Rachel Hargreaves talks to  Helen Carter after her conviction for infanticide
fields.trailText: A depressed, exhausted mother shook her crying baby. The baby died. Rachel Hargreaves talks to Helen Carter after her conviction for infanticide.
fields.body:
Like any proud parent, Rachel Hargreaves has framed photographs of her baby daughter dotted around her living room. Her favourite is in a large frame, showing the tiny newborn with dark hair and grey eyes, clutching a small white teddy bear. But, unlike other parents, Hargreaves has nothing left but pictures and memories.

Chelsea hardly stopped crying in the 15 weeks leading up to her death in April. One day, Hargreaves, who was alone at the time and suffering from post-natal depression, snapped. Unable to calm the baby, she picked her up and shook her. Chelsea died in hospital the following day.

Last week, Hargreaves, a trained nursery nurse, was given a three-year probation order by Leeds crown court after pleading guilty to infanticide. Expressing sympathy, the judge acknowledged her remorse.

Hargreaves, now 24, became pregnant after a brief relationship with the baby's father. He was not aware of the pregnancy and played no part in Chelsea's short life. Her waters broke five weeks early on December 28 last year and she was taken into Pinderfields hospital, Wakefield. The following day at 9.41pm she gave birth to Chelsea, who had problems breathing.

Although Hargreaves had just gained a diploma in childcare studies, she had more experience with toddlers and school-age children than with infants. "At first, Chelsea was the most perfect baby," recalls Hargreaves, "who never cried unless she wanted feeding. When she was awake, she was perfectly happy and contented and she didn't need to be picked up and held all the time."

All that changed when Chelsea was five-and-a-half weeks old. "She started screaming at dinnertime and she wouldn't stop," says Hargreaves. "She wouldn't take her feed and I tried changing her and cuddling her, but she wouldn't stop crying. It was a completely different cry to what I had heard before - it was like she was in pain."

Hargreaves is smartly dressed in a grey roll-neck jumper and black trousers. Though frank and articulate, she seems nervous about discussing what happened to her baby. She is painfully thin. Despite her freckles and long chestnut hair, she looks older than her 24 years.

"I went and talked to the health visitor and she said it might be colic. So we tried different colic drops, none of which worked. We laid her on her tummy, but that didn't work - and the crying just seemed to get worse and worse. She continued to refuse her feeds and her weight gain started to drop."

Hargreaves became exhausted and frustrated: the worst feeling was uselessness at not being able to settle her baby. Chelsea cried incessantly. At most, Hargreaves was getting a couple of hours of sleep at night and during the day.

Hargreaves attended a baby clinic every week with Chelsea and talked about her concerns. A health visitor suggested the baby might be allergic to cow's milk, so she switched to soya milk. It worked for a few days, but Chelsea soon became irritable again. The health visitor suggested aromatherapy massage and swaddling, which made Chelsea feel secure for a few minutes, but didn't last.

Hargreaves is not particularly close to her parents but used to meet her mother once a week in Wakefield. Her parents bought things for Chelsea and her mother knitted for her. "I am a person who tries to cope - that is the way I have been brought up. It is very difficult to pick up the phone when you are trying to soothe your own baby."

But Hargreaves was not coping. She was prescribed anti-depressants by her general practitioner. "I felt I was in a deep hole and couldn't get out. It all felt as if it was never-ending. I remember my health visitor saying there would be an end one day when she gets older, but I couldn't believe it," she says.

Chelsea was admitted to hospital for observation in March because of her incessant crying. "By this point I was really down and felt really alone," says Hargreaves. "The hospital staff said they thought her inability to settle was down to my anxiety. When I needed help, they were telling me my illness was causing her crying."

On April 12, the day she shook Chelsea, she had been to the baby clinic and spoken to her health visitor. The baby had been crying constantly all the day. "I had hit rock bottom. I asked the health visitor if adoption agencies were listed in the Yellow Pages because I couldn't cope any more. I think she tried to brush it off really."

They went home and the baby was still crying. They were sat together on the sofa and Hargreaves was holding Chelsea with her knees drawn up, resting the baby on her stomach. "I just picked her up not knowing what I was going to do," she says, her face wet with tears. "I said to her 'God Chelsea, I don't know what to do to make you happy. Please stop it, I can't do anything.'

"It was just one shake that I remember and it wasn't even very hard or violent. It was more out of frustration than anything. It didn't stop the crying and afterwards I felt really bad about it and immediately gave her a big hug. She seemed to be OK and then I went to change her nappy and laid her on her changing mat and she stopped breathing.

"I picked her up, thinking she must be choking. Her eyes rolled back into her head and she had gone stiff. She was making a choking and gasping noise. I just picked up the phone and called an ambulance. At the time I was panicking because my baby was not breathing. I didn't really link it with me shaking her. I tried to give her mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. I was in the worst panic you could imagine."

Chelsea was transferred from Pinderfields hospital to Leeds general hospital. Questioned by the medical staff, Hargreaves was too scared to say she had shaken Chelsea and instead said she had suddenly developed breathing difficulties. "I didn't want it to be my fault," she says. "The fact that I had caused my baby's death was too much for me to cope with. I was in a complete state of shock. I just wanted them to say it was something else. She was on a life support machine that night and I just wanted a miracle to happen so that everything would be OK, although I had been told right from the beginning that there was no chance for her.

"She was in a cot with wires attached to every part of her body and I just touched her cheek, talked to her and held her hand."

The next day Hargreaves was questioned by police, but didn't mention shaking Chelsea. Three months after the baby's death, the results of the autopsy were released. They revealed that the baby had been shaken. The police contacted her again. "That was when it hit me that it was my fault, that I had caused her death," she says. "It was very difficult to admit what I had done, but I told my solicitor, then I confessed to the police."

After being charged with infanticide, Hargreaves's depression worsened and her medication was increased. She became too anxious to leave the house and mostly stayed in bed. "I wanted to die as well as Chelsea," she says.

On July 10, the evening of her daughter's funeral, she took an overdose of her prescription tablets. As a result, she spent 12 days being treated in a psychiatric unit.

Hargreaves says she doesn't know how she is going to rebuild her life. Her career is destroyed - she can no longer work in childcare, the only career she ever wanted. She eventually wants more children, but accepts she will be closely supervised. "I want children in the future, but it is something that also scares me," she says. "I absolutely wish that all the support I have now was there before - but it is too late now." Hargreaves has a psychiatrist, a community psychiatric nurse, a social worker and a probation worker working with her.

Gwen Adshead, a forensic psychotherapist at Broadmoor hospital, says: "Thousands of women suffer from post-natal depression, but they don't all go on to kill their babies. But children who are premature are more at risk because it often makes them irritable and they may cry more.

"For the first four to six weeks it can be dreadful, with no sleep and the loss of social structures. We have to take the process of being a parent more seriously because it is not always going to be joyful and a treat - it is a proper job and should be treated as such."

This is cold comfort for Hargreaves, who smiles only when she looks at photographs of her daughter. "I still think about Chelsea all the time," she says. "I dream about her and sometimes I wake up and forget that she is dead. I think she is still in her moses basket and open my eyes and she is not there."
fields.bodyText: Like any proud parent, Rachel Hargreaves has framed photographs of her baby daughter dotted around her living room. Her favourite is in a large frame, showing the tiny newborn with dark hair and grey eyes, clutching a small white teddy bear. But, unlike other parents, Hargreaves has nothing left but pictures and memories. Chelsea hardly stopped crying in the 15 weeks leading up to her death in April. One day, Hargreaves, who was alone at the time and suffering from post-natal depression, snapped. Unable to calm the baby, she picked her up and shook her. Chelsea died in hospital the following day. Last week, Hargreaves, a trained nursery nurse, was given a three-year probation order by Leeds crown court after pleading guilty to infanticide. Expressing sympathy, the judge acknowledged her remorse. Hargreaves, now 24, became pregnant after a brief relationship with the baby's father. He was not aware of the pregnancy and played no part in Chelsea's short life. Her waters broke five weeks early on December 28 last year and she was taken into Pinderfields hospital, Wakefield. The following day at 9.41pm she gave birth to Chelsea, who had problems breathing. Although Hargreaves had just gained a diploma in childcare studies, she had more experience with toddlers and school-age children than with infants. "At first, Chelsea was the most perfect baby," recalls Hargreaves, "who never cried unless she wanted feeding. When she was awake, she was perfectly happy and contented and she didn't need to be picked up and held all the time." All that changed when Chelsea was five-and-a-half weeks old. "She started screaming at dinnertime and she wouldn't stop," says Hargreaves. "She wouldn't take her feed and I tried changing her and cuddling her, but she wouldn't stop crying. It was a completely different cry to what I had heard before - it was like she was in pain." Hargreaves is smartly dressed in a grey roll-neck jumper and black trousers. Though frank and articulate, she seems nervous about discussing what happened to her baby. She is painfully thin. Despite her freckles and long chestnut hair, she looks older than her 24 years. "I went and talked to the health visitor and she said it might be colic. So we tried different colic drops, none of which worked. We laid her on her tummy, but that didn't work - and the crying just seemed to get worse and worse. She continued to refuse her feeds and her weight gain started to drop." Hargreaves became exhausted and frustrated: the worst feeling was uselessness at not being able to settle her baby. Chelsea cried incessantly. At most, Hargreaves was getting a couple of hours of sleep at night and during the day. Hargreaves attended a baby clinic every week with Chelsea and talked about her concerns. A health visitor suggested the baby might be allergic to cow's milk, so she switched to soya milk. It worked for a few days, but Chelsea soon became irritable again. The health visitor suggested aromatherapy massage and swaddling, which made Chelsea feel secure for a few minutes, but didn't last. Hargreaves is not particularly close to her parents but used to meet her mother once a week in Wakefield. Her parents bought things for Chelsea and her mother knitted for her. "I am a person who tries to cope - that is the way I have been brought up. It is very difficult to pick up the phone when you are trying to soothe your own baby." But Hargreaves was not coping. She was prescribed anti-depressants by her general practitioner. "I felt I was in a deep hole and couldn't get out. It all felt as if it was never-ending. I remember my health visitor saying there would be an end one day when she gets older, but I couldn't believe it," she says. Chelsea was admitted to hospital for observation in March because of her incessant crying. "By this point I was really down and felt really alone," says Hargreaves. "The hospital staff said they thought her inability to settle was down to my anxiety. When I needed help, they were telling me my illness was causing her crying." On April 12, the day she shook Chelsea, she had been to the baby clinic and spoken to her health visitor. The baby had been crying constantly all the day. "I had hit rock bottom. I asked the health visitor if adoption agencies were listed in the Yellow Pages because I couldn't cope any more. I think she tried to brush it off really." They went home and the baby was still crying. They were sat together on the sofa and Hargreaves was holding Chelsea with her knees drawn up, resting the baby on her stomach. "I just picked her up not knowing what I was going to do," she says, her face wet with tears. "I said to her 'God Chelsea, I don't know what to do to make you happy. Please stop it, I can't do anything.' "It was just one shake that I remember and it wasn't even very hard or violent. It was more out of frustration than anything. It didn't stop the crying and afterwards I felt really bad about it and immediately gave her a big hug. She seemed to be OK and then I went to change her nappy and laid her on her changing mat and she stopped breathing. "I picked her up, thinking she must be choking. Her eyes rolled back into her head and she had gone stiff. She was making a choking and gasping noise. I just picked up the phone and called an ambulance. At the time I was panicking because my baby was not breathing. I didn't really link it with me shaking her. I tried to give her mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. I was in the worst panic you could imagine." Chelsea was transferred from Pinderfields hospital to Leeds general hospital. Questioned by the medical staff, Hargreaves was too scared to say she had shaken Chelsea and instead said she had suddenly developed breathing difficulties. "I didn't want it to be my fault," she says. "The fact that I had caused my baby's death was too much for me to cope with. I was in a complete state of shock. I just wanted them to say it was something else. She was on a life support machine that night and I just wanted a miracle to happen so that everything would be OK, although I had been told right from the beginning that there was no chance for her. "She was in a cot with wires attached to every part of her body and I just touched her cheek, talked to her and held her hand." The next day Hargreaves was questioned by police, but didn't mention shaking Chelsea. Three months after the baby's death, the results of the autopsy were released. They revealed that the baby had been shaken. The police contacted her again. "That was when it hit me that it was my fault, that I had caused her death," she says. "It was very difficult to admit what I had done, but I told my solicitor, then I confessed to the police." After being charged with infanticide, Hargreaves's depression worsened and her medication was increased. She became too anxious to leave the house and mostly stayed in bed. "I wanted to die as well as Chelsea," she says. On July 10, the evening of her daughter's funeral, she took an overdose of her prescription tablets. As a result, she spent 12 days being treated in a psychiatric unit. Hargreaves says she doesn't know how she is going to rebuild her life. Her career is destroyed - she can no longer work in childcare, the only career she ever wanted. She eventually wants more children, but accepts she will be closely supervised. "I want children in the future, but it is something that also scares me," she says. "I absolutely wish that all the support I have now was there before - but it is too late now." Hargreaves has a psychiatrist, a community psychiatric nurse, a social worker and a probation worker working with her. Gwen Adshead, a forensic psychotherapist at Broadmoor hospital, says: "Thousands of women suffer from post-natal depression, but they don't all go on to kill their babies. But children who are premature are more at risk because it often makes them irritable and they may cry more. "For the first four to six weeks it can be dreadful, with no sleep and the loss of social structures. We have to take the process of being a parent more seriously because it is not always going to be joyful and a treat - it is a proper job and should be treated as such." This is cold comfort for Hargreaves, who smiles only when she looks at photographs of her daughter. "I still think about Chelsea all the time," she says. "I dream about her and sometimes I wake up and forget that she is dead. I think she is still in her moses basket and open my eyes and she is not there."

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: Theme parks
fields.trailText: Theme parks
fields.body:
October half-term can be a bit dim and dismal - why not brighten it up with a trip to a theme park? They may be cheesy and over-hyped and you can have anything to eat so long as it's a burger but the bottom line on theme parks is that kids love them. Which is why most of us are just about willing to give up a wodge of tenners and an outing to a museum for a day of thrills and queues, rollercoasters and traffic jams, crowds and candy floss. Play your cards right, and you can even pull off Hallowe'en and bonfire night in one fell swoop - many theme parks are offering tricks, treats and fireworks for usual entry price or less next week.

For hard-pressed dads who don't see enough of the children, opportunity knocks: Fathers Direct is running its first Fathers Go Free day on Monday at theme parks and attractions around the country (find out more at www.fathersdirect.com ). For other ideas of where to go and what to do at half-term, try the new what's on for kids website at www.wizziwiz.co.uk.

Alton Towers

What is it? At 20, one of Britain's oldest theme parks.

Where is it? Alton, Staffs.

Why should I go? Because you can't resist a white-knuckle ride. Try Oblivion, the world-first vertical drop rollercoaster.

Anything special for half-term? Firework and laser show on October 21, 22, 27, 28 and 29. Hallowe'en events including a witches' show on ice.

Special offers? Check the website before you book.

Best age range: Lots for teens, but good for toddlers too.

What the kids thought: "I can't wait to go back again, it was wicked!"

What the parents thought: "It was clean and modern - less tacky than others we've been to."

Rating: 8/10.

Further info: 01538 703344 or www.alton-towers.com.

Thorpe Park

What is it? Water theme park which shot to fame when Diana, Princess of Wales took William and Harry.

Where is it? Between Staines and Chertsey in Surrey, off the M25.

Why should I go? For the new Tidal Wave ride, which plunges 85ft.

Anything special for half-term? On October 21, 22, 28 and 29 there's a fireworks, laser and stunt show.

Special offers? See website for buy-one-get-one-free offer.

Best age range: Eight to 14s .

What the kids thought: "Take a spare pair of jeans. Mine got drenched."

What the parents thought: "Take your own macs or capes: they charge £3.50 for adults and £2.50 for kids."

Rating: 7/10.

Further info: 0870 4444466 or www.thorpepark.com.

Legoland

What is it? Theme park based on Lego.

Where is it? Near Windsor, Berks.

Why should I go? If you have primary school kids, this is for you.

Anything special for half-term? A carnival of lights and music is promised, with a firework display at the end of the evening.

Special offers? None.

Best age range: Under 10s.

What the kids thought: "Best bits were Castleland and Harbourside."

What the parents thought: "A bit more upmarket than the others - you can even get quite decent pasta and salads. Loads for little ones."

Rating: 9/10.

Further info: 01753 626111 or www.legoland.co.uk.

Lightwater Valley

What is it? Theme park surrounded by countryside.

Where is it? Near Ripon, N Yorks.

Why should I go? Because you love rollercoasters: this park claims to have the longest one in the world - The Ultimate, 1.4 miles - as well as Britain's only underground rollercoaster, the delightfully named Sewer Rat.

Anything special for half-term? Fireworks on October 21 and 28.

Special offers? Evening entry from 4pm on fireworks night at £3 advance or £3.50 on the day.

Best age range: Over 10s.

What the kids thought: "Brilliant dodgems."

What the parents thought: "Not enough whole-family rides, but the shopping complex is good."

Rating: 6/10.

Further info: 01765 635368 or www.lightwatervalley.co.uk.

Disneyland Paris

What is it? Europe's ultimate theme park.

Why should I go? You'll have to go sometime, so it might as well be now.

Anything special for half-term? For October, Frontierland has been Hallowe'en Land. The evening parade is a ghoulish delight with a procession of witches, skeletons, bats and scary music.

Special offers? The Bella Notte package has a night in a hotel plus breakfast and two days' entry to the park. It starts at FF690 (£69) for adults and FF335 (£35) for kids.

Best age range: Five-plus.

What the kids thought: "One of the best days of my life."

What the parents thought: "Get there at opening time and go straight to the popular rides."

Rating: 9/10.

Further info: 08705 030303 or www.disney.co.uk.

The Dome

What is it? You cannot be serious.

Where is it? Greenwich, London.

Why should I go? It's (almost) the last chance to see it. You never know, you might love it.

Anything special for half-term? A screaming competition, ghosts and ghouls, bat-making workshops.

Any special offers? Half-price entry to Tesco Clubcard holders in October (call 0870 2411702). Otherwise, the ticket helpline is 0870 6062000.

Best age range: Something for all.

What the kids thought: "The best bit was seeing it from the outside."

What the parents thought: "Too exhausting to do it all in a day. Choose the zones you think your kids will enjoy and miss the rest out."

Overall rating: 7/10.

Further info: www.dome2000.co.uk.
