fields.headline: Your Granny in heaven
fields.standfirst: When his mother died,  Peter Stanford  decided that he must keep her memory alive for his little boy, Kit
fields.trailText: When his mother died, Peter Stanford decided that he must keep her memory alive for his little boy, Kit.
fields.body:
Kit and I are in the swimming pool. Kit has just been awarded his five metres badge from Terry the Tiger and is splashing away like a demented sea horse. I am crying. It's a good place to cry, a public swimming pool. Oddly private - with all that water, chlorine and condensation to explain away the tears, no one looks at you askance. Not even my three-year-old son. Anyway, he's seen me cry before. He knows I'm thinking of Granny.

My mother was a championship swimmer in her youth - I still have her medals. A grandson who is a water baby would have made my mother so happy, and if I look up from the pool I swear I can see her sitting there watching us and smiling.

But the fact is, she isn't there. As Kit unabashedly tells anyone who asks: "Granny is with Jesus in heaven." When recently he lost his grip on his balloon at Legoland, he watched it floating ever upwards and found some comfort in the thought: "It's a present for Granny."

My mother died of cancer at the age of 77. It was just before Kit's second birthday, and I beat myself up with the thought that I should have taken Kit to see her more often to forge a stronger bond between them. Yet even if I had, I'm not sure if it would have imprinted something substantial on his memory. In adult life a two-year relationship with another can be pivotal - books have been written about a week spent with Marilyn Monroe - but the two years at the start of your life register later as if blank.

But if they are as nothing to Kit, the time they did spend together was special to my mother. Latterly, she spent quite a lot of each day resting in bed. If we were staying overnight, Kit would wander in to see her as soon as he got up. I would appear much later and find him chuntering away to her. She would be smiling, and for a moment it was hard to believe that she wasn't in tip-top health.

It was only on the night she died, as we all sat in the room next door and my sister took out the family photo album, that I realised what my mother must have been thinking on those glorious early mornings. For Kit looks like a carbon copy of me at the same age and I had been her baby, the afterthought who came along a decade later than after my siblings, the child into whom she channelled all her frustrated energy as multiple sclerosis slowly but inevitably reduced her world before cancer shut it down.

How, now, do I explain all of that to Kit? How do I help him to know it as his own? Yes, he knows about heaven and dutifully lights a candle for Granny when we go to Mass, but he doesn't know about death. He was, we thought, too young to attend her funeral - although a psychotherapist friend now tells me that was a mistake; that children, however small, have to be confronted with the evidence of loss before they can comprehend it. (I'm not convinced.)

Kit knows that Granny couldn't walk and that she used a wheelchair, but he knows nothing of pain and disability. And he knows that he loves his own mummy to distraction, but struggles with the idea that his daddy was ever a little boy, let alone one who loved his mummy with a similar passion. So how do I explain about Granny? Should I even try?

The second question is easier. Being a child of parents who were both in their forties when I was born, I never knew my own grandparents. Both my grandfathers died years before I was born and my grandmothers, who died when I was still at primary school, are dim memories. I could write down most of what I know about them on the back of a raffle ticket.

I don't want it to be that way with Kit. I want him to have a sense of his place in the cycle of generations, so that when I am no longer here he does not feel as alone as I do now. I know, of course, that Kit will know his Granny through me. If I am what she made me, then he will benefit - or not - from that. The trouble is, that feels like a poor substitute. And so I struggle to make her someone we talk about often and happily, a real, flesh-and-blood person, someone who is still a part of our family, albeit from her lofty perch on high.

So, in the swimming pool, I remind him of how good she was at swimming and later I show him pictures of her in her bathing costume on some windswept English beach in the middle of March. And as I do so, I experience this almost unbearable physical ache that makes me want to cry out in pain. Perhaps that was why my own parents were so silent for so long about my grandparents. They couldn't bear to talk about them.

Yet there is the problem. My desire to plant in my son a rounded memory of his Granny can often be at odds with my own still raw grief. The result for Kit is, I hate to admit, that he now associates his Granny with sadness - sadness that she couldn't walk, sadness that she had to stop swimming, sadness that she has gone to live with Jesus, sadness that she makes Daddy so sad.

I recently decided to take Kit to see his Granny. Visiting is a concept he understands in terms of everyone else in his life, so why not her? We went to her grave. I told him it was a special place where people could go to be close to Granny. I made no mention of corpses and burial or anything like that. When we got there I asked him as casually as I could what he remembered about her, which was very little, so then we sat on the grass and I told him some stories about her. And I promise I didn't cry, but at the end, quite unprompted, he got up, walked over and solemnly hugged her tombstone as if he were hugging her.

webTitle: Women sent in to fight for swing vote on abortion

fields.headline: Women sent in to fight for swing vote on abortion
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Republicans have sent Barbara Bush into battle this week to try to win the women's vote which has consistently leaned towards the Democrats' contender for the presidency, Al Gore.
fields.body:
The Republicans have sent Barbara Bush into battle this week to try to win the women's vote which has consistently leaned towards the Democrats' contender for the presidency, Al Gore.

But what the offensive by the former US first lady will not address openly is the key reason that female floating voters have gone Mr Gore's way: abortion rights.

When the US vice-president announced at the Democratic convention in Los Angeles in August that he supported a woman's right to choose, he got one of the noisiest standing ovations of the week. It was an indication of the impact the abortion question can have on how women vote.

The licensing last month by the Food and Drug Administration of the RU-286 abortion pill has brought the issue to the forefront of the presidential race.

Mr Gore used the FDA decision to proclaim his support for abortion rights. Barbara Bush's son, the Republican contender George W Bush, used the occasion to say that his aim was to make abortion "more rare" in the US.

This week's Republican offensive also sees Laura Bush, the candidate's wife, and Cindy McCain, wife of his former rival for the Republican nomination, John McCain, pressed into service.

Abortion is as controversial as ever in the US where 1.3m terminations are carried out annually, but where 86% of all counties lack abortion facilities. Several doctors who carry out abortions have been murdered by pro-life activists in past years. Others have been threatened and their families harassed. Two weeks ago, a priest in Illinois drove a car into an abortion clinic and attacked the building with an axe.

When the film Cider House Rules, featuring Michael Caine as an abortion doctor, won an Oscar for its author, John Irving, for best adapted screenplay this year, Mr Irving dedicated his prize to pro-choice groups, angering the anti-abortion movement.

At the heart of the issue in terms of this election is the 1973 Roe v Wade supreme court decision which ruled that a woman's constitutional right to privacy gave her the right to choose an abortion.

Pro-abortionists fear that a supreme court packed with the conservative judges Mr Bush favours would reverse decisions on abortion and return the country to a situation where terminations were illegal. Bruce Shapiro, a journalist of the Nation magazine and a former director of a monitoring group, Supreme Court Watch, described abortion as "probably the single largest issue pulling the swing vote".

Mr Gore has now firmly declared his support for the right to choose although this has not always been his position.

In 1984, he wrote to a student saying that "it is my deep personal conviction that abortion is wrong" and in 1977 he voted to ban federal funds for abortions for poor women unless the woman's life was in danger.

His running mate, Joe Lieberman, has not always been wholehearted in support of abortion either, but both have become born-again pro-choice advocates for the election.

Mr Bush, in contrast, has said he will "do everything in my power" to restrict abortion. He is opposed to all abortion except in cases of rape, incest and danger to the health of the mother.

He also appears to have shifted his views over the years. He was reported in the Lubbock, Texas Avalanche-Journal in 1973 as saying that, while he was personally against abortion, he believed the matter should be left to the woman and her doctor. His team now denies this report.

"Governor Bush realises this is a controversial issue," said spokeswoman Mindy Tucker yesterday. "But he wants to bring people together on what we can agree on: reducing abortions in America."

The major pro- and anti-organisations have both put big money into the race. The National Abortion and Reproductive Rights League (Naral) said yesterday it would be spending $5m (£3m) to help Mr Gore.

fields.headline: The Hatfield train crash
fields.standfirst: The train derailment near Hatfield has left people speculating over the possible cause and the implications for the safety of Britain's railways. Simon Jeffery examines the issue
fields.trailText: The train derailment near Hatfield has left people speculating over the possible cause and the implications for the safety of Britain's railways. We examine the issue.
fields.body:
Southall, Clapham, Ladbroke Grove and now Hatfield. Why are there so many train accidents?
Yesterday's derailment near Hatfield, Hertforshire, was the latest in a series of fatal rail accidents stretching back over 12 years. Unlike the previous three, however, the London to Leeds intercity did not collide with another train but simply came off the rails. Until the investigation is complete we will not know why.

Who carries out the investigation?
The government's health and safety executive will examine the wreckage with the railways inspectorate and around 60 to 70 officers from the British Transport Police. The investigators are all specialists and this time last year many would have been working at Ladbroke Grove. They will be looking for anything out of the ordinary that would cause the intercity to derail. Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, has said he wants answers quickly.

What are the likely causes?
Vandalism and terrorism have been ruled out so the investigators will be looking for faults on the track or train. Preliminary investigations have revealed that a rail was smashed and, if it was damaged before the accident, that would have been enough to derail the train. But until forensic tests are complete we will not know when the track was smashed. If it was damaged during the accident, the investigators will then look for faults on the rolling stock's wheels and axles.

Are the railways safe?
Thirty-five people died at Clapham, seven at Southall and 31 at Ladbroke Grove. Four died at Hatfield and, in total, 94 people have died on the railways since 1988 in accidents including those already mentioned and others at places such as Purley, Glasgow and Stafford.

What do the train operators say?
Christopher Garnett, the GNER chief executive, says the railways are safe: "There is a perception that rail travel is unsafe, but when you look at the statistics it is an incredibly safe way of travel," he said today. Train travel may be statistically safer than making a journey by car but that does not mean it is safe, or as safe as it could be. The Southall inquiry recommended automatic train protection (ATP) for the rail network to stops trains passing red signals at danger and crashing into each other. The Ladbroke Grove inquiry is not complete but many believe that accident, which happened on the same stretch of track, would have been avoided if ATP had been installed, as it is in much of the European Union.

Will it be installed?
Successive governments and the rail industry have dragged their heels for so long that the ATP equipment they were expected to fit a decade ago is now out of date. Railtrack is now pressing ahead with a project to install the non-computerised, and inferior, train protection warning system (TPWS) but, on the other hand, plans to fit the superior European train control system (ETCS) on the west coast line between London, the Midlands and Glasgow by 2005. However, with no firm plans beyond that date it is likely to be at least a decade before Britain has a decent high speed rail network with automatic safety systems. Is it fair to say the privatised rail companies are more interested in profit than safety?
The rail companies say that the number of accidents in recent years has nothing to do with privatisation. Some disagree: Vernon Hince, of the RMT rail union, said today that there is widespread concern that the privatised operators are not observing safety procedures. Whatever the answer, the last government cut the money given to British Rail as it prepared it for privatisation (to make it attractive for investors, for which read cheap.) If the recent accidents are due to a lack of investment, it goes back a lot further than the four years that Railtrack and the private operators have been in control.

Is the network in a bad state?
There were 949 broken rails last year, up from 656 in 1995. In August the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, said he was unhappy with Railtrack's failure to make "an appreciable reduction" in the number of broken rails. Railtrack makes £1.3m profit a day looking after the 20,000 miles of lines, signals and stations that make up its network. What steps is Railtrack taking?
The speed limits of trains across the country have been cut until the cause of yesterday's disaster is clear. This does not mean that train was going too fast - it is a precaution to take the stress of what may be faulty rails or rolling stock. A train that normally travels at 100 mph will now be restricted to 65 mph.

What if it is Railtrack's fault?
Gerald Corbett, the company's chief executive, has tendered his resignation and Railtrack's board meets tonight to decide whether to accept it. He bore the brunt of much of the criticism in the wake of the Paddington disaster and today expressed regret for Hatfield. "I, personally, am distraught that another tragedy has occurred on our railways," he said. If Railtrack were found responsible it would have enormous repercussions for the company and the future of rail travel in the UK.

Could the rail companies be charged with corporate manslaughter?
The current law states that charges of corporate manslaughter can be brought against named individuals in companies only if the prosecution can prove they have "controlling" responsibility. That has led to executives escaping charges in a string of high-profile disasters ranging from the King's Cross tube station fire that killed 31 people in 1987 to last year's Paddington rail crash. New proposals are being introduced to make it easier to prosecute company bosses but they will come too late for Hatfield.

webTitle: Premiership will have to slash price

fields.headline: Premiership will have to slash price
fields.standfirst: NTL pulls out of PPV soccer deal
fields.trailText: 3.45pm update: The collapse of the NTL soccer deal will cost each Premier League club £3m in profit, according to one analyst, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The collapse of the NTL pay-per-view soccer deal will cost each Premier League club at least £3m in profit, according to one football analyst.

William Davies said that clubs will be demanding answers from the Premier League, whose lawyers should have ensured the deal was watertight before it was accepted.

He said: "Everyone was surprised with the amount of money NTL paid in the first place. It was felt that the only reason NTL could justify the price was to write it off as a marketing task. They hoped they could lure customers into their network of services and flog them telephony and internet access."

ONdigital and BSkyB - which was originally prohibited from bidding for PPV in addition to live rights - are now the only two broadcasters expected to look at PPV rights. But Mr Davies said the Premier League will have to slash its asking price by up to 70 per cent.

A spokesman for OnDigital, which is owned by Granada and Carlton Communications, said: "We have seen the reports but we have nothing to say."

ONdigital also screened England's World Cup qualifier against Finland on its PPV channel, OnRequest. It refused to divulge how many people signed up for the match, but said three-quarters of viewers were subscribing to OnRequest for the first time.

fields.headline: NTL pulls out of PPV soccer deal
fields.standfirst: Premiership will have to slash price
fields.trailText: 2pm update: The Premier League is seeking a new broadcasting partner to launch live pay-per-view football next season, following NTL's shock withdrawal from negotiations today.
fields.body:
The Premier League is seeking a new broadcasting partner to launch live pay-per-view football next season, following NTL's shock withdrawal from negotiations today.

The US-owned cable operator has been unable to agree final terms with the Premier League for the UK PPV football deal and announced today that negotiations had ceased.

NTL secured the Premier League PPV rights in June with a £327m three-year deal for 40 live matches per year. BSkyB paid £1.1bn to retain the Premier League pay-TV rights, but was barred from bidding for PPV rights under the terms of the original rights auction.

Barclay Knapp, NTL's chief executive, said the company was unable to comment further on the surprise move to walk away from the PPV deal, under the terms of a confidentiality agreement signed with the Premier League.

Mr Knapp added: "Naturally we are very disappointed that we have not been able to complete negotiations under terms which both we and the Premier League found satisfactory."

It is not yet clear precisely why the contract remains unsigned and why the deal has fallen through.

However, after assessing the potential gains for the prohibitive price being paid for the package, it may be that NTL have decided they cannot make the contract pay.

Only last week, England's World Cup clash with Finland was shown on pay-per-view channel udirect.

Although the company are adamant that their viewing figures were in line with expectations, they refused to release the number of subscribers who actually signed up for the game.

Today's development is an embarrassment for Premier League chiefs, who are insistent that their product has a value way beyond even the current fees being paid for exclusive rights.

NTL have been active players in football recently, buying substantial stakes in a number of clubs, including Newcastle and Aston Villa.

The company also have a joint sponsorship deal with Scottish Premier League duo Celtic and Rangers.

fields.headline: Thousands pay tribute to Dewar
fields.trailText: The funeral of Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, took place today at Glasgow Cathedral.
fields.body:
The funeral of Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, took place today at Glasgow Cathedral.

The 12th-century building was filled to capacity by 1,300 of Mr Dewar's friends, colleagues and family, who gathered together to pay their final respects to the man described as the father of the nation.

The Rev Douglas Alexander, who conducted the service, was a longstanding friend of Mr Dewar and the father of Scottish communities minister Wendy Alexander, the first minister's protege, and Paisley South MP Douglas Alexander.

He paid tribute to Mr Dewar and spoke of his 50-year friendship with the first minister that began during their days at Glasgow University.

Another friend, the chancellor Gordon Brown, raised muted laughter with an anecdote from his friend's life.

"Though he has gone from us, let his cause endure," he concluded at the end of his oration.

Outside the cathedral, hundreds more mourners listened in silence as the service was broadcast in the nearby Barony Hall.

Many of Mr Dewar's friends and constituents watched the ceremony via a video link at Knightswood community centre in the first minister's Anniesland constituency.

And many more followed the service on television as it was broadcast live to the nation.

Others lined the streets of Glasgow to pay tribute to Mr Dewar, whose funeral cortege traveled through the city to a private family ceremony at Clydebank crematorium.

A single red rose lay on top of his coffin.

The mourners were led by Mr Dewar's two children, Ian and Marion, and his former wife Alison, who was with her husband the Lord Chancellor Lord Irvine.

The Prince of Wales, prime minister Tony Blair and many members of the Westminster cabinet were present.

The Scottish cabinet arrived at the cathedral led by acting first minister Jim Wallace.

Mr Blair read from the Old Testament.

Mr Dewar died from a brain haemorrhage last Wednesday at the age of 63. He had been taken to Edinburgh's western general hospital after falling outside his official resident in the capital Bute House the previous day.

The first minister had undergone major heart surgery in May to replace a leaking heart valve, which required him to take anticoagulant drugs to thin his blood, making him more susceptible to internal bleeding.

fields.headline: White out
fields.standfirst: Is there a crisis in black theatre in Britain? You bet. And it seems to be getting worse.
fields.trailText: Is there a crisis in black theatre in Britain? You bet. And it seems to be getting worse.
fields.body:
Nicolas Kent, who runs the Tricycle Theatre in north London, has done as much as anyone in British theatre to raise our consciousness of race issues. It was he who presented the most important play of last year - The Colour of Justice, a work that dealt with the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. So when I asked Kent whether British theatre is racist, whether there is a prejudice against black and Asian companies, whether our theatre fails to reflect the cultural diversity of modern Britain, I expected him to be critical. What I did not expect was a wholesale indictment of theatrical racism and a vigorous seminar on the subject.

We were talking in Kent's office 90 minutes before the Tricycle's curtain rose on an intriguing double bill. The plays were Alice Childress's Wine in the Wilderness - a 1969 black American play - and Winsome Pinnock's Water, a modern British response to it. When I asked Kent if there is a crisis in black theatre in Britain, he went off like a rocket.

"Absolutely," he said. "A total crisis. In the past two years alone a number of companies and events have disappeared: Carib, Temba, Double Edge, the Black Theatre Season, the Roundhouse Project. Along with the companies, the regular African-Caribbean audience is also dissolving. But I could go on and on listing the problems. The fact that there is no theatre building run by a black or Asian director, that there is no black children's company and that theatre staffs and boards are overwhelmingly white. If you read the Arts Council-commissioned Boyden Report into English Producing Theatres, you discover that only 16 out of 463 board members nationwide are black. Given that we at the Tricycle have eight of them, Stratford East five and Hampstead two, that must leave one black board member for the rest of the country."

But hasn't some progress has been made? The National Theatre and the Royal Shakespeare Company, for instance, actively pursue a policy of integrated casting that transcends mere tokenism. "That's welcome," says Kent. "But it's not the real issue any more than are the kind of cosmetic schemes dreamed up by the London Arts Board. We don't just need to be told that the RSC is to have a black Henry VI. What we need is enough money to support black companies to do black-generated work. I think we also need to confront our own racism on a personal and institutional level. The press and broadcasting media, for instance, have a built-in racism that is just as pervasive as anything you will find in the theatre."

All the facts support Kent's arguments about the British theatre. Once there were 18 revenue-funded black and Asian theatre companies, now there are two. All but 80 of the 2,009 staff permanently employed in English theatres are white. And with odd exceptions - such as a season of short plays called Ticket to Write produced by Paines Plough and West Yorkshire Playhouse - contemporary black and Asian experience goes largely unrecorded.

Yet within all this I discover a strange paradox. While Kent attends to pressing first-night matters, he asks three colleagues to add their perspectives. In defiance of economic logic and social fact, it is their overwhelming faith in the future that hits me between the eyes. Two of them, both Kent protegees, have the advantage of youth. Gemma Emmanuel-Waterton is a trainee administrator who radiates energy the moment she walks into a room. In July 2001 she will be running a black arts festival called Push, on the South Bank. If there is a crisis in black theatre, she thinks it's partly because young artists are drawn to the economic security of TV. "Racism," she says, "is my last port of call as an excuse."

Surian Fletcher-Jones, an Asian director, also finds she has acquired enough confidence and contacts at the Tricycle to launch herself into the freelance world. And actor Ray Shell, who spent four years in Starlight Express and who is writing a new musical, talks animatedly about the melting-pot mateyness he finds in his part of the east end. None of the three is complacent. Each desperately wants to raise black and Asian profile. But each has a fiery positiveness that counterpoints Kent's legitimate sense of crisis.

So too does the Tricycle's double bill. It puts to shame much of the gilded shit that currently passes for entertainment in the West End. Winsome Pinnock's Water is a fascinating two-hander about a young black painter, famed for the raw, blood-and-guts veracity of her work, who turns out under journalistic probing to be not quite what she seems. Like Welles's F for Fake, it deals with questionable notions of authenticity in art. Vigorously performed by Cecilia Noble and Gary McDonald, it also suggests that much overhyped Britart is a load of bull and that, in our celebrity-crazed culture, the hoaxer is the ultimate hero.

Whereas Pinnock's play is about the commercial value of artistic lies, Alice Childress's Wine in the Wilderness, originally written for American television, is about the moral value of personal truth. The setting is a Harlem studio at the time of the 1964, riots where a young artist is painting an iconic triptych exploring black womanhood. Youthful innocence and mythic nobility have been done. Now he needs an image of messed-up modernity and, to that end, is provided with a brash factory worker named Tomorrow whose flat has just been burned to the ground.

Essentially, this is a variation on the Pygmalion story. Instead of a statue that comes to life we have a funky Harlemite who persuades the painter that real beauty is to be found not in dead myths but in the rich variety of 1960s black America. Childress sometimes makes her points with the subtlety of a sledgehammer, but the play has a soaringly affirmative conclusion, reminiscent of Arnold Wesker's Roots, and yields a stunning central performance from Jenny Jules. A product of the Tricycle's Youth Theatre, she combines an attenuated frame with a spirit as big as Grand Central Station. In her mixture of ebullience and vulnerability, she knocks into several cocked hats the superannuated supermodels and celluloid idols who reduce some theatre critics to pulp. She not only crowns an intricately programmed and richly entertaining evening, but also embodies the perverse paradox of black theatre. On an institutional level, it is in deep crisis. We were talking in Kent's office 90 minutes before the Tricycle's curtain rose on an intriguing double bill. The plays were Alice Childress's Wine in the Wilderness - a 1969 black American play - and Winsome Pinnock's Water, a modern British response to it. Along with the companies, the regular African-Caribbean audience is also dissolving. But I could go on and on listing the problems. webTitle: Charity Award 2000: Phoenix Community Furniture Scheme

fields.headline: New life in the country
fields.standfirst: Phoenix Community Furniture Scheme
fields.trailText: Until five years ago, no charity in Powys had taken on the job of providing the household needs of people in rural mid-Wales who were on low incomes or receiving benefits
fields.body:
The scheme is simplicity itself; the needs it meets are staggering; running it is straightforward; the costs are not enormous. Yet until five years ago, no charity in Powys had taken on the job of providing the household needs of people in rural mid-Wales who were on low incomes or receiving benefits.

Such is the demand, however, that the Phoenix Community Furniture Scheme, based in Newtown, has had to move into larger premises on a small industrial estate to display its stock of everything from beds and blankets to washing machines and wardrobes - all donated by local people.

Only a second glance reveals that everything is second-hand. It has all been collected, checked and cleaned by Phoenix staff, and put on display for clients to select and take away - free, except for a small handling charge.

Almost 40 agencies from advice bureaux to social services refer the needy to Phoenix, to provide the basic domestic items that the tightening net of officialdom either appears to ignore or offers only loans for their purchase, thereby adding to the burdens of the poor while appearing to help them.

Celia Gardiner, the scheme's co-ordinator, has seen demand grow recently: not only through referrals from other agencies but also in terms of people with income just above benefit level who are asking Phoenix for assistance.

Powys is a patchwork of poverty. There are thriving farms and factories, but there is also low pay. "Ten thousand a year is regarded as a good salary round here," says Gardiner.

Pride about seeking help compounds the problem for some of the middle-aged and elderly. And the fact that "the consumer society came late to Wales", as Gardiner puts it, means that there is not a huge market in really good discarded furniture or white goods in working order. "There are still families with no fridge or freezer, and I know of homes with no electricity," she says.

On a typical day, half of Gardiner's calls are from people with items to get rid of - too many big sideboards and wardrobes, alas, and too many cookers and electrical goods that fail their safety tests - and half from unmarried mothers, care-in-the-community clients, ex-prisoners and the elderly, all lacking one, or many, bare necessities.

However, Phoenix has evolved into something more than an exchange between the over-furnished and the under-furnished. A range of skills is required to deal with the items and providing these has turned the charity into a small trainer and employer. As well as a driver, a volunteer part-time electrician, a carpentry supervisor and an administrator, Phoenix takes on young people under the New Deal programme and hopes to extend its carpentry section so that it can make new items out of old, unfashionable pieces.

There is also an environmental side to processing household clutter. "We're playing our part in recycling brown and white goods," says Gardiner. Thanks to Phoenix, the landfills of mid-Wales are not filling up quite so fast, as more people realise that their old dining table or television - providing it is still working - might have a further lease of life if given to somebody in need.

Phoenix started in a very small way, with a couple of advice bureau workers using a trailer to cart furniture around, but with no proper storage space. That came when a vicar offered a shed in the grounds of his church; the first permanent home was part of a disused factory in Newtown - really unsuitable, say Gardiner.

Last year, a substantial grant from the National Lottery Charities Board facilitated a move to the new, much bigger base - at a much higher rent. The Guardian award will allow Phoenix to go on with its expansion plans. More and more donors and clients are hearing about it all the time, says Gardiner. Word of mouth is still the way in rural Wales.

 Phoenix Community Furniture Scheme, Unit 2, Vastre Enterprise Park, Kerry Road, Newtown, Powys SY16 1DZ (01686-623336)

fields.headline: A problem shared
fields.standfirst: Place 2 Be
fields.trailText: Place 2 Be stepped into the breach at Albion primary school, to provide emotional and therapeutic support for children
fields.body:
At Albion primary school in Southwark, south London, teachers and pupils alike face a daily struggle against circumstance. Just eight dedicated teachers are responsible for 182 pupils, many from some of the most testing of backgrounds. About 59% of children receive free school meals (treble the national average) and for 49% English is a second language.

"For whatever reason, we have some needy pupils," says head teacher Penny White. Broken homes, bereavement, bullying, poverty and a myriad of other difficulties colour the lives of many of the children who trek each day to their school in sight of the southern approach to the Rotherhithe Tunnel. Such backgrounds present emotional challenges to the youngsters that even a totally dedicated staff - "They would work 6am to midnight if they could," says White - finds hard to meet.

A year ago, however, the Place 2 Be stepped into the breach at Albion. The charity was founded in 1993 to provide emotional and therapeutic support for children in schools. Last year, it was operating in 28 schools across six local authorities in the capital, and, in the coming 12 months, will roll out its first scheme outside London, in Nottingham.

The charity offers help for a wide range of emotional problems, from seemingly mundane matters such as arguments with friends, family or school authorities, to the most serious challenges a child can face - divorce, drugs, sexual abuse.

With staff at Albion stretched by the twin demands of the curriculum and Ofsted inspection - the school came off "special measures" at the end of last term - Place 2 Be offers a crucial crutch for children who would otherwise not have the benefit of independent adult advice.

"We offer emotional support to kids who need it," says Chris Forest, the Place 2 Be school project manager at Albion. "The focus is totally on emotional need, vital to a child who may have experienced serious problems at home or in school." This need can express itself in many different ways. "A teacher may notice that a child has become withdrawn and sad, or may be expressing anger in some way, being disruptive and generally unsettled."

If a teacher is aware of such problems, they refer the child to Place 2 Be, which has four volunteers at Albion two days a week. Parents are asked to approve the referral and the child is spoken to about what the scheme can offer. This conversation is, arguably, the most crucial one in the whole process, for no stigma must be attached to attending sessions with Place 2 Be that might put other pupils off attending sessions that range from art and play therapy to straightforward conversation. Remarkably, children who attend appear envied by their classmates. "It is made to seem an attractive proposition to the kids, and their friends want to come too," says Forest.

The key to Place 2 Be's success, she says, is the independence of the counsellors. "We're within the school but were not of the school. We're insiders who are somehow outside; we have a detachment from the authority figures that the children relate to. Many children don't have an independent adult to turn to, and we provide that."

So popular is Place 2 Be that the charity is introducing Place 2 Talk, an open-door service that operates in lunch hours. Children can drop in and talk without obligation to a counsellor. "Sometimes children just want to talk to an adult about something," says Forest.

White is convinced of the benefits. Place 2 Be operated at her previous school and she says that since it came to Albion, a year ago, there has been a positive effect. "All these things take time, but the children are more able to deal with conflicts as a result of Place 2 Be. The playground seems a lot calmer and the children realise that there are other ways of sorting things other than fists and shouting. It can help the socially isolated to become integrated and make those that lack confidence become a little more assertive where they need to be."

 Place 2 Be, Edinburgh House, 154-182 Kennington Lane, London SE11 4EZ (020-7820 6346)

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: The hole truth? | Ex-exotica | Good riddance
fields.body:
The hole truth?

The ozone hole has expanded to a record 17.1m square miles - larger than north America - says the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Climate Institute. Meanwhile, global warming is at last considered official. But is there any link between the two phenomena? Until recently, the hole was linked uniquely to emissions of a group of synthetic chemicals, mainly chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), that destroy ozone in the presence of sunlight. But a new theory is emerging, suggested by Dr Michael H. Proffitt, senior scientific officer at the World Meteorological Organisation in Geneva. It goes like this:

1. A build-up of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping industrial gases, while warming the lower atmosphere, may be acting in the opposite way in the stratosphere, causing it to radiate more heat to space and grow colder than it would otherwise be.

2. The loss of ozone itself may be causing stratospheric cooling. Without ozone, this layer of the atmosphere does not absorb the energy arriving from the sun as ultraviolet radiation, making the thin air even cooler.

3. The more cold high air there is, the more ice clouds there are; the more ice clouds, the more CFCs and other ozone-destroying chemicals can do their work.

4. In the latest ozone bulletin, Proffitt noted the average expanse of extremely cold stratospheric air from 1995-2000 has been double that seen in any other five-year period.

5. In short, global warming could be indirectly abetting the chemical reactions that destroy ozone.

Ex-exotica

Where do you buy snakes and exotic spiders? Until this week you could nip into any one of hundreds of Focus Do It All's DIY branches, buy one, then expect to see it die within the year. Focus has now stopped selling them but they seem loath to thank Animal Aid, whose members have been demonstrating outside the shops for nine months.

Good riddance

There's another side to the floods. Eco soundings was present when one man was fished out of a wrecked caravan park near Tonbridge, having lost everything. "How do you feel," gushed a TV reporter. The man beamed widely: "Absolutely terrific. I hated the place." He then realised he was on television and changed his tack: "No, I'm absolutely devastated. It's the end of my world."

fields.headline: Filling the sage gap
fields.standfirst: Beth Johnson Foundation
fields.trailText: The Beth Johnson Foundation helps build bridges between the younger and older generations
fields.body:
Doug Tipper used to be a miner and then he worked in the potteries. Now he is retired and in his second year as volunteer mentor with children at a school in Stoke-on-Trent. His work with the Beth Johnson Foundation, he says, helps build bridges between the younger and older generations.

"Children are very respectful and very interested in what the older generations get up to," says Tipper. "I am getting a lot out of it too - it has enabled me to become computer-literate and the teachers are very supportive of our work.

"I find the children have got the same aspirations as we had as youngsters. The biggest compliment I have had was when one young lad told me I was 'wicked' and 'cool'. I felt as if I was on the same wavelength."

The foundation, which started in Stoke in 1972, works within four main project areas: health promotion for older people; developing sustainable initiatives with the African-Caribbean community; advocacy for people with dementia; and inter-generational activities such as those involving mentors and schoolchildren. It also works on developing support services for older people in the local Polish community.

Overall, there are some 150 volunteers working directly for the foundation on a range of projects involving people aged over 50. Their inter-generational approach in schools is based on the belief that if young and old generations are brought together in positive ways, then barriers and misunderstandings between them disappear and relationships of trust and mutual respect develop.

When the mentoring project was set up five years ago, it involved one primary school and two secondary schools in Stoke. Currently, half a dozen schools are involved and next year it will be expanded to 10. Each school identifies children who may be at risk of failing and they are assigned to mentors for a year.

Doug Tipper says it is important to listen to the children, to be non-judgmental and not to criticise them or do their work for them. "A lot of the time when they are stuck, they don't want to ask the teacher for help. But they can ask us."

The young people involved are equally complimentary about their mentors. One student says: "My mentor is a gentle, quiet man with a low voice. He helps me with reading and writing and especially maths, which I hated. But now it's OK and I feel better about the work." Another says: "My mentor is my friend and I think that she is everyone's friend."

Anita Oxford is about to start her fourth year as a mentor. "Mentoring is all about making them think and resolve problems," she says. "My young mentee got all his sums wrong and I asked what he was going to do about it - he said he didn't know. If I had not been there, he probably wouldn't have pushed himself to work it out. But then he worked it out and he thanked me for it. That is what mentoring is all about - helping them resolve problems."

Lynn Purcell, mentoring project co-ordinator, says 18 of the 20 mentors who worked in schools last year have signed up for another year's work. "This success is a reflection of how much those people enjoyed mentoring."

The foundation - named after the wife of the local benefactor who set it up - plans to use the Guardian award as a springboard to get more funding for its projects. It also hopes to develop a project with the local youth justice team to look at intergenerational approaches to youth offending.

Alan Hatton-Yeo, the foundation's chief executive, says the charity's aim is to continue to challenge the stereotypical way that older people are seen within society. It seeks to achieve an inclusive approach, with equality of access and support for all citizens. "Older people are not a homogeneous group," adds Hatton-Yeo. "There are the young old, the old old and the frailer old - it is such a diverse community. Often, people over 50 do not see themselves as old."

 The Beth Johnson Foundation, Parkfield House, 64 Princess Road, Hartshill, Stoke-on-Trent ST4 7JL (01782-844036)

"Mentoring is all about making them think and resolve problems," she says. "My young mentee got all his sums wrong and I asked what he was going to do about it - he said he didn't know. If I had not been there, he probably wouldn't have pushed himself to work it out. But then he worked it out and he thanked me for it. That is what mentoring is all about - helping them resolve problems." Lynn Purcell, mentoring project co-ordinator, says 18 of the 20 mentors who worked in schools last year have signed up for another year's work. "This success is a reflection of how much those people enjoyed mentoring." The foundation - named after the wife of the local benefactor who set it up - plans to use the Guardian award as a springboard to get more funding for its projects. It also hopes to develop a project with the local youth justice team to look at intergenerational approaches to youth offending. Alan Hatton-Yeo, the foundation's chief executive, says the charity's aim is to continue to challenge the stereotypical way that older people are seen within society. It seeks to achieve an inclusive approach, with equality of access and support for all citizens. "Older people are not a homogeneous group," adds Hatton-Yeo. "There are the young old, the old old and the frailer old - it is such a diverse community. Often, people over 50 do not see themselves as old."  The Beth Johnson Foundation, Parkfield House, 64 Princess Road, Hartshill, Stoke-on-Trent ST4 7JL (01782-844036)

fields.headline: Book up - it's showtime
fields.standfirst: Shape Ticket Scheme
fields.trailText: 30,000 Londoners benefit each year from a scheme run by a disability arts organisation, to give disabled and older people access to the capital's cultural events
fields.body:
Londoner Frank Howling has had a packed social schedule this year - recitals at the Albert Hall, concerts at the Barbican, plays at the Royal National Theatre. Not that remarkable perhaps, except that Howling is a pensioner and visually impaired.

Howling is just one of more than 30,000 Londoners to benefit each year from a scheme run by Shape London, a disability arts organisation, to give disabled and older people access to the capital's cultural events through cheap tickets and user-friendly venues.

Set up more than 10 years ago, and core funded by London Borough Grants, the Shape Ticket Scheme works with 100 London arts venues and companies to provide its members with discounts of up to 50% off normal ticket prices for events like the opera, theatre, dance, cinema and museums. This year's programme ranges from Ralph Fiennes's Richard II to Kiri Te Kanawa.

Members must live in a London borough to participate in the scheme and are charged an annual fee of £10 for individuals and £20 for organisations, which currently include hospitals and self-help groups. In return, they receive a regular newsletter (also available on tape and in Braille for people with visual impairments) listing forthcoming events, and reductions on all tickets booked for themselves and friends or relatives accompanying them to events.

Many events are sign-interpreted or audio-described for people with hearing or visual impairments, while the free ticket booking service takes into account individual requirements such as the need for wheelchair access. Shape works with its partner venues to provide tickets at off-peak times, usually matinees or weekday evenings, as these are usually convenient both for members and venues.

Howling, who has just booked tickets for Romeo and Juliet at the National in December, is a lifelong fan of the arts ("except opera - I just couldn't get on with it") and says paying just £3 to hear the London Philharmonic has meant an enjoyable retirement. "As I'm a pensioner, I couldn't afford the high prices these places charge. I'd be bereft of culture without the scheme."

While Howling attends events with a friend, some members have nobody to accompany them, or find that public transport is inaccessible. The scheme's volunteer driver service addresses these problems, by matching volunteers owning their own transport with members wanting a lift to and from their chosen venue and some company during the event.

"Disabled and older people often face barriers to getting to mainstream arts events, not just to do with access but because they may be alone. The scheme helps to break down these barriers," says Julie Reynolds, ticket scheme manager.

About 100 volunteers participate in more than 1,000 trips a year. The volunteer's ticket and other expenses, such as petrol and car parking, are covered by Shape, which recruits them through volunteer bureaux across the capital and via local and national media.

Gloria Rees-Jones has been a volunteer driver for the past three years and says members are not alone in benefiting from the scheme. A former research psychologist, she says it offers her a chance to combine an interest in opera, theatre and ballet with voluntary work.

"It's very much a two-way thing, particularly as we're both going to something that we enjoy. People who can't usually go out, or who can't afford transport, are delighted that they can have access to these events, and we as volunteers go to a lot of things we couldn't afford to go to and make good friends at the same time," Rees-Jones says.

At present, the scheme has 1,500 individual and 200 group members, recruited through publications for older or disabled people, or social services departments across London. Members and volunteers meet every two months to discuss ways of improving the scheme and future developments. One priority is attracting more volunteers to meet increased demand for companion drivers. Another idea is to widen the scheme to other leisure activities, including attractions like Madame Tussaud's and Rock Circus.

Currently on the agenda is computerising the "labour-intensive" manual booking service - a task that Reynolds says will enable staff to spend more time on client care and on promoting the service to new potential users, particularly young disabled people. The prize money from the Guardian award will contribute to this, she says. "With 250,000 registered disabled people in London and 14% of the population of retirement age, we want to expand our service to meet the needs of a growing membership."

 Shape Ticket Scheme, LVS Resource Centre, 356 Holloway Road, London N7 6PA (020-7700 8138)

webTitle: How dementia blighted a brilliant nursing reputation

fields.headline: Victim of ignorance
fields.standfirst: How dementia blighted a brilliant nursing reputation
fields.trailText: How dementia blighted a brilliant nursing reputation
fields.body:
She was the most famous nurse of her era. She was years ahead of her time in her views on patient-focused care, nurse training and nursing management. Yet today she is little known. Is it because she developed Alzheimer's?

According to a new biography, the outstanding contribution of Dame Muriel Powell has not been adequately recognised because of the embarrassment of her last years in the profession, when she was increasingly unwell. Far from facing up to her predicament, the worlds of health and government - in which she moved at the most senior levels - sought to deny it or cover it up.

This was less than 30 years ago. And that the true story can emerge only now is testimony to how recently we have come to understand and accept the reality of Alzheimer's and of dementia in general.

Powell was matron and later chief nursing officer at St George's hospital, then in central London, for an astonishing 22 years. For six years after that, until her retirement, she was Scotland's chief nurse. But the contrast between those two stages of her career could scarcely have been more stark.

At St George's, in the words of biographer Elizabeth Scott, she rose to become "the undisputed leader of her profession". She knew how to use the media and was regularly in the press and on radio and television. Such was her profile that she was chosen to appear in the first television campaign against drink-driving.

Within the hospital, where she was appointed matron in 1947 at the age of 32, she pioneered a brand of nursing that brought the profession into the modern age. While by no means revolutionary - she told students: "A good nurse is someone who reads the Times editorial every day" - she was convinced of the need to humanise the hospital environment.

Until the 60s, it was unquestioned practice in hospitals to wake patients any time after 4.30am, but certainly by 6am, in order for the night nurses to bathe them and make their beds. Powell instructed that no patient be woken before 7am and would watch from her flat to check that no lights appeared on the wards until that time - even though it put a great strain on the nurses to get everything done before doctors started their ward rounds at 9am.

Powell was lively, confident and assertive. When she moved to Scotland, however, she appeared subdued, forgetful and increasingly prone to flashes of anger. In top level meetings, she failed to shine. "From having been an enthusiastic participant in all professional discussions, she became a shadowy, quiet presence who contributed little," says Scott. By 1974, four years after moving north, she was so distracted that elaborate arrangements were made to look after her when she attended meetings outside the Scottish Office. Yet nobody grasped the nettle. At one meeting in London, a medical officer accompanying her is said to have remarked in conversation: "Sadly, Dame Muriel is away with the fairies these days."

Powell's contract was even extended for two years beyond age 60. When she retired in 1976, says Scott, she left "under a pall of numbness and near silence".

Today, it seems extraordinary that such a decline was not acted upon by colleagues at the Scottish Office. But the biograpy, Muriel Powell Remembered, concludes: "Here was an eminent nurse who had a national and international status and reputation. She was, for want of a better word, their boss who appeared to be developing a mental illness. To have raised questions ... could have been seen as criticism."

Powell died in 1978, aged 64, in a psychiatric hospital in Gloucestershire, where she had retired. Some 800 people, including government ministers, attended a memorial service in London. A year later, an article in the Observer newspaper on "the sad, quiet epidemic", led to the setting up of what is now the Alzheimer's Society.

Harry Cayton, the society's chief executive, says greater awareness of the condition makes it unlikely that any comparable figure would today be treated the same way. But he fears the pendulum may have swung to the other extreme, with growing evidence of people with Alzheimer's being summarily sacked from their jobs.

"We recently had to fight for compensation to restore pension rights for somebody who had been dismissed as incompetent or neglectful. It later turned out to be Alzheimer's," says Cayton. "It's not uncommon to find that people who are getting Alzheimer's in their 50s and 60s are being treated quite badly."

 Muriel Powell Remembered is available at £12.50, plus £1.20 p&p, from the St George's Nurses League, c/o Chief Nurse's Office, Room 32, 1st Floor, Grosvenor Wing, St George's Hospital, London SW17 0QT

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.body:
Good for democracy

You report that chief executives are uneasy about their role under a system of elected mayors (Clash of the titans, October 11).

One can understand the unease when you know the pivotal position these unelected officers have enjoyed for so long; in many cases they are the major decision-makers, and not the politicians, and consequently are not held responsible by the public. In the changed town hall environment, their role will be advisory, along the lines, as David Clark intimates, of a Whitehall permanent secretary.

Elected mayors have been a feature of local government life in many parts of the world. I was surprised that no reference was made to the role of a senior officer in the administration of an elected mayor. Perhaps the Society of Local Authority Chief Executives could find consolation in the way the elected mayoral system operates in other countries.

Tom Jackson
Stockport

Inspiration to us all

I found the article about the London mental health campaign interesting, and I felt inspired reading about Mohammed Mujahid's incredible dedication (The end of the line, October 11).

I am a children and families social worker and often return home tired, stressed and fairly deflated, having spent my working day seemingly taking one step forwards and at least three back. Good mental health is something I know is important not only for the families I work with, but also for myself and my colleagues, yet it gets overlooked as the demands of the job take over and people become less willing to give up more time for others.

Mujahid makes it seem so simple, so straightforward and so satisfying, and yet he clearly puts an enormous amount of time and effort into enabling others to maintain good mental health. His positive attitude reminded me why I chose this profession in the first place and made me realise I should try to take more notice of the times when I gain something from the work I do, as well as it helping other people.

Cintha Archer
Berkshire

Pheasant shoot is no sport

Following the article about pheasant shooting in mid-Wales (Feathers are flying, October 4), I offer my own account as one of the residents concerned. As a witness to the mass shooting of specially-bred game birds on Cwm mountain, I am now altogether against this activity.

One Saturday, a group of us found ourselves in the middle of mass gunfire while walking on a public footpath near our homes. The shooters, standing directly on the path, broke what I believe to be the laws of safety - and common sense. My wife, myself and others were deeply upset, intimidated and enraged, feeling ourselves to be physically endangered.

Birds were reduced to pathetic bundles of feathers, crying, maimed and struggling on the ground. Later, they were gathered by the gamekeeper, still struggling, with no merciful dispatch to end their suffering. Where is the clean sporting kill professed to be the aim?

The shooters were grim, stony-faced men, too intent on their "sport" to care for us mere locals, or our safety. Any belief that this is sport as we know it, far less that there is any honour of a skilled hunt - forget it!

David Price
Cwm-Nant-y-Meichiaid, Powys

Abandoned cause

I have just had to close a charity project which over six years enabled 839 homeless, unemployed people from this small city to take up tenancies. We have closed because no one will continue to give us core funding - not the government, the National Lottery Charities Board (NLCB), major charities, nor the local council.

Our clients were no one's priority when we housed them, but had we not done so, they would most likely have resorted to crime or sunk into depression, and the costs of rescuing or coping with them in prison, or on the NHS, would have been many times what it cost us.

Timothy Hornsby, NLCB chief executive, is wrong to say that the government cannot take on long-term commitments. The people we are now failing will be a very long term and expensive problem, as well as a blot on our consciences.

Richard Hilken

former chair, Exeter Homes Committee, Exeter

Rightful place

The Rev Bill Lynn, pastoral director of NCH Action for Children, is far more than "a nod to its Methodist roots" (Purse strings, October 11). I am sure Tony Manwaring, NCH's director of external affairs, would not have used such a phrase.

The Methodist churches still actively support and fundraise for NCH, as well as raising awareness of the work of the charity in the community. Both the corporate and community sections are important in charities such as NCH.

Sybil Handley
Marple, Cheshire

How to lip read

Alan Watling's letter about ambidexterity (Letters, October 11) struck a chord with me.

Some time ago, when I noticed how some of my older friends had started to lose their hearing, I began to wonder if it would be useful to start to learn to lip read before I reached that state myself. Does anyone know of a suitable learning method? I was told there is a video-based self-teach pack, but have not been able to get further details.

Jules Hurry
London

Rare delicacy

I notice in the item Walky, porky? (Front to back, October 11) that somebody has discovered a source for that rare delicacy - goats' eggs. I think he or she should share this information with the world.

Allan Craig
Worcester

webTitle: Councils in crisis over children in care

fields.headline: The fuse is lit
fields.standfirst: The number of children in care has risen sharply in recent years putting many councils in crisis.  Mike George reports
fields.trailText: The number of children in care has risen sharply in recent years putting many councils in crisis. Mike George reports
fields.body:
As social services leaders meet today in Edinburgh for the start of the sector's annual conference, many will be exercised by problems caused by rising numbers of children being looked after by local authorities. At a meeting last week between councillors in the north-west and the Local Government Association, a majority of councils complained that growing numbers of children in care - many of them with complex needs - were leading to budget deficits. Salford city council is warning it faces a "social timebomb" as it struggles to cope with a 75% increase in numbers over the past six years.

Elsewhere in the north-west, Wigan, Rochdale and Bury, in particular, say they are facing substantial overspends. In the Greater Manchester area as a whole, where at least 4,000 children are now in care, almost half the authorities say their budgets are under pressure.

While north-west councils have been particularly vocal, Rob Hutchinson, who chairs the Association of Directors of Social Services' children and families committee, says most authorities are experiencing increases in the number of children in care. Latest figures from the Department of Health show an overall increase of 4% last year, continuing an upward trend from a low point in 1994-95, with an even more marked rise in the number of children entering care as a result of care orders granted by the courts.

Why should this be so? Anne Williams, Salford's social services director, says independent research shows that the increase experienced by her authority is not attributable to her staff getting tougher or being more willing to seek care orders. Her belief, shared by several other directors, is that social services are being asked to cope with the consequences of much broader changes in society.

In Salford's case at least, Williams says that although there has been a steady, though moderate, rate of increase in the number of children coming into care, the main reason for the overall trend has been an inability to safely discharge children back into the community. Some of this is because of the children's often complex needs, demonstrated perhaps in challenging and inappropriate behaviour as a result of abuse or severe neglect.

Other factors might be that parents cannot continue to care for their children or that, increasingly, several children from one family have to be taken into care at the same time - making it difficult not only to keep them together while in care, but also to discharge them together.

Williams and Wigan's director of social services, Bernard Walker, point to a number of worrying trends. In some areas, families are suffering from the effects of two or even three cycles of deprivation through poverty, poor health, inadequate housing, and often substance misuse. There continues to be an increase in some parts in the number of very young parents, including lone parents, who might be less able to parent adequately. And as Hutchinson points out: "Compared to 20 years ago, we're seeing a really substantial increase in the number of young parents in particular with major drug and alcohol misuse problems."

Penny Thompson, Sheffield's director of social services concurs with such analysis. Her authority has seen the number of children in care rise from 568 in 1998 to 724 today, she says, and only a small element of this growth has resulted from improvements in social workers' practice standards.

Authorities' difficulties are compounded by the increase in use of care orders, especially for emergency admissions, as opposed to voluntary arrangements agreed with parents. The neglect or other damage suffered by children is often quite severe, and is then followed by a traumatic separation and a hunt by the authority for an appropriate placement.

Hutchinson, director at Portsmouth, points out that foster carers are now being asked to carry out a quite different, often much more difficult, job than they were two decades ago. It is hardly surprising, he says, that some authorities are facing very serious problems recruiting foster carers, despite the offer of better financial recompense.

As a consequence of all this, there has been a marked upturn in the use of placements in specialist facilities. This, the affected authorities argue, has created substantial extra pressures on their children and families departmental budgets. Recent research for north-west authorities, carried out by charity NCH Action for Children, suggests they are spending £38m a year on placements with specialist outside agencies. The research also shows that 60% of these placements with independent sector agencies are made straight away - that is, the agencies are not used as a placement "of last resort" after in-house placements have failed.

Few would argue that it is realistic to expect social services departments to be able to offer a wide range of residential or other specialist services. But both Walker and Hutchinson maintain there is a "sellers' market" and, consequently, authorities are often having to pay whatever fees are required. They want the health department to recognise these cost implications in advance of the chancellor's comprehensive spending review.

But what of the government's Quality Protects, Sure Start, neighbourhood renewal schemes and other initiatives aimed at improving family and community life? Are they not helping the situation?

Thompson stresses that such schemes are giving a welcome boost to authorities' efforts to carry out preventative work, which may help to reverse the seemingly inexorable rise in the number of neglected and abused children and young people. But the effects may take some years to address both the underlying problems and the cash crises being faced by so many social services departments.

webTitle: Direct action wins the land war day

fields.headline: Arrow of peace
fields.standfirst: Direct action wins the land war day
fields.trailText: Direct action wins the land war day
fields.body:
They came with turquoise and yellow macaw-feather headdresses, carved javelins, bows and arrows, teeth and beads, and faces painted with achote "war" paint. Seventy people in three canoes - elders, shamans, leaders, archers and Amazonian women. They came to seek justice armed with a few of modernity's arrows: a copy of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) convention No. 169 on indigenous and tribal rights, the title deeds to their land and two documentary film-makers.

The destination was an illegal goldmine, two hours upriver by motorised canoe from Tres Islas in Madre de Dios, Peru. The Shipibo, one of the indigenous peoples of Peru, own this land and, supported by other indigenous groups, they are on the warpath.

Gold miners have taken over an area amounting to between a half and a third of their land. Though they have "legal" concessions, they have not, as required, obtained permission from the Shipibo. In law the concessions are invalid. The Shipibo want the miners out. The miners don't look set to leave. The authorities move firmly between inaction and inertia. So the Shipibo have taken to their canoes.

Indigenous peoples of Madre de Dios have long suffered at the hands of rubber barons, Catholic and Evangelical god-barons, "eco-tourism" barons and gold barons. Gold mining in rainforest areas is profoundly destructive; gold extraction uses mercury, which gets washed into the river, contaminating the fish. The river is also contaminated by oil, leaking batteries and other discharges, and silted up with soil and stones dug out of the forest in vast swathes. Flora and fauna are destroyed. The Shipibo see this as colonisation - a conquest in a long tradition.

With whoops and clapping, the Shipibos reach the first mine. The manager and owner sit in their shack, behind a set of scales for weighing the gold. Ranged around the hut on small hilltops are young Shipibo archers, bows drawn, ready for defence. They fear that, as in other protests against mining, the miners will set dogs on them, or shoot them.

The talking begins. The Shipibos explain their views politely. Their way of negotiating has a graceful, fundamental democracy: the leaders report what the community's wishes are - it is not their role to do more.

The mine owner tells them he has no intention of leaving. Instead he offers them money. All hell breaks loose. "You came and destroyed our land and you offer us dollars. Tranquillity is worth more than dollars," says their leader. In a symbolic act, the shaman takes out his machete and begins sharpening his arrows.

The Shipibos reboard the canoes to head for the next mine. This is the big one. Acre after acre of jungle surrounding a long-loved lake has been turned to shingle and dust. The Shipibo had wanted to build an eco-tourist lodge, which they would manage. But this sustainable project has been blasted away by the mining.

Where they remember dense forests shimmering with life, they now walk through a devastated land, appalled. Small fires burn, charred tree stumps scrape the empty horizons, rusting machinery litters puddles of water thick with oozing oil. To the Shipibos this is tragedy. "If the earth is maltreated, it's as if we ourselves are maltreated," says one of their leaders.

The mine owner insists that, by holding a concession, he has the right to do this. It throws up one of the most malignant examples of laws governing land: the "land" belongs to the Shipibo, but everything underneath it and above it belongs to the state, and can thus be given to miners, making the idea of "land" paper-thin. It also clashes with the holistic indigenous world view which includes all land, including subsoil and trees.

This land, repeats the owner, is my land. In sudden revolt, the Shipibos move to the heart of the mining operations and simply "undo" it. They dismember it, pulling out dredging pipes, carefully taking apart the platforms for sifting gold. Nothing is broken: "Tranquillo, tranquillo," say the leaders.

They meet no resistance. Night falls. The canoes head over to the far river bank. In minutes, wigwams are erected, with banana-leaf coverings for the torrential rain. In the cool morning, the canoes return to the mine. The police have arrived after being called by the miners.

The Shipibos offer the police a guided tour of all the illegalities on the ground and of the international law on paper. Eventually the police draft an agreement setting a date for the miners to leave. For the Shipibos, it's a huge victory. And a moral victory for wise - and above all peaceful - direct action. "Our way is not to be violent," they say.

fields.trailText: Hands on experience
fields.body:

Wolverhampton Express & Star, 26.9.00 (Mary Cooper, Wolverhampton)

Ewe and me A best man from Farnham, Surrey, lined up a sheep as a bridesmaid when his best friend got married.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 21.10.00 (Jan Davies, Birmingham)

Hot-footing it A walker in Todmorden, West Yorkshire, had to flee from a barn in his underwear when he set light to his clothes and the barn after sheltering there from torrential rain.
Yorkshire Post, 28.9.00 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Blooming cheek A man in Brighton who won a competition for a £5,000 garden make-over only has a few pot plants in his flat.
Sunday Independent, 24.9.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

After burn The waste oil from poppadoms is being converted for use by lorry drivers in Manchester to fuel their vehicles.
Evening Mail 2.10.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Hot dog A fire crew called to rescue a dog from a blazing haystack in Shropshire was forced to use thermal imaging cameras to track down the animal.
Shropshire Star, 3.10.00 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Hunger strikers Vegans taking part in a soccer match in Taunton, Somerset, decided to quit the game because the ball was made of leather.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 25.9.00 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Cop shop Three men who broke into a van parked outside Ikea in Wednesbury, West Midlands, found themselves face to face with police officers who were keeping watch for car thieves.
Express & Star 5.10.00 (C Caldwell, Stourbridge)

Romantic tip A Coventry couple have won a competition on the most unusual place to fall in love. He was a dustman collecting her rubbish and she was rummaging in her bin searching for lost car keys.
Coventry Evening Telegraph, 4.10.00 (John Forster, Daventry)

Fair copter Police in Suffolk swooped down in their new £2m helicopter to make their first night arrest of a man on a rooftop, only to find that the target had climbed up there to get a closer look at the helicopter.
News North West, 6.10.00 (Jon Booth, Stockport)

Write-off A man in Lewes, East Sussex, who was sorting out the paperwork after buying a second-hand car returned to find that the car had been taken away by contractors and crushed.
Brighton Evening Argus, 18.9.00 (T Hallett, Burgess Hill)

Caught red-faced Police in Nottingham dropped a UK-wide hunt for a "stolen" police car after it turned up in a garage where they had taken it to be repaired.
Daily Record, 23.9.00 (June Newman, Chichester)

Gum by A shepherd had to have a hole drilled in the front of his false teeth because his dogs could not hear him whistling.
News North West, 3.10.00 (A Wright, Fleetwood)

Foot fault An engineer at a tenpin bowling alley in Rubery, West Midlands, had to throw his shoes into the lane to attract attention after his thumb became jammed in the machine which resets the pins.
News North West 2.10.00 (Ian Fletcher, Manchester)
