But the game was soured by frequent confrontations, which Vieira claims Mihajlovic was at the heart of. "There were a lot of bad things said to me and it they all came from one player - Mihajlovic", Vieira said. "I was called a black bastard and a f***ing black monkey. You don't want to hear that on the pitch coming from a professional player. "It was the worst that has been directed at me as a player. I talked with some of the other Lazio players and I asked them what they thought of that. They said they know him and he is stupid. They were sorry, they apologised." The abuse was not restricted to Mihajlovic however, as the Arsenal squad were pelted with plastic bottles from the crowd at the end of the game. Vieira claims the experience means he will never consider a return to club football in Italy. "I know that there are a lot of Italian clubs who would like to sign me but I don't want to play in Serie A", he said. "I can't stand the racist atmosphere that you can almost breath here." Lazio have built up a reputation for extreme support, and were in trouble only last season when fans began carrying banners declaring their allegiance with Mussolini and the Serbian warlord Arkan.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Disaster strikes at 115mph
fields.standfirst:
Rail safety under scrutiny again as four are killed as London-Leeds train is derailed

Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: October 18 2000: On this day four people were killed in the Hatfield rail crash. This is how the Guardian reported the news.
fields.byline: Keith Perry, Vikram Dodd, Steven Morris  and  Keith Harper, transport editor
fields.body:
The safety of Britain's rail system has been thrown into question yet again after the third serious accident in three years left four people dead and 33 injured yesterday.

The tragedy happened shortly after midday yesterday when a high-speed train derailed and broke up at more than 100mph, hurling some passengers onto the track.

The cause of the crash is still being investigated but police ruled out terrorism as the cause last night despite receiving a bomb threat just two days ago.

Railtrack has launched a full investigation and safety experts are concentrating on whether a section of axle could have failed as the train reached speeds of 115mph. Another possibility is that the track may have contributed to the horrific crash, either due to vandalism or a fault on the line.

Many expressed a sense of disbelief that the death toll had not been higher. The train literally came apart as it took a right-hand bend on one of the busiest stretches of line in Britain. The timing of the accident has jarred emotions; it comes less than two weeks after the first anniversary of the Ladbroke Grove crash at Paddington.

The 12.10pm GNER London King's Cross to Leeds service left the track near Hatfield, Hertfordshire, barely 20 minutes into its journey.

The train split in two and a giant hole was torn in the buffet car. Some passengers reported that a loud bang was heard seconds before the carriages skewed off the track. Three ended up on their side, with four others derailed.

The dead and most severely injured came from the middle section of the train.

Two first-class carriages and the rear locomotive separated from the main section of the train and screeched to a halt; the buffet car, six standard class coaches and the front locomotive careered a few hundred yards further up the track. The buffet car then toppled over and smashed into a trackside pylon which tore off its roof.

Of the 200 passengers on board the train, four were pronounced dead at the scene and 33 were taken to local hospitals.

Witnesses described scenes of "mayhem", with bodies by the track and people weeping.

Most of the casualties - 14 women and 12 men - were taken to the Queen Elizabeth II hospital in Welwyn Garden City, with the Lister hospital in Stevenage taking seven.

In June 1998, another high-speed GNER train derailed on the same track just 20 miles away, injuring nine people, the Health and Safety Executive said.

Chris Garnett, the chief executive of GNER, said the train, built in 1990, would have been serviced every night and there was nothing in its records which indicated any problems.

He would not be drawn on suggestions that two years ago another GNER train suffered a broken wheel, reportedly because of metal fatigue. GNER was fined in that case.

At the scene of yesterday's disaster a set of wheels, called bogeys, had come off a carriage that was left resting in bushes 100 yards away from the front section of the train.

Mr Garnett said: "We are investigating all the reasons, we do not know the cause. The problem we did have with the broken wheel was fully investigated and all repairs carried out, we don't believe it is that [the cause] but I keep saying, we do not know the cause of the accident at this stage."

Nick Pollard from Railtrack, which is responsible for maintaining the tracks, said: "The track is patrolled on a very regular basis, no less than on a weekly basis. We will be working through the findings of this to see if they can shed any light."

He added that incidents of vandalism in the Hatfield area were not high, but vandalism could not be ruled out.

The transport minister, Lord MacDonald, visited the scene within hours of the disaster, and expressed his sympathies to the relatives of the dead and the injured.

He said that the railway inspectorate were carrying out an investigation into the causes of the disaster. He praised the emergency services and said that his thoughts were with the families of those who had died. He has also asked the HSE to provide an "urgent" report on the crash.

The Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, Don Foster, said the Hatfield crash made it all the more urgent that the recommendations of the Cullen inquiry into the Paddington crash were implemented as soon as possible.

A spokesman for the train drivers' union, Aslef, expressed "heartfelt condolences" and said it was cooperating with the investigation. The driver was breathalysed after the crash as a matter of routine.

Survivors and relatives of passengers who died in the Paddington and Southall rail disasters today spoke of their sense of devastation that four people had been killed in yesterday's crash.

Carol Bell, 35, from Reading, who survived the 1997 Southall crash, said: "The staggering thing is that this happened during the Ladbroke Grove inquiry, just as that happened during the Southall inquiry."

Ms Bell, who is vice-chairwoman of the Safety on Trains Action Group, spent the day telephoning other survivors and relatives of victims from Southall and Paddington to let them know there had been another tragedy.

"I have sat through the Southall inquiry and half of the Ladbroke Grove inquiry and I always believed there would be another major crash," she said. "It will keep happening again and again."

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your emails to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: WHY DO RIVER PLATE HATE BOCA?
fields.body:
WHY DO RIVER PLATE HATE BOCA?

"Does anyone know the basis of the rivalry between River Plate and Boca Juniors of Argentina? Is it true that the clubs are supposed to be for the rich and for the poor of Buenos Aires respectively?" asks Matt Walker.

"To some extent, the rivalry does stem from the antagonism between the rich and the poor," says Stefan Müller. "River was founded after the model of an English football club when the English influence among the upper class in Buenos Aires was dominant in the late 19th century. Hence the anglicised club name (from "Rio de la Plata").

"In contrast, Boca has always been the poor mans' team, since its name refers to the quarter of La Boca, south of the city centre, which even nowadays has the reputation of a rough, somewhat ramshackle but charming neighbourhood, with brightly painted houses, traditionally inhabited by immigrant families from Italy. Even today you can hear the plain Genovese dialect on the streets of La Boca and get the best ice cream and pizza outside of Italy.

"However Geography is also an important element of self-definition in Buenos Aires. The River stadium is located in north-eastern Belgrano, which is one of the more liveable residential areas. In contrast, La Boca is located south of the Rivadavia Road, which geographically (and socially) divides the city in half."

THE CASE OF THE EXECUTED FOOTBALLER

"Is it true that a winner of a Cup Final medal was hung for sheep stealing in Australia in the early 1900s? I was told that it was an ex-Everton player," asked James Carlin a few weeks back.

After James' original letter one of our Australian readers pointed out that sheep stealing wasn't a hanging offence down under in the early 1900s. So that part of the question surely can't be true. However Hamish McDouall insists that Alex 'Sandy' Young from the Everton team of 1906 (and scorer of the winning goal) was hung. "For what crime or where I don't know, but Gary Lineker mentioned it on telly once and he never lies or gets booked," he says. Can anyone else shed any further light on the situation?

THE ORIGIN OF CLICHÉS

"We've all heard the football cliché 'get stuck in' enough times. What is the derivation of this expression?" asks Steven Randall.

"Too bloody easy," reckons Andy Harper, who says that the New Shorter Oxford English Dictionary defines stuck in, or get stuck into, as: (a) lay into, make a physical attack on; (b) make a serious start on, get down to in earnest.

"I'm more interested in where the origin/usage of some of the phrases I hear in when playing for my Sunday League team in the Manchester Accountants League," he says, "including a) Keep stepping! b) Stick it in the onion bag! c) Put it in the mixer! d) Feed the channels! e) Skin him! and f) Put the cat out!" Can anyone help?

SOCIALIST FOOTBALLERS (PART 3 IN A SERIES)

Tony Galvin, Chris Houghton, Brian McClair, Bill Shankly, Alex Ferguson, Diego Maradona, Jorge Valdano, Fernando Redondo, Pep Guardiola, Paul Breitner and Egil Olsen have all been cited as socialists (of varying degrees) during recent editions of Knowledge Unlimited. But are there any more out there? And what about the fascists?

"Niall Quinn, the man who works so hard to get that record breaking goal for Ireland, also believes in the working man," says Paddy Dwyer. "After signing for Sunderland, I read an interview with him in one of the papers where he excoriated Thatcher and the damage she had done to the industrial communities of the north of England."

Meanwhile Ged Malsher reckons Sinisa Mihajlovic is a supporter of the far-right. "His behaviour during last night's Lazio-Arsenal match reminds me of another of this agreeable individual's finest hours, when he wrote an article for a Serbian "newspaper" glorifying the late war criminal/mass murderer Arkan."

COULD THE 1966 WORLD CUP FINAL HAVE BEEN DECIDED BY A TOSS OF A COIN?

"What would have happened if the 1966 World Cup Final had ended in a draw? I'm sure that there would not have been provision for a penalty shoot-out, so would it have been a replay? I heard that European ties were decided by a toss of a coin at this time - so is it conceivable that Bobby Moore may have had to call correctly to have won the World Cup for England?" asks Alain Verdun.

"No, Bobby wouldn't have had to toss a coin, in fact there would have had to be a replay. If you watch the game, Kenneth Wolstenholme actually says so," says Jarrod Lythgoe.

TOUGH TACKLING TOFFS

"Does anyone know of any footballers that went to public school? I know Frank Lampard Jnr was one (he went to Brentwood). But are there any others?" wonders Joel Davison.

"Keith Gillespie attended the exclusive County Down school Bangor Grammar. Not quite Eton, but pretty posh nonetheless," says Paddy Dwyer. "They played rugby."

Meanwhile Hamish McDouall asks: "Can anyone top Oxford United's centre back and New Zealand international Ceri Evans. He was in Oxford due to his Rhodes Scholarship and while he was there he worked towards his Ph.D in psychology."

CAN YOU HELP?

"One currently doing the rounds in my local is that prior to moving North for the group stages for the 1966 World Cup Finals, the Brazilian squad trained in front of the public in Finsbury Park. I have checked local papers of the time without success. Can anyone help?" asks Andrew Catling

How is it possible for a player to score two goals in a match without anyone else touching the ball in between? asks Mad Dan Eccles.

"Where does the Villa in Aston Villa come from? Does it have anything to do with the Aston-Martin motorcar?" asks Bob Hobbs.

Send your emails to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: Casting news: Cleese Nearly Headless in Potter adaptation?

fields.headline: Cleese Nearly Headless in Potter adaptation?
fields.trailText: Plus: Jada Pinkett Smith may jack into Matrix mainframe, here be dragons for Matthew McConaughey and Dern confirms third Jurassic outing
fields.body:
 The Harry Potter movie continues to bulk up its cast. The latest name to be associated with the project is John Cleese. The Monty Python star told fans at a special screening of The Life of Brian that he could be playing the role of Nearly Headless Nick, one of Hogwart's resident ghosts.

 Jada Pinkett Smith, aka Mrs Will Smith, is in talks to appear in the two Matrix sequels. The Hollywood Reporter states that she will play the love interest of Laurence Fishburne's character Morpheus. The sequels are due to begin filming in Australia in March. Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss and Fishburne will all be reprising their original roles.

 Matthew McConaughey is set to star opposite Christian Bale in Reign of Fire, Rob Bowman's action feature about a brood of megalomaniac fire-breathing dragons. McConaughey will play the head of an American militia that has come to England to battle the dragons.

 Jurassic Park heroine Laura Dern has announced she will be returning to the prehistoric action drama series and will appear in Jurassic Park 3. Dern joins Jurassic regular Sam Neill and newcomers William H Macy and Téa Leoni.

webTitle: Livingstone challenges advertising industry to create new logo for London.

fields.headline: Livingstone challenges ad industry to create 'logo for London'
fields.standfirst: Beattie pours scorn on Livingstone's London logo
fields.trailText: 9.30am: London mayor Ken Livingstone has challenged the advertising industry to create a new logo for London, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, has challenged the advertising industry to create a catchy new slogan to rival the Big Apple's I love New York and seduce new visitors into the city.

The Greater London Authority (GLA) has approached advertising and design agencies this week with a brief to create a "logo for London" to combat the city's negative image of expensive hotels, a poor tube network and lack of civic pride.

Harry Barlow, Mr Livingstone's communications adviser, is handling the pitch process. He said: "We want something that will replicate the success of 'I love New York' or 'Glasgow Smiles Better'. Something that will promote London nationally and encourage investment."

Mr Barlow said he hoped the GLA would have the campaign ready to launch by the end of the year.

Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper, the agency behind Mr Livingstone's election campaign, is involved in the pitch.

webTitle: Beattie pours scorn on Livingstone's London logo

fields.headline: Beattie pours scorn on Livingstone's London logo
fields.standfirst: Livingstone asks for London logo
fields.trailText:
11.30am update: Trevor Beattie, creative director at TBWA, the Labour party's advertising agency, has criticised Ken Livingstone's decision to plough up to £5m into creating a logo for London.
Livingstone asks for London logo
fields.body:
Trevor Beattie, the creative director at TBWA, the agency that holds the advertising account for the Labour party, has criticised Ken Livingstone's decision to plough up to £5m into creating a logo for London.

He said: "My first reaction is to laugh out loud. Ken needs to stop fannying about with logos and sort out the travel system, which is the job he was hired to do.

"London doesn't need a logo. London is a great brand. The priority should be making sure that is works more efficiently. London has never been a funkier place to be and I can't think of anything more naff than a great big River Thames logo."

Mr Livingstone's decision to devise a brand and logo for London will be seen as a controversial move by cynical Londoners who want urgent attention paid to other issues such as transport and the environment.

Mark Lund, the chief executive at Delaney Lund Knox Warren - the agency behind the government's recent teenage pregnancy campaign - believes the government is facing a tough job.

Londoners share the same sense of civic pride to New Yorkers, he said, but they are also more cynical. "In the UK, the city is somewhere you work but your heart is in the country. It may work as a badge of pride but it will be tough in London."

David Farrow, marketing director at D'Arcy, one of the government's roster advertising agencies, was similarly sceptical. He said Mr Livingstone would have to plough at least £5m into a new logo for London if it was to succeed in turning around the negative feeling associated with the capital.

"This is going to cost a lot of money," he said. "If you are going to energise people right across London you'll need a big push to make it happen. He will need to spend at least £5m."

Mr Farrow compared the problem to that faced by the Evening Standard, which spends around £4m a year and doesn't aim to target every Londoner.

Mr Farrow also questioned whether the new logo was even necessary. He said: "'I love New York' worked at a time when the city was bankrupt and losing visitor numbers. This is not the case with London and I'm not sure it's worth it."

webTitle: In brief: Dinosaur stomps on competition

fields.headline: Dinosaur stomps on competition
fields.trailText: Plus: Woody rails against soda pop evils, "unsophisticated" Bruce may quit action flicks, Little Crumb to fight Dutch corner in Oscars and Sun photographers bag wrong wizard
fields.body:
 On the first weekend of its release, Dinosaur has trampled the competition to take the top spot at the UK box office. Disney's computer-animated film took £2.1m over the weekend compared to second placed Road Trip which made £1.9m. Billy Elliot continued to delight cinema-goers. The British film has now made £7.2m in its three weeks of release.

 Woody Harrelson is preparing to cycle across America accompanied by a solar-powered bus full of wheatgrass to teach the nation's youth about addictive substances, but not in a manner the government will be endorsing. Harrelson's war against sugar and caffeine comes in part from his vocal pro-marijuana stance. "The hypocrisy of this marijuana thing really upsets me," said the actor. "There's probably not more than a handful of people in this country who are not drug addicts. That includes children, because children are addicted to sugar. Sugar not only has no nutritional value, it is without question harmful. Children are addicted to caffeine too, particularly in soda pop. These are drugs. Try to tell a kid they can't have their soda pop for a week."

 Don't hold your breath, but rumour has it that Bruce Willis is considering quitting action films - because his Spanish girlfriend Maria Bravo Rosado thinks they make him look "unsophisticated". The actor and his trusty vest are still due to make Die Hard 4 next year, but he insists there will be less violence, no swearing and a more "human dimension".

 Dutch film Little Crumb (Kruimeltje), which was more successful in its native Netherlands than the Star Wars prequel, has been chosen as the country's entry for the Oscar nomination for foreign-language film. Based on the classic Dutch children's book of the same name, Little Crumb is the story of a Dutch street kid in the early 1920s whose father has gone to America. Oscar nominations will be announced on February 13, and the awards will take place on March 25.

 The Sun newspaper was very proud of its Harry Potter exclusive pictures yesterday, donating its page three slot to large photographs of the production (in a small picturesque Yorkshire village, they revealed). No comment however today on allegations by rival paper the Mirror, who reveal, with a smirk, that far from the first exclusive snaps of the young wizard, the "dozy hacks" managed to shoot the stand-ins for all three main characters. Meanwhile, if you really care that much, the internet is awash with "exclusive" pictures of the very chairs and tables that will be used in one of the classroom sets, or, even better, the very same owl that you will see in the movie. Yawn.

fields.headline: Who's the buffoon now?
fields.trailText: In 1955 Donald Carr and his fellow MCC players - unhappy with lbw decisions - bundled Pakistani umpire Idrees Beg into the back of a cart, smuggled him back to their hotel, and doused him with cold water. Carr and Co. laughed off what they called the Water Treatment as a prank; the Pakistanis didn't find it at all amusing and rallies were in held in Peshawar demanding that the MCC team go home. (It didn't do Carr much harm though: he went on to become secretary of the TCCB - now the ECB.) Beg had officiated in Pakistan's first Test and was well respected. This so-called prank reeked of colonial arrogance. One of the first principles that the English drummed into the culture of cricket was the hegemony of umpires. Shakoor Rana would argue the same 32 years later.
fields.body:
In 1955 Donald Carr and his fellow MCC players - unhappy with lbw decisions - bundled Pakistani umpire Idrees Beg into the back of a cart, smuggled him back to their hotel, and doused him with cold water. Carr and Co. laughed off what they called the Water Treatment as a prank; the Pakistanis didn't find it at all amusing and rallies were in held in Peshawar demanding that the MCC team go home. (It didn't do Carr much harm though: he went on to become secretary of the TCCB - now the ECB.) Beg had officiated in Pakistan's first Test and was well respected. This so-called prank reeked of colonial arrogance. One of the first principles that the English drummed into the culture of cricket was the hegemony of umpires. Shakoor Rana would argue the same 32 years later.

Times might change, but attitudes, it seems, don't. First there is Pakistani journalist Asghar Ali who is still insisting on a retraction of Michael Atherton's press-conference buffoon insult - four years after the incident. If the title didn't fit then, Mr Ali is certainly making a play for it now. His opportunistic whining is an unwanted distraction from a promising Test series, in which Atherton will play a key role.

But before Mr Ali picks up the Buffoon of the Tour award, let's consider another contender. Lord MacLaurin presided over England's plummet to the bottom of the Test rankings only to be saved by the accidental coupling of Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher. There is a lesson here: never let a Lord near the administration of English cricket - be he Ted or Tesco.

MacLaurin's latest foray is his most ill-conceived. In his topsy-turvy interpretation of natural justice, the good Lord is convinced that all players and officials accused of corruption should be banned until they are proved innocent.

Apart from this toffee-nosed sanctimony, MacLaurin appears to be quite forgetful too. Ban players is what England would do, he says. So why didn't he when Chris Lewis coughed up three names? Obviously because accusation doesn't equate with suspicion in the English game. Those no-good Pakistanis, by contrast, must still have a case to answer even though an 18-month judicial inquiry could not find enough evidence to convict them.

It must have escaped MacLaurin's attention that his policy would have players and officials at the mercy of their enemies. Fabricating a lurid tale of match-fixing and corruption isn't difficult, but it is much harder to prove your innocence beyond any doubt. MacLaurin, I suspect, really has his sights set on next summer's Ashes tour. A few well-timed bombshells - either in the tabloid press or in the Telegraph, which seems to have a hotline to HQ - and he could eliminate some of the best Aussie cricketers too.

I'd be surprised if Lord MacLaurin has even read the Qayyum Report. To make such daft comments on the eve of England's most sensitive tour for years speaks volumes for his political and diplomatic acumen. Last year, Simon Briggs suggested on wisden.com that he should go back to his prunes; Tesco also do a neat line in Asian food (by the way, I highly recommend the gobi saag). So MacLaurin, you should do the decent thing: resign, abdicate, clear off. For you, your Lordship, the parathas are waiting.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday. Orin Gordon's Anglo-Caribbean View returns next week. To read the previous Anglo-Asian column, on England's 13-year Pakistani itch, click here

fields.headline: Muhammad Ali biopic stalled
fields.trailText: Talks between director Michael Mann and executives at Columbia pictures have failed in an effort to resuscitate the currently postponed biopic of boxing legend Muhammad Ali
fields.body:
Talks between director Michael Mann and executives at Columbia pictures have failed in an effort to resuscitate the currently postponed biopic of boxing legend Muhammad Ali.

Daily Variety reports that the movie, in which Will Smith plays the enigmatic heavyweight world champion, found itself in difficulties when Mann could not guarantee that the film would be produced for the agreed price tag of $100m.

The Los Angeles Times suggests that the 57-year-old director failed to convince studio heads that he could pull off the movie without going at least $5m over.

Mann, meanwhile, angered that Columbia gave the go-ahead on the film, is threatening to withdraw from the troubled production. The director reportedly offered to cut some expensive locations, and Mann, Smith and producer Jon Peters have all agreed to take "substantial cuts" in their upfront fees, the Times reports.

Matters remain at stalemate, and despite the fact that Will Smith has spent the last year training for the role, the project might be abandoned at this late stage.

Check Upcoming movies for the latest updates.

fields.headline: Malkovich signs for Spider-Man
fields.trailText: Director Sam Raimi has confirmed that John Malkovich will take the part originally destined for Nicholas Cage, and play arch-baddy the Green Goblin in Spider-Man
fields.body:
Director Sam Raimi has confirmed that John Malkovich will take the part originally destined for Nicholas Cage, and play arch-baddy the Green Goblin in Spider-Man. The director also revealed that that he's close to casting Alicia Witt in the role of Peter Parker's girlfriend Mary Jane (the role was recently passed over by Kate Hudson).

Tobey Maguire, as we reported earlier this year, will play the mild-mannered Peter Parker, high school student by day - and after he's bitten by an arachnid - superhero by night.

Meanwhile Raimi looks set to upset Spiderman aficionados - by changing his famous red and blue costume. In a recent interview, he warned fans hoping for authenticity, "I can't say [the costume] will be what the kids have seen in comic books."

For all the rumours and hype, keep an eye on Spider-Man Hype!.

fields.headline: Razorfish axes 200 staff
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Razorfish has announced it is laying off 200 staff worldwide - 10% of its workforce, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The interactive agency Razorfish has announced it is laying off 200 staff worldwide - 10% of its workforce.

Thirty staff from the UK office have been affected by what Razorfish is calling a "performance improvement plan". A statement from Razorfish said: "Through this plan we are streamlining and aligning certain parts of our business to respond to evolving market needs, our clients and ultimately our shareholders."

Industry sources suggest that cracks have been apparent at Razorfish, in which Omnicom has a minority stake, since the start of the summer when a number of the 300 staff at the UK office found they had no accounts to work on.

"The problem with Razorfish is that it expanded too rapidly and kept trying to expand even further because it needs to keep pleasing the US stock market," said one onlooker.

Part of the difficulty at present is that big-spending clients have begun moving away from appointing new media agencies on a retainer basis in favour of using them on a project-by-project basis. This has had a damaging impact on agencies that went through periods of rapid expansion at the end of the 90s, prompting observers to suggest that the cutbacks at Razorfish could soon be followed by other Omnicom-backed agencies such as Organic, Agency.com and Think New Ideas.

"Someone had to do it first, but I would not be surprised if some of the other bigger agencies followed suit. The market is very different for everybody nowadays and it was always going to hit the big guys first. The smart money is now on mergers and rationalisation, particularly among network agencies," said Jon Bains, chairman of Lateral, an independent agency.

Razorfish bought its way into the UK in 1998 with the purchase of fledgling new media agency CHBi and the digital creative agency Sunbather. It has bought local agencies in other global markets.

Razorfish, which now has offices in the US, Asia, and Europe, floated on Nasdaq in April last year. Its share price is currently languishing around the $5 (£3.26) mark, a far cry from the high of $56 (£36.5) it reached earlier this year.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip scrapes through to the Second Group-Match Stage
fields.trailText: Former German national coach Berti Vogts has put himself forward for the England manager's job. "England is one of the great jobs in football," he said, "and there are coaches all over the world now who would love to take up the challenge."
fields.body:
Former German national coach Berti Vogts has put himself forward for the England manager's job. "England is one of the great jobs in football," he said, "and there are coaches all over the world now who would love to take up the challenge."

George Weah looks likely to join Marseille, although according to the Daily Star, Everton could make a late bid to sign the former World Footballer of the Year.

Meanwhile Man City could be lining up Atletico Madrid's Kiko as a replacement for the departed Liberian. The Spanish international forward, 28, has announced his intention to leave the country and, according to the Mirror, Manchester looks the most likely destination. According to Planet Football however, Chelsea are also ready to dip their hands in their pockets.

The Daily Mail predicts a new arrival at Pride Park. The paper believes that Jim Smith is on the verge of signing Norwegian international midfielder Runar Berg from Italian side Venezia, for a fee of around £500,000.

The Mirror reports that Derby will also try to re-sign Christian Dailly from Blackburn for £1.5m. The Scottish international, who joined Rovers for over £5m only two years ago, does not feature in Graeme Souness's plans at Ewood Park.

Another Ewood outcast looks likely to be Jason McAteer who was dropped for Rovers recent defeat at Fulham. "Jason's attitude has not been right," Souness is reported to have said. "I have told him so and left him out."

Bologna are keen to sign Newcastle's French centre-half Alain Goma, according to the Daily Mail. After announcing losses of nearly £19m Newcastle may have to offload some playing staff, and Goma could be the first, although the Italians are apparently unwilling to meet his £3.5m asking price.

fields.headline: Travels with the Queen
fields.standfirst: Being a journalist on a royal tour is a bit like being on a superior package holiday, writes Stephen Bates in Rome
fields.trailText: Being a journalist on a royal tour is a bit like being on a superior package holiday, writes Stephen Bates in Rome.
fields.body:
Being a journalist on a royal tour is a bit like being on a superior sort of package holiday. We pile on the bus chortling each morning and head off for a quick tour of the local sites while our guides, mostly seconded diplomats, tell us as little as they think we need to know.

We could have been told weeks ago that the Queen would not be defying tradition and would wear black to see the Pope. Perhaps the Palace just liked watching us speculating. But was there really any need to have kept the guest list at the British Ambassador's dinner from us until the guests actually arrived last night? Perhaps they thought we would spill the beans to an expectant world.

"We can tell you now what the Queen is giving the Pope," one of our minders told us with an air of suppressed excitement as our coach drew up at the Vatican yesterday. "So long as you observe the embargo," he added.

It was almost as if the Queen might even now change her mind and instead of giving Pope John Paul II facsimile prints from the Royal Canaletto collection might yet decide to choose the fish knives instead. Or perhaps the diplomats were concerned that the Pope would be anxiously scanning the wires even now to discover what presents he had in store.

Probably it is in the absence of real news that we fall to writing about trivia, such as the Italian baggage handlers' dropping of the Royal frocks at Rome airport on Monday. At least here was something we could see with our own eyes.

There were two ways of doing the story, as a shock-horror as in: "Goodness! Those dresses are worth tens of thousands of pounds! It must be my lead!" as the lady journalist from OK! magazine exclaimed (these exclamation marks are infectious), or as a traditional tale of Italian incompetence, as the more euro sceptic members of the media entourage preferred to pitch it.

Useless to point out that as the dresses were all encased in covers no harm was done. They will all have to be pressed said OK! Almost as if the Queen would have to stay up all night to do it herself.

We live in a world of pools. There are tight pools as when only one newspaper reporter and one camera team are allowed in to watch the Queen meet the Pope and loose pools when anyone can just dive in. Just as on a real package tour, by the end of the week apparently no one wants to use the pool anymore at all. We'll all have seen quite enough by then.

This is an agreeable world, though. Now the Queen is in her 70's, she does not want to start her engagements before 11am and she likes to finish quite early too, with breaks in-between. It is a world of smiles and polite handshakes, of diplomatic greetings and applause, of strained necks and waving flags. A world in which the worst that may befall is to miss the Duke's latest genial gaffe or fail to whip out our binoculars in time to spot that - yes - the Queen appears to be wearing three rows of pearls today.

All this obscures and trivialises the visit, but all our news desks fall on it as manna from heaven. Never mind. If it's Wednesday it must be Milan. Only two more days to go...

webTitle: Discovery astronauts head out for final day of spacewalks

fields.headline: Discovery astronauts head out for final day of spacewalks
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A few final chores and one choice job - test-driving a mini-jetpack - awaited a pair of astronauts Wednesday, the last of four days of spacewalks around the international space station.
fields.body:
A few final chores and one choice job - test-driving a mini-jetpack - awaited a pair of astronauts Wednesday, the last of four days of spacewalks around the international space station.

On their second trip outside space shuttle Discovery since Monday, spacewalkers Michael Lopez-Alegria and Jeff Wisoff had to clean up the top of the newly installed station truss for the arrival of a 240-foot pair of solar wings in December.

The duo also had to deploy a tray on the truss that will hold connections between the station and the US Destiny laboratory module, scheduled for installation in January. But with that work out of the way, the spacewalkers were to fire up a mini-jetpack they had only experienced via endless practice in Nasa's virtual reality laboratory.

Lopez-Alegria and Wisoff were enthusiastic about the tests well before launch.

"They want to do it and we want them to do it," said Daryl Schuck, the lead spacewalk officer in Mission Control. First, the duo had to attempt a few jetpack maneuvers about 40 feet above Discovery - 240 miles above Earth.

Then, one at a time, they were to jet down to the rear of the cargo bay while one followed alongside on the end of the shuttle robot arm holding a tether - just in case. Japanese astronaut Koichi Wakata was tasked with controlling the robot arm from inside Discovery.

Flight director Chuck Shaw said the 50-foot trips, which were supposed to take about three minutes apiece, would be "a little like watching paint dry."

The rescue jetpack is not nearly the hot rod it would seem. Since it's built only to bring an errant astronaut back to the shuttle or the space station, each move has to be deliberate to conserve its limited fuel.

Earlier astronauts have flown on a bigger jetpack designed for zooming around space, but Nasa stopped using those in the 1980s. In keeping with the rescue theme, Wisoff and Lopez-Alegria also planned to take turns acting as space lifeguards. One was to feign injury while the other carried him to safety, so Nasa could see how astronauts would handle an injured or incapacitated spacewalker.

Discovery's other spacewalkers, Leroy Chiao and Bill McArthur, ventured outside for their second spacewalk of the mission Tuesday. They mounted two power converters on the truss and connected a few cables. Their spacewalk lasted about 17 minutes beyond its scheduled 6 1/2 hours.

"That might be attributed to Bill and Leroy's reluctance to come inside. They did make some comments about that," Schuck said. "I really don't think that was a factor but I guess I can't blame them."

Because Discovery has boosted the station's orbit, the launch of the orbiting outpost's first permanent crew from Kazakstan has been delayed one day, to October 31, Nasa said. The three men will arrive at the station on November 2.

fields.headline: Antony Darnborough
fields.standfirst: Producer who brought a freshness to postwar British films
fields.trailText: Producer who brought a freshness to postwar British films
fields.body:
In the late 1940s, Somerset Maugham, still at the height of his fame, was prevailed upon by the film producer Antony Darnborough, who has died aged 86, to travel from the south of France to Pinewood studios to introduce, on film, four of his stories in Quartet (1948). It was a real coup for Darnborough, a hands-on operator conscious of the need for British films to make money in the United States - and aware that Maugham was even more popular in the US than in England.

Darnborough went to great lengths to reproduce Maugham's study in the studio, even duplicating his favourite chair with worn patches on the arms. The 74-year-old author was so impressed with the rejuvenating effect of his make-up that he told Darnborough: "I would wear it all the time if it were not for the possibility that people might get the wrong impression."

Darnborough had the largest say in the selection of the stories, which were four of Maugham's most celebrated: The Facts Of Life, The Alien Corn, The Colonel's Lady and The Kite, each contrasted in mood, pace and rhythm, and each directed by a different director (Ken Annakin, Harold French, Ralph Smart and Arthur Crabtree), with superb casts that included Cecil Parker, Nora Swinburne, Dirk Bogarde, George Cole, Mai Zetterling, Basil Radford and Naunton Wayne.

Quartet was a box-office hit, and Maugham was easily persuaded by Darnborough to return to do Trio (1950) and Encore (1951). The former was made up of The Verger, Mr Knowall and Sanatorium, while the latter consisted of The Ant And The Grasshopper, Winter Cruise and Gigolo And Gigolette. Again, excellent direction and fine casts - Nigel Patrick, Jean Simmons, James Hayter, Michael Rennie and Glynis Johns (to whom Darnborough was briefly engaged) - provided excellent entertainment.

Those three omnibus films were Darnborough's greatest successes in a career as a feature-film producer that ran from 1947 to 1956.

Darnborough was born in Weybridge, the son of wealthy parents. On leaving boarding school in St Albans, family connections got him a job as a Daily Mail gossip columnist, before wartime service in the Royal Artillery, during which he won a military cross.

After the war, with the help of his brother-in-law, the film conductor and composer Muir Mathieson, Darnborough became production manager for Sydney Box at Gainsborough studios. His first film as producer was The Calendar (1947), a good Edgar Wallace racetrack melodrama, which was followed by My Brother's Keeper (1948), an effective piece about two escaping convicts, Jack Warner and George Cole, handcuffed together. Shot on location, it had a fresh- ness which suggested a new sense of direction in British cinema.

Boys In Brown (1949), another realist film about criminals, now seems rather preachy and meek. The over-age borstal boys included whining Richard Attenborough, decent Jimmy Hanley, cocky Michael Medwin, and troublemaker Dirk Bogarde, with Jack Warner as their humane governor. Also among the boys was Graham Payn, Noel Coward's lover, trying to make a career as a film actor.

Coward also helped Payn get a role in The Astonished Heart (1950), an adaptation of his one-act play, which Darnborough produced and co-directed with Terence Fisher. After Coward, who wrote the screenplay and music, saw some of the rushes, he decided that Michael Redgrave was not right for the piece, and took over the part himself - giving one his most stilted performances.

Darnborough and Fisher also co-directed the intriguing So Long At The Fair (1950), based on the story of a man who disappeared without trace during the Paris Exhibition of 1889. It starred Jean Simmons and Dirk Bogarde.

The rest of Darnborough's productions were competent rather than sparkling: Highly Dangerous (1950), a cold- war drama with Margaret Lockwood; The Net (1952), an aeronautics melodrama in which a communist sympathiser has ideas of sabotage; To Paris With Love (1955), a lightweight comedy with Alec Guinness; and The Baby And The Battleship (1956), featuring John Mills and a cute Italian child afloat during the second world war.

In 1957, Darnborough formed a production company, which made documentaries and whisky advertisements. An excellent golfer and a lover of good wine, he is survived by Angela Beyfus, his wife for more than 40 years, and their son.

Antony Darnborough, film producer, born October 6 1913; died September 24 2000

webTitle: Bond issue to fund university rejig

fields.headline: Bond issue to fund university rejig
fields.standfirst: Cuts, property sales and city finance to fund Edinburgh's development of teaching and research facilities
fields.trailText: Cuts, property sales and city finance to fund Edinburgh's development of teaching and research facilities.
fields.body:
Edinburgh University announced yesterday that it is to use a bond issue to help fund a £40m radical reshaping of its teaching and research activities over the next seven years. The issue will run alongside cuts in staff numbers over the next four years, the jettisoning of some subjects and the selling off some of its large stock of buildings throughout the city.

The issue, which is being negotiated with a leading financial institution, would help sustain and develop Edinburgh's teaching and research to international standards of excellence, said the principal, Sir Stewart Sutherland.

"We are taking our future into our own hands after 20 years of cut, cut, cut. We are at the bone. To remain internationally competitive, we need an income stream," he said.

Student funding had fallen by 40% in real terms during that period and unless expenditure was reduced - or income boosted by - £3m a year the university would slide into deficit, he added.

Edinburgh is not the first university to raise money from a bond issue. Seven years ago, Lancaster raised £35m to expand and build student residences in a move that contributed to a financial crisis. After the university borrowed at 9.75% interest, the government capped student numbers and interest rates fell. Staff numbers had to be cut and departments closed.

Sir Stewart, however, insisted that Edinburgh could reach a good deal and added that the Scottish Higher Education Funding Council approved. "We are raising this money while we are in a position of strength and while rates are good, and we are investing on tough criteria," he said.

The new funds would not be used to plug gaps but to initiate activities that would bring a financial as well as academic return, or to rationalise activities and the use of buildings, he added.

As part of the plans, a new medical school being built as part of the city's new hospital will release Edinburgh's 19th century medical school for other uses and in turn make it possible to sell off commercially valuable property.

At the same time, the university is embarking on a drive to recruit 800 extra overseas students (paying full fees) and further fundraising from alumni. Research income and contracts negotiated via Edinburgh Research and Innovation would be increased from this year's record £108m, said Sir Stewart.

This summer Edinburgh announced it would no longer offer agriculture degrees - other courses are expected to follow from a university that has prided itself in offering the widest range of subjects in UK higher education, but is determined to compete with the "golden triangle" of Oxford, Cambridge and London.

webTitle: Slater savages Warne, Kartik takes nine

fields.headline: Slater savages Warne, Kartik takes nine
fields.standfirst: A new series begins today as wisden.com takes a weekly look at domestic cricket overseas, from the Pura Cup in Australia to the Quaid-e-Azam Trophy in Pakistan, from the Busta Cup in the West Indies to the Ranji Trophy in India. So log on every Wednesday to find out how the world's best cricketers are getting on in their own country
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Michael Slater gave the Australian one-day selectors selectors a sharp elbow in the ribs as New South Wales crushed neighbours Victoria in the Mercantile Mutual Cup at the North Sydney Oval. He hit 61, including 18 off an over from Shane Warne, as NSW raced to their target of 194 with more than 14 overs to spare. Under new laws this season, NSW became the first side to pick up a bonus point for scoring at least 1.25 times as quickly as their opponents.

Because of Australia's unexpected early departure from the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya, both teams had the luxury of fielding all their international players. But when Steve Waugh won the toss and asked Victoria to bat it was one of their lesser names that did the damage. Nathan Bracken, a 23-year-old left-arm seamer, took 4-36 as Victoria stumbled to 193. There were two wickets each for Shane Lee (2-33) and Stuart MacGill (2-40) but none for the international new-ball duo of Glenn McGrath and Brett Lee.

NSW began explosively in reply. Brad Haddin creamed 69 off just 52 balls and added 109 for the first wicket with Slater. Warne, on his comeback after undergoing shoulder surgery, conceded 47 runs from six wicketless overs and was swiftly removed from the attack. Steve Waugh and Michael Bevan wrapped up the match in style.

Victoria 193 in 48.5 overs (BJ Hodge 87)
*New South Wales 197-2 in 35.5 overs
New South Wales won by 8 wickets

South Australia recorded their first win of the season when they beat Tasmania in a thrilling rain-affected match in Adelaide. Set 249 to win, Tasmania were on course while Ricky Ponting (68) and Michael Di Venuto (124) were adding 137 for the second wicket. And Di Venuto was still there with 10 needed off the last five balls. But he was brilliantly run out by the South Australian wicketkeeper Graham Manou, before Jason Gillespie bowled Dene Hills for 1 with a ball to go. Damien Wright needed to hit a six off the final ball to force a tie, but could manage just two.

Earlier, SA made 248-6 off their 43 overs, with solid contributions from all the top order, although they were helped by some wayward bowling from the Tasmanians, who conceded 32 extras, including 23 in wides and no-balls. Gerard Denton, in his first match after a year's lay-off due to a back injury, conceded 40 off just three overs.

South Australia 248-6 in 43 overs (JM Vaughan 57, CJ Davies 54)
*Tasmania 244-5 in 43 overs
South Australia won by 4 runs

In the first-class Pura Cup, Queensland looked to be off to a flying start as they ran up 442 in their first innings against Western Australia at Perth, thanks mainly to 175 from Jimmy Maher and 128 from Stuart Law. The situation looked even brighter when they bowled WA out for 195 (Adam Dale 5-41) enforced the follow-on and then reduced them to 43/3 in their second innings.

It all started to go wrong after that, though, as a lifeless pitch and some uninspired bowling allowed Damien Martyn to dig in for 78, before an unbeaten sixth-wicket partnership of 166 between Durham's Simon Katich and Adam Gilchrist spared the Western Australian blushes. Katich's gritty 105 not out took nearly eight hours, while Gilchrist's unbeaten 109, including 15 fours, was more aggressive. He smashed Dale for four fours in succession, then hit him for three more in a row in Dale's next over.

Queensland 442
*Western Australia195 and 349-5
Match drawn
Queensland win on first-innings lead
Queensland 2pts, Western Australia 0

India

The Rest of India thrashed Mumbai by 10 wickets as the Indian season got under way with its traditional curtain-raiser, the Irani Trophy. Mumbai, who were playing because they won last year's Ranji Trophy, started slowly in their first innings, but 56 from Wasim Jaffer, plus a late flurry by Ramesh Powar (40) and a last-wicket stand of 42 between Nulesh Kulkarni (14*) and Santosh Saxena (27) edged them towards a respectable 260. Offspinner Sharandeep Singh (4-55) and slow left-armer Murali Kartik (4-73) were the best of the Rest. The Rest's first innings was tottering at 29-3 before VVS Laxman took over - he stroked his way to 167 with impeccable timing, taking few risks along the way, and was backed up by Mohammed Kaif (75), with whom he shared a fourth-wicket stand of 201, and Jacob Martin (51).

History beckoned in the Mumbai second innings, as Kartik picked up the first nine wickets in a bid to become only the fifth Indian to take all ten in a first-class game. It was not to be, though, as Singh snapped up the wicket of No. 11 Santosh Saxena for a first-ball duck. There was some consolation for Kartik as his figures of 9-70, coming off an unchanged spell of 24 overs, were a new record for the Irani Trophy. It gave him match figures of 13-143. The Rest, needing only 56 to win, quickly polished them off without loss to retain the trophy.

*Mumbai 260 and 184
Rest of India 389 and 58-0
Rest of India won by 10 wickets

Pakistan

There were runs aplenty in the opening round of matches in the first-class Quaid-e- Azam Trophy first division, with no fewer than 10 centuries in the six matches. There were big wins for Sargodha, who beat Sheikhupura, and Faisalabad, who defeated Gujranwala. And, in two high-scoring matches, Lahore Blues beat Lahore, while Karachi overturned Karachi Blues, the highlight of the match being scores of 100* and 50* for Hasan Raza, who made his Test debut four years ago at the alleged age of 14. Peshawar and Rawalpindi fought out a draw, as did Bahawalpur and Islamabad.

Sargodha 212 (Naveed Latif 64, Jaffer Nazir 6-62) and 254 (Misbah-ul-Haq 102, Kashif Raza 5-52)
*Sheikhupura 209 and 131 (Ahmed Hayat 5-62)

Lahore Blues won by 143 runs

*Bahawalpur 309 (Hamad Tariq 134, Kamran Hussain 53) and 19-0
Match drawn

West Indies

The new expanded Red Stripe Bowl is underway, with Canada, the USA, Bermuda and the Cayman Islands joining the six traditional regional sides. And USA caused the sensation of the early rounds by beating Barbados by two wickets at Sabina Park - their first win since joining the competition three years ago. Barbados, whose side contained five internationals, including Adrian Griffith and Philo Wallace, were skittled for 129 in 38 overs with spinner Rudy Narine taking 4-35. USA then reached 98-3, lost five wickets for 21, before sneaking home with one over to go.

Earlier in the competition, the underdogs all got off to the worst possible start, losing their first matches in one-sided fashion. Laurie Williams took 5-12 from 9 overs as Jamaica crushed the USA, and Carl Hooper played his first game after 'retiring' 18 months ago - he made 41 from just 43 deliveries as Guyana defeated the Cayman Islands.

Barbados scored only 185 against Trinidad and Tobago, but then dismissed them for 118. The absence of Brian Lara through injury helped. Jamaica, the defending champions, had big wins against the USA and Trinidad and Tobago, but crashed to a 49-run defeat against Barbados after four run-outs in the space of four overs.

South Africa

A rumbustious century by 37-year-old former international Mike Rindel helped Easterns to a formidable total of 232/9 off their 45 overs and set up victory against Kwa-Zulu Natal in the one-day Standard Bank Cup in Benoni. Rindel dominated the scoring: his 128 came off 139 balls and included 18 fours, and the next highest score was Derek Crookes' 37. In reply Kwa-Zulu Natal collapsed against the new-ball pairing of Kenny Benjamin, the former West Indian Test player, and Andre Nel, who each took 3-25 from 9 overs. The total of 153 could have been a lot worse had it not been for a last-wicket stand of 50 between Kyle Bender and Gary Gilder. Gilder, batting at No. 11, top-scored for Kwa-Zulu Natal with 36 off just 28 balls, including an astonishing four consecutive sixes off the bowling of offspinner Derek Crookes.

On a good batting pitch at Bloemfontein a Northern total of 191 never looked enough, but Free State made it hard for themselves, struggling to 194-7 with 11 balls left. Northerns had collapsed to 58-5 before Martin van Jaarsveld (88) and Finley Brooker (39) added 99 for the sixth wicket. Free State laboured in reply but wicketkeeper-captain Gerard Brophy pushed his side over the line with 47, to add to the five dismissals (four caught, one stumped) he had taken earlier in the day.

In an exciting finish Eastern Province dismissed Boland with one ball to go at Port Elizabeth to win by one run. Boland went into the last over with nine wickets down and needing six runs to win, but Henry Williams, recently banned from international cricket until the new year for his part in the Cronje affair, was run out off the penultimate ball with two needed. Mfuneko Ngam, a fast-medium right-armer who recently toured West Indies with South Africa A, took 4-26. Poor batting had earlier reduced Eastern Province to 45-6 in their innings, but they were rescued by Justin Kemp (95*) who put on an unbeaten 62 for the 8th wicket with Meyrick Pringle (25*).

fields.bodyText: Australia Michael Slater gave the Australian one-day selectors selectors a sharp elbow in the ribs as New South Wales crushed neighbours Victoria in the Mercantile Mutual Cup at the North Sydney Oval. He hit 61, including 18 off an over from Shane Warne, as NSW raced to their target of 194 with more than 14 overs to spare. Under new laws this season, NSW became the first side to pick up a bonus point for scoring at least 1.25 times as quickly as their opponents. Because of Australia's unexpected early departure from the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya, both teams had the luxury of fielding all their international players. But when Steve Waugh won the toss and asked Victoria to bat it was one of their lesser names that did the damage. Nathan Bracken, a 23-year-old left-arm seamer, took 4-36 as Victoria stumbled to 193. There were two wickets each for Shane Lee (2-33) and Stuart MacGill (2-40) but none for the international new-ball duo of Glenn McGrath and Brett Lee. NSW began explosively in reply. webTitle: Men In Black beats ITV 9pm news special

fields.headline: Men in Black sees off ITV 9pm news special
fields.trailText: 12.30pm overnights: ITV scheduled a 9pm news special last night, but BBC1 won peak time with its Men in Black movie premiere, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV scheduled a high-rating 9pm news special following the Hertfordshire rail crash last night, but BBC1 won peak time with the terrestrial premiere of Men In Black.

The ratings war between the two main channels stepped up another gear last night, with ITV scheduling the one-off 10-minute news bulletin in the aftermath of the latest rail tragedy, which claimed four lives.

The BBC dismissed the move as a one-off stunt, but the bulletin drew an audience 8.5m and a 34% audience share, according to unofficial overnights - huge numbers for news, even in peak time. An ITV source commented: "Clearly, the BBC would have hit at least 8m for their news had they been at 9pm."

But a BBC spokeswoman hit back, saying it would be "interesting to see whether ITV keeps the news at 9pm, if they are crowing about what big audiences are available".

Overall, BBC1 enjoyed an even more successful night for the second outing of its beefed-up Ten O'Clock News schedule, pulling off a rare Tuesday night peak time share victory over ITV. The channel had a 37% share of viewing in peak time (6-10.30pm), compared with only 26% last week. ITV slumped to 33%, after notching up 41.5% on Tuesday night last week.

Men in Black, the Hollywood blockbuster featuring Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones as alien-busting US government agents, led the BBC1 ratings charge. The film averaged 9.8m - 40% share - between 8.30-10pm.

The second BBC1 Ten O'Clock News bulletin was slightly up on Monday's opener, with 6.1m viewers and a 30% share, though a bigger audience might have been anticipated following the rail crash.

Earlier yesterday evening, the BBC1 Six O'Clock News audience was boosted to 7.2m and a 38% share, as people switched on to find out the latest on the GNER derailment. Last Tuesday the Six O'Clock News took 6.3m, while the old BBC1 Nine O'Clock News managed just 4.1m.

On ITV last night, before the specially scheduled 9pm news bulletin, The Bill majored on the continuing storyline of dodgy cop DS Beech's fall from grace. The ITV cop drama beat BBC1 sitcom My Family in its first half-hour, but fell behind Men In Black in its second half and averaged 8.5m and a 35% share overall.

From 9.10pm, after the news special, ITV repeated a 90-minute edition of A Touch of Frost, starring David Jason as grumpy northern detective Jack Frost. The drama was also beaten by Men in Black and drew an audience of 7.5m and a 33% share.

fields.headline: The Cops call it a day after three series
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The Cops, BBC2's critically-acclaimed police drama, will not be returning after the current run of specials finishes. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed that BBC2's critically-acclaimed drama, The Cops, will not be returning after the current run of specials finishes.

Two further two-part specials of the hard-hitting Tony Garnett-produced drama, which was shot in a hand-held documentary style on the streets of a north-west town, will be screened on BBC2.

But after that production will cease, a BBC spokesman confirmed. "Tony Garnett has always said he only wanted to do three series," he said.

The Cops was made by Mr Garnett's company, World Productions, and ran for two series in 1998 and 1999. The show returned earlier this autumn with a 2 x 50-minute format. The two remaining specials are thought likely to go out before the end of 1999 and in the first half of next year, respectively.

The BBC dismissed suggestions that the lack of police cooperation led to the demise of the series.

A spokesman said: "We didn't have a great deal of co-operation after the first series, but it was never a factor. There were plenty of people who'd left the force who were willing to tell how it really is."

fields.headline: BBC ditches Newsnight's regional opt-outs
fields.trailText: 8.45am: The controversial post-Newsnight opt-outs in Wales and Northern Ireland will not be replaced, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The controversial post-Newsnight opt-outs in Wales and Northern Ireland will not be replaced, although the corporation has admitted that it is considering changing the format of Newsnight Scotland.

BBC News has extended the regional bulletins which follow the main evening news programme at 10pm to 6.5 minutes. A spokesman for BBC nations and regions said: "Wales and Northern Ireland have been campaigning for a mainstream slot like this on BBC1 for a long time."

The move will be seen as a climbdown for the corporation's plan to have a regional current affairs opt-out on Newsnight. The opt-outs have been criticised by BBC journalists as unworkable and last year presenter Jeremy Paxman branded the regional opt-out for Scotland "a damn fool idea".

After the bulletin was launched, technical problems surrounding the handover from the main news bulletin to the regional opt-outs led some insiders to claim that Mr Paxman and others had deliberately sabotaged the bulletin, a claim that has always been denied.

The spokesman played down the move, saying that the regional slots at the end of Newsnight "were never Newsnight-branded".

John McCormick, BBC Scotland's controller, said in a statement: "Over the next two months we will be discussing the implications of the changes with the national governor, the Broadcasting Council for Scotland and colleagues. One of those discussions will be whether Newsnight Scotland remains broadly as is or, alternatively, whether we change the format and timing of the programme overall. What is not at issue is the programme's existence."

One of the plans under discussion for the programme is thought to be an earlier-evening current affairs programme for Scotland.

Meanwhile, Newsnight Scotland editor David Kerr has told BBC Scotland chiefs he is to step down in order to stand as a Scottish National Party candidate in the Falkirk west byelection. Mr Kerr is today expected to hear whether he has been selected.

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 19.
fields.trailText: October 19: OMD UK has lost £50m of business after Boots consolidated its marketing into WPP.
fields.body:
Marketing Week's lead story is that Boots' decision to consolidate all its marketing into WPP will see media agency OMD UK lose £50m of business.

Skoda swept the board at the Marketing Week/CIM Effectiveness Awards, winning the brand award in its category and the marketer of the year award as well as walking off with the Grand Prix.

Rover is reportedly ditching its no-frills advertising to focus on re-establishing the brand. Roster agency M&C Saatchi is working on a new TV campaign.

Toy manufacturer Mattel is expanding into clothing with the launch of a range of Fisher Price-branded children'swear.

Volkswagen has poached Alan Doyle from Yellow Pages to be its communications manager. Doyle, who is head of consumer marketing at Yellow Pages, replaces Bernard Bradley who left to join Volvo in July.

Vodafone is launching its biggest-ever campaign for pre-pay phones with a £12m advertising blitz to promote the Pay As You Talk service in the run-up to Christmas.

Granada Media and Boots are looking for an agency to promote the health and beauty venture they are setting up. The new company, which has yet to be named, will launch an interactive television channel and website specialising in health, beauty and wellbeing.

Saatchi & Saatchi has scooped the £15m task of launching Procter & Gamble's Physique haircare brand in the UK. The brand launches in January and will be supported by press and television advertising.

OMD UK is understood to have hired Nestle's UK media manager Matthew Pilcher for a senior international planning role.

fields.headline: TBWA creates Thomascook.com campaign
fields.trailText: 9.30am: TBWA is launching a national campaign for Thomascook.com, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
TBWA is launching a national press, outdoor and radio campaign for Thomascook.com as part of a £7m drive to establish the brand as the on and offline leader in the travel market.

The campaign, which breaks this week, will carry the tagline, "Why go anywhere else".

All advertising will focus on the company's winter sun and winter snow packages and will plug Thomas Cook's range of products and the knowledge and experience it can offer consumers. The campaign will run until the end of November.

Media planning and buying is through BLM.

fields.trailText: 8.45am: Ford and Vauxhall are trying to outdo each other with internet initiatives, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It was wing mirrors at dawn at the Birmingham Motor Show yesterday when Ford and Vauxhall, the UK's leading two car companies, tried to outdo each other with internet initiatives.

Vauxhall, which has been selling a limited range of models on the web for the past year, said it would include all new models from November and would sell cars online for 3.5% cheaper than in the traditional manner.

Not to be outdone, Ford announced it would sell cars via its website, and would start by selling new models of Ka, Puma, Focus and Fiesta at 5% cheaper than current prices.

Ford's website, Fordjourney.com, launches at the end of this month. The company said it expects to have its full range of new cars available for purchase online by summer next year.

Ian McAllister, chairman of Ford UK, said at the show: "Ford fully intends to be a leader in e-commerce on the internet."

Separately, Mazda has signed a deal with the car e-commerce site, Showroom4cars.com, which will see its UK dealerships becoming involved in the delivery of cars bought from the site, rather than completely being cut out of the equation.

fields.headline: Manifestos
fields.standfirst: Six candidates running for the Speaker's job have issued statements explaining why they think they should be elected. These are the key extracts.
fields.trailText: Six candidates running for the Speaker's job have issued statements explaining why they think they should be elected. These are the key extracts.
fields.body:
David Clark (Lab, South Shields)

 Promises to be a modernising Speaker, discarding 18th-century costume, including the wig, silk stockings and buckle shoes, for all but ceremonial occasions.
 Supports limited working hours, with Commons votes taking place by 10pm Monday-Wednesday and 7pm on Thursdays. Calls for family-friendly Commons, including facilities for children and childcare.
 Wants more power for select committees and the right for members to bring lap-top computers into committees. Believes MPs should have more resources to meet needs of constituents.

Sir Patrick Cormack (C, South Staffs)

 Favours "improvement" of Parliament, rather than modernisation, stressing that traditions should not be discarded for the sake of change.
 Wants the creation of a Speaker's Conference, bringing together members of all parties with the Speaker to discuss procedural changes.
 Supports improvements to Prime Minister's Question Time and changes to make it easier for backbenchers to be called to speak. Cautious about restrictions to working hours, stressing that "we must not forget that Parliament is not there for our convenience".

Gwyneth Dunwoody (Lab, Crewe & Nantwich)

 Wants to bring power back to the Commons by enhancing the role of backbench MPs in scrutinising measures proposed by government and European institutions, as well as giving them greater freedom from party discipline.
 Believes MPs should receive "adequate" pay and facilities to enable them to discharge their duties to constituents.
 Supports changes to working conditions to allow MPs to sustain personal and family lives in the way expected by ordinary working people.

Michael Lord (C, Central Suffolk & North Ipswich)

 Promises to be independent of mind and "jealously guard the rights of backbenchers", keeping the House of Commons separate from the government.
 Wants to see more pre-legislative scrutiny, more power for select committees and more help for new MPs when they arrive at Westminster.
 Says that MPs will be able to judge his fitness for the role of Speaker from his performance in three-and-a-half years as deputy speaker. Identifies fairness, firmness and a sense of humour as some of the qualities needed by the Speaker.

John Mcwilliam (Lab, Blaydon)

 Wants to reverse changes introduced by successive governments which have interfered with the role of the House in scrutinising the executive. Advocates a stronger role for select committees and the allocation of time for the Commons to debate their reports.
 Strongly supports modernisation to make the Commons more family-friendly, with fixed dates for recess linked to state-school holidays. Wants to sweep away "niggling and irrelevant" rules on MPs' attire and parliamentary language.
 Promises to use Speaker's powers to end "abuses" which lead to debates dragging on into the early hours of the morning. Calls for the introduction of timetables for debates on the floor of the House.

Nicholas Winterton (C, Macclesfield)

 Supports moves to make the experimental "parallel chamber" in Westminster Hall a permanent fixture of the Commons.
 Promises that he is "totally committed to the role of the House of Commons in holding the government of the day to account and properly scrutinising all legislation".

fields.headline: Revolution round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 18.
fields.trailText: October 18: Launch.com has recruited music journalists Jim Irvin and Barney Hoskins for the launch next year of a UK site.
fields.body:
US online music giant Launch.com is to launch a UK site next year. Noted music journalists such as Jim Irvin, former senior at Mojo, and Barney Hoskins, who worked at CDnow's ill-fated London operation, have been recruited to set it up.

SmithKline Beecham has launched Ribena.co.uk - the brand's first global consumer website.

French e-delivery service Koobuycity has denied rumours that it is in trouble after its UK site went out of action at the same time as competitors Urbanfetch and BagsofTime went out of business.

Online IT business exchange E-exchange is understood to have laid off all its UK staff after investors pulled out.

GMTV is moving into e-commerce and plans to push Gmtv.co.uk as a women's portal.

There is an interview with Alan McGee (on page 31) - now an internet man with Poptones.com.

Ben Way wins Revolution's award for Persistence In Staying Together (PIST for short) after surviving his strict "no sex, no booze" contract with his venture capitalists.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The Guardian carries a front-page story about Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman receiving the stolen Enigma machine in the post. (p1)
The paper reports that the BBC won the news ratings grudge match on the first day of the corporation's new-look schedule, with the new series of the Royle Family helping to draw viewers to the BBC's first Ten O'Clock News. (p11)
And British TV shows dominate the nominations for the international Emmy awards announced yesterday. Comedies Da Ali G Show and Smack the Pony and the dramas Longitude and Warriors were among them. (p11)
In the comment pages, Polly Toynbee says we urgently need more leftwing newspapers to counterbalance the predominantly right-wing press and urges "good owners" to step up for the Express. (p22)
The letters page carries the reaction of Tony Hall, the BBC's head of news, to Elizabeth Forgan's comments yesterday on the corporation's decision to move its news operation back to the centre of London. Mr Hall insists that building the news centre was not a mistake, rather it produced cost savings that enabled the BBC to invest in journalism. (p23)
The City pages report that the Hinduja brothers will today make their bid for the Express newspaper group. (p27)
And that, while ONdigital is now on target to have 1m subscribers by the end of the year, nearly one in five customers have allowed their contracts to lapse after just a year (p28)

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

The Financial Times puts a positive spin on the rise in ONdigital's subscriber numbers, saying the company is now close to its target of 1m. But it adds that analysts have expressed concern about a churn rate of close to 20%. (p33)
Procter & Gamble, the US consumer goods manufacturer, has said it is looking for internet investment opportunities in Europe. (p38)

THE INDEPENDENT

The Independent reports that Adam Singer, chief executive of Telewest, has ruled out a near-term merger with NTL, the biggest UK cable group, due to the companies' combined £13bn debt load. (p20)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

The Daily Telegraph also carries a story about Mr Paxman receiving the stolen Enigma machine in the post, under the headline: "Stolen Enigma machine sent by post to Paxman? Oh come off it." (p1)
And on the business pages the paper reports that Hollywood ticket.com, the interactive entertainment company backed by pop star Michael Jackson, is to lay off a quarter of its staff and become a business-to-business specialist. (p34)

THE TIMES

The parents of Siamese twins Jodie and Mary are reportedly close to selling their story to ITV. An exclusive interview with Trevor McDonald could be shown as early as tonight, according to The Times. (p3)
The BBC has accused ITV of using dirty tricks to scupper its first Ten O'Clock News by adding nearly four minutes to Who Wants to be a Millionaire? so that it overran the news bulletin's start time. (p8)

THE DAILY MAIL

Ephraim Hardcastle has a dig at the Express, saying potential buyers include Harrods boss Mohamed Al Fayed, soft porn expert Richard Desmond of Northern & Shell and the Hinduja brothers, sponsors of the Millennium Dome's ill-regarded Faith Zone. "Do you suppose we might hear from Saddam Hussein before bidding closes?" he asks. (p15)
And The Daily Mail says the viewing public has gone off actor Robson Green, who has a £3.75m "golden handcuffs" deal with ITV. Mr Green's recent outings have not performed well, leaving ITV bosses with egg on their faces, according to the paper. (p46)

THE DAILY EXPRESS

The Daily Express reports that "Nasty" Nick Bateman's eviction from Big Brother has been voted one of television's top 10 live events in a survey commissioned to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the first television broadcast. The schemin' stockbroker beat Live Aid and the fall of the Berlin Wall. (p23)
Graham Lord writes a double-page feature on how Richard Whiteley became a king of daytime television. (p32)

THE MIRROR

Eamonn Holmes, who co-hosted GMTV with Anthea Turner, revealed yesterday that long-suffering GMTV staff dubbed her Tinkerhell. (p9)

THE SUN

The Sun carries exclusive pictures of the new-look Homepride cartoon mascot. The flour brand is updating its image in a £3m campaign featuring the bowler-hatted Fred in a variety of more modern outfits. (p9)

AND FINALLY

The Star reports that BBC bosses are moving Anne Robinson's hit tea-time gameshow, the Weakest Link, to a peaktime slot. The show will go up against ITV's Fat Friends and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? on Tuesdays and Thursdays. (p6)

webTitle: Murdoch warning over News Corp earnings

fields.headline: Record advertising for Murdoch titles
fields.trailText: 9.30am: News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch has warned of uncertainty in the company's projected earnings for 2000-1, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch has warned of some uncertainty in the company's projected earnings for the 2000-1 financial year, while praising the performance of UK newspaper subsidiary News International.

Mr Murdoch - speaking at News Corp's annual general meeting in Adelaide, Australia, earlier today - was upbeat about the firm's UK newspaper business, commenting that "our advertising is running at record levels and we're ahead of our budget".

But he was unwilling to make firm predictions about News Corp's overall performance for the current financial year. Mr Murdoch pointed to the Fox TV broadcasting business in the US, which was facing a weaker advertising market after a strong start to the year.

However, he said that News Corp's US TV business would enter 2001 in a much stronger position than the year before, with 19 Fox shows playing in prime time across five US networks. He also predicted that Fox News Channel would reach break-even by the second quarter of 2000-1.

Mr Murdoch declined to give firm forecasts for the company's film business subsidiary, Fox, after a poor performance last year with the box office failure of animation Titan AE. But he noted that Fox had enjoyed recent success with X-Men and Big Momma's House.
