webTitle: After the turmoil, a scramble to safety

fields.headline: After the turmoil, a scramble to safety
fields.standfirst:
A queue for lunch then chaos as passengers flung in all directions

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The 12.10 Leeds-bound train was just 20 minutes into its journey from King's Cross when the buffet car opened for lunchtime passengers who started queueing up in the corridor.
fields.byline: Keith Perry, Steven Morris and Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
The 12.10 Leeds-bound train was just 20 minutes into its journey from King's Cross when the buffet car opened for lunchtime passengers who started queueing up in the corridor.

As the 450-seat GNER high-speed express reached its maximum speed of 115mph, a deafening bang shook the carriages. The train lurched violently to one side, throwing passengers to the floor.

Two of the train's eight coaches slewed off the track and slid along the ground tearing the roof from the buffet car and sending a shower of sparks and gravel into the air. Four passengers were killed instantly, some of them hurled on to the track.

A moment's silence was followed by moaning and stirrings of panic. A guard in carriage D ordered passengers to remain where they were, even though they tilted crazily at a 45-degree angle.

Dazed and bloodied, survivors among the 200 passengers started to climb out as the screams of the trapped and injured sounded from within the wrecked middle carriages. Many, including the driver, were able to walk to safety.

Stephen Morgan, a passenger on the derailed train, said: "I just heard a big bang and then just everything went - the train went over on its side. A couple of carriages went over, I grabbed the nearest thing I could to get myself a little bit of comfort and luckily I came through all right.

"The door was on its side so we managed to get that open to get some air in there, in case there was any fire. It was mayhem. There were ladies crying and everything.

"We saw a few people down near the bar area, near the buffet, and we couldn't get in to them because it was mangled up, so I think that's probably where it happened, where people died."

Another passenger, Justin Rowlatt, a Channel 4 news reporter, said: "I felt the train go right along the gravel as it came off the rails. It slewed in the gravel and the windows were smashing.

"As we disembarked, you could see there was debris all over the track and we realised quite how serious the accident had been.

"The roof of one carriage had been pulled off as if it was a sardine can. I looked into the carriage and you could see the twisted metal of the seats. There were bags and newspapers everywhere.

"Our carriage was upright. The carriage beyond me was lying at 45 degrees and the next one was on its side. The buffet car beyond that had its roof ripped off."

As the light faded over the Hertfordshire countryside last night, the 11 carriages of the class 91 train lay sprawled along the track.

The yellow front of the electric locomotive that had been pulling the train was clearly visible 200 yards south of Hatfield station. Behind the locomotive the two carriages, bearing the red striped livery of GNER trains remained upright. The third carriage behind the engine was askew, and the one behind that even more so. The next carriage was upright. Then 100 yards further back, resting on its side in bushes, was another carriage, its underneath facing the track. Its wheels, known as bogies, had been ripped off.

Walking wounded

Investigators will be examining how the bogies, which weigh eight tons, came to be separated from the carriage. The train had been travelling along one of the country's busiest rail lines, with trains passing every two to three minutes. The short stretch of track had four lines, with the GNER service travelling on the third. After the crash, around 150 "walking wounded" were taken by bus and ambulance to the University of Hertfordshire's conference centre two miles away.

Doctors attending a conference helped tend the injured people. Student nurses from the university and local St John Ambulance staff also rushed to the centre.

Insurance company manager Greg Johnson, 49, was on his way to visit his mother in Boston, Lincolnshire, after the death of his father the previous night.

He said: "I had just got the laptop out when there was a big bang. It was a bit like air turbulence - there were shudders and shakes and then rapid deceleration. It was a very strange feeling, surreal almost. It became clear that we had come off the rails but we managed to stay upright. There were one or two screams but nobody lost their cool totally. A few windows came in, I suppose because they were hit by stones and we ended up at a list.

"The railway authorities seemed to be on the scene very quickly, telling us to stay calm. They got us out and on to the side of the track. Behind me there were carriages on their sides and several hundred yards further down it seems like there was one carriage totally detached."

Nick Sutch, 22, a student, was travelling from his home in Camberley, Surrey, to Hull university after an operation. He was sitting on one of the pull-down seats in between two carriages in front of the buffet car and first class section.

He said: "The train was going quite fast and it was like it hit something on the track. There was a loud bang, smoke and I was thrown on to the floor of the carriage. It seemed like there was a lot of noise, a lot of screaming and panic, though not many people seemed badly injured on my coach. I was struggling because of my crutch but somebody broke a window and helped me out."

As police and fire crews picked their way through the wreckage, investigators searched the scene for possible causes.

Police confirmed that a bomb threat had been made against the King's Cross to Peterborough line two days ago.

Speaking near the crash scene, assistant chief constable Paul Nicholas, of British transport police, said: "Terrorism is always a possibility as well as vandalism. We are carrying out inquiries and the Metropolitan police will be involved.

Johnson Cox, director of operations for Railtrack, said: "It is too early for us to be able to comment on what may have caused the derailment. The site is at the moment in the hands of the emergency services and as soon as we can we will be carrying out a full investigation."

Later, it emerged that another high-speed GNER train was derailed on the same track 20 miles away in June 1998, slightly injuring nine people, according to the Health and Safety Executive.

Last night doctors said that three people who had been seriously injured could remain in hospital for up to three weeks. One woman in her 30s had a broken rib and a punctured lung, a man, 41, with a broken leg and a woman, 62, with a fractured spine. They are being treated at the Queen Elizabeth II hospital in Welwyn Garden City, Herts.

A further 11 men and 12 women aged between 20 and 65, were being treated at the hospital for cuts, bruises and whiplash. Staff at the Lister hospital in Stevenage treated seven people for minor injuries.

fields.headline: Street fighters defy peace deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: It didn't look like a ceasefire: a dozen young Palestinians, whirling slings at the Israeli blockhouse and waiting for the familiar crack of rifle fire from the concrete tower.
fields.body:
It didn't look like a ceasefire: a dozen young Palestinians, whirling slings at the Israeli blockhouse and waiting for the familiar crack of rifle fire from the concrete tower.

With the ink barely dry on the Sharm al-Sheikh agreement, Rachel's Tomb on the outskirts of Bethlehem was as much as a battleground yesterday afternoon as has been at any time in the bloody fortnight preceding it.

Two Palestinians died and one Israeli was critically injured even before Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat flew home. And defiant voices on the ground insisted that whatever the summiteers had promised, violence would go on.

"They have to put an end to the Israeli occupation," Marwan Barghouti, leader of the Tanzim militia, declared. It is the Tanzim gunmen, ostensibly loyal to Mr Arafat and his Fatah group, who have been shooting at Israeli forces on an unprecedented scale - and drawing deadly fire in return.

"If they didn't deal with this issue, they didn't succeed," Mr Barghouti added. "The peaceful intifada will continue."

But peaceful it wasn't: across the wadi from Rachel's Tomb, between Palestinian Beit Jallah and the Israeli neighbourhood of Gilo, built on occupied land but now annexed to Jerusalem, machine-gun fire brought Israeli tanks into action.

As terrified civilians fled outlying streets, an Israeli border policemen was shot. In all, 160 families were evacuated, a development which will increase Israeli fears.

Later, senior army officers warned ominously that if Jews were forced to leave their homes - just 15 minutes from central Jerusalem - the same would happen to Palestinians.

"As long as there's still shooting this summit agreement is just talk," one Gilo resident, Rami Meyer, said. "Barak signed and right away they opened fire."

If implementation on the ground is the test of Sharm al-Sheikh, the omens were bad. Mr Barghouti's men will have to be disarmed, or at least stop firing, and abide by "detailed security understandings".

Without that, Israel will clearly not feel bound to withdraw its tanks and heavy weapons - now stationed at roadblocks and outside most Palestinian cities.

"Fatah people and supporters were against the summit and we know that Arafat went there because of pressure on him," Bassam Naim, the Fatah leader in the West Bank town of Nablus, said. "We cannot accept the resumption of security coordination."

The trouble yesterday at Rachel's Tomb followed a wearily familiar pattern: 11 Palestinians were reported wounded as they hurled stones and petrol bombs at an army post.

In a vicious, self-perpetuating cycle, it followed the death of a 15-year-old Muayed Darwish on Monday. He was shot dead as he took aim with a molotov cocktail from behind a makeshift barricade. As the boy from the Aida refugee camp was buried, mourners shouted: "No to Sharm al-Sheikh, yes to armed struggle."

"Nothing will change now," one middle-aged onlooker said. "Peace is for Arafat and Barak, but not for our people."

Outside Nablus, a Palestinian farmer, named as Farid Nasrara, 28, was killed by Jewish settlers, who were later arrested. Three other villagers were injured.

Palestinian witnesses said the shooting was unprovoked and that the man was simply picking olives. But Yehoshua Mor-Yosef, a settler spokesman, insisted the farmers had first attacked with knives and iron bars, and that the settlers had fired warning shots in the air before aiming.

In the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian was killed and 10 more were hurt as hundreds threw stones at the Israeli military checkpoint at Erez. The army said a sniper also injured a firebomb thrower.

The Israelis say they are firing rubber-coated bullets at firebomb throwers in order to minimise casualties - a claim greeted with incredulity by Palestinians, the UN and human rights groups.

Security officials from both sides were due to meet last night to hammer out the understandings promised at the summit. The details will not be released.

Pro-peace Israelis, devastated by recent events, said a ceasefire was not enough. Peace Now called for the disarming of Jewish settlers as a well as the Tanzim militia. "Armed militias on the West Bank are a clear and present danger to the peace process and to Israel's security," it said.

webTitle: Broken wheel or rail may be to blame

fields.headline: Broken wheel or rail may be to blame
fields.standfirst:
Tough questions loom for GNER or Railtrack

Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: A cracked wheel or a broken rail were last night put forward as the two most likely reasons for the derailment.
fields.body:
A cracked wheel or a broken rail were last night put forward as the two most likely reasons for the derailment.

If the culprit turns out to have been a broken wheel or detached axle, GNER will face some difficult questions. It operates the east coast main line franchise from London to Edinburgh and the north of Scotland and has applied to the shadow strategic rail authority to extend its franchise.

Its record on the line has been good until recently, but the SSRA will want guarantees about future performance.

Broken rails are a continuing problem for the industry. Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, has told Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, that he is unhappy at the growing incidence, and that unless Railtrack acts quickly he will issue an enforcement order.

The discovery of a broken rail would almost certainly be blamed on Railtrack. It would place Mr Corbett in an increasingly invidious position.

Broken rails are partly a legacy of privatisation and underinvestment by Railtrack in the rail infrastructure. It has been accused of being slow off the mark, with parts of the industry worse off than before privatisation.

The wheel theory was put forward by railway experts based on a similar crash two years ago when a high-speed train operated by GNER was derailed at Sandy in Bedfordshire. The derailment in June 1998 took place as the train was on its way from King's Cross to Edinburgh. Nine passengers received minor injuries.

The railway inspectorate found that a fractured wheel from the one derailed carriage had caused the accident. The rolling stock on the Sandy train and the Hatfield train are said to be similar. At the time, the inspectorate chief Vic Coleman said the wheels - known as bogies - and wheelsets on the Sandy train were only used by GNER in the UK.

Mr Coleman ordered the removal of all coaches and said they would only be allowed back into service once each wheel had been checked for signs of deterioration.

The inspectorate also changed the rules governing inspections, which means that wheelsets are now examined every 10 days instead of every 90 days.

If a cracked wheel is found to have caused the accident, the inspectorate will want to know if the train's wheels had been checked regularly.

One of the early theories for the crash yesterday was vandalism. This followed local reports that the incidence of vandalism on the line has been increasing. But the theory was seen as unlikely when became known that the front of the train had escaped without damage.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Britain's Colt Telecom Group has opened Austria's largest internet hosting centre, which houses computers, covers some 7,000 sq metres and can hold 2,000 processing "racks".
fields.body:
 New centre

Britain's Colt Telecom Group has opened Austria's largest internet hosting centre, which houses computers, covers some 7,000 sq metres and can hold 2,000 processing "racks".

The company said it plans to have up to 12 hosting centres around Europe by the end of 2000.

 Product

The US technology group 3Com has introduced a home internet appliance called Audrey which provides e-mail, web access, address book, and can communicate with personal digital assistants. Audrey costs $499 (£276).

 Joint venture

Japan's Nippon Television Network has applied to create jointly with other companies a cable satellite broadcasting business to be launched by March 2001.

webTitle: Eyewitness account of the Hatfield crash

fields.headline: 'The train juddered, screeched and jumped around like a rollercoaster'
fields.standfirst:
Eyewitness: Passenger tells of shock and relief

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The wail of sirens pierced the silence as the police helicopter came into view, dipping and ducking to examine the twisted trunk of the train.
fields.body:
The wail of sirens pierced the silence as the police helicopter came into view, dipping and ducking to examine the twisted trunk of the train.

Fifteen long minutes earlier, the 12.10 GNER King's Cross to Leeds train had juddered, screeched and jumped around in a gruesome parody of a rollercoster to a topsy turvy, silent halt.

"Nobody move," screamed a guard, "Stay in the carriage. I repeat, nobody move."

Nobody was listening. Amid strangled cries of relief and uncontrolled sobbing, the passengers of Coach D scrabbled under seats for missing laptops, handbags and phones before clambering up along the aisle, now at 45 degrees, and helped each other over a pile of suitcases 6ft high.

An elderly man banged frantically on the door release button. I smelled and saw smoke rising above the blackened window; eventually, the door creaked slowly ajar.

One by one, we leapt on to the tracks and huddled, like refugees, on the stony side of a steep and thorny-hedged embankment.

From our vantage point, we could see the locomotive and first two carriages, still upright in the sunshine. The tilt started with the third carriage, while the back of the train lay smashed and broken across the rails.

Behind me, a woman in a pressed white shirt, now blackened with grease and mud, cradled a member of the train's crew. The attendant had lost several layers of skin on her right hand; her forearm was seared and raw.

Beyond her, a portly man in an expensive suit, tie still impeccably knotted, clutched a mobile phone to his black and bleeding ear.

Next to him, a young shaven-headed chef sucked on an unlit cigarette. His hand was swathed in a makeshift bandage and his chequered pants were spattered with blood and soot.

The Welwyn fire brigade arrived at the same time as a group of schoolboys, jeering and sniggering on the road below.

Murmurs of dialogue got louder and louder as we were herded off the tracks to the far bank. "I'm fine thank goodness." - "The third derailment in two days." - "Ladbroke Grove." - "At least two, I heard."

We were taken to a conference centre, where there was tea and coffee. Over the loudspeaker came a voice, asking repeatedly for a passenger to come forward. Everyone looked at each other, silently relieved they were not asking for us.

webTitle: Third crash in three years as safety remains second best

fields.headline: Third crash in three years as safety remains second best
fields.standfirst:
Little has changed after Southall and Paddington

Special report: Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The Hatfield crash could not have come at a worse time for Britain's rail industry. After Southall and Paddington, this is the third serious accident in little over three years, and public confidence in the industry is shattered.
fields.body:
The Hatfield crash could not have come at a worse time for Britain's rail industry. After Southall and Paddington, this is the third serious accident in little over three years, and public confidence in the industry is shattered.

Hatfield happened as the industry appeared to be recovering after its fragmentation following privatisation four years ago. Passenger numbers have risen by 30%, more than £30bn is to be invested in the industry by the government over the next five years and numbers are forecast to rise by a further 50% over the next 10 years.

But the break-up has led to poor control. Railtrack, which operates track and signalling, has been a law unto itself, a private monopoly which bristles at regulation; the shadow strategic rail authority, a hybrid son of British Rail, has no strategy; and the 25 rail companies are either dominantly healthy or about to call it a day.

Southall and Paddington highlighted gross deficiencies in rail safety. At Southall a driver passed through a red signal; the safety devices on his train which could have prevented the accident were not working.

Paddington exposed even more critically the limitations of the privatised railway. A poorly trained driver passed through a red signal; he was unfamiliar with the key section of line outside one of Britain's biggest stations.

The track outside Paddington had been remodelled to incorporate the new Heathrow Express. Railtrack and the industry did nothing to deal with expressions of concern about signal siting and the number of signals passed at red. In other words, the new loosely knit industry messed up.

The crashes at Paddington and Southall exposed the lack of investment in safety. Instead of installing the expensive but superior system recommended 11 years ago after the Clapham rail crash, the industry and the government are still toying with a cheaper, less reliable alternative.

It will cost around £400m to install and requires a further three years before it is adopted on wide sections of the rail way. Relatives of those killed at Paddington have called for the adoption of the automatic train protection system, at a cost of between £1b and £2bn. ATP is widely used in Europe, but the British are waiting for a more sophisticated model.

Another key aspect of rail disasters is the inordinate amount of time it takes to identify the cause of a tragedy and then to apportion blame. The role of the railway inspectorate has also been exposed. Pitifully undermanned, the inspectorate has belatedly been told by the government that it can double its numbers from 70 to 140 between now and 2002. But this action has been forced on ministers after the inspectors were shown to be unable to carry out their job in the lead-up to Paddington.

Another common thread running through the sorry history of Southall, Paddington and now Hatfield is underinvestment. Parts of the railway are still worse than before privatisation, and Guardian reports over the past three years have constantly underlined how railway staff have been struggling to maintain an inadequately funded industry.

The government has to take its share of the blame. After Paddington, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, declared that money would be no object in ensuring the safety of the railway.

What the government should have been saying was that it could not transform the industry overnight. Ministers misled the public into thinking that it was about to undo the evils of privatisation. But having set its face against renationalisation its hands were tied.

The rail companies have been given watertight franchises for between seven and 15 years and continuing subsidies, allowing the better off among them to make good profits.

Second-best safety equipment, ageing rollingstock and a poorly maintained track expose the frailties of the system as a rising number of passengers use it.

The government would dearly like a short-term fix for the railway, but Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, says he cannot throw money at it and expect overnight miracles.

The sad fact is that despite new large-scale investment it will take some years before passengers see a marked improvement in performance. The railway is going to get worse before it gets better, as official statistics from the SSRA confirm.

fields.headline: Paxman's post solves Enigma riddle
fields.trailText: Jeremy Paxman is a man rarely lost for words. The six he chose yesterday, which heralded the reappearance of the Enigma encryption machine stolen six months ago, hardly needed decoding by staff at Station X.
fields.body:
Jeremy Paxman is a man rarely lost for words. The six he chose yesterday, which heralded the reappearance of the Enigma encryption machine stolen six months ago, hardly needed decoding by staff at Station X.

"What the bloody hell is this?" he roared as he ripped into the large package encased in brown paper and bubblewrap that was sent to him at the BBC.

It was not, as some colleagues had suspected, a present from an admirer, but something of far greater journalistic value - a scoop.

The Enigma machine was captured by the Royal Navy in 1941 and then used to crack German codes. It is believed to be the one stolen from Bletchley Park museum on April Fool's Day. The museum received threats in the post demanding a £25,000 ransom or the Enigma machine would be smashed up. The museum agreed to hand over £25,000, but a deadline expired on October 6, and contact with the letterwriter ended.

Paxman does not know why the Enigma machine was sent to him. It arrived on Friday, hidden inside three boxes. "I was away in Manchester filming University Challenge," he said. "Someone pointed it out to me when I got in today."

A careful inspection showed the machine had the same serial number as the one which disappeared from the museum at Bletchley Park. There was nothing else with it.

Thames Valley detectives will examine the machine but police are cautiously optimistic that this is the genuine decoder.

webTitle: Train hit minibus trapped on line

fields.headline: Train hit minibus trapped on line
fields.trailText: A group of minibus passengers cheated death by seconds yesterday when they left the vehicle moments before a 60mph train ploughed into it.
fields.body:
A group of minibus passengers cheated death by seconds yesterday when they left the vehicle moments before a 60mph train ploughed into it.

Nine passengers were on the No 41 minibus when it became trapped by the automatic barriers at a level crossing at Pooley Green, near Egham, Surrey, at 9.15am. As an empty commuter train bore down on them, its horn blaring, the bus driver led them to safety.

The impact derailed the front carriage of the eight-car South West Trains train. It was left lying across the tracks at an angle of 30 degrees, blocking the line in both directions. The train shunted the bus 70 yards across gardens and into the wall of a nearby cottage.

The train driver suffered minor cuts and bruises but refused hospital treatment.

Her Majesty's rail inspectorate launched an investigation.

webTitle: Royle flush of victory for BBC in news war

fields.headline: Royle flush of victory for BBC in news war
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC won the news ratings grudge match in the first day of the corporation's relaunched peak-time schedule, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
The BBC won the news ratings grudge match in the first day of the corporation's relaunched peak-time schedule, according to figures released yesterday.

The results meant a huge fillip for the new controller of BBC1. Jim Royle might well have broken wind and declared, "Ratings, my arse", but Lorraine Heggessey was more measured in her reaction to the news that this hit comedy had helped deliver more than 6m viewers to the start of the first-ever Ten O'Clock News. "I couldn't have had a better first night," she said.

But public relations machines went into overdrive, ITV and the BBC each accusing the other of foul play.

ITV claimed a narrow victory for Monday night as a whole, helped by massive ratings for Coronation Street and the underhand tactic of slipping an extra commercial break into Who Wants To Be A Millionaire. The hit quiz show ran over by four minutes, meaning viewers who then turned to BBC1 missed the start of the 10pm news.

But the BBC showed it could play dirty too. It transmitted One Foot in the Grave two minutes early, hooking in viewers just before 9pm who might otherwise have turned over to Chris Tarrant on ITV. The BBC explained the anomaly by claiming the Royle Family - which followed the antics of Victor Meldrew - was slightly longer than expected.

Unofficial ratings showed that One Foot in the Grave drew 10.2m viewers at 9pm, double the audience for the old Nine O'Clock News and pulling off a rare feat for a BBC1 show by beating Millionaire on ITV.

A record 8.4m sat through the Royle Family, and more than 6m watched the start of the Ten O'Clock News. The bulletin averaged 5.9m, which was higher than this year's 5.1m average for the 9pm incarnation. BBC1's main news bulletins at 6pm and 10pm drew a combined audience of 12.1m, easily beating ITV's 9m for the 6.30pm and 11pm news programmes.

The BBC achieved its two main aims for the new schedule, rushed through by the director general Greg Dyke - increasing the audience for the late evening news and boosting ratings for the 9pm to 10pm slot. But ITV managed to maintain its traditional lead across the evening, with a peak time share of 36.3%, against BBC1's 32.8%.

Mark Thompson, the BBC's director of television, said: "Although it's very early days in a very long game, it is very encouraging to see that a significant number of viewers will turn to a Ten O'Clock News." An ITV spokesman commented: "ITV remained Britain's most popular channel despite the BBC throwing their strongest programmes at us. It was the one night they thought they would win. They must be disappointed."

The BBC will increase the stakes in two weeks' time with an hour-long EastEnders special in peak time. It is also screening several editions of its hit daytime quiz, The Weakest Link, in the evening.

ITV claimed the ratings battle was a betrayal of corporation's public service values, while the BBC said its rival was just running scared. Yet some at the BBC question whether it can keep its strong position. There are only a limited number of hit comedy episodes, and few blockbuster films. Its main drama series are 50 minutes long, causing headaches for schedulers trying to fill the key 9pm to 10pm slot.

(9pm-9.30pm 9.4m; 9.30-10pm, 10.9m)

webTitle: Kostunica fails to win over Montenegro on first visit

fields.headline: Kostunica fails to win over Montenegro on first visit
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's president, Vojislav Kostunica, failed yesterday to persuade the leaders of Serbia's small sister republic of Montenegro to join the next federal government of Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's president, Vojislav Kostunica, failed yesterday to persuade the leaders of Serbia's small sister republic of Montenegro to join the next federal government of Yugoslavia.

After a visit of several hours, he secured only an agreement to keep talking: "I am satisfied and when the talks become fruitful you will be informed," he told reporters.

The Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, who applauded the democratic changes in Serbia since Mr Kostunica took office on October 7, said he would take part in national institutions only if Yugoslavia's two republics redefined their relationship.

While Mr Djukanovic politely referred to Mr Kostunica as president, the Montenegrin government itself declared last month's elections in Yugoslavia illegal and refused to recognise Mr Kostunica as the new Yugoslav president.

Mr Djukanovic himself remains angry about a plan by Mr Kostunica's allies to offer the position of prime minister of Yugoslavia to his Montenegrin rivals, who had supported Slobodan Milosevic.

Mr Kostunica's task was delicate; any move by Montenegro to secede would destroy Yugoslavia and undermine the basis of his rule.

Yet, short of a risky lurch towards independence - which would be opposed by the Yugoslav army, western governments and a large part of Montenegro's people - President Djukanovic's government has few bargaining cards.

Mr Milosevic's defeat has left it nervous and uncertain. While he was in power in Serbia, western states flattered and supported Mr Djukanovic and poured money into the small territory, which has a population of 600,000 compared to Serbia's 10m. Now the west's attentions have turned to Belgrade.

Montenegro not only fears a loss of aid but also increasing pressure from the west to forge close links with Serbia and drop its aim of turning Yugoslavia into a loose federation of two sovereign states, let alone any thought of independence.

Montenegro's relations with Belgrade are also in crisis. Mr Djukanovic did not recognise the last Yugoslav government on the grounds that Mr Milosevic formed it illegally by appointing the Montenegrin opposition leader, who heads the pro-Belgrade party, as prime minister.

Similarly, he boycotted the elections which brought Mr Milosevic's downfall on the grounds that the constitution had been changed illegally. As a result, Mr Djukanovic has no MPs in the federal parliament.

Worse still, Mr Kostunica has said that - like Mr Milosevic - he will nominate a leader of the pro-Belgrade party as federal prime minister. (By convention, when the president is a Serb, the premier is Montenegrin).

Mr Djukanovic had urged Mr Kostunica to appoint a non-political "government of experts" to avoid the issue, but the Yugoslav president needs the pro-Belgrade party to give him a majority in parliament.

After a five-hour crisis meeting with senior ministers on the eve of Mr Kostunica's visit, President Djukanovic decided to heed western warnings to be patient and supportive of Belgrade.

The Yugoslav army also remains an irritant to the Montenegrins.

The Yugoslav Second Army, which is based in Montenegro, was regularly used by Mr Milosevic as a pressure point. Mr Djukanovic was also concerned when the army last year created a special paramilitary force, the seventh battalion. It was seen as a weapon for mounting a coup.

The least the Montenegrin government wants immediately is the disbandment of the seventh battalion, and the withdrawal of the extra troops sent to Montenegro on the eve of last month's elections.

But General Nebojsa Pavkovic, the long-time Milosevic loyalist whom Mr Kostunica seems unwilling to sack as army chief of staff said this weekend: "The extra troops will remain until the relevant political decisions are taken."

webTitle: When the Queen met the Pope ...

fields.headline: When the Queen met the Pope ...
fields.standfirst:
Noble sentiments and mumbled greetings

Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Two elderly heads of state met across a wooden table in the Vatican and exchanged pleasantries. As they were the Pope, supreme head of the Roman Catholic Church, and the Queen, Defender of the Faith and head to the Church of England, the pleasantries came in sealed white envelopes.
fields.body:
Two elderly heads of state met across a wooden table in the Vatican and exchanged pleasantries. As they were the Pope, supreme head of the Roman Catholic Church, and the Queen, Defender of the Faith and head to the Church of England, the pleasantries came in sealed white envelopes.

The Pope handed his to the Queen. The letter inside told her of the pontiff's wish for "ever more perfect communion" between Catholicism and Anglicanism: "There can be no turning back from the ecumenical goal we have set ourselves in obedience to the Lord's command ... a unity capable of excluding forever the kind of conflicts which have been so much a part of its past."

In reply, the letter inside the Queen's envelope spoke of her trust that the two religions would continue "to advance along the path that leads to Christian unity" and offered grateful thanks for the Pope's help and support for the peace process in Northern Ireland: "Many share a sense of real hope now, although there is so much still to do."

By such means do two such sovereigns communicate. If it was less than British diplomats had been predicting - even such banalities as were expressed were still being drafted and amended a few hours before the meeting - it was perhaps the surest means of communicating.

During the Queen's 24 minute private meeting in the papal library, she may have struggled to catch what the 80-year-old pontiff was saying, although he was apparently speaking in English.

Looking frail and bowed, his left hand shaking, Pope John Paul II struggled to the door of his library to greet the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh with a handshake before escorting them inside. Those allowed to watch observed the Queen to say loudly and slowly: "It is a great pleasure to see you again."

The Pope then mumbled something which may have been: "Last time we met ..." before the Queen interrupted brightly to finish the sentence: "Was at Buckingham Palace, wasn't it?"

Later came the exchange of gifts - 50 facsimile prints of Canaletto drawings bound in leather for the Pope, and a facsimile copy of a 13th century illuminated New Testament from the papal library for the Queen.

The Queen said: "We have a huge collection of Canalettos and I hope this will be of interest for the library here." Then accepting the red-leather bound Bible: "How very kind, how generous, what wonderful illustrations. These will go back into our library at Windsor."

Yesterday's meeting came 20 years to the day since the Queen last visited the Vatican to meet John Paul II - now eighth longest reigning pope in history - although the two did last meet in London during the papal visit 18 years ago.

Although billed as an official rather than a state visit, the meeting proceded with great formality. The Queen, it has been stressed, was visiting as head of state, not as head of a church.

She was greeted on arrival by an honour guard of the Swiss Guards, helmets waving with red feathers and bearing fearsome silver halberds.

The Queen wore black for the meeting, as Protestant monarchs traditionally do, though not the long formal dress of previous visits.

The 14 strong royal party, with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and his wife in tow, were shown to the Pope's library by Bishop James Harvey, prefect of the papal household, though all but the Queen and Prince Philip were left at the door.

The royal party was taken to view the restored Sistine Chapel. Perhaps the Queen reflected, as she gazed at Michelangelo's Last Judgment, that the next time these two spiritual leaders meet it is unlikely to be in this world.

fields.headline: Prince 'should have black wife'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales should have been told to marry a black woman to promote multiculturalism, Lady Gavron, vice-chairwoman of the Runnymede Trust's commission which prepared last week's report into the future of a multi-ethnic Britain, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales should have been told to marry a black woman to promote multiculturalism, Lady Gavron, vice-chairwoman of the Runnymede Trust's commission which prepared last week's report into the future of a multi-ethnic Britain, said yesterday.

She condemned the royal family as part of an "unattractive hierarchy" and the peerage as too Anglo-Saxon.

"It would have been great if Prince Charles had been told to marry someone black. Imagine what message that would have sent out," she told the Daily Telegraph. Lady Gavron is the wife of Lord Gavron, the Labour peer and former chairman of the Guardian Media Group, the parent company of the Guardian newspaper.

She said the royal family was superfluous to the country's needs, but useful for attracting foreign visitors. "We don't need them but they're fun for tourists to look at," she said.

The image which the royal family sent out about modern Britain was regressive: "They're a symbol of our unmeritocratic tendency and, of course, they are all white. It is part of a very unattractive hierarchy."

Lady Gavron praised Labour, to which her husband has donated £500,000, for appointing more black and Asian people to the peerage, which she said was too Anglo-Saxon.

She said: "Anything hereditary is completely anachronistic and illogical; you wouldn't have a hereditary cricket team. At least this government has made some peers from ethnic minority groups."

Oona King, Labour MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, said the social circle Prince Charles moved in made it unlikely he could marry a black woman. "I don't really think that marriages can be formulaic."

fields.headline: Three arrested over Omagh bombing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Irish police arrested three men yesterday in connection with the Omagh bombing which killed 29 people in the worst massacre of Northern Ireland's conflict.
fields.body:
Irish police arrested three men yesterday in connection with the Omagh bombing which killed 29 people in the worst massacre of Northern Ireland's conflict.

The men, in their twenties, were last night being questioned at Monaghan police station, as part of the continuing investigation into the car bomb on August 15 1998, police said.

Yesterday's early morning arrests at locations in Co Louth and Co Monaghan came a week after four men were named by the BBC's Panorama programme in connection with the Real IRA blast.

The documentary produced evidence which it claimed linked the four to mobile telephones used in Omagh on the day the explosion ripped through the market town in Co Tyrone.

One of those named in the programme, Colm Murphy, a publican and builder from Dundalk, Co Louth, has already been charged at the special criminal court in Dublin with conspiring to cause an explosion. So far Murphy is the only person to have been charged over the explosion.

The Panorama documentary divided opinion both in Northern Ireland and in the Republic, although many bereaved families supported the showing of the programme.

However, the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, and the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, were all among those who condemned the programme's decision to name the four people.

webTitle: British TV shows dominate the line-up for Emmy awards

fields.headline: British TV shows dominate the line-up for Emmy awards
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: British television shows dominate the nominations for the international Emmy awards announced yesterday.
fields.body:
British television shows dominate the nominations for the international Emmy awards announced yesterday.

Some 21 shows from around the world have been nominated, and 12 of them are from Britain. The winners of awards are to be announced on November 20.

Channel 4 has done particularly well, with five out of the 12.

The spoof satirist Sacha Baron Cohen is nominated for his Ali G character, as is another Channel 4 show, the all-woman Smack the Pony. Both are listed in the popular arts category.

Da Ali G Show has won a string of awards since being shown earlier this year, and Cohen's character has even ended up in Madonna's latest video for her chart hit, Music.

Other major homegrown shows include the epic historical drama Longitude, shown on Channel 4, which is up against BBC1's Warriors for the drama title.

Six of the British nominations are from the BBC, while the ITN news report for ITV takes the 12th.

A record number of 549 programmes were entered for the 28th international Emmys.

Also nominated are:

Masterworks (BBC) and Gloriana (BBC), competing for the performing arts category;

Correspondent Inside Chechnya (BBC) and ITN's report on the Mozambique floods, up for the news title;

Playing the China Card - Nixon And Mao (Channel 4), competing for the documentary award;

Howard Goodall's Big Bangs (Channel 4) and Tell Me the Truth About Love (BBC), competing for arts documentary;

and The Magician's House (BBC), up for the children and young people award.

Buckingham Palace recently announced plans for a new gallery at Holyrood in Edinburgh to show drawings from the collection - further evidence that the royal family want to publicise themselves as patrons and protectors of art.

They might be better off keeping quiet. Britain is the last country in Europe to have a royal collection on this scale that has not long since passed into the public domain. Even though the Queen is only giving away facsimiles of the art she holds "in trust for the nation", the meaning of her gesture - " Look at all the great stuff I've got" - is impossible to miss.

The Pope probably is the only other person in the world who has private access to such artistic treasures.

As the Queen boasted to the Pope, the Royal Library at Windsor Castle has "huge" numbers of graphic works by Canaletto, most famous of the 18th century Italian vedutisti, or view painters, who specialised in perspective views of the canals of Venice.

But that is nothing. She also has unrivalled holdings of drawings by Leonardo da Vinci, including his anatomical studies. These drawings have been lent to exhibitions on occasion - some are in Spectacular Bodies, a show opening at the Hayward Gallery this week - but the rest of the time they are the Queen's to peruse at her leisure.

She can also study her drawings by Raphael and Michelangelo, perhaps wondering at the fuss caused recently by the discovery of a new Michelangelo drawing in Britain.

The drawings alone in the royal collection constitute a priceless archive, some of the world's greatest art.

As for paintings, the collection includes masterpieces by Rembrandt, Raphael, Holbein, Titian, Brueghel, Cranach, Van Dyck, Orazio Gentileschi, and his more famous daughter Artemisia.

These paintings are claimed to be "integral" to the decor of the palaces where they hang. Some paintings are on public view, including the ones displayed at Hampton Court. Others, including Rembrandts, are hidden away.

Britain's royal collection makes other famous private collections seem trivial; accumulated over centuries, it is on the scale of the world's great public museums.

Its greatest enthusiast was Charles I. No significant additions to the collection were made in the 20th century.

The archaic rite between the Queen and Pope sums up the strangeness of all this great art being stuffed away in our royal palaces.

It also alerts us to the fact that, by comparison with the British royal family, the Vatican is an admirably public and open holder of its art collections, which are mostly on permanent view.

fields.headline: Blocked Bannister needs to pause for thought
fields.standfirst: When Greg Dyke's leadership Sun fell on Matthew Bannister's executive Mars, one of them had to go. The answer, says Maggie Hyde, was written in the stars.
fields.trailText: October 18: Greg Dyke's leadership Sun fell on Matthew Bannister's executive Mars and the BBC marketing director just had to go, reveals Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
There has been speculation that Matthew Bannister was a square peg in a round hole as director of marketing and communications at the BBC. Even so, his decision to quit just six months after getting the job, with his new marketing strategy about to be launched, is a surprise.

Bannister is an ambivalent Piscean (March 16 1957) and with two fish swimming in opposite directions, Pisces often has a confused mix of motives. Yet with assertive Mars in persistent Taurus he has durability, shown by his 22-year stint at the corporation, and he has a proven ability to take tough but imaginative decisions, demonstrated in his time at the helm of Radio One.

As an expected successor to John Birt, he was in the running for director general before being trumped by Greg Dyke. Dyke's leadership Sun falls on Bannister's executive Mars, but in April the astrology shows that he accepted a job he didn't want, in a different field of expertise to his own. By doing so, he sowed the seeds of disappointment. This began to manifest in July as limiting Saturn moved slowly across Dyke's Sun and Bannister's Mars, marking the start of a period which must have left Bannister feeling blocked and unable to take effective initiatives, in a post which smacked of demotion. Under Saturn, one player's mantle of authority becomes the other's cloak of failure. It is a galling planetary line-up, equivalent to driving with the brakes on, and Bannister won't be clear of this symbolism until late spring 2001.

Bannister says that it is "a good time to move my career in a different direction", and he is talking of an independent career in "talent management". However, there are no obvious indications that he leaves on the crest of a new wave, and he would be wise to assimilate and reflect before he pushes the boat out. It can be a long process to purge a corporate mindset from the soul and, for some time to come, the only talent that Bannister could be called upon to manage is his own.

fields.headline: Boy, 10, faces anti-social order
fields.trailText: A 10-year-old boy is set to become the youngest person in the country to be the subject of an anti-social behaviour order.
fields.body:
A 10-year-old boy is set to become the youngest person in the country to be the subject of an anti-social behaviour order.

The 4ft tall child has wreaked havoc in the Wythenshawe district of Manchester, and has been arrested five times since his birthday three months ago.

He has been known to police in the area since he was eight, but they were powerless to do anything until he reached 10 - the age of criminal responsibility.

He has been arrested for stealing lager, cigarettes, a lighter and condoms from shops and is thought to be suspected of at least another 32 criminal offences.

The boy has been caught shoplifting in Hadfield in the Peak District and at Manchester airport. He is also accused of stealing Pokemon cards from an older boy and assaulting the child. He has been bailed by police for the alleged offences.

The boy's mother, who can not be named for legal reasons, said: "He's no angel but he has emotional and behavioural difficulties. His school could not control him and he was excluded. It was 10 months before I could get him in somewhere else and during that time he got in with the wrong crowd."

Superintendent Zoe Lord, of Wythenshawe police, said: "If the position does not change, then he will become the subject of an anti-social behaviour order. He has been arrested five times since he was 10 and before he was 10 there were a number of incidents that we were aware of.

"We have done things to support him and to warn him about his behaviour, but nothing has had the desired effect.

"He is out of control because there are no boundaries or structures in his life. His mum does not seem able to control him and has had no effect on modifying his behaviour."

The boy has been excluded from his primary school and has been offered a place in a secure establishment, but he rarely attends.

She said other children were frightened of him and police were aiming to curb his behaviour before it worsened.

Social services have suggested moving him from the area instead of seeking an order.

At the Forum leisure centre, part of the Wythenshawe civic centre, which includes a theatre and library, the boy has set off fire alarms on two or three occasions, forcing evacuation of the centre.

A shop worker, who did not want to be named, said the boy had terrorised locals and he was not alone. "He is only the tip of the iceberg," he said. "He and his friends are the 1% of youngsters who are spoiling it for the majority."

At Wythenshawe civic centre yesterday afternoon, groups of six children in uniform hustled past the mounds of rubbish and construction work, shouting and laughing.

But there were others, aged between 10 and 12, in casual clothes, darting between market stalls, pawn brokers and the Poundstretcher shop, throwing stones.

William Jones, who has a run a market stall for five years, said traders and shop owners faced a huge problem with delinquency. There used to be gangs of 10-year-olds running amok through the markets, but they had not been seen for a few weeks, because of a police clampdown.

"The children shout, scream and thieve," he said. "They mostly pick on women traders because they dare not mess with the men. But the biggest problem is in shops; the children know when security guards take their lunch hours."

He said there was also a problem with groups of girls stealing purses and small items from stalls, but the worst problem was with heroin addicts, who stole things early in the morning, and with gangs carrying knives at night.

If an anti-social behaviour order is granted by magistrates, the boy could be banned from shops and other areas of Wythenshawe. The orders were introduced last year under the Crime and Disorder Act as a last resort for offenders who make people's lives a misery.

webTitle: Robinson backs down in funds row

fields.headline: Robinson backs down in funds row
fields.standfirst:
Labour cash queries Ex-minister concedes cheques were made out to general fund
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Robinson was forced yesterday to back down on the claim in his book that he directly funded Tony Blair's political office.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Robinson was forced yesterday to back down on the claim in his book that he directly funded Tony Blair's political office.

He claimed in the book, An Unconventional Minister, that he funded the office in the run-up to the general election, but he admitted on Radio 4's World at One programme that his cheques were made out to the Labour party general fund.

A Labour peer who has raised money for the party told the Guardian: "However large the donation and however important the donor, they cannot specify where the money goes if they give the cash to the general fund. It could go anywhere, and you do not get an account back on how it was spent."

In his book Mr Robinson stated: "I was happy to support the political offices of Gordon and Tony, just as I had for Neil Kinnock and John Smith."

On BBC2's Newsnight programme on Monday, Mr Robinson got himself in a tangle on whether he had funded the office through Mr Blair's "blind trust" fund - money from donors who are supposed to remain anonymous.

Most observers do not believe that the recipients are ignorant of the donors' identities. Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, has recommended that blind trusts be abolished. They will be outlawed in a new party funding act in the new year.

Mr Robinson was faced on Monday with a denial from Lady Jay, who chairs the trustees of Mr Blair's fund. She said: "The only donations Geoffrey Robinson made were general donations to the Labour party. He did not donate any money to Tony Blair's private office." Mr Robinson insisted that this was just a "narrow point" adding: "My support for his office is known."

Yesterday on the World at One, under specific questioning, he said: "As far as I remember I made it [the payment] through the Labour party itself, and that is the end of it."

Party accounts show that he made donations of over £5,000 in 1995, 1996 and 1997 to the general fund.

Mr Robinson said he had checked his own records of his donations before he wrote his book. These are kept by his secretary, Brenda Price, and are said to show that the cheques were made out to the Labour party and not to the leader's blind trust.

Party procedures allow general donations to be used on a wide range of activities, such as leaflets, travel costs of the leader and the shadow cabinet, and the electricity bill for Labour's headquarters at Millbank.

In theory, some of Mr Robinson's money could have been spent on activities involving Tony Blair, but he would not have been told.

This is quite different from Mr Robinson's donations to Gordon Brown, the chancellor, which went on specific research programmes - and he has outlined them in his book.

David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow trade and industry secretary, demanded a fresh investigation by Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, of Mr Robinson's claims in his book.

Mr Heathcoat-Amory said Mr Blair and Mr Brown had failed to declare the funding in the register of members interests, and that "it is not clear if Mr Robinson's donations were made direct to the MPs concerned, or through a blind trust".

webTitle: Auction to make hearts of diva's devotees soar

fields.headline: Auction to make hearts of diva's devotees soar
fields.trailText: For years they languished in the garage of a Greek villa, but now some of Maria Callas's most intimate possessions are to go on sale in Paris at an auction which is expected to raise more than £1m.
fields.body:
For years they languished in the garage of a Greek villa, but now some of Maria Callas's most intimate possessions are to go on sale in Paris at an auction which is expected to raise more than £1m.

Locks of the opera diva's hair, a pair of ungainly thick-lensed horn-rimmed glasses, and even a selection of her underwear will be sold by the French auction house Calmels Chambre Cohen on December 2 and 3, and the event will be broadcast live in Britain via the Auction Channel.

Most of the 417 items were kept at the Greek villa of Giovanni Meneghini, the husband from whom she was estranged for 18 years, but they were bought in 1982 by a collector, Ilario Tamassia.

"I gathered, preserved and admired these belongings, and through them I believe I know and love Callas. But I think it would be unjust if this collection were to remain hidden in my house," Mr Tamassia said.

The remainder of the items are being sold by Nicolas Petsalis-Diomidis, a close friend of the singer until she died, a virtual recluse, in her Paris apartment in 1977, aged 53.

Among the possessions to be sold will be a tiny oil painting of the Holy Family, which is expected to fetch £50,000. The 18th century picture was given to Callas by Meneghini in 1947 before the couple were married. He presented her with the painting on August 1, the night before her debut performance in Verona.

Subsequently Callas refused to sing in a theatre unless the painting was displayed in her dressing room. Once, before a performance in Vienna, she dispatched a private aeroplane to collect it from Milan.

A short, handwritten note scribbled with a make-up pencil is expected to fetch £2,000. This letter of apology, composed by Callas and written by her husband on a scrap of paper and the back of an envelope, explains why she suddenly left the stage after the first act of Bellini's Norma on January 2 1958, an event which came to be known as "the Rome scandal".

A respiratory infection had caused Callas's voice to fail during the gala performance before an audience that included the Italian president. But the note was never read to the audience, and as a result Callas was condemned for insulting the president by failing to finish the performance.

A pair of tortoiseshell glasses is expected to fetch as much as £9,000. "On stage, I am in the dark," Callas once said. "Blind as a bat without my glasses. How could I sing Casta Diva wearing horn-rimmed glasses? So I can see hardly anything: my fellow performers only just; the conductor not at all."

Also on sale will be a large selection of Callas's elegant wardrobe. The clothes vary in size, reflecting the diet which between 1952 and 1954 saw Callas slim from the size of a plump Brunnhilde to that of the kind of consumptive heroine beloved of Bizet and Verdi.

They include an emerald green silk and chinchilla fur coat, expected to fetch up to £25,000, and the green blouse she wore in 1970 for a television interview with David Frost.

Devotees of the star will even be able to buy corsets, stockings, underwear, boots, shoes and hats. But perhaps only the most avid will bid for the dullest item on offer - a Pyrex measuring jug.

webTitle: A week of despair in hunt for girl swept into river

fields.headline: A week of despair in hunt for girl swept into river
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Police will today continue their search for Hannah Black, 13, a week after she was swept away by the swollen waters of a beck in the Yorkshire Dales.
fields.body:
Police will today continue their search for Hannah Black, 13, a week after she was swept away by the swollen waters of a beck in the Yorkshire Dales.

Hannah and 14 other year nine pupils from Royds School in Oulton, near Leeds, were on a week-long adventure trip supervised by two teachers.

Some of the group are believed to have been walking up Stainforth Beck above the hamlet of Stainforth, three miles from Settle, when Hannah and her friend Rochelle Cauvet, 14, appear to have overbalanced after the boot of one of them was caught by a rock.

The pair would have been carried down the beck, under a wooden bridge, through Stainforth under a trunk road and then into the river Ribble.

Rochelle's body was found 18 hours after the accident in a bend on the Ribble, about four miles from where she waded into the beck.

But the search for Hannah goes on, with police joined by army divers, canoeists from a cave rescue team and local volunteers.

A North Yorkshire police spokesman said yesterday that the search will continue along the 50-mile length of the Ribble to its estuary at Lytham St Anne's on the Irish Sea. "But we will be concentrating our efforts in the two or three miles closest to where Hannah went in," he added. "Eventually there will come a time when we have searched the area completely and it is impossible to search any more -but we are still a long way from that."

Liaison officers are still supporting members of Hannah's family and fiercely protecting their privacy during the agonising wait for news.

Steve Finch of the Cave Rescue Organisation based at Clapham, north of Stainforth, said yesterday that more than 30 members had been involved in last week's initial search. The team's canoeists were back out on the river yesterday and the organisation was continuing to help police with advice based on local knowledge.

"The lower section of the river [close to Settle Junction, where Rochelle's body was found] is extremely dangerous when it is in flood," he said. "In places, the river there is20 to 30 feet deep. That area can take people by surprise when they get down on the ground and look at it.

"We are supplying canoeists each day because that is the fastest way to check the entire length of the river. The police are concentrating on an extremely methodical search of the river with divers.

"It is very stressful for everyone. We are used to going in and hoping for a good result. Whatever we do, we normally have a resolution to it. But we haven't here. It is unfinished business. Everyone who has been involved is still very much on edge about it."

Mr Finch suggested that if Hannah had not survived, her body could be found close to where Rochelle was discovered. "There can be no certainty in this sort of thing but I would think that is very probable," he said.

"If anything crops up and the police need our help, we are ready to go in. We are only minutes away."

North Yorkshire police and Leeds education authority have both launched investigations into the incident.

But the search for Hannah goes on, with police joined by army divers, canoeists from a cave rescue team and local volunteers. A North Yorkshire police spokesman said yesterday that the search will continue along the 50-mile length of the Ribble to its estuary at Lytham St Anne's on the Irish Sea. "But we will be concentrating our efforts in the two or three miles closest to where Hannah went in," he added. "Eventually there will come a time when we have searched the area completely and it is impossible to search any more -but we are still a long way from that." Liaison officers are still supporting members of Hannah's family and fiercely protecting their privacy during the agonising wait for news. Steve Finch of the Cave Rescue Organisation based at Clapham, north of Stainforth, said yesterday that more than 30 members had been involved in last week's initial search. The team's canoeists were back out on the river yesterday and the organisation was continuing to help police with advice based on local knowledge. "The lower section of the river [close to Settle Junction, where Rochelle's body was found] is extremely dangerous when it is in flood," he said. "In places, the river there is20 to 30 feet deep. That area can take people by surprise when they get down on the ground and look at it. "We are supplying canoeists each day because that is the fastest way to check the entire length of the river. Whatever we do, we normally have a resolution to it. But we haven't here. It is unfinished business. Everyone who has been involved is still very much on edge about it." Mr Finch suggested that if Hannah had not survived, her body could be found close to where Rochelle was discovered. "There can be no certainty in this sort of thing but I would think that is very probable," he said. "If anything crops up and the police need our help, we are ready to go in. We are only minutes away." North Yorkshire police and Leeds education authority have both launched investigations into the incident.

fields.headline: 'This is about taking Peter out'
fields.standfirst:
Cat and mouse game over memoir
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: On Monday night John Prescott placed a call to Belfast from distant Beijing. The deputy prime minister knew that the Robinson memoirs were about to break in the Mail and urged Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson to keep his nerve. You will be supported, he said.
fields.body:
On Monday night John Prescott placed a call to Belfast from distant Beijing. The deputy prime minister knew that the Robinson memoirs were about to break in the Mail and urged Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson to keep his nerve. You will be supported, he said.

As every senior minister knew, the Robinson attack on Mandelson had been a year in the making. What none of them knew was quite how much damage he intended to inflict. For months Downing Street, Mr Mandelson, Mr Robinson and his associates have been playing a game of cat and mouse over the contents of the former paymaster-general's book, The Unconventional Minister.

Intermediaries, including Tony Blair's personal assistant, Anji Hunter, and Fraser Kemp, the backbench fixer, used their influence either to kill the book, delay it, or soften its most damaging elements.

Last December it looked as if the deft Ms Hunter had succeeded when Mr Robinson indicated he would shelve the idea. Downing Street's tactics had been a mixture of charm and implict hints. They prompted the millionaire businessman to claim privately that his financial difficulties, including two DTI inquiries into his companies, were being used to discourage his book-writing. Sir Michael Scholar, permanent secretary at the DTI, was forced to issue a denial.

But this was always a battle conducted in the shadows through hints and rumours, a virtual war over a virtual memoir which has delivered far less than Mr Robinson's media mouthpieces promised. It was an operation Mr Mandelson, the arch-spinner, must grudgingly have admired.

Thus it was claimed at one point that the book would allege that Alastair Campbell, No 10 press secretary, or Jonathan Powell, Mr Blair's chief of staff, solicited money for the leader's blind trust. Mr Powell was "touting" for cash for Mr Blair's office from many people, including Mr Robinson, the Sunday Times damagingly reported.

As recently as last month's Labour conference the rumour mill claimed that Mandelson had written to Robinson on the leader of the opposition's notepaper (he had) concerning the loan for his Notting Hill home (he hadn't), and implying that Blair knew of the loan (he didn't). But mud sticks. William Hague's rottweillers got on the case. The Tory press gleefully took it up.

In the end, the negotiations broke down. Last spring Mr Robinson decided to go ahead. When they quit government in December 1998, they remained friends. But Robinson was infuriated by Mandelson's return as Northern Ireland secretary.

Out in the cold he felt hurt and forgotten. Foolishly Mandelson had failed to invite him to his housewarming party in Notting Hill. Politically naive, manipulated by his Iagos and embittered, Robinson has this week hawked his grievance round the TV studios.

But it was not all pique. All the while he was also being encouraged by political allies who want to see Mandelson and his agenda removed from office forever.

Who was behind it? In what was supposed to be an off-the-record interview with the Mirror yesterday, Mandelson, no slouch at mud-slinging himself, blamed Charlie Whelan, Gordon Brown's ex-press aide, now a freelance journalist and outside the Brown inner circle.

Mandelson told the Mirror's editor Piers Morgan, he had every sympathy with Robinson. "He is a kind and generous man who does not deserve what has happened to him. But others have manipulated him and made him attack me now and I find that very sad... Geoffrey is a vulnerable guy being used for dubious political motives by people who have an agenda against me".

What is striking about Robinson's Brownite account of cabinet tensions on tactics for handling the EU single currency issue is that it puts all the blame on Mandelson, when Robin Cook and Stephen Byers have also been making the pro-euro case.

As another pro-European minister explains: "This is not just about the past, or revenge. This is about the future and taking Peter out. This is about removing what they perceive to be a strong pro-European influence around the prime minister."

fields.headline: Violence spreads despite agreement
fields.standfirst:
Clinton browbeats both sides into uncertain deal
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Middle East peace was given the slimmest of second chances yesterday after President Bill Clinton browbeat Israel and the Palestinians to agree to end the violence.
fields.body:
Middle East peace was given the slimmest of second chances yesterday after President Bill Clinton browbeat Israel and the Palestinians to agree to end the violence.

After 29 hours of exhausting efforts from the high flyers of international diplomacy, yesterday's brief statement, read out by Mr Clinton, is barely a shade better than admitting the summit was an outright failure.

But the hollowness of the pledges Mr Clinton obtained from the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to end the violence that has claimed more than 100 lives, was immediately apparent.

Within an hour of Mr Clinton's declaration, a gun battle was raging in an outlying suburb of Jerusalem, critically injuring an Israeli border policeman. Last night, the Israeli army threatened to use combat helicopters to attack snipers in the adjacent Palestinian village of Beit Jalla.

Meanwhile, the West Bank chieftain of Mr Arafat's Fatah militias, called tanzim in Arabic, said the intifada would continue.

With Mr Barak and Mr Arafat refusing to spend time alone in each other's company - let alone sign a ceasefire agreement - yesterday's declaration is the best Mr Clinton could hope for. The two men shook hands for the cameras just once - and at the president's insistence.

Egypt's Hosni Mubarak and Jordan's King Abdullah also balked at giving their official endorsement to end the unrest that has reawakened support for the Palestinian cause in the Arab world and beyond.

Lebanon dismissed the summit for failing to resolve fundamental Palestinian problems which sparked fighting. "We were hoping the meeting would result in an announcement of clear principles to resolve the national issues which caused the Palestinian uprising, including [sovereignty over] Jerusalem, the return of refugees and the Israeli presence on Arab land," said the acting prime minister Selim al-Hoss.

The spiritual leader of the Islamic militant Hamas group said the agreement insulted Palestinian popular opinion and was not binding on his resistance movement. "We will continue in resisting the occupation," Sheikh Ahmed Yassin told reporters.

"Our meeting has not been easy because the last two weeks have been so hard," an ashen-faced Mr Clinton said. "This tragic and terrible confrontation costing many lives and injuries is threatening everything we have tried to achieve in the past seven years."

The presidential statement has only three ambitions. The crucial one commits the CIA, Israeli and Palestinian security officials to end the violence, countered by Israeli promises to roll back the tanks from the entrances to West Bank cities, and to lift a closure on Palestinian areas that is akin to sentencing more than 2m people to an open-air prison.

It also calls for Mr Arafat and Mr Barak to issue a public call to end the violence. But even before Mr Barak had returned home, a senior official on his aircraft said Israel had given up hope that Mr Arafat would fulfil his pledge to Mr Clinton. However, he said that Israel would be willing to look beyond that lapse, provided violence ceased anyway.

In addition, Mr Clinton, and his successor as president, will head an investigation into the violence, perhaps the most contentious areas of dispute. Israel has balked at any suggestion of an international inquiry, for fear of further fuelling widespread international criticism that its army has executed a shoot-to-kill policy against stone-throwing Palestinian youths.

Despite Palestinian demands for a full-scale investigation, involving the United Nations and European leaders, the US Secretary General, Kofi Annan, will play only a nominal role in the inquiry. From start to finish, this will be a US enterprise, and unlikely to produce a rigorous investigation, or even to publish its findings.

The final pledge is the most surreal, given the atmosphere of recrimination and distrust that now surrounds Israel and the Palestinians, and Mr Barak's plans to form an emergency government with the rightwing Likud party. If it stays quiet for a fortnight, Mr Clinton said, the US will consider reviving the peace process.

Desperate to avoid the appearance of failure, Mr Barak pronounced himself satisfied with the results. "I believe we have achieved the main goal of the summit," he told reporters. But even he cautioned: "The proof of the pudding is in the eating. We have to carry the responsibility together with the Palestinians to put an end to the violence in the region."

However, Israeli and Palestinian officials both warned that this is an agreement that will be put to the test hour by hour, at several flashpoints for the violent convulsions of the last 19 days. "We will see if Israel is serious only when it starts implementation," said Yasser Abd Rabbo, a senior Palestinian negotiator.

Yesterday's agreement is virtually identical to a ceasefire brokered by the US Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright, in Paris two weeks ago, that collapsed in a matter of hours. Since then, the confrontation has turned cataclysmic, with Israel sending combat helicopters to rocket Mr Arafat's headquarters following the brutal slaying of two reservists by Palestinian mobs.

Despite Mr Clinton's arm-twisting, conducted in the spotlight of international diplomacy, the Palestinian leader may find it even harder to rein in the protests now. Yesterday's violence, which erupted in Gaza as well as in the West Bank, was the product of Palestinian anger at his very presence at the summit.

Senior Israeli officials said yesterday they were sceptical about achieving a real calm at least until after an Arab summit in Cairo at the weekend, when Mr Arafat is going to seek more active championship of his cause.

fields.headline: France Army may guard synagogues
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The leaders of France's Jewish community said yesterday that they had asked the government if it would bring in the army to guard synagogues if the wave of attacks on Jewish targets began to escalate.
fields.body:
The leaders of France's Jewish community said yesterday that they had asked the government if it would bring in the army to guard synagogues if the wave of attacks on Jewish targets began to escalate.

"We asked that if the situation worsened, for example if anyone was killed ... the army could be called in to protect community institutions," said Moise Cohen, the president of Paris's Jewish religious board.

The interior ministry confirmed it had been notified of the request, made during a meeting with national police chiefs on Monday night, but a spokeswoman did to comment beyond noting that security at potential targets of anti-Jewish violence had been quadrupled.

The interior minister, Daniel Vaillant, has blamed the spate of some 80 scattered attacks on Jewish property in France over the past fortnight on young troublemakers rather than on a genuine increase in anti-semitic sentiment caused by the violence in the Middle East.

The leaders of France's 3m-4m Muslims have said the perpetrators of the attacks, in which schools and synagogues belonging to the 750,000-strong Jewish community have been sprayed with graffiti or firebombed, are not representative of the Muslim faith.

The prime minister, Lionel Jospin, met representatives of France's Jewish, Muslim, Protestant and Catholic communities on Monday and appealed for calm.

webTitle: Europe's Jews on alert after attacks

fields.headline: Europe's Jews on alert after attacks
fields.standfirst:
Attack on student fuels tensions
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Jewish and Muslim community leaders in Stamford Hill, north London, last night held an emergency meeting to try to defuse local tensions after the stabbing of a Jewish student thought to have been targeted because of his faith.
fields.body:
Jewish and Muslim community leaders in Stamford Hill, north London, last night held an emergency meeting to try to defuse local tensions after the stabbing of a Jewish student thought to have been targeted because of his faith.

Mayer David Myers, 20, who is studying at Gateshead Talmudic College, was stabbed more than 20 times on Monday morning while travelling on a bus through one of the capital's most prominent Jewish communities.

Mr Myers, from Finchley in north London, is an Orthodox Jew who sports a full beard and a skullcap. He was attacked by a man using a six-inch blade. His assailant forced open the doors of the bus before walking away and boarding another bus.

Last night Mr Myers was in a stable condition at Homerton hospital.

The attack shocked Stamford Hill, where a 17,000-strong Jewish community has long peacefully coexisted with large Muslim and Asian communities. But last week five men were arrested on suspicion of distributing racist literature after leaflets calling for a jihad against Jews were distributed.

Yesterday Scotland Yard said security would be stepped up at Jewish targets in the capital.

Last night police charged a man with the attempted murder of Mr Myers. Nabil Ould Eddine, 27, of London N5, will appear today at Thames Magistrates Court.
