webTitle: India sells back helicopter fleet to Britain

fields.headline: India sells back helicopter fleet to Britain
fields.trailText: India has sold its entire fleet of Westland helicopters back to Britain for the scrap value of just £900,000, nine years after the machines were found to be technically faulty and grounded.
fields.body:
India has sold its entire fleet of Westland helicopters back to Britain for the scrap value of just £900,000, nine years after the machines were found to be technically faulty and grounded.

In an ignominious epilogue to the Westland saga, nine of the 19 helicopters acquired by India for £65m in the mid-1980s have been shipped back to the UK to be stripped down for spare parts. The second and final consignment is expected to leave Bombay by the end of the year.

India's state-owned helicopter firm, Pawan Hans Helicopters, which operated the Westland 30s, dispatched the first shipment to AES Aerospace, a British firm based in West Sussex, in July. The flawed machines had spent the previous eight years rusting in crates at New Delhi's Safdarjung airport.

"We have not made any firm plans about what to do with them," AES's managing director, Vic Aven, said last night. The contract to ship the helicopters back to his firm's depot in East Grinstead was agreed two-and-a-half years ago but only signed last year, he said. He denied that the final shipment had been withheld due to "payment problems". The troubled helicopters might be repaired and flown commercially, he added.

India bought 21 Westland 30s in 1985 after Margaret Thatcher persuaded Rajiv Gandhi, then prime minister, to ignore the advice of his aviation experts, who were against the sale. The money came out of Britain's aid budget and was given to India on condition it bought the helicopters.

The deal - later described by officials as a "catastrophic waste of money" - bailed Westland and Mrs Thatcher out of trouble (though it failed to prevent the resignation of Michael Heseltine, then defence secretary).

The 14-seater Westland 30s proved to be highly unreliable and a commercial disaster. Soon after their arrival in India in 1987 two crashed - one in the north Indian state of Jammu, and another in Nagaland killing 10 people. They proved to be unsuited to the tropical climate, needed constant servicing and repairs, and were flown only sporadically.

In 1991 the helicopters were withdrawn from service on safety grounds. Two years later, after obtaining permission from the British government under the original 1985 "sale" agreement, Pawan Hans invited global tenders for the Westland 30s. But no one wanted to pay the £1.9m reserve price. Eventually AES Aerospace emerged as sole bidder. So far it has paid £450,000, half the sale price.

Last night Pawan Hans said that the return of the helicopters to Britain would soon be completed.

A spokesman for Westland helicopters last night admitted that sales of the W30s had been "mediocre". The helicopter, a civilian version of the Lynx, was no longer in production after the civil aviation authority withdrew its licence.

Three years ago the international development secretary, Clare Short, ordered an inquiry into the helicopter deal, which she described as "outrageous". She criticised Lady Thatcher's role in the affair, saying it showed the importance of de-linking aid from political considerations.

The national audit office, in its subsequent investigation, concluded that the government lost more than £105m, including money on research.

Since the helicopters' purchase price was paid for using British aid, the Indian government is obliged to return the £900,000 to the UK's department for international development. In a final irony, though, Ms Short has pledged that the money will be sent back to India again to be used for poverty alleviation.

The national audit office, in its subsequent investigation, concluded that the government lost more than £105m, including money on research. Since the helicopters' purchase price was paid for using British aid, the Indian government is obliged to return the £900,000 to the UK's department for international development. In a final irony, though, Ms Short has pledged that the money will be sent back to India again to be used for poverty alleviation.

fields.headline: After Arafat
fields.standfirst:
Candidates for PLO chief
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: No one in the Middle East was holding their breath last night over Yasser Arafat's pledge at the Sharm al-Sheikh summit to end the armed "Al-Aqsa" intifada against Israel.
fields.body:
No one in the Middle East was holding their breath last night over Yasser Arafat's pledge at the Sharm al-Sheikh summit to end the armed "Al-Aqsa" intifada against Israel.

But signs are multiplying that if the Palestinians do reach a final peace settlement with the Jewish state, another leader may have to do the deed.

Before the summit wound up, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, had made clear that he no longer saw the veteran 71-year-old head of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation as a partner Israel could deal with.

Mr Arafat's poor health has already made the succession a live issue. If bloodshed does resume, as seems likely, and brings no benefit, as also seems likely, pressure could grow from abroad - and perhaps at home - for a change at the top. The likely candidates are:

Mahmoud Abbas

Secretary of the PLO's executive committee and a founder of the Fatah movement, its largest member and historic core. He is 66 and better known by his nom de guerre, Abu Mazen.

Born in Safad in northern Palestine, Mr Abbas helped draft the 1993 Oslo accords. For his own people, he would be the candidate of continuity, but he has little charisma. He would probably be acceptable to Israel and the US.

Ahmed Qurei

The PLO negotiator at Oslo, and speaker of the Palestinian Legislative Council and the closest Mr Arafat has to a formal deputy.

But any successor will need the firm support of two other powerful but younger and more shadowy figures in the Palestinian leadership, both holding the key security portfolios which were central to making Oslo work.

Muhammad Dahlan

Head of the elite preventative security apparatus in the Gaza Strip and a veteran of talks with his Israeli security counterparts. Like other Fatah cadres, Colonel Dahlan spent time in Israeli prisons before being deported to join Arafat in his Tunis exile.

Jibril Rajoub

Col Dahlan's preventative security counterpart in the West Bank; a tall and powerfully built man with a menacing manner and fluent Hebrew learnt during his 17 years behind bars.

Marwan Barghouti

A new and relatively unknown name, he is also a former prisoner, deportee and Arafat supporter, and leads the tanzim (organisation) of armed Fatah activists, the gunmen who have been firing at the Israelis and who will now face demands to disarm to comply with the Sharm al-Sheikh deal.

Mr Barghouti, 41, is closely allied to Col Rajoub and has risen to prominence since Oslo. He is seen as the man most responsible for the success of the recent demonstrations.

Part of Mr Barghouti's appeal is that he is seen as the only man capable of coordinating with extremist Islamic groups like Hamas and the Islamic Jihad.

The question of who should follow Arafat is not a matter for public discussion, and especially not now, as Palestinians close ranks in a confrontation whose final outcome is still far from clear.

Yet no one can be sure that a successor will be able to deliver what "Mr Palestine" has not. "Everyone knows that only Arafat can stand the pressure of making concessions to Israel," commented Danny Rubinstein, a leading expert.

"It is not only the candidates to succeed Arafat who wish him good health so he can sign up to a permanent settlement. Many Israelis also believe that without Arafat it will take many more years before there is another Palestinian leader who will be strong enough to complete this peace process."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Extra time for Microsoft
fields.body:
Extra time for Microsoft

The European commission has given Microsoft extra time to answer charges it is abusing its power to gain an edge in the global market for server software.

"The deadline for Microsoft to respond is now mid-November," said a spokesman. "They asked for an extension and we granted it."

If Microsoft does not satisfy the commission's concerns, it could be fined up to 10% of its worldwide revenues, although such a large fine has never in practice been imposed.

TU funds dump Widows

Britain's TU Fund Managers has dumped Scottish Widows Investment Partnership as manager of its £185m in assets, citing staff losses and poor performance at the Edinburgh-based firm.

Rothschild Asset Management will now run TU Fund Managers' £100m British unit trust, the £82m European unit trust and the £2.5m Income unit trust.

Scottish Widows lost more than £1bn in institutional funds in August this year and on Monday confirmed that it had been sacked as adviser by the £450m Hill Samuel Property Unit Trust.

EdF cautious on market

The head of Electricité de France said yesterday that EdF was prepared eventually to open 100% of the French market to competition but not faster than the majority of its European Union rivals.

EdF chairman Francois Roussely told Reuters that France would have liberalised 34% of the market by the end of the year, allowing it to attain the EU average level of market opening.

All French industries which consume over nine gigawatt hours of power per year, or some 250 plants, will be eligible to purchase their electricity from the EU supplier of their choice from December. But state-owned EdF - which produces over 90% of France's power - was not prepared yet to start allowing domestic customers to shop around for supplies.

The dope on directors

A third of financial directors have tried cannabis, according to a survey out today. The research, conducted by Reed Accountancy Personnel and Accountancy Age, asked 250 financial bosses across Britain if they had tried cannabis.

Almost a third said yes, 61% said they had never tried the drug and 6% refused to answer.

Bathroom jobs to be cut

Irish bathroom manufacturer Qualceram Shires is to cut 80 jobs from UK ceramics, acrylics and shower manufacturer Shires, which it bought last month for £34m in cash.

Shires employs more than 660 people at production sites in Longton and Hanley, Stoke-on-Trent; Bradford; Rochdale; and Darwen, Lancashire.

Qualceram Shires said no decision had been made on where the jobs cuts would be made.

webTitle: British Biotech in pact with Serono

fields.headline: British Biotech in pact with Serono
fields.trailText: Embattled drug development company British Biotech is pooling resources with Europe's largest biotech firm, Serono, in a research alliance aimed at finding treatments for inflammatory diseases such as arthritis and multiple sclerosis.
fields.body:
Embattled drug development company British Biotech is pooling resources with Europe's largest biotech firm, Serono, in a research alliance aimed at finding treatments for inflammatory diseases such as arthritis and multiple sclerosis.

Under the terms of the deal, British Biotech will receive an upfront payment of $5m (£3.4m) from Geneva-based Serono. If the collaboration successfully takes three or more products through clinical trials, British Biotech could receive up to $80m.

British Biotech's chief executive, Elliot Goldstein, said: "One of the things we pride ourselves on is that the company is now more externally focused." He described the tie-up as a significant endorsement of the company's core technology, which is focused on targeting metalloenzyme inhibitors - enzymes in the body which contain metal.

The deal will go some way towards addressing criticism that the Oxford-based company lacks sufficient products in its development pipeline, although critics want to see licensing deals to introduce drugs at a more advanced stage. British Biotech's shares edged up 1.5p to 23.5p.

Analyst Eva Haas of Old Mutual Securities said: "I would not say it adds a vast amount to valuations of the company but it shows that the management is delivering the deals it promised." Serono has an option to obtain exclusive rights over BB-2827, a drug for inflammatory diseases which British Biotech has just taken into human trials.

The Swiss firm has also been granted rights over BB-76163, a multiple sclerosis drug in pre-clinical development. The two companies will share the cost equally of researching new anti-inflammatory products. Serono owns one of the leading medicines for multiple sclerosis, Rebif.

webTitle: The day a £30bn company went missing

fields.headline: The day a £30bn company went missing
fields.trailText: The London stockmarket's automatic settlement system, Crest, yesterday "lost" a £30bn company, after becoming confused about a capital reshuffling by the insurance firm Zurich Financial Services.
fields.body:
The London stockmarket's automatic settlement system, Crest, yesterday "lost" a £30bn company, after becoming confused about a capital reshuffling by the insurance firm Zurich Financial Services.

Investors were left in limbo for much of the day as millions of pounds worth of shares in the company disappeared from their settlement accounts overnight. The confusion arose after London-based Allied Zurich, which owned 43% of Zurich Financial Services, was absorbed into the Swiss company on Monday. Investors ought to have been automatically allocated shares in the combined organisation, which has a primary listing in Switzerland and a secondary quote in London.

But a "technical error" meant that all trace of the insurance company disappeared from Crest's systems, which are used by nearly all institutions trading in blue-chip shares. A Crest spokesman said: "The cross-border corporate action was an immensely complicated one. There were technical issues which meant that the out-turned security which should have appeared in settlement accounts was slightly delayed."

The error was corrected during the late afternoon. Furious traders had spent hours trying to establish their positions.

"We had a large position in this company and today, at the crucial moment, we were unable to complete our business," one senior arbitrage trader said. "Having a reliable and robust settlement system is crucial to any equity market and today it failed." Until this week, big investment banks, typically the large Wall Street firms, have routinely traded between Allied Zurich in London and Zurich Financial in Switzerland, picking up profits from price discrepancies between the two markets. Their trading positions in the stock typically run to tens of millions of pounds.

One fund manager was quoted as saying: "We have wasted half a day trying to reconcile this bargain. We are trying to sort it out and move the UK position to the Swiss one but we can't." Crest stressed that no one had permanently lost any shares. Crest's spokesman said: "No blame is being apportioned to any party. It would be inappropriate to start pointing fingers." The insurance group's complicated capital arrangements date back to a merger two years ago between Zurich Financial Services and the financial arm of British American Tobacco. The firm kept a dual share structure but has unified them after becoming frustrated that the London-listed end traded at a constant discount to shares in Switzerland.

fields.headline: Buffett decides to split heirs
fields.trailText: Warren Buffett, one of the world's greatest investors, has left instructions for not one but three men to replace him as head of Berkshire Hathaway, his Omaha-based investment company.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett, one of the world's greatest investors, has left instructions for not one but three men to replace him as head of Berkshire Hathaway, his Omaha-based investment company.

The man known as the Sage of Omaha, who turned 70 in August, has been plagued for years by questions about his successor. Following an operation to remove benign polyps this summer, his first surgery in 61 years, Mr Buffett has drawn up an official succession plan.

In a letter seen by only a handful of people, Mr Buffett said three people should be appointed chairman, chief investment officer and chief executive in the event of his death.

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Mr Buffett said his son Howard should take over as chairman in the event of his death. Mr Buffett, a self-made man who has often stated his opposition to inherited wealth, does not plan to bequeath his 31% stake in the company to his children, however. The Buffett stake will be left to his wife, who is then expected to bequeath it to a trust.

Mr Buffett said yesterday that he wanted his family to continue its involvement with Berkshire, which owns 50 disparate businesses, to guarantee its distinct personality. Mr Buffett's folksy style and pithy comments draw thousands of the 300,000 shareholders to annual meetings in Omaha.

It is unclear whether Howard Buffett, a farmer with little involvement in Berkshire to date, would continue this tradition.

Mr Buffett also said yesterday that he had anointed Louis Simpson, head of investments for Geico, Berkshire's largest company, as investment chief of the new regime.

The identity of the chief executive, arguably the most important post, will remain unknown outside the small circle of insiders until Mr Buffett dies. The world's fifth-richest man is enjoying the suspense. "When the envelope is opened, it will be like the Miss America pageant," he said.

In previous annual reports, Mr Buffett had said his job would be divided into two executive posts, one to manage investments , the other operations. Debbie Bosanek, Mr Buffett's secretary, confirmed that she had typed a letter on behalf of her boss which began "Yesterday I died".

webTitle: The 4am talks that clinched a shaky deal

fields.headline: The 4am talks that clinched a shaky deal
fields.standfirst:
Furious exchanges erupted as frosty atmosphere prevailed
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Immediately after announcing that Israel and the Palestinians had agreed to a ceasefire yesterday, Bill Clinton wandered away from the gloomy inner circle of the world's diplomatic high flyers, walked around the back of the two-storey clubhouse which had served as summit venue, and began to hit golf balls. It was a measure of his frustration with the protagonists.
fields.body:
Immediately after announcing that Israel and the Palestinians had agreed to a ceasefire yesterday, Bill Clinton wandered away from the gloomy inner circle of the world's diplomatic high flyers, walked around the back of the two-storey clubhouse which had served as summit venue, and began to hit golf balls. It was a measure of his frustration with the protagonists.

Yesterday's peace deal at the Red sea resort of Sharm-el-Sheikh was neither endorsed in writing nor sealed by a handshake between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. To many observers, the agreement was identical to a US-mediated ceasefire announced two weeks ago - which fell apart within hours.

The omens were never promising. President Clinton conceded in his opening remarks that the negotiating table was "piled high with grievance". The summit host, Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak, even called for "saving what is left of the credibility of the peace process".

The Israelis and Palestinians kept to themselves throughout the negotiations, which dragged out from 9am on Monday to 4am yesterday morning. Mr Barak and Mr Arafat sat 10ft apart around a horseshoe-shaped table, with Mr Clinton and Mr Mubarak at the head.

When the Israeli and Palestinian leaders crossed paths in a corridor they did not even look at each other, an Israeli source said. They shook hands only once when Mr Clinton tugged them together, and refused to spend a minute alone in each other's company.

The Palestinians had demanded an international commission, involving UN and European leaders, to investigate the causes of the bloodshed. Israel launched a propaganda blitz to counter criticism from the UN security council that its troops have pursued a shoot-to-kill policy against stone-throwing youths, and have failed to spare young children.

By 7pm on Monday night it was clear the summit was in deep trouble when a meeting of foreign ministers ended in a shouting match. According to one account, the Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, told the chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, that the inquiry sought by Mr Arafat was an excuse to prevent progress. Mr Erekat retorted: "You are a real hero, threatening us with guns." Another version alleged he had called the Israelis "Nazis".

After pounding his fist on the table Mr Ben Ami stormed out of the meeting. He was coaxed back later by the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, but it was clear that the officials could produce no agenda for their leaders to discuss.

Relations were not improved at the summit banquet. Mr Barak stayed only an hour, returning to his hotel while fellow guests were still drinking coffee. Israeli officials said he had been "humiliated" by the atmosphere at the talks. Egypt refused to hoist Israel's Star of David alongside the American and Palestinian flags, and its state-controlled media referred to the country as "the zionist entity".

The crucial session between an exhausted Mr Barak and Mr Clinton appears to have taken place between 2am and 4am, when the Israeli leader assented to a declaration which binds him to calling for an end the violence, and to easing security controls on the Palestinians.

But by the closing ceremony the Israeli side was attempting to put a positive gloss on the outcome. According to Mr Barak, the first measures would be implemented moments after his jet landed back home, when Israeli and Palestinian security officials were to meet to decide on how to defuse points of friction.

The agreement, if it holds, will unfold in three stages. First, the Israelis were to immediately reopen the Gaza airport and border crossings to Egypt, which were sealed last week. Tomorrow night, should the violence have abated, Israel is toroll back its tanks in the West Bank and Gaza, and rip up the metal spikes at roadblocks at the entrances to Palestinian cities.

Only then will Israel take a decision about lifting the closure imposed on the West Bank and Gaza, which was one of the Palestinians' primary demands. But an official on Mr Barak's aircraft said the deal gained added weight through a secret agreement for the CIA to work jointly with Israel's intelligence chief and Palestinian security officials to defuse the flashpoints of the past 19 days.

The two sides also agreed to convene an investigation into the carnage which has claimed more than 100 lives. The Palestinians are bound to be bitterly disappointed by the agreement to establish a "fact-finding committee". Though the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, is to be a member, the US president has total authority over the inquiry's scope.

The summit's reward comes two weeks from now. If - and this is a huge if - all goes smoothly on the ground, and the killing in the West Bank and Gaza stops, then US officials will explore the possibilities of reviving the peace process.

But within an hour of Mr Clinton's announcement that the two sides had agreed to stop the bloodshed a gunbattle raged on the outskirts of Jerusalem.

The agreement, if it holds, will unfold in three stages. First, the Israelis were to immediately reopen the Gaza airport and border crossings to Egypt, which were sealed last week. Tomorrow night, should the violence have abated, Israel is toroll back its tanks in the West Bank and Gaza, and rip up the metal spikes at roadblocks at the entrances to Palestinian cities. Only then will Israel take a decision about lifting the closure imposed on the West Bank and Gaza, which was one of the Palestinians' primary demands. But an official on Mr Barak's aircraft said the deal gained added weight through a secret agreement for the CIA to work jointly with Israel's intelligence chief and Palestinian security officials to defuse the flashpoints of the past 19 days. The two sides also agreed to convene an investigation into the carnage which has claimed more than 100 lives. The Palestinians are bound to be bitterly disappointed by the agreement to establish a "fact-finding committee". Though the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, is to be a member, the US president has total authority over the inquiry's scope. The summit's reward comes two weeks from now. If - and this is a huge if - all goes smoothly on the ground, and the killing in the West Bank and Gaza stops, then US officials will explore the possibilities of reviving the peace process. But within an hour of Mr Clinton's announcement that the two sides had agreed to stop the bloodshed a gunbattle raged on the outskirts of Jerusalem. fields.headline: Dead to the world
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Premature Burial/Modern Day Eunuchs/ Channel 4 News/Attachments
fields.body:
Phrases you don't often hear on television, number one: "The second time I woke up in a morgue..."

Poor Alison Burchill went to see an Abbott and Costello film in 1956 and, after laughing a bit too much, fell over into a coma. Had she fallen over unconscious today, she would have either drowned in the sea of spilt cola or else suffocated on all the dropped popcorn, but this being the 50s, an usherette called an ambulance without rummaging through her pockets first. Alison was rushed to hospital where she was, rather unfortunately, pronounced dead.

It was rather unfortunate since she was, in fact, alive and suffering from narcolepsy catalepsy. Apparently, the condition causes one to fall over as though one were dead or extremely bored with one's surroundings (those close to William Hague may be familiar with the symptoms) and it was only because she motivated herself into moving that she wasn't buried alive. As Premature Burial (Channel 5) showed, Alison suffered attacks of narcolepsy catalepsy twice more, was twice more presumed dead and twice more nearly dispatched to a soily grave. Imagine avoiding being buried alive three times only to surface on Channel 5. What ignominy.

While Premature Burial was potentially interesting, it evolved into one of the most ludicrous pieces of pseudo-documentary television in recent years. Its experts actually undermined any hope the programme had of being taken seriously, with one dour doctor - whose PhD is perhaps in stating the obvious - calling Alison's situation "tragic", while another went by the marvellous name of Dr Douglas Diggle.

Coupled with some of the shoddiest, most laughable reconstructions ever seen on British TV, Premature Burial stretched those interesting stories it focused on (actually just Alison's) until it creaked under the strain of the overly dramatic narration and the weight of the thesis that perhaps thousands of people had been buried alive throughout history. Perhaps, as Doris Day once said, perhaps, perhaps. And then again, maybe not.

Phrases you don't often hear on television, number two: "For some reason, I didn't see myself with testicles." So spake Brett, one of the subjects of Modern Day Eunuchs (Channel 4). After 30 years of fantasising about castration, he turned his fantasy into reality and became a eunuch. Turned on by pain, you'd think Brett might have tried getting his back waxed before going for the bollocks- in-secateurs option, but he got a thrill from the fantasy of castration so the reality proved irresistable. Testicle-less, Brett felt complete though his penis did resemble a forlorn German sausage. It wasn't a pretty sight.

Now an internet agony uncle to those who fantasise about and seek castration - with agony being the operative word - Brett helps other men who suffer from a castration compulsion like his. Since such men cannot approach surgeons for help, they are left alone and to their own devices, devices which include big chopping plier-type things and other bloodcurdling implements which will have had the male audience crossing their legs at the very least, and running screaming from the room at the not-so-very least. I know I should understand and sympathise with these men, most of whom seemed not to know from where their compulsion came, and say c'est la vie to the ever-expanding boundaries of human sexuality and the expression thereof, but I'm sorry, I can't. Get over "the ick factor" and this documentary may be an amazing insight into a heretofore unknown world, but don't get over it and you'll be flicking over to A Touch Of Frost with indecent haste. Suddenly, premature burial alongside David Jason seems an attractive option.

As part of Channel 4 News , Naomi Klein introduced an informative, entertaining item, based on her excellent book, No Logo. Travelling from Seattle, home of Starbucks and Microsoft, to Prague, she eloquently exposed the multi-national corporations' hypocrisies, the main one being how they pursue us as consumers but abandon us as workers. With the CEO of Starbucks now named as one of Britain's most powerful people, the time is ripe for a whole series about the corporations which shape our lives, rather than a mere 24 minutes.

Phrases you don't often hear about television, number three: " Attachments (BBC2) is just getting better and better."

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What novelists are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What novelists are watching on TV
fields.body:
Nicholas Blincoe: "I watch lots of Seinfeld, because it's on every single day. I like George (pictured) best, because of his, um, warm-spirited embracing of mankind. Ha! It's the opposite of that, his philosophy in a nutshell is basically misanthropy, with laughs. I watch the news. A lot. Soaps? That would be wasting my time, hee! Oh, I must say I don't like Attachments, it reminds me of Press Gang. My favourite personality is the man who does the economics commentaries on Channel 4 News. I don't know his name, but he explains economics and I understand it. Boring, I know, but I'm 35. [Pause] Or is it Newsnight?"

Rebecca Ray: "I hardly watch anything. I hate the bloody thing, TV. The annual TV licence fee is an extortion payment. I don't believe anyone should be charged with paying for the crap you have to sit through. What do I watch? Friends - it's a bit like smack, addictive. Favourite character? [Snarls] They're all my favourite, they're my friends, I live in their fluffy little world."

Matt Thorne: "I like Buffy The Vampire Slayer and Angel, the spin-off. I didn't watch them on TV but my girlfriend started buying them on video, and I was sucked in. I spent a long time trying to avoid them, but I've just got into it. It's got really good characters - a stuffy librarian is revealed to have a sordid past, that sort of thing. You think you know people then they turn into something else. I like Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, it's the only game show that I watch. I have a sordid quiz show past, actually. I was on Blockbusters once with my sister and won a holiday to Prague!"

Scarlet Thomas: "I watch Home And Away and Neighbours, but Home And Away is my favourite, it's a brilliant programme, and they've just taken it off ITV. Channel Five have bought it and I can't get that channel! I've been checking the schedules, so I can get cable, but they haven't started broadcasting it yet."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to writers featured in All Hail The New Puritans (Fourth Estate).

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Long Day Closes/The Ice Storm/Village of the Damned
fields.body:
The Long Day Closes

(Terence Davies, 1992)

8pm, FilmFour

Warm and affectionate autobiographical account of Davies's childhood in 1950s Liverpool. Times are hard for 11-year-old Bud (Leigh McCormack), and he is threatened by school bullies and the Catholic terror: but all fears founder on the great rock of his family and community. The mother of all mothers is Marjorie Yates; a beautiful, emotionally honest evocation of time, place and childhood.

The Ice Storm

(Ang Lee, 1997)

12 midnight, Sky Premier

A delicately crafted, superbly acted study of suburban morality in 70s America: all self-consciously hip partner-swapping parties and inner torment. It focuses on the Hood family. Student son, Paul (Tobey Maguire) is returning home for Christmas, finding parents Kevin Kline and Joan Allen's relationship in deep freeze: Dad's having an affair with a neighbour (Sigourney Weaver, playing borderline bitter). Meanwhile, Paul's sister Wendy (Christina Ricci, in an engaging early role) is exploring her own sexuality, and there's a tragedy in the offing.

Village of the Damned

(Wolf Rilla, 1960)

2.30am, TCM

Eerie adaptation of John Wyndham's novel The Midwich Cuckoos, offering conclusive proof that the English countryside is a much better setting for sci-fi horrors than, say, the Nevada desert. Nine months after a strange torpor blankets little Midwich, a dozen village women give birth to identical children, chillingly intelligent and possessed of supernatural powers. In the absence of X Files agents, physicist Gordon Zellaby (George Sanders) sets about the destruction of the far-from-innocents.

fields.headline: Exhume Hanratty's body, say judges
fields.trailText: One of the most contentious of alleged miscarriage of justice cases took a significant twist yesterday when the court of appeal said the body of James Hanratty, who was hanged for murder 38 years ago, should be exhumed to allow scientists to conduct DNA tests.
fields.body:
One of the most contentious of alleged miscarriage of justice cases took a significant twist yesterday when the court of appeal said the body of James Hanratty, who was hanged for murder 38 years ago, should be exhumed to allow scientists to conduct DNA tests.

Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, said public concern that an innocent man might have been executed for a crime he did not commit made the exhumation "desirable in the interests of justice", even though it was against the wishes of Hanratty's family.

The decision was an important one for the crown, which hopes modern DNA analysis will prove Hanratty's convictions for the murder of Michael Gregsten and the rape of Valerie Storie are safe.

Campaigners, however, yesterday insisted that DNA tests will be meaningless because exhibits from the murder scene were mixed with material taken from Hanratty and are therefore "contaminated."

The two sides are preparing for an appeal against his conviction, which is likely to start next spring.

Hanratty, a 25-year-old petty thief, went to the gallows at Bedford prison on April 4, 1962, for what became known as the A6 murder.

He was accused of being the gunman who burst into Mr Gregsten's Morris Minor car as he sat with his lover, Miss Storie, in a cornfield at Dorney Reach, Buckinghamshire.

The couple were forced to drive to Deadman's Hill, south of Bedford, where Mr Gregsten, a scientist, was murdered and Miss Storie was raped, shot five times, and left for dead. She survived the attack but was paralysed.

Hanratty was arrested when detectives found spent cartridges from the murder weapon in a London guest house he often used.

Miss Storie picked him out an an identity parade and other criminals gave evidence against him.

Nevertheless, Hanratty's father was convinced of his son's innocence and began a campaign to clear his name. Eleven witnesses have since claimed Hanratty was 250 miles away in Rhyl, north Wales, at the time of the murder.

Miss Storie's identification of Hanratty has been questioned. Before the key identity parade she told detectives her memory of the man who raped her was "fading", but this was not disclosed to the jury.

In 1994, one of Scotland Yard's most senior officers, Detective Chief Superintendent Roger Matthews, reviewed the evidence. His findings were presented to the criminal cases review commission, which referred the case back to the court of appeal last year.

The crown has consistently refused to concede that Hanratty's conviction should be quashed, pointing to DNA tests. DNA samples from Miss Storie's underwear and from a handkerchief used to wrap the murder weapon have matched strands taken from two of Hanratty's relatives. Nigel Sweeney, for the crown, told Lord Woolf it was 2.5m times more likely Hanratty was the source of the profile than anyone else.

Comparing samples with Hanratty's own DNA would help to establish the identity of the killer, the court heard. Lawyers for Hanratty's family said the exhumation would cause unnecessary hurt, as his remains are buried in the same plot as a relative.

But Lord Woolf, sitting with Mrs Justice Smith and Mr Justice Richards, said: "If some one has been executed for an offence for which he was not guilty, that is a matter of very great public concern."

Tamsin Allen, a lawyer acting for the Hanratty family, said exhumation would be a pointless exercise.

In a statement through Scotland Yard, Miss Storie said she had "total and absolute belief that James Hanratty was guilty of the crime for which he was hanged".

fields.headline: Governor's death clouds final debate
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush said they had no choice but to go ahead with their third and final presidential debate in Missouri last night despite the death of the state governor.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush said they had no choice but to go ahead with their third and final presidential debate in Missouri last night despite the death of the state governor, a key figure in Mr Gore's Democratic party, in a plane crash on Monday night.

Governor Mel Carnahan, who was running for election to the US Senate next month, was killed when a private plane taking him to a fundraising event crashed in poor weather about 30 miles south-west of St Louis, the scene of last night's debate.

The crash cast a pall over what was already a tense, high-stakes event in the presidential race. Both candidates agreed to pay tribute at the start of the debate to Carnahan and then go ahead with the debate as scheduled.

Carnahan, 66, died in a light-engine Cessna 335 piloted by his son Roger, 44, who also perished. Another passenger, Carnahan's campaign adviser, Chris Sifford, 37, was killed too.

Floral tributes were accumulating rapidly outside the governor's mansion in the state capital, Jefferson City, where Carnahan's widow Jean, his high school sweetheart, was being consoled by their three surviving children. Pres ident Clinton called Mrs Carnahan from Egypt to offer his condolences.

The death was big news across the US because Carnahan had been involved in a crucial part of the Democratic effort to retake the US Senate.

The popular and distinguished two-term governor was engaged in a neck-and-neck battle to unseat Senator John Ashcroft, a strong conservative, on November 7. Missouri is also a key swing state in the Gore-Bush race and one of five top target seats which the Democrats need to win to overturn the Republicans' current 54-46 majority in the Senate.

Mr Ashcroft suspended his campaign yesterday, and put all political advertising on hold "out of respect".

Under Missouri law, however, Carnahan's name must remain on the ballot because the deadline for nominations had closed, raising the macabre possibility that he could yet be elected posthumously. If that happens, and local Democrats will try to ensure it does, Democrat Roger Wilson who was preparing last night to succeed Carnahan as governor, will have the duty of appointing a replacement.

Carnahan was one of the most important moderate Democratic politicians in the US. His success in wresting control from the Republicans in the 1992 elections, and then maintaining it, mirrored Bill Clinton's strategy on the national stage. He was due to have attended the debate.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police chief faces hearing
fields.body:
Police chief faces hearing

Ian Beckett, deputy chief constable of Surrey, will face internal disciplinary charges, the police authority announced yesterday, believed to arise from allegations made by female civilian staff. Last month a jury aquitted him of sexually assaulting two women subordinates.

Award for Scots researcher

Dario Alessi, 32, a research fellow at the University of Dundee, will next month in Dusseldorf receive the Eppendorf award for his work on insulin, the first time in 55 years it has gone to Scotland.

Accountant drops race case

Indrajeet Lalbeharry, 57, of Haringey, north London, withdrew a claim for race discrimination on the third day of an industrial tribunal. The accountant's former employer, Lloyd's Register of Shipping, said in a statement he accepted unreservedly that his race was not the reason why he was refused promotion.

Guardian award for charities

Five charities at the sharp end of the drive against social exclusion are winners of this year's Guardian Charity Award for smaller voluntary organisations: the Beth Johnson Foundation, Stoke-on-Trent, working with older people; the Phoenix Community Furniture Scheme, Powys, providing for needy families; the Place 2 Be, helping children with emotional difficulties; the Shape Ticket Scheme, London, cut-price theatre tickets for disabled and older people; and the Semiside Community Gardens Association, north London, horticultural therapy for people with mental health problems.

fields.headline: Opera house job application liable to hit sour note with the old guard
fields.trailText: When Sir Colin Southgate was appointed chairman at Covent Garden he made it clear where he stood on the issue of the hoi-polloi: "We musn't downgrade the opera house. I don't want to sit next to somebody in a singlet, a pair of shorts and a smelly pair of trainers."
fields.body:
When Sir Colin Southgate was appointed chairman at Covent Garden he made it clear where he stood on the issue of the hoi-polloi: "We musn't downgrade the opera house. I don't want to sit next to somebody in a singlet, a pair of shorts and a smelly pair of trainers."

So heaven knowns what Sir Colin made of an application for the position of ROH executive director from the self-proclaimed founding father of a "people's opera" - commercial impresario Raymond Gubbay.

The self-appointed scourge of the ROH sent his application in time for Monday's closing date for a position that has been dogged by rumours of clashes with the ebullient chairman and several resignations. The latest of which, by Michael Kaiser in July, came less than two years after the American was drafted to shake up the house's troubled operation.

Mr Gubbay said yesterday that he made the application on behalf of his company, Raymond Gubbay Limited, after seeing an advertisement for the job in the Guardian a few weeks ago.

"I'm absolutely serious and ready to face the challenge to run one of the greatest opera houses of the world," he said.

Mr Gubbay said that he would change the house's image if he were appointed. "The house is still perceived to be a rich person's play-thing, a vaunt of corporate hospitality," he said.

"It needs to made more accountable, more accessible with better scheduling and a greater number of performances. The seat prices should be at a level that the public can afford," he said.

Mr Gubbay's application contains a 12-point plan of measures he would implement.

These include suggestions to tighten up the number of tickets given to "Friends of Covent Garden" in return for donations and an increase in the automony of the executive director, the music director of the Royal Opera and artistic director of the Royal Ballet.

Mr Gubbay's work has caused many a sharp intake of breath among the opera establishment. His stagings of La Bohème in 1995 and Carmen in 1996, they concluded, were cheap and tacky. Undeterred by disapproval, Mr Gubbay went on to attract 60,000 people to his production of Madame Butterfly in 1998 which involved flooding the Royal Albert Hall to create a water garden and a popularist version of Tosca at the same venue last year. Both productions managed that rare combination in the opera world: critical acclaim and popular appeal.

An ROH spokesman said: "If this application has been submitted, it will be considered with all the other applications." He added that the ROH would like to make the appointment - which will be decided by a recruitment consultancy, Sir Colin and a sub-committee of the house's board - by the end of November.

Andrew Clements, the Guardian's chief music critic, said: "It's rather amusing. He's always been a very strong critic of the way the ROH has been run."

fields.headline: It's in the bag, environment-wise
fields.trailText: UK shoppers use 8bn plastic carrier bags a year - 323 for every household in England or 134 for every person in the country.
fields.body:
UK shoppers use 8bn plastic carrier bags a year - 323 for every household in England or 134 for every person in the country.

For the government this poses a problem - eventually the bags have to be disposed of, and a year's supply of carrier bags thrown on the ground could cover an area 200,000 times the size of Oxford Street.

But the Department of Envi ronment is heartened by a survey which shows four out of five people re-use plastic bags, half of them for shopping, 43% for work or school, and 39% for packing gym kit.

The survey carried out for the government's £25m "Are you doing your bit?" campaign worries about the one in five people who never re-use their bags. With the bags taking many years to decompose the campaign believes the bag problem is ballooning.

Michaela Strachan, spokeswoman for the campaign, said: "Supermarket carrier bags may not be glamorous, but it is encouraging that people are finding ways to re-use them - we are all clearly bag ladies at heart."

The government campaign is encouraging supermarkets to extend "bags for life" schemes in which shoppers can opt for a more substantial bag that can be used repeatedly or even plastic crates to put in the car.

www.doingyourbit.org.uk
www.useitagain.org.uk

fields.headline: Frontrunners for new speaker
fields.standfirst: Special report: Who will be the new speaker?
fields.trailText: Michael Martin, 55, Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn; an engineer and union organiser, and a former councillor, he has been an MP since 1979. His quiet talents for organisation quickly made him Denis Healey's parliamentary private secretary (1981-83) and now the bookies' favourite.
fields.body:
Michael Martin, 55, Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn

An engineer and union organiser, and a former councillor, he has been an MP since 1979. His quiet talents for organisation quickly made him Denis Healey's parliamentary private secretary (1981-83) and now the bookies' favourite.

As first deputy chairman of the ways and means committee, he is Betty Boothroyd's No 3.

He is a Highland piper and a teetotaller who believes in family-friendly Commons hours and cautious modernisation.

He has courted the "tearoom vote" and New Labour women though, as a Roman Catholic, he voted to curb abortion. There are doubts about his grip, but he is both genial and determined.

Sir George Young, 59, Conservative, North West Hampshire

MP for Ealing Acton from 1974 until he did the "chicken run" to his present, safer seat in 1997. As a Tory moderate and economist, he was sacked and (much rarer) later reinstated by Lady Thatcher, despite him being a persistent poll tax rebel. He ended up under John Major as the transport secretary who pushed through rail privatisation.

A descendant of one of Nelson's admirals at Trafalgar, he went to Eton but demolished the rickety family seat at Cookham when he inherited it at 22. Very tall (6ft 5in) he was known as "the bicycling baronet" until officials insisted he could not safely cycle while carrying ministerial red boxes.

A moderate moderniser, he is considered likeable and capable, but aloof.

Gwyneth Dunwoody, 69, Labour, Crewe and Nantwich

She has been an MP on and off since 1966. She says she would restore power to Commons by enhancing the backbench role in scrutinising measures proposed by the government and EU institutions, plus maintaining greater freedom from party discipline.

She believes MPs should receive "adequate" pay and facilities, and have the chance to enjoy personal and family lives.

At present she is the chairwoman of the Commons transport select committee (where she bashes John Prescott as the minister in charge), and is the maverick candidate with cross-party support, attractive to those who would want someone to stand up to Tony Blair. Apparently fearless and outspoken, she has lots of friends, and enemies.

Alan Beith, 57, Liberal Democrat, Berwick-upon-Tweed

An MP since 1973, he has risen to be deputy leader of his party.

As an MP he is moderniser who favours changes in the working practices of the Commons, and is keen to be more involved in planning business in the chamber, which is at present done by the leader of the house.

He backs the breast-feeding lobby among women MPs.

He has some Labour support in the north-east, but the Liberal Democrats themselves are divided over Menzies Campbell's bid.

In summary: "A good Commons man."

And the rest:

Sir Alan Haselhurst, 63, Tory, Saffron Walden

Has represented Stansted airport country since 1977, as well as being a company director.

A super-moderate: soft spoken, Oxford-educated, pro-European, and anti-apartheid. He is Betty Boothroyd's deputy, but is considered not tough enough, and lacks sufficient support.

David Clark, 60, Labour, South Shields

This ex-cabinet moderniser wants to discard the 18th-century costume - including the wig, silk stockings and buckle shoes - for all but ceremonial occasions.

He backs a family-friendly Commons, with facilities for children and childcare, and the right for Members to bring their lap-tops into committees.

Michael Lord, 62, Conservative, Central Suffolk and North Ipswich

His platform is a promise to be independent of mind and "jealously guard the rights of back benchers", keeping the Commons separate from the government.

He identifies fairness, firmness and a sense of humour as some of the qualities needed by the Speaker.

Menzies Campbell, 59, Liberal Democrat, North East Fife

Has represented his Fife constituency (which includes the Royal and Ancient Golf Club at St Andrews) since 1987.

A smart lawyer, a QC in fact, he was a friend of the late John Smith and is also a former Olympic sprinter. At present he is the Lib Dem foreign affairs spokesman. A natural liberal and moderate. But Labour MPs say: "We won't back Ming."

Sir Patrick Cormack, 61, Conservative, South Staffordshire

He favours "improvement" rather than modernisation, stressing that traditions should not be discarded for the sake of change.

Solid Commons man despite reputation for pomposity, he is keen to restore Parliament to the "centre of the nation's life".

John Buterfill, 59, Tory, Bournemouth West

Wants reform of Speaker election, independent body to appoint chairs of select committees, and look at alternative forms of legislature.

John McWilliam, 59, Labour, Blaydon

Wants to reverse changes introduced by successive governments that have interfered with the role of the House in scrutinising the executive.

He also wants to sweep away "niggling and irrelevant" rules governing MPs' attire - including Speaker's wig - and Parliamentary language.

Opposes late sittings.

Nicholas Winterton, 62, Conservative, Macclesfield

He supports moves to make the experimental "parallel chamber" in Westminster Hall a permanent fixture of the Commons.

He is also likely to support more family-friendly facilities in the House.

A Tory trouble-maker, he was denied his knighthood - hence he is too controversial.

Richard Shepherd, 67, Conservative, Aldridge-Brownhills

A widely-admired rightwing libertarian who has been an MP since 1979; he supports freedom of information and other liberal causes. But he is too emotional to be Speaker, MPs say.

webTitle: Test case on status of 'male bride'

fields.headline: Test case on status of 'male bride'
fields.trailText: A woman who was born male and became a bride launched a ground-breaking case in the high court yesterday to try to have the marriage recognised as legally valid.
fields.body:
A woman who was born male and became a bride launched a ground-breaking case in the high court yesterday to try to have the marriage recognised as legally valid.

Mr Justice Johnson said he was "sympathetic" towards Elizabeth Bellinger, 54, who had lived with her husband Michael for 19 years.

Their plea was being challenged by the attorney general on the grounds that though the marriage ceremony occurred in front of a registrar, it was not lawful as Mrs Bellinger had never been female.

Under English law, a person registered male at birth remains male despite corrective surgery. The couple are challenging the law which allows marriage only between two people whose birth certificates show they are of opposite sex.

Ashley Bayston, representing Mrs Bellinger, described her client as "a male to female post-operative transsexual" who had always considered herself female. She had been "forced into marriage" with a woman and fathered children. She "broke free" and lived as a woman from 1971, beginning treatment at Charing Cross hospital, which led to surgery in 1981. She met her future husband in 1980, before surgery to remove her male genitals.

The couple married in 1981, without having to show their birth certificates, and Mrs Bellinger brought up her husband's daughter.

Ms Bayston said the question for the judge was whether Mrs Bellinger was a female in the eyes of the law and therefore able to marry a man. She asked the court to redefine what was meant by "man" and "woman" because the law was "outdated and unreliable".

Mr Justice Johnson spoke of those lumbered with maleness and with a terrible urge to be the opposite sex. "They are locked up in the wrong body. That seems such a terrible thing to endure...the law seems to be shutting its eyes."

The hearing, expected to last four days, continues today.

webTitle: Spying on admiring eyes of art lovers

fields.headline: Spying on admiring eyes of art lovers
fields.trailText: A spy camera was installed yesterday at the National Gallery in London to film people looking at one of the world's best-loved paintings. Unsuspecting gallery visitors were filmed peering at Van Gogh's Sunflowers and the images were relayed to a large plasma screen.
fields.body:
A spy camera was installed yesterday at the National Gallery in London to film people looking at one of the world's best-loved paintings. Unsuspecting gallery visitors were filmed peering at Van Gogh's Sunflowers and the images were relayed to a large plasma screen.

The exhibition, entitled Telling Time, covers the way time is portrayed in art and includes a look at the time people spend gazing at paintings and at the movement their eyes make.

Alexander Sturgis, the curator of the exhibition, said: "It shows the time it takes to look at a painting [covering] a few seconds to hours. Eyes are constantly jumping from point to point."

The show features the largest ever eye-tracking experiment, allowing visitors to see their own eye movements as they look at any of the 200 gallery pictures on display. The eye movments are monitored and then images are relayed by infrared reflection to a neighbouring screen.

David Wooding, of Derby university's applied vision research unit, which is running the experiment with the gallery, said: "No two people view a picture in exactly the same way and precisely how the viewer selects what to look at is not yet understood."

He added: "We hope to attract 20,000 people to take part...it is fun to see where you have looked. We hope to process the data and draw conclusions. It is known that the position of eye fixation is not random, but it is not fully understood which aspects of an image attract fixations."

The exhibition is sponsored by Esso and includes a range of artworks, from comic strips of Tintin to Rembrandt's Belshazzer's Feast. The pictures were chosen for the common theme of time, and show variously an entire story in a moment, blurred, fragmented, moving pictures, and double images.

The exhibition at the National Gallery runs from tomorrow until January 14 with free admission.
Press Association

fields.headline: Right out of order
fields.standfirst:
Recent poor election results are forcing European extremists to moderate their rhetoric. But the threat to democracy remains

Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: Last Sunday Jörg Haider's party did surprisingly poorly in regional elections in Styria. Its support dropped to 12.4%, under half of its share of the vote when his Austrian Freedom Party pushed their way to power in Vienna earlier this year.
fields.body:
Last Sunday Jörg Haider's party did surprisingly poorly in regional elections in Styria. Its support dropped to 12.4%, under half of its share of the vote when his Austrian Freedom Party pushed their way to power in Vienna earlier this year.

But this setback for the far right followed strong showings in Belgium (33% for Vlaams Blok in Antwerp city elections) and growing public support for the Fremskrittspartiet (Progress party) in Norway.

Cool judgment says the far right is not on the march across Europe. Extreme right parties do not exist in, for example, Ireland and Iceland and are irrelevant in Greece and Spain. Even in Germany the Deutsche Volksunion (German People's Union) and Die Republikaner (the Republicans) have never been able to sustain their occasional electoral successes, achieved only at the regional level. The Netherlands and Sweden and now even France have recently seen the far right's implosion.

What happened in the 90s was that the extreme right started to diversify. It failed electorally in some countries but in others became strongly established. Far right parties made it into government, first in Italy, where the "post-fascist" Alleanza Nazionale (National Alliance) joined the short-lived Berlusconi government in 1994, then in Austria, where Haider's Freiheitliche Partei Österreichs teamed up with the conservative People's party. In Germany the far right has terrorist elements which constitute a threat to public order. There are daily attacks on "undesirables" (the homeless, foreigners), notably in the regions of the new east. The German government has tried to save its reputation, as well as to ease its increasingly worried business community, by outlawing various small neo-Nazi groups. The Nationaldemokratische Partei Deutschlands (National Democratic party of Germany) may also be barred, which would be the first banning of a real political party since the 50s.

Germany is not the only European country facing terrorism from the right. Extremists in Sweden, following an American example, have sought to foment racial war. The Vitt Ariskt Motst nd (White Aryan Resistance) has robbed banks, threatened opponents and killed. The Swedish media responded earlier this year by publicly identifying some of its most violent members.

Extreme right parties have split internally. Moderates have moved to court mainstream rightwing parties by moderating their rhetoric. This strategy has been most successful for the Alleanza Nazionale in Italy and for Haider: they won the ultimate prize of inclusion in government. But in France, the hardline leader of the Front National, Jean-Marie Le Pen, ousted his moderate vice-chairman, Bruno Mégret, who is, incidentally, his son-in-law. Within the Vlaams Blok in Belgium, the camps are personified by Filip Dewinter (hardline) and Gerolf Annemans (moderate), which are only kept together by the boycott of the Blok by the mainstream parties.

Moderates (these terms are relative) have won votes by toning down the xenophobia and often using neo-liberal rhetoric - for example the Norwegian Progress party, the Italian Lega Nord (Northern League) and Haider. This has distinguished them from extreme right parties which tend to fight on a welfare-chauvinist platform, supporting a welfare state that is only for "our own people". But as they have attracted more working-class voters, neo-liberalism has been less in evidence. The ideological mix of such parties as the Norwegian Progress party and the Northern League in Italy is interesting. The League and Haider's Freedom party recently even changed their national allegiance - the League from Italy to "Padania" and the Freedom party from Germany to Austria.

Despite its diversification and electoral moderation, the extreme right still poses a threat to the democracies of western Europe in general, and to Austria, Belgium and Italy in particular.

It is not so much the health of extreme right parties as the feeble state of the mainstream rightwing. Modernised social democratic parties have triumphed in several countries, pushing the "old right" out of government and sometimes out of the ideological centre as well. In response, the old right has sought to revamp itself by taking over issues and positions from the extreme right.

The Bavarian Christian Social Union's recent campaign in regional elections was almost a copy of earlier Republican campaigns, while much of the UK Tory party's rhetoric on crime and refugees can hardly be distinguished from that of extreme right parties on the continent. There are voices within mainstream rightwing parties calling for a "normalisation" of the relationship with the extreme right. The threat has been perceived by governments. The sanctions against Austria agreed by the 14 other member states of the European Union were - it has even been argued - intended as a warning to the mainstream right.

But extreme right opinions cannot be wiped out by party bans or sanctions. They have to be addressed at the root, in the reasons why people choose to support the extreme right. The issues driving such support - immigration for example - fully deserve to be put on the political agenda, but not the right's prescriptions. It is up to the mainstream democratic parties to come up with policy solutions to extreme right problems.

 Cas Mudde teaches at Edinburgh University and wrote The Ideology of the Extreme Right, Manchester UP. c.mudde@ed.ac.uk

There are daily attacks on "undesirables" (the homeless, foreigners), notably in the regions of the new east. The German government has tried to save its reputation, as well as to ease its increasingly worried business community, by outlawing various small neo-Nazi groups. The Nationaldemokratische Partei Deutschlands (National Democratic party of Germany) may also be barred, which would be the first banning of a real political party since the 50s. Germany is not the only European country facing terrorism from the right. Extremists in Sweden, following an American example, have sought to foment racial war. The Vitt Ariskt Motst nd (White Aryan Resistance) has robbed banks, threatened opponents and killed. The Swedish media responded earlier this year by publicly identifying some of its most violent members. Extreme right parties have split internally. Moderates have moved to court mainstream rightwing parties by moderating their rhetoric. This strategy has been most successful for the Alleanza Nazionale in Italy and for Haider: they won the ultimate prize of inclusion in government. But in France, the hardline leader of the Front National, Jean-Marie Le Pen, ousted his moderate vice-chairman, Bruno Mégret, who is, incidentally, his son-in-law. Within the Vlaams Blok in Belgium, the camps are personified by Filip Dewinter (hardline) and Gerolf Annemans (moderate), which are only kept together by the boycott of the Blok by the mainstream parties. Moderates (these terms are relative) have won votes by toning down the xenophobia and often using neo-liberal rhetoric - for example the Norwegian Progress party, the Italian Lega Nord (Northern League) and Haider. This has distinguished them from extreme right parties which tend to fight on a welfare-chauvinist platform, supporting a welfare state that is only for "our own people". But as they have attracted more working-class voters, neo-liberalism has been less in evidence. The ideological mix of such parties as the Norwegian Progress party and the Northern League in Italy is interesting. The League and Haider's Freedom party recently even changed their national allegiance - the League from Italy to "Padania" and the Freedom party from Germany to Austria. Despite its diversification and electoral moderation, the extreme right still poses a threat to the democracies of western Europe in general, and to Austria, Belgium and Italy in particular. It is not so much the health of extreme right parties as the feeble state of the mainstream rightwing. Modernised social democratic parties have triumphed in several countries, pushing the "old right" out of government and sometimes out of the ideological centre as well. In response, the old right has sought to revamp itself by taking over issues and positions from the extreme right. The Bavarian Christian Social Union's recent campaign in regional elections was almost a copy of earlier Republican campaigns, while much of the UK Tory party's rhetoric on crime and refugees can hardly be distinguished from that of extreme right parties on the continent. There are voices within mainstream rightwing parties calling for a "normalisation" of the relationship with the extreme right. The threat has been perceived by governments. The sanctions against Austria agreed by the 14 other member states of the European Union were - it has even been argued - intended as a warning to the mainstream right. But extreme right opinions cannot be wiped out by party bans or sanctions. They have to be addressed at the root, in the reasons why people choose to support the extreme right. The issues driving such support - immigration for example - fully deserve to be put on the political agenda, but not the right's prescriptions. It is up to the mainstream democratic parties to come up with policy solutions to extreme right problems.  Cas Mudde teaches at Edinburgh University and wrote The Ideology of the Extreme Right, Manchester UP. c.mudde@ed.ac.uk

fields.headline: Problems that may be less than skin deep
fields.standfirst: Purchase could provide remedy
fields.trailText: The £233m deal to buy teenage spots remedy Clearasil is Boots' biggest acquisition since its disastrous purchase of retail conglomerate Ward White 10 years ago.
fields.body:
The £233m deal to buy teenage spots remedy Clearasil is Boots' biggest acquisition since its disastrous purchase of retail conglomerate Ward White 10 years ago.

It paid £900m for the Halfords, Payless and Fads group, but within a year it was clear it had overpaid - outrageously. Far from putting some fizz into Boots, Ward White was a white elephant which succeeded only in denting Boots' profitability. Piecemeal, it was unloaded and today only Halfords remains part of the Boots empire.

That dismal deal was the brainchild of Lord Blyth, then chief executive. It is probably no coincidence that this new adventure into dealmaking comes only shortly after his departure as chairman.

But the Clearasil acquisition looks far from being a Ward White-style stinker. It adds £94m annual sales to Boots Healthcare International - until now a £200m-a-year business. And that is before Boots rebrands a variety of French and German spot creams it already owns. It will also give BHI access to crucial American and Japanese markets for other big brands like Nurofen and E45.

Above all it will draw attention to BHI - a wallflower of a business, currently afflicted by the cloud of gloom which is hanging over all retail stocks.

Boots has its problems - not least its 120 stores in town centres with too much square footage now that it is pulling out of the home and leisure merchandise which traditionally filled its second floors. Boots is trialling services such as physiotherapy and beauty treatments in those wide open spaces and crossing its fingers the plan will work.

Analysts reckon BHI alone could be worth £1bn. If the new services show any signs of success - and there are encouraging signs, according to insiders - then Boots' share price is far too low.

Granada's gain

There also is something rather churlish about the way the investment community has treated Granada Compass since the hotels and catering group was created in the summer.

The first raspberry came on day one, with the City complaining that splitting the old Granada in two and merging its hotels with Compass risked diluting the reputation for go-go growth built on the pure catering side by Francis Mackay. So, last month news leaked here that Mr Mackay and his new chairman, Gerry Robinson, had accepted the City's arguments and were now ready to sell the hotels to French rival Accor. The market's reaction was one of indifference.

This week news emerged that Accor has pulled out of the talks, leaving Granada Compass to put the business up for auction instead. The market's reaction this time? Fresh hostility.

Now, it is argued, the whole thing will drag on deep into next year, with Compass probably being forced to sell off the various hotel brands piecemeal. Shares in Compass fell another 1.25% yesterday to make a shocking 32% loss over the past six weeks.

This appears to be a classic case of one-speed thinking in the City, where being in line with the consensus tends to be a greater prize than being right.

Whatever Messrs Robinson and Mackay say, it is a safe bet that the two planned to sell the hotels business from the outset - the complexity of the overall merger dictating that this part of the grand plan would have to wait. It can also be assumed that the leaking of the Compass/Accor discussions was more damaging to the French group's negotiating position than to the British firm. Accor stock slumped on fears it would have to raise cash to complete what was likely to be a £3bn deal.

It is fair speculation that Compass received a number of 11th hour offers for the hotels once it became clear it was genuinely ready to sell. And it is not too much of a leap of faith to believe that Compass would only have allowed Accor to flounce away from the negotiating table if it were confident of achieving better value elsewhere.

It has taken 10 years to turn Granada from a sprawling, underperforming wreck into two lean, well managed Footsie businesses. Griping now over whether the job is completed in two months or four months is plain crass.

Void vision

There it was, gone. Anglo-Swiss insurer Allied Zurich switched its primary share listing this week from Britain to Switzerland, becoming Zurich Financial from yesterday morning. But London's trading community did not receive their new shares. They could not trade and, in effect, this £30bn European blue chip all but disappeared for a day.

It was not immediately clear who was at fault, with the Crest settlement authorities in London blaming the Swiss. But the affair is another reminder that in an increasingly sophisticated international investment environment, Europe's trading and settlement infrastructure remains a long way short of adequate.

webTitle: Benn may change election of Speaker

fields.headline: Benn may change election of Speaker
fields.standfirst:
Veteran MP pushes for reform of arcane procedures

Special report: Who will be the new speaker?
fields.trailText: Tony Benn will today make a last-minute attempt to open up the arcane procedures for electing the 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons by securing agreement to change the rules as soon as MPs return to Westminster on Monday.
fields.body:
Tony Benn will today make a last-minute attempt to open up the arcane procedures for electing the 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons by securing agreement to change the rules as soon as MPs return to Westminster on Monday.

Contrary to expectation that nothing can be done despite a determined campaign by modernisers all summer, there is now a real chance for change. Instead of voting on candidates two at a time - hoping to get a consensus candidate from a crowded field - it would allow all 13 hopefuls to be voted on at once, with a second vote play-off between the top two.

That is Mr Benn's plan. The 75-year-old former Labour cabinet minister will meet Sir Edward Heath, father of the Commons and nine years his senior, to argue that the former Conservative premier has the power to let MPs choose directly between up to 13 aspirants to Betty Boothroyd's office.

The two old rivals are the only survivors of the 1950 parliament and have sat as MPs under eight speakers. Sir Edward, who may retire at the coming election - as will Mr Benn - has been telling MPs he will stick to the existing rules unless strongly persuaded otherwise. Sir Edward is keen to "get it right", while Mr Benn would relish a last blow for enhanced democratic procedures.

To nudge Sir Edward along, a clutch of senior ministers and ex-ministers, including John Major and Kenneth Clarke, as well as committee chairmen are backing changes. These include either a new voting system or the kind of hustings for candidates which younger MPs like Labour's Peter Bradley and Gordon Prentice are organising on Monday. In meetings yesterday the clerk of the Commons, Bill McKay, a key player, told Mr Benn and Sir Edward that, as acting speaker for the day Sir Edward can change the rules if MPs agree - a crucial concession to the case many MPs have made in letters to the former prime minister.

With or without a change of rules, and barring a spectacular upset, Michael Martin, a 55-year-old Glasgow trade unionist, will be elected. Miss Boothroyd will resign as Speaker and an MP this weekend after eight years of keeping order and running the £200m parliamentary budget.

Many MPs who support Mr Martin's candidacy also believe the rules should be changed. So do some on both sides who believe that he lacks the necessary grip or firmness to manage an unruly Commons and run the labyrinthine Palace of Westminster.

A high degree of consensus remains important. The past two speakers - Miss Boothroyd and Tory Bernard Weatherill - were elected by backbenchers against government-favoured runners. This time, candidates whose names have been promoted by ministerial "narks" have suffered accordingly.

Liberal Democrat Menzies Campbell has been hurt this way as has the Tory front-runner, former minister and arch-moderate Sir George Young, the most likely winner if Mr Martin stumbles.

Part of the problem lies in the timing of Miss Boothroyd's departure, designed to give the existing Commons the choice, but coming just as they began a 12-week summer break. The other problem this time is the number of would-be speakers who will not stand down though their hopes are slender.

In 1983 Margaret Thatcher hoped her former cabinet ally, Humphrey Atkins would win. When support was lacking he pulled out and backed Mr Weatherill, another Tory and ex-whip whom she disliked. In 1992 John Major backed Peter Brooke, who was popular but a recent cabinet member.

He proved the fallguy. Miss Boothroyd's name was put forward as an amendment to the Brooke motion - and carried convincingly by 372 to 238. Other Tory hopefuls melted away. If no Benn amendment is pushed through MPs expect a similar deal whereby someone, probably Alan Haselhurst, Miss Boothroyd's Tory deputy, is proposed - the fallguy - and Mr Martin's name added as the amendment.

He would probably win easily. If not Sir George's name might be proposed. But many MPs would regard it as an affront to democractic practice that 10 candidates never had their chance.

webTitle: Collins Stewart staff in line for £157m

fields.headline: Share fare
fields.standfirst: Collins Stewart staff in line for £157m
fields.trailText: The 182 employees of stockbroking firm Collins Stewart will share in a £157m windfall following its flotation next week.
fields.body:
The 182 employees of stockbroking firm Collins Stewart will share in a £157m windfall following its flotation next week.

Terry Smith who parted company with investment bank UBS 10 years ago after writing his controversial book Accounting for Growth, will own an 8% stake worth more than £25m.

Mr Smith and deputy chairman Andrew Stewart led the buy-out of the business from investment bank Singer & Friedlander this year for £120m. The flotation will value Collins Stewart at £326m, well above City estimates of £250m.

Mr Smith and his fellow directors will own 20% of the company after its flotation while the remaining employees will own 28%. They have agreed to wait 2 years before being allowed to sell up to half of their stakes.The shares are being placed at 316p and will start trading on October 24. Mr Smith, whose book highlighted unscrupulous auditing methods allegedly used by firms to boost their financial performance, said the business would not be run any differently after flotation.

"We do not take a massive amount of risk," Mr Smith said. "We don't pay big basic salaries and we don't have secretaries."

In additional to their personal stakes in the business, individuals would receive incentive packages, related "directly to what we make".

Collins Stewart made an operating profit before tax of £17.8m in the six months to the end of June. The £73m raised by the flotation will be used to pay off existing debts as well as develop Quest, its online equity research and share evaluation service.

Leigh Collins, co-founder of Collins Stewart, left in March.
