fields.headline: Boots picks up Clearasil for £233m
fields.trailText: Boots has splashed out £233m hoping to clean up in the market for teenage acne treatments.
fields.body:
Boots has splashed out £233m hoping to clean up in the market for teenage acne treatments.

The retail chain's medicines division, Boots Healthcare International, is buying the 50-year-old Clearasil brand from the US group Procter & Gamble in a deal which will increase BHI's sales by nearly a third.

BHI's managing director, Barry Clare, said Boots intended to use the "neglected" Clearasil brand on a range of anti-acne products it has in its portfolio after the purchase of skin care groups Lutsia in France and Hermal in Germany in the mid 1990s. "We have a lot of technology and a whole range of products we can exploit."

The Clearasil brand had sales of £94m last year and is the market leader in the US and across a number of European markets.

Boots said the market for teenage acne treatments is growing at 5% a year.

Acquiring the brand would also give BHI access to the US and Japanese markets, Mr Clare said.

"It will be our first venture into those markets. We will then be able to put the rest of our skin care range through those channels and follow up with the rest of our portfolio."

Boots Healthcare International is the fifth biggest over-the-counter medicines company in Europe and the fastest growing, even before yesterday's deal.

The group sells in more than 100 countries and focuses on three main product categories: skin care, analgesics, and cough and cold remedies - the last featuring brands such as E45, Nurofen and Strepsils.

Mr Clare said: "The Clearasil acquisition is an excellent strategic fit, substantially increasing NHI's global scale and coverage. It enables us to leverage our skin care technology and also broaden distribution in Europe to drugstore and grocery channels."

BHI hoped to do other, similar deals.

Analysts greeted the deal enthusiastically, calculating it would add £10m to the group's bottom line by March 2002.

Nick Bubb of SG Securities said the acquisition was "a good deal at a sensible price" and it "enhances the value of BHI".

Boots shares added 0.5p to 527.5p.

webTitle: No sex please, we're not Italian stallions

fields.headline: No sex please, we're not Italian stallions
fields.trailText: Pensioners have vastly more satisfying sex lives than the young or middle-aged, Italian researchers said yesterday. The absence of stress or the need to prove themselves makes housewives and the over-60s better lovers than professionals in their prime.
fields.body:
Pensioners have vastly more satisfying sex lives than the young or middle-aged, Italian researchers said yesterday. The absence of stress or the need to prove themselves makes housewives and the over-60s better lovers than professionals in their prime.

Narcissism and performance fears are ruining the new generation of Latin lovers, according to a survey of 60,000 people conducted by the Florence-based Italian Institute of Andrology, which studies sexual behaviour.

Three quarters of respondents aged 60-70 said they were happy with their sex lives. "They have learned that failure in bed is not a drama, but a problem that can be solved with a partner," said Vincenzo Mirone of the institute.

Younger people, especially men, were plagued by the conviction that they must always strive for sublime sex."This is already a premonition of failure," Prof Mirone said.

One in five men aged 18-30 suffered from premature ejaculation and 18% did not have a sex life. The daily Corriere della Sera commented: "The Latin lover is in decline. This reveals the new and disappointing sexual behaviour of the Italians."

Poor sex education and the pressure to appear macho were blamed.

On a satisfaction scale of 1-10, housewives scored the highest with eight, which researchers attributed to low stress levels. The same reason was cited for pensioners' and civil servants' ratings of seven.

Plunging below six, the cut-off point for satisfaction, were sportsmen, engineers, managers, journalists, pilots, air hostesses, actresses and television presenters.

Lawyers and exercise fanatics scored three, which was attributed to a narcissistic focus on the self, rather than the partner. Separated or divorced women scored lowest at two, which was thought to reflect infrequency rather than quality.

webTitle: Leader: Train crashes undermine public confidence

fields.headline: Less safe than it should be
fields.standfirst:
There is rising concern over railway safety

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: These are boom times for the railways. People complain about high fares and trains running late but they still take the train where a year or two back they might have relied on the car.
fields.body:
These are boom times for the railways. People complain about high fares and trains running late but they still take the train where a year or two back they might have relied on the car. Passenger numbers are 30% up since privatisation: freight tonnage is up 13%. The roads may still seem horribly crowded, but without this impressive shift they would be even worse. The government is banking now on a further 50% rise in passenger numbers within a decade.

But all that is bound to be jeopardised if the sense begins to spread that the railway is less safe than it should be. The circumstances in which a GNER train travelling from London to Leeds at a speed of around 115 mph left the rails yesterday near Hatfield, leaving six people dead and 24 in need of hospital treatment, are still far from clear. Terrorist involvement is not yet entirely ruled out. A broken wheel or axle is one possibility. Another is a broken rail: should that prove to have been the case it would be deeply ominous for Railtrack (whose shares fell by almost 10% on the news of the accident.) But whatever explanation emerges, this is the third major crash in three years, following Southall - still the subject of litigation - and Paddington - still under the painstaking scrutiny of the Cullen inquiry. The overwhelming majority of railway journeys are still completed safely, if not always on time. But after this sequence the confidence with which passengers settle into their seats at the start of a journey is bound to be undermined.

There will of course be an exhaustive inquiry. Yet the time these exercises take to come up with the answers is a further source of unease. Lord Cullen's findings on the Paddington disaster are expected at the end of the year - 14 months after the crash which killed 31 people. In the interests of travellers' confidence the inquiry into what happened at Hatfield yesterday will need to work to a tighter time scale than that.

People complain about high fares and trains running late but they still take the train where a year or two back they might have relied on the car. Passenger numbers are 30% up since privatisation: freight tonnage is up 13%. The roads may still seem horribly crowded, but without this impressive shift they would be even worse. The government is banking now on a further 50% rise in passenger numbers within a decade. webTitle: Comment: Election of the parliamentary speaker

fields.headline: Speak up
fields.standfirst:
Richard Shepherd is a Tory backbencher with a reputation for defending free speech. Now he is running for Speaker
Special report: New parliamentary speaker
fields.trailText: Has anyone noticed that the Commons has not met for three months, and does anyone care? Well they should, because this Monday's election of a new Speaker gives the nation a chance to check the stealthy sidelining and downgrading of parliament by an overmighty executive.
fields.body:
Has anyone noticed that the Commons has not met for three months, and does anyone care? Well they should, because this Monday's election of a new Speaker gives the nation a chance to check the stealthy sidelining and downgrading of parliament by an overmighty executive.

William Hague noted earlier this year that only in a country with a strong parliament is there genuine representative democracy. Those are the words of the leader of the opposition, but others say the same thing. The former Labour chief whip Derek Foster, speaking in the Commons, said: "This place must never be the prime minister's poodle. Unfortunately, it has become so."

Ministers hardly trouble themselves with supporting their own collective business in the most basic way, by voting for it. The chancellor has voted in 18% of divisions; the foreign secretary, more understandably, in 15%; the education secretary in 27%. Even more instructive is to see how often our prime ministers have voted: Harold Wilson in 35% of divisions; Ted Heath in 36%; Jim Callaghan in 38%; Margaret Thatcher in 45%; John Major in 41%. But in the case of Tony Blair, the figure is 5%. If a prime minister and his team care so little for parliament why should anyone else care?

The seeming indifference of ministers to the Commons is matched by their persistence in making policy announcements outside parliament. Not long ago a new policy, on-the-spot fines for hooligans, was announced to what one can only assume was a bemused conference of German theologians at Tübingen.

In some departments the interest of parliament is regarded as secondary to media presentation. This spinning is unaccountable and, I believe, self-defeating for it creates cynicism. There is another loss: senior ministers and frontbenchers participating in their department's business are the talent spotters for their successors. Only by taking their Commons business seriously can they understand and assess the qualities of their colleagues and hear how a new generation argues and reasons for the future of our country.

The government's changes to the House of Lords have accidentally brought about a significant shift of power from the elected to the unelected chamber. Who would have suspected that the government's deal with Lord Cranborne to half-castrate the legislative powers of hereditary peers would now be revitalising the unelected house into an increasingly formidable debating chamber with more teeth and more clout than the servile Commons?

The choice of a new Speaker will help MPs define how we see ourselves. Speakers have great power to influence the regard in which the Commons is held. As the chamber's "chairmen" they keep order in our debates, allow or disallow parliamentary questions to ministers, accept or refuse closure motions, select or reject backbench motions or amendments, permit or deny private notice questions or emergency debates, call or not call backbenchers, certify a money bill and rule on matters of privilege. The Speaker has the power to recall par liament in an emergency. To many people it seems a ceremonial job, of wig, breeches and mace, but it is at the heart of our democratic proceedings. As once a Speaker stood up to the demands of Charles I, so a Speaker must be able to stand up to the demands of his successors in Downing Street.

A new Speaker should also play his or her part in modernising conditions for those who work in the Commons. Good and able members are seeking to do that as the liaison committee showed in its report, Shifting the Balance. For 17 or 18 weeks a year the house is in recess. Perhaps by surrendering a few of those weeks the question of late-night sittings could be addressed without compromising the proper needs of oppositions and of backbenchers through the imposition of guillotines.

Perhaps the Commons could sit a little earlier. I know few who believe that debate late at night or through the night is really appropriate, except in extremis. In this parliament 38 bills have been guillotined, making scrutiny of bills very patchy. The guillotine on the Northern Ireland police powers bill was so unrealistically tight that it denied the house - and in particular elected members from Northern Ireland - the opportunity to debate amendments on its most contentious and central issue, the proposal to change the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. David Trimble was prevented from speaking on third reading. This cannot be right.

Reform of hours requires great discipline from government. Too many bills not properly prepared - or, indeed, being written as they go through committee - place a great burden on backbenchers. As always, proper reform should not tilt the balance further towards the executive and away from the house.

And we must ensure that the election result has not already been quietly fixed between the whips' offices of the major parties.

Richard Shepherd is the Conservative MP for Aldridge Brownhills.

fields.headline: Shire horse for Footsie course
fields.trailText: By the time specialist drug group Shire Pharmaceutical, unveils its third quarter figures in 13 days time there is every chance it will be a FTSE 100 constituent.
fields.body:
By the time specialist drug group Shire Pharmaceutical , unveils its third quarter figures in 13 days time there is every chance it will be a FTSE 100 constituent.

Following yesterday's promotion of property group Canary Wharf , down 31.75p at 527p, to the blue chip index Shire is the biggest company on the FTSE 100 reserve list and the City's favourite to snatch the place being vacated by Woolwich , off 2.25p to 369.75p.

Barclays , down 20p to £17.60p, is due to complete its £5bn acquisition of Woolwich next Tuesday, a process that will free up a FTSE 100 slot the following morning.

Index compiler FTSE International is set to replace Woolwich with the company on the reserve list that has the biggest market capitalisation. This figure will be based on Monday night's closing prices and as things stand that company is Shire.

Based on last night's closing price of £13.16, down 10p, Shire had a market value of £3.3bn, putting it comfortably ahead of the other candidates, Psion (£2.15bn), Hanson (£2.4bn), Rolls-Royce (£2.7bn) and AB Foods (£2.9bn).

Dealers expect promotion to be positive for Shire. It will benefit from the kudos of being a blue chip stock and funds that track the FTSE 100 will be forced to buy Shire shares. This should result in Shire's share price being squeezed higher in the coming week.

The real test could be whether Shire can retain its place. The next quarterly index reshuffle is due in early December and Shire could fall back.

Elsewhere, the three session winning streak of leading shares came shuddering to a halt, unsettled by the sharp decline of telecoms stocks, and speculation that Goldman Sachs was waiting for the right moment to unleash a huge "sell" order on to the market.

Whether or not Goldman had executed such a trade, dealers said the speculation served to highlight how jittery the market is at the moment. The FTSE 100 ended the day 82.5 points weaker at 6,203.2, while the FTSE 250 fell 43.8 to 6,435.1 and the Techmark slipped 84.81 to 3,362.32.

Further evidence of the nervous tone was provided by the performance of CMG . The share price of the Anglo-Dutch IT services group plunged 202p, or 15.28%, to £11.20, on rumours the company had been advising analysts that their profits forecasts were too high. In fact, CMG had contacted a number of investment banks to check on the complex models they use to produce their profits forecasts. One, Lehman Brothers, was forced to cut its earning forecast by 2% to incorporate a higher interest charge related to CMG's acquisition of IT consultancy firm Admiral.

However, fund managers interpreted this piece of mun dane number crunching as bad news because of its relationship with the Admiral deal - one that was never popular, not least because Admiral had already issued two profits alerts. "Every investor knows, profit warnings come in threes and investors remain convinced another is on the way", one dealer said.

The rest of the IT service sector suffered, with Logica falling 95p to £18.50 and Sema surrendering 44p to 925p.

Vodafone led telecoms stocks lower, diving 10.75p to 252p in the response to Monday's news that the flotation of Verizon Wireless, in which Vodafone holds a 45% stake, had been delayed. Elsewhere, BT fell 38.5 to 682p and Cable & Wireless lost 32p to 860p

Defensive stocks were in demand. Tobacco groups BAT and Imperial Tobacco rose 18p to 480p and 27p to 695 respectively, while Scottish & Southern Energy added 14p to 557p.

Lower down the market, software firm Innovation Group rose 162.5p to £10.87 on the back on an upbeat trading update and engineering group Booth Industries added 4p to 25.5p on news a director had bought 12,500 shares.

fields.headline: Misys on the move
fields.trailText: Speculation about a possible profits warning from CMG dragged Misys shares 50.5p lower to 669.5p yesterday. The weakness could provide a good buying opportunity.
fields.body:
Speculation about a possible profits warning from CMG dragged Misys shares 50.5p lower to 669.5p yesterday. The weakness could provide a good buying opportunity.

While CMG was yesterday busy denying any problems, Misys was bringing an important sector of the financial services industry onside. Together with six ofBritain's leading insurers, Misys is planning a business-to-business internet portal that is expected generate several million pounds of transaction revenues.

The new venture coincides with a growing feeling that demand in the banking sector is returning and earnings growth is likely to accelerate. Misys has called an analyst conference to talk about the issue next Friday and the message is expected to be a positive one.

Morgan Stanley reckons Misys shares are worth 825p. Upward movement in the price seems likely.

fields.headline: At this price?  Regus
fields.trailText: One year after being forced to postpone flotation plans amid a wave of investor scepticism, Regus, which runs business centres, was celebrating last night after finally making its stock market debut in London and New York.
fields.body:
One year after being forced to postpone flotation plans amid a wave of investor scepticism, Regus, which runs business centres, was celebrating last night after finally making its stock market debut in London and New York.

The bold decision to press ahead despite the recent market turbulence proved to be justified as the stock rose from its 260p-per-share offer price to close the day in London at 277p.

City analysts expect the shares to surge even higher as the company, regarded as one of the fastest growing in Europe, continues its aggressive expansion plans.

Most of the £235m raised in yesterday's flotation will be used to set up more business centres in the US.

The company, set up 11 years ago by chief executive Mark Dixon, started off as one Brussels-based office catering for the city's stressed travelling executives.

It now has 302 centres in 47 countries offering fully equipped office space, secretarial and technical support.

Last year, institutional investors were questioning the company's financial strength and its ability to achieve expansion targets. These worries, it seems, have been banished by a strong performance, with revenues for 2000 predicted by management to be between £385m and £415m.

"The view is this is a real growth story," said one analyst. "It's the sort of story investors are happy to buy into."

Regus is by far the dominant force in a sector with just a handful of players, although more competitors are expected to emerge over the next couple of years.

Its nearest rival, albeit unlisted, is US-based HQ Global Workplaces, while the smaller Servcorp of Australia is also on the scene.

The company's business centre roll-out programme is not, however, totally free of problems.

The costs associated with setting them up, such as finding sites and signing leases, are high and it can take many months before they make it into profit.

It does bear many hallmarks of old economy companies, such as links to the property market, though it is not directly exposed to oil price volatility.

The positive aspects, however, far outweigh the negative and this could well be a good addition to the portfolio.

Buy.

fields.headline: Common ground
fields.standfirst:
The Middle East conflict is not a battle between good and evil but between right and right

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Middle East conflict is not a battle between good and evil but between right and right
fields.body:
The verdict came swiftly and with characteristic eloquence. The leaders had spent 28 hours arguing, shouting and finally negotiating in Sharm el-Sheikh - but the people they represent took just minutes to deliver their response. As the summit ended, Palestinian militiamen aimed their guns at a Jewish neighbourhood of Jerusalem and Israel responded with tank-mounted machine gun fire. So much for the paper truce, painstakingly pieced together by Bill Clinton and his unique brand of insomnia diplomacy.

Not that you can blame the American president. Nor can you point the finger at Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak: they are merely reflecting the mood on the Palestinian and Israeli streets. For both sides in this conflict have returned to the hardest of hard lines. The past two weeks have put them back on a war footing, and they are digging into their trenches.

Ordinary Palestinians and Israelis, and their defenders outside the region, are returning to the old, cold positions. The email that has reached me this last week is revealing enough. Advocates for Israel are singing once more the 1970s refrain that the Palestinians already have a home ("It's called Jordan") or that the Arabs have 22 other countries to go to, so why must they have poor little Israel too? These are arguments that Israel and Zionism were meant to have abandoned two decades ago. Yet here they go again.

The same regression has occurred on the Palestinian side. The email inbox speaks not only of the evils of Israel's post-1967 occupation, or the grotesque record of discrimination inside Israel proper, but of the country's fundamental crime: its mere existence. Longtime rejectionists such as Edward Said are back in business, appearing on Start the Week to call implicitly for the dissolution of the Jewish state - and facing only the slightest challenge. The clear undertow of the phone-in shows and letters pages is the same: not opposed to this border or that settlement, but to the very idea of Israel. As one veteran peace activist told the Guardian this week: "It's not that they don't want us here as occupiers. They don't want us here at all."

For those who thought the 1993 handshake between Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin heralded a new dawn, this return to core hostilities is profoundly depressing. The breakthrough of the Oslo accords was to move beyond the absolutist demands of the past - in which each side claimed exclusive right to the land - to a new place, where the two nations finally saw each other. It was that new premise, that both sides had a claim on the same, disputed territory, that underpinned the so-called two-state solution: one for Palestinians, one for Israelis.

The trouble, it seems now, is that that logic was never fully accepted by both sides. Palestinians say that Israel never understood it: hence the paltry, pocket Palestine Barak was offering at Camp David. Israelis say Arafat never understood it: hence his regular rhetorical flourishes, in Arabic, hinting at the eventual liquidation of Israel.

We are in the realm of retro nationalism, with both Israelis and Palestinians sinking their noses back into history rather than lifting their eyes to the future. But the paradox may be that this could be just what the Israel/Palestine battle needs. Perhaps, if they are ever to have a chance of making peace, both sides need to get to the bottom of their argument once and for all.

For Palestinians that means a recognition from Israel that they are a people with national rights. Rabin and Barak both dipped a toe in this water, and Israel's liberal intelligentsia have gone much further. But now Israelis themselves may have to dive in. Yesterday's Ha'aretz newspaper contained an extraordinary essay, all the more remarkable for being published in the current climate. In it sociologist Danny Rabinowitz adds to the current back-to- basics mood by suggesting Israel needs to reflect on its own birth in 1948 - and make amends. He urges his fellow countrymen to acknowledge at last that their state was created at the cost of tragedy and dispossession to another people. He suggests government memorials for the 400 Palestinian villages destroyed in 1948, proper care for ruined mosques and churches, an official memorial day for the Palestinian tragedy - even perhaps a change to Israel's national anthem and flag. What Rabinowitz, in common with Israel's "new historians", wants is for the Jewish state finally to see the other side: to recognise the Palestinians' history and understand their claim.

I sraelis, of course, want the same thing. Among the ironies of the peace process is that, while one of the great sticking points was always Israeli recognition of a Palestinian state, it is Israel which desperately wants Palestinian recognition - of the Jewish state. It is a constant neurosis of the Israelis that their presence in the Middle East is not accepted as legitimate by their neighbours. They need to hear the Palestinian intelligentsia, if not Arafat himself, at least acknowledge that Israel has a right to exist - yes within smaller borders, yes with an end to occupation and brutality, yes with a policy of internal equality - but a right to exist.

Yet such acceptance never comes. Until now, the best Israelis could hope for was a pragmatic recognition by Palestinians that there are 5m Jews in the region and they cannot be wished away. But that grudging, de facto acceptance has not been enough to make Israelis feel secure - and ready to forge a genuine peace with their neighbours.

What Israelis, and indeed Jews around the world, need to hear is that Palestinians, and their supporters, recognise that Jews have a right to self-determination like every other people: the Scots, the Catalans, even the Palestinians themselves. Of course the tragic difference is that the territory designated by Jews as the stage for their self-determination already had another people living there. In an ideal world, the Jews would have gone somewhere else. But where? There was no land without a people for "the people without a land".

Besides, much as the anti-Zionist absolutists refuse to see it, the Jews do have a millennia-old connection to that terrain. No matter what Hanan Ashrawi may say, Jews did not "fabricate" Joseph's Tomb. Nor is Haram al-Sharif important only to Muslims: it is also the site of the Jews' Second Temple. It would be easier if the claim was all on one side, as the Palestinian hardliners and Zionist right insist it is. But the truth is not so absolute.

So maybe there's hope to be had in this current return to first principles. Maybe, through this argument, those outside the region will see that this is not a Wild West battle of cowboys and Indians, Zionist villains against Palestinian heroes, but a tragedy - pitting against each other two needy peoples, whose causes are both just. When both sides see each other that way, then maybe they will decide to share the land, not only because they have to - but because it is right.

Advocates for Israel are singing once more the 1970s refrain that the Palestinians already have a home ("It's called Jordan") or that the Arabs have 22 other countries to go to, so why must they have poor little Israel too? These are arguments that Israel and Zionism were meant to have abandoned two decades ago. Yet here they go again. The same regression has occurred on the Palestinian side. The email inbox speaks not only of the evils of Israel's post-1967 occupation, or the grotesque record of discrimination inside Israel proper, but of the country's fundamental crime: its mere existence. Longtime rejectionists such as Edward Said are back in business, appearing on Start the Week to call implicitly for the dissolution of the Jewish state - and facing only the slightest challenge. The clear undertow of the phone-in shows and letters pages is the same: not opposed to this border or that settlement, but to the very idea of Israel. As one veteran peace activist told the Guardian this week: "It's not that they don't want us here as occupiers. They don't want us here at all." For those who thought the 1993 handshake between Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin heralded a new dawn, this return to core hostilities is profoundly depressing. The breakthrough of the Oslo accords was to move beyond the absolutist demands of the past - in which each side claimed exclusive right to the land - to a new place, where the two nations finally saw each other. It was that new premise, that both sides had a claim on the same, disputed territory, that underpinned the so-called two-state solution: one for Palestinians, one for Israelis. The trouble, it seems now, is that that logic was never fully accepted by both sides. Palestinians say that Israel never understood it: hence the paltry, pocket Palestine Barak was offering at Camp David. Israelis say Arafat never understood it: hence his regular rhetorical flourishes, in Arabic, hinting at the eventual liquidation of Israel. We are in the realm of retro nationalism, with both Israelis and Palestinians sinking their noses back into history rather than lifting their eyes to the future. But the paradox may be that this could be just what the Israel/Palestine battle needs. Perhaps, if they are ever to have a chance of making peace, both sides need to get to the bottom of their argument once and for all. For Palestinians that means a recognition from Israel that they are a people with national rights. Rabin and Barak both dipped a toe in this water, and Israel's liberal intelligentsia have gone much further. But now Israelis themselves may have to dive in. Yesterday's Ha'aretz newspaper contained an extraordinary essay, all the more remarkable for being published in the current climate. In it sociologist Danny Rabinowitz adds to the current back-to- basics mood by suggesting Israel needs to reflect on its own birth in 1948 - and make amends. He urges his fellow countrymen to acknowledge at last that their state was created at the cost of tragedy and dispossession to another people. He suggests government memorials for the 400 Palestinian villages destroyed in 1948, proper care for ruined mosques and churches, an official memorial day for the Palestinian tragedy - even perhaps a change to Israel's national anthem and flag. What Rabinowitz, in common with Israel's "new historians", wants is for the Jewish state finally to see the other side: to recognise the Palestinians' history and understand their claim. I sraelis, of course, want the same thing. Among the ironies of the peace process is that, while one of the great sticking points was always Israeli recognition of a Palestinian state, it is Israel which desperately wants Palestinian recognition - of the Jewish state. It is a constant neurosis of the Israelis that their presence in the Middle East is not accepted as legitimate by their neighbours. They need to hear the Palestinian intelligentsia, if not Arafat himself, at least acknowledge that Israel has a right to exist - yes within smaller borders, yes with an end to occupation and brutality, yes with a policy of internal equality - but a right to exist. Yet such acceptance never comes. Until now, the best Israelis could hope for was a pragmatic recognition by Palestinians that there are 5m Jews in the region and they cannot be wished away. But that grudging, de facto acceptance has not been enough to make Israelis feel secure - and ready to forge a genuine peace with their neighbours. What Israelis, and indeed Jews around the world, need to hear is that Palestinians, and their supporters, recognise that Jews have a right to self-determination like every other people: the Scots, the Catalans, even the Palestinians themselves. Of course the tragic difference is that the territory designated by Jews as the stage for their self-determination already had another people living there. In an ideal world, the Jews would have gone somewhere else. But where? There was no land without a people for "the people without a land". Besides, much as the anti-Zionist absolutists refuse to see it, the Jews do have a millennia-old connection to that terrain. No matter what Hanan Ashrawi may say, Jews did not "fabricate" Joseph's Tomb. Nor is Haram al-Sharif important only to Muslims: it is also the site of the Jews' Second Temple. It would be easier if the claim was all on one side, as the Palestinian hardliners and Zionist right insist it is. But the truth is not so absolute. So maybe there's hope to be had in this current return to first principles. Maybe, through this argument, those outside the region will see that this is not a Wild West battle of cowboys and Indians, Zionist villains against Palestinian heroes, but a tragedy - pitting against each other two needy peoples, whose causes are both just. When both sides see each other that way, then maybe they will decide to share the land, not only because they have to - but because it is right. Contact: jonathanfreedland@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Highway panic as snake legs it to freedom

fields.headline: Highway panic as snake legs it to freedom
fields.trailText: A family outing to a pet shop to buy dog shampoo ended with a police armed response unit prowling the A46 in Warwickshire, after a three-foot snake slithered out of a bag of shopping and up a car passenger's trouser leg.
fields.body:
A family outing to a pet shop to buy dog shampoo ended with a police armed response unit prowling the A46 in Warwickshire, after a three-foot snake slithered out of a bag of shopping and up a car passenger's trouser leg.

David Wilson, 29, of Warwick, was travelling home from Coventry on Monday with his wife and two young children when the snake emerged from a carrier bag.

The intruder was, in fact, a non-poisonous corn snake.

Mr Wilson said yesterday: "I saw a snake coming out of the bag and it started climbing up my leg.

"I just panicked. I was hysterical. When my wife saw the snake's head it set her off, and then my daughter started crying."

Mr Wilson's wife Natalie, who was driving, managed to pull over. The couple fled the vehicle with their two children, aged six and 18 months.

By chance, a police armed response unit was travelling down the dual carriageway near Leek Wootton, and stopped to give assistance.

"One of the officers joked that if the worst came to the worst, he could always shoot the snake," said Mr Wilson, a supermarket manager.

Mrs Wilson had gone to the pet shop to buy dog shampoo, while her husband had a haircut. While she was in the shop, she also bought a fish tank suction pipe, and it is thought that the snake must have earlier taken up its abode inside the pipe.

The reddish-brown reptile, also known as the red ratsnake, is native to the south-eastern United States, where its natural habitat is in abandoned buildings and rubbish piles. It lives on rodents and small birds.

The stowaway was eventually recovered from the car's engine and taken to a nearby pet shop for safety.

Mr Wilson added: "It may have been only about three feet long but as far as I was concerned it was 10ft and a python."

webTitle: Leader: Peace in Israel is still uncertain

fields.headline: A deal, but only just
fields.standfirst:
Hope still burns low in the Middle East

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The agreement to halt the latest round of Israeli-Palestinian violence, grudgingly and gracelessly accepted by the two sides yesterday after intense American arm-twisting, is as fragile as a gossamer thread on a windy autumn's day, and possibly just as transient.
fields.body:
The agreement to halt the latest round of Israeli-Palestinian violence, grudgingly and gracelessly accepted by the two sides yesterday after intense American arm-twisting, is as fragile as a gossamer thread on a windy autumn's day, and possibly just as transient. Like Sharm el-Sheikh, the Red Sea resort where the crisis summit was held, the deal is built on sand. Nothing was written down, nothing signed, nor were any handshakes exchanged. All depends on implementation, and on mutual trust and goodwill, of which at present there is none.

The participants of this forced, angry meeting, seething with resentment and grievance, at times simply substituted diplomatic stone-throwing for the pitched street battles of the past 20 days. For all Bill Clinton's patient, unctuous trauma counselling, for all his pious hopes of a return to the path of peace, this cold fury remains undispelled. Its root causes, Mr Clinton's specious fact-finding committee to one side, remain unaddressed. Its future, unpredictable expression, sparked perhaps by another child killing, another lynching, or by a marketplace bomb, may swiftly destroy all tentative hope of rapprochement. For even as Mr Clinton headed back to Washington for the funerals of US sailors killed by the new intifada's sympathisers in Yemen, blood was flowing again in occupied Palestine and, on both sides of the divide, the deadly dance resumed.

That, against the odds, yesterday's deal will stick, will halt the killing and defuse the crisis, is profoundly desirable. But even if it does, it is difficult to escape the conclusion that recent events have permanently changed the broader context of the search for a Middle East settlement. The deep, unfeigned anger of younger generations of Palestinians at a peace process they see as weighted against their nation's interests has both wrongfooted and galvanised their corrupt, lacklustre leadership, and stirred the apathetic Arab world beyond. Yasser Arafat may seek the plaudits and backing of the Arab League summit in Cairo this weekend, but his standing with his own people is shakier than at any time. He is increasingly in danger of being seen by them as the stooge of a discredited, US-led scheme to circumvent UN resolutions, stifle Palestine's legitimate aspirations, and consolidate Israel's quasi-colonial dominance. Nor are US-backed leaders in Egypt, Jordan and the Gulf immune from this radicalising shift in opinion, one encouraged as before by Iran and Syria but now also by a dangerously resurgent, oil-rich Iraq.

In Israel, too, many of the assumptions of the past decade are under scrutiny. Israel's peace camp, both at home and in the US, has - like Ehud Barak's government - been deeply destabilised and dismayed by this furious eruption. The belief here is that the Palestinians, acting out of visceral racial and religious hatred, and not as a matter of principle and in reaction to Israel's excessive use of force, have deliberately betrayed the peace process. This disarray, of course, only strengthens the Likud's Ariel Sharon and the religious right who somehow contrive to find in the corpses of nearly 100 Palestinians a vindication of their own confrontational policies. It is hard to see how Mr Barak can now work his way back to full negotiations, as Mr Clinton urged, even if Mr Arafat is strong enough to try again. Indeed, he has already withdrawn previous, proffered concessions. Like the Palestinians, Mr Barak must know that even if yesterday's agreement holds, the balance has fundamentally shifted - and for those interested in peace, probably for the worse.

fields.headline: and moving the BBC news
fields.trailText: Peter Preston's argument that the BBC's decision to move the Nine O'Clock News was a result of "quality" (of programme) over "quantity" (of viewers) is unconvincing (Knives are out at the Borgia Broadcasting Corporation, October 16).
fields.body:
Peter Preston's argument that the BBC's decision to move the Nine O'Clock News was a result of "quality" (of programme) over "quantity" (of viewers) is unconvincing (Knives are out at the Borgia Broadcasting Corporation, October 16).

Preston's criticism of Chris Smith's "lecturing" of broadcasters and his suggestion that new laws to regulate television are probably unnecessary in a multichannel age are also misplaced. Like it or not, television remains the single most powerful means of communication in our society, and it is crucial to ensure that content is not left entirely to the mercy of the market.

Repeated surveys show that over 80% of British people use television as their main source of information on international issues. Yet weaker regulation in the last broadcasting act in 1990 heralded a decade in which programmes on international issues declined by 50% across all channels, and most of those that remain focus on wildlife or travel. Deregulation may well produce the quality over quantity that Preston admires - quality programmes on international issues relegated to niche channels with tiny audiences.
Cathy Corcoran
Head of external relations, Cafod

 I saw the first edition of the BBC's new, much-vaunted 10 O'Clock News. The timing and presentation may be different, but the news has not improved.
David Johnson
Harrogate, North Yorkshire David.Johnson@bl.uk

fields.headline: China accused of infiltrating India
fields.trailText: A claim that Chinese troops have been making regular forays into Indian territory on the disputed border has thrown relations between the two countries into turmoil.
fields.body:
A claim that Chinese troops have been making regular forays into Indian territory on the disputed border has thrown relations between the two countries into turmoil.

Mukut Mithi, the chief minister of the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh, said that Chinese army patrols had been crossing mountain terrain there and harassing villagers.

The disputed 650-mile border in India's north-east, known as the Line of Actual Control (LAC), has long been a flashpoint between the two nuclear powers which fought a border war there in 1962.

The chief minister claimed that Indian intelligence had uncovered a Chinese-built mule trail on the Kaila pass, in the remote Dibang valley. The trail proved "repeated" incursions across the LAC, he said, adding that Chinese troops disguised themselves as hunters and farmers.

Unchecked, the incursions would "snowball into another controversy", he warned.

China claims a large swath of territory in Arunachal Pradesh - which is home to many Buddhist Tibetan tribes - while India maintains that China still holds 40,000 sq km of territory which New Delhi claims in Kashmir. Indian commanders on the border were reported to be refusing to discuss the matter last night.

On Monday, China's state media dismissed the reports as "inaccurate". An Indian foreign affairs spokesman said he would not confirm or deny the claims, adding that both sides signed agreements to resolve the border issue in 1993 and 1996.

Unlike the frontier between India and Pakistan in Kashmir - where rival troops shell each other every day - Indian and Chinese units do not exchange fire. Postmen from both countries even exchange letters for villagers. Suspicions remain, however.

The Chinese army last crossed the border in 1986, into the Tawang valley, and built a helipad (later destroyed by India).

If superficially polite, relations between New Delhi and Beijing are best characterised as mistrustful. India accuses China of helping Pakistan to stockpile a nuclear and missile arsenal much larger than its own - a claim backed by US intelligence.

In 1998, India defended its controversial nuclear tests by pointing to a Chinese nuclear threat. China said India was trying to dominate south Asia.

webTitle: 'This will be massive... we want Mugabe gone!'

fields.headline: 'This will be massive... we want Mugabe gone!'
fields.standfirst:
Spread of rioting in the capital, and a move to impeach him, pile pressure on Zimbabwe leader

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Anti-government riots swept through Harare yesterday, increasing pressure on President Robert Mugabe who also faces a call for his impeachment in parliament this week.
fields.body:
Anti-government riots swept through Harare yesterday, increasing pressure on President Robert Mugabe who also faces a call for his impeachment in parliament this week.

Two military helicopters were deployed as the government tried to contain the riots, which were spreading. They were triggered this week by increases in the price of staple foods and basic transport.

"To hell with Mugabe," shouted a tall young man as he threw a rock at a passing police vehicle in the Ardbennie township. "We don't want to see Mugabe any more."

Thousands of protesters disrupted business yesterday by putting barricades across main thoroughfares and stoning police vans and other passing vehicles. Policemen fanned out across the capital city's sprawling townships shooting teargas canisters at clusters of people.

About 50 people have been arrested. No serious casualties were confirmed yesterday, although the capital is awash with rumours of shootings and deaths.

The riots, which have so far been concentrated in poor black neighbourhoods, erupted early Monday in the eastern Mabvuku and Tafara townships, where residents protested against higher bus fares and 30% increases in bread and sugar prices in recent days.

Yesterday, the demonstrations swept through the rest of the city's teeming townships. Helicopters flew over industrial and residential areas to identify trouble spots, before sending in troops.

"This is not just an economic protest, this is political. We want Mugabe out. This is going to grow and it will be massive. We cannot wait until 2002 [the next presidential election] for Mugabe to go," said one man, Tendai, between hurling rocks. "We want him gone by the end of this month!"

There are reports that Zimbabwe's main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, has organised the disturbances. The MDC denies this, but its president, Morgan Tsvangirai, added to the pressure on Mr Mugabe when he said his party would introduce an impeachment motion in parliament this week.

With 57 of the parliament's 150 seats, the party can initiate impeachment proceedings. Mr Tsvangirai said the MDC would charge that Mr Mugabe has "maliciously abused his office and grossly violated the constitution". He said the riots were not a surprise because "the anger of the people can only be contained for so long".

At the barricades in Ardbennie, just south of the city centre, Leonard, a young auto electrician, said: "This government has to go because it has failed to address the bread and butter issues of the people."

Ministers were "lining their pockets and driving in luxurious cars. They don't bother to think about the ordinary person who can no longer afford to put basic food on the table. Mugabe says everything is about land. We don't care about land, we care about the economy. We want jobs and we want living standards to stop dropping."

Some of the most vicious violence was in Mbare township, a kilometre south of the centre of Harare, where swarms of angry rioters indiscriminately pelted passing vehicles with rocks before looting any valuables they found inside.

"All the windows of my car were shattered and the sides are all battered, but I was not injured and I just drove on," said Neville James, who was surprised by the violence.

"I am angry and shaken by such senseless violence," he said, "but if this is what it takes to bring a change in the government and more sensible policies, then maybe it is necessary."

fields.headline: An unhealthy obsession
fields.trailText: Your report ('Explosive' NHS plans revealed, October 17) speculating that the Institute for Public Policy Research may propose the privatisation of NHS management, is a product of successive governments failing to invest in training and IT systems which leave many managers, unsurprisingly, poorly equipped to deal with change.
fields.body:
Your report ('Explosive' NHS plans revealed, October 17) speculating that the Institute for Public Policy Research may propose the privatisation of NHS management, is a product of successive governments failing to invest in training and IT systems which leave many managers, unsurprisingly, poorly equipped to deal with change.

To believe naively that the private sector can do better is silly: their managers, just like NHS bureaucrats, can be remote, rude and unaccountable as anyone who has grappled with insurance, bank and other private sector bureaucracies can vouch. Like the private finance initiative, this proposal at worst will be a stupid hangover from monetarism and unsubstantiated faith in the private sector. At best it may make the government realise that its ambitious and overdue programme of NHS reform requires investment to ensure excellence in management systems and performance. That would be a welcome change to the current approach, which uses barely disguised threats of retribution to "encourage" the NHS troops.
Prof Alan Maynard
University of York akm3@york.ac.uk

 Faced with the latest business-obsessed proposals from the IPPR, I wonder which aspect of New Labour and its satellites is the more worrying. Is it the astonishing naivety of those academics, party members and MPs who have no experience whatsoever of the realities of the commercial world, or is it the influence of the cleverer figures who do?
Chris Williams
London lyra@mcmail.com

That would be a welcome change to the current approach, which uses barely disguised threats of retribution to "encourage" the NHS troops. Is it the astonishing naivety of those academics, party members and MPs who have no experience whatsoever of the realities of the commercial world, or is it the influence of the cleverer figures who do? fields.headline: On moving the BBC...
fields.trailText: I was sorry when Liz Forgan resigned from the BBC (There and back again, October 17). I'd enjoyed working with her when we came together to set up Radio 5 Live. But it's no secret Liz did not agree with John Birt and me when we argued for building a news centre at Shepherd's Bush.
fields.body:
I was sorry when Liz Forgan resigned from the BBC (There and back again, October 17). I'd enjoyed working with her when we came together to set up Radio 5 Live. But it's no secret Liz did not agree with John Birt and me when we argued for building a news centre at Shepherd's Bush. The idea was to bring all the BBC's network journalists together, as most other broadcast news organisations have done. Up to that point the BBC's journalists had been five miles apart.

In the BBC's case this has not led to output that sounds or looks the same, as Liz feared. There is no "amorphous and interchangeable troupe of journalists" producing the programmes. There are distinct teams producing the widest and most diverse range of news broadcasting across radio, television and online anywhere in the world.

As to the cost, my recollection does not tally with Liz's. I remember it being scrutinised closely and carefully by the governors. The savings we have made have, as promised, been reinvested in first-hand journalism, the most distinctive quality of BBC news.

Building the news centre was not a costly mistake as Liz Forgan argues. It is a good and exciting place to work - and admired by visiting news broadcasters the world over.

No one is talking now about splitting up the BBC's journalists again. Five years on, though, we are looking to see if we can bring together an even wider community of BBC journalists, in the second half of this decade.
Tony Hall
Director of News, BBC

webTitle: Letters: We're still searching for peace

fields.headline: We're still searching for peace
fields.trailText: In response to Robert Readman's attack upon humanity's belief in "gods" (Letters, October 14), it is important to distinguish between the universal truths and aspirations that are embodied in such beliefs and the systems that develop from them.
fields.body:
In response to Robert Readman's attack upon humanity's belief in "gods" (Letters, October 14), it is important to distinguish between the universal truths and aspirations that are embodied in such beliefs and the systems that develop from them. Religion is the imperfect human attempt to formulate divine ideals in human terms and, as such, is inevitably flawed.

To suggest, however, that this should cause humanity to abandon its belief in an all-loving God is to miss the point. The challenge for our violent society is to rediscover that divine essence, not to continue to abandon and betray it. As such, the desperate situation in the Middle East represents not only humanity's failing but also its greatest challenge - to rediscover and to implement the divine will for all of humankind, and not to claim that it applies only to selected groups.
Rabbi Pete Tobias
Glasgow rabbipete@gns.org.uk

 The problem in the Middle East is not religion but power. I have Palestinian relatives in Nazareth. They have Israeli passports but they are second-class citizens, denied basic human rights and dignity by a racist state. Today they live in fear and we have received emails pleading for international protection. This family is Christian, but it doesn't matter what religion they are - all Palestinians are asking the same questions: when will the international community protect them from ethnic cleansing in the same way that they protected the people of Kosovo? When will an Israeli leader be treated with the same ire as Milosevic?
Brenda Addison
Birmingham

 Dr Francis Clark-Lowes writes (Letters, October 16) that "what lies behind the Israel-Palestine conflict is the systematic colonisation and ethnic cleansing of a piece of land, all of which used to be called Palestine." This encapsulates several historical myths; chiefly, that the Palestinian Arabs have been in Palestine from time immemorial and that the Jews came on the scene recently.

The name "Palestine" existed long before there were any Arabs in the area, and Jewish settlement long predates the arrival of the Arabs. "Palestine" was originally the coastal land of the Philistines, who were Greek in origin. Jews were the main occupants of the central area from about 1300BC right up to the time of the Arab conquest in the seventh century AD. Jews continued to form part of the population throughout the Middle Ages, though much depleted by Christian Crusader massacres. They maintained considerable numbers up to modern times. As a perennial element in the population they are at least as entitled to political independence as any other element, and have special rights as aboriginals.

Outside Palestine, Jews never ceased to maintain their attachment to the land of Israel in their prayers and hopes. In modern times, they have met with murderous antisemitism in the west, which motivated the Zionist movement of return to the homeland. It is ironic that after all their sufferings in the west, the Jews are caricatured as western colonists.
Hyam Maccoby
Centre for Jewish Studies, University of Leeds

 The other night I phoned my Palestinian friend Feisa, who lives in el-Fawwar, a refugee camp south of Hebron. She told me how Israeli soldiers have set up a blockade at the camp's entrance, digging up the road to stop cars passing. Some days people are not even allowed out on foot to go to work or school in nearby towns. A young man who went up on his roof to phone his aunt - roofs are like extra rooms there - was shot dead by Israeli soldiers. These are the realities of life for ordinary people, and they are not being reported in this talk of a "war" between "two sides".

My friend was downhearted, believing the west takes Israel's part and forgets the Palestinians. What is needed is a popular movement to persuade western and Israeli governments that apartheid is no more acceptable in the Middle East than it was in South Africa.
Alex Klaushofer
London alex@klaushofer.fsnet.co.uk

 The parallels between the Middle East and Northern Ireland are clear. In both cases, centuries-old problems seemed close to solution, thanks partly to international intervention but mainly to the efforts of relatively moderate local leaders - Barak and Arafat in one case, Trimble and Adams in the other.

And there have been key issues in each - the status of Jerusalem and arms decommissioning respectively - which have not been resolved to the satisfaction of one of the parties. Extremists on both sides have exploited the situation, and peace is at risk.

Practical solutions are hard to come by. In Northern Ireland there is still time for men and women of goodwill on both sides to use democratic means to preserve the agreement that has been achieved. In the Middle East, however, this may not be the case.

We in the UK we can help to support the moderates in Ireland. We can only pray that moderates in Israel and Arab countries will work to prevent a conflagration that would not only cause much bloodshed and misery in their own lands but imperil the economy, if not the stability, of the rest of the world.
Anthony Garrett
Falkland, Fife

fields.headline: Speaking up for women
fields.trailText: Lord Russell is painfully misguided if he thinks the Liberal Democrats deserve a slap on the back for their record on women (Letters, October 17). The Lib Dems demonstrate just how seriously they take women's concerns by appointing a man as women's spokesperson. They have only five women in the Commons.
fields.body:
Lord Russell is painfully misguided if he thinks the Liberal Democrats deserve a slap on the back for their record on women (Letters, October 17). The Lib Dems demonstrate just how seriously they take women's concerns by appointing a man as women's spokesperson. They have only five women in the Commons.
Gill Kirk
London

 I have been trained by one of the major High Street banks to go to a shrine on their premises, where I insert a small card through a hole in the wall and press buttons to receive a reward of cash (Letters, October 17). When no cash is forthcoming I cease to make the journeys. To what am I addicted, or of what have I been cured?
Denis McLaughlin
Carisbrooke, Isle of Wight

 In Answer Me (G2, October 17), Jeremy Sheffield expresses the desire to meet a "new guile nymph". Is it really a "nubile" one? Or is she perhaps very intriguing?
Kate Odgers
Hove, East Sussex kodgers@talk21.com

 Geoffrey Robinson no doubt chose the Daily Mail for the serialisation of his memoirs (Mystery hangs over donation, October 17) knowing it always gives a fair hearing to Labour.
Mike Mitchell
Manchester

 Yes, Hitler did ban hunting, but only for a brief period, after which he yielded to pressure from people like Clarissa Dickson Wright (G2, Portrait, October 17) and reinstated it.
Dave Godin
Sheffield dave@deepsoul.freeserve.co.uk

 Presumably (Italians feast on royal fear of garlic, October 11), one likes garlic, but it doesn't like one.
James Allum
Bristol james.allum@virgin.net

fields.headline: Home truth
fields.trailText: My father is 92 and in a nursing home. He no longer smiles or laughs. He is no longer able to do anything except sit, sleep and eat.
fields.body:
My father is 92 and in a nursing home. He no longer smiles or laughs. He is no longer able to do anything except sit, sleep and eat.

It is costing him £402.50 a week. Thankfully he does not realise that his savings are being depleted. He has never had a package holiday in his life. He would have thought it extravagant. He is paying the equivalent cost of a holiday in the sun every week. He has not had to sell his house: to buy a house he would have had to borrow and he did not approve of debt.

Lord Lipsey has said that it is the richest 7% who pay full nursing home costs. My father rich? He started his working life pushing a bogey in a cement works. He ended it as a shift foreman. He is forever grateful for his promotion and his pension.
Phyllis Holroyd
Fareham, Hants

fields.headline: Gus Hall
fields.standfirst: American communist leader whose rigidity reflected his party's decline
fields.trailText: American communist leader whose rigidity reflected his party's decline
fields.body:
From 1959, until his death aged 90, Gus Hall was secretary-general of the Communist party of the United States. During that time, the once-powerful organisation passed, remarkably unchanged, through social struggle and reaction, isolated but rarely threatened by the internal turmoil which shattered so many of its counterparts. Hall's rigidity kept American communists simultaneously faithful to eastern bloc-style state socialism - even in its absence - and to the Democratic party.

Born Arvo Halberg in Iron, Minnesota, one of the nine children of a Finnish-American mining family which supported the Industrial Workers of the World - the Wobblies - he left school at 14 and became a lumber worker. His blacklisted father was a founding CPUSA member.

In 1927, Arvo (renamed Gus Hall in the 1930s as part of "Americanising" communism) joined the young communist league. He spent two years at Moscow's Lenin Institute, organised the unemployed at home, and, in 1937, was charged with attempted dynamiting of a steel plant - rivals later considered his escape from prosecution suspicious. He then became a full-time communist.

After naval service in the second world war, Hall joined the CPUSA national executive in 1945. In 1948, he was convicted of conspiring to overthrow the government by force. Sentenced to five years' imprisonment, he became a model party leader, absent from duty but unflinching in the face of persecution. Thus his arrest in 1951, for jumping bail and seeking political exile in Mexico, added years to his sentence - and credibility to his status.

Hall emerged from prison in 1957 into a ghostly remnant of his party, which had peaked during wartime with 85,000 members, a popular following perhaps 10 times that size, and influence from Hollywood to the civil rights and industrial union movements. Legislative repression and FBI pursuit had narrowed the party, but disillusionment had nearly erased it. In 1956, rebellion in Hungary, and Nikita Khrushchev's revelations of Russian anti-semitism, had demoralised survivors.

A reform wing of the organisation argued for openness and internal democracy, but the hardliners outlasted their opponents, thus preparing the way for the Gus Hall era. Yet Hall apparently promised to take advantage of new winds from the civil rights, peace and labour movements.

Taking power, he asserted a tone that never again left the CPUSA. Further threats of federal persecution seemingly legitimised his military-style posture. But so did the conspiratorial character of American responses to post-colonial developments, from the Caribbean and Latin America to Africa and Asia. Russian support for Fidel Castro, in particular, but also of many new regimes and guerilla movements, gave the Soviet Union its last measure of support from younger generations, and American communists an element of reflected glory.

Hall set the communists apart from the emerging new left, quite as much through cultural conservatism as through their undying faith in Moscow. The mostly middle-aged (or older) communists, including Hall, were morally offended by campus activists' sexual politics and drug use. But they also opposed breaking with the Democrats, and celebrated Lyndon Johnson's crushing 1964 defeat of Barry Goldwater as a "people's victory". They opposed the black power slogan as divisive.

Highly influential in antiwar mobilisations in Manhattan, and enjoying a modest resurgence in selected unions and some African-American causes, communists nevertheless recruited few youngsters until the new left's collapse. Thereafter, the election of African-American mayors in Chicago, Detroit and Berkeley - with decades-long personal ties to local communists - symptomised the prospects for revival. Armed with a daily newspaper, and hardworking mobilisers around causes like Vietnam, South Africa, Chile, El Salvador and Nicaragua, communists enrolled campus activists and union reformers - many of them the offspring of the communist faithful.

By this time, Hall seemed an obstacle to revival, and rebuffed the grooming of successors - and quickly identified Mikhail Gorbachev as a traitor to socialism. In 1988, the People's Daily World became a weekly, and during the aborted Soviet party coup against the reformers, Hall issued a taped message of support for Gorbachev's opponents. This gesture sparked a significant internal party rebellion, but he outmanoeuvered the reformers.

Thereafter, most of the CPUSA's past heroes, including Angela Davis, abandoned the organisation. Yet Hall soldiered on, past the fall of the Berlin wall. The long-hated Chinese Communist party now appeared admirable, if by no means as praised as the governments of Vietnam, North Korea, or - above all - Cuba. The CPUSA had outlived Mao-inspired rivals and, compared to its nearest left survivor, the Democratic Socialists of America, remained an organisation of activists (if increasingly octogenarian), with a weekly press, likeable local figures, and the energy to support the post-cold war leadership of the AFL-CIO.

Hall's memories of past struggles, like the happier days in Roosevelt's New Deal coalition, demonstrated the power of nostalgia and the absence of alternatives. In that light, Hall had been a museum piece for almost his entire career. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth, and a son and daughter.

Gus Hall (Arvo Kusta Halberg), political organiser, born October 8 1910; died October 13 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Iraq has rejected a request from Saudi Arabia to extradite the two hijackers of a Saudi plane diverted to Baghdad at the weekend, the Iraqi state news agency, INA, reported.
fields.body:
Iraq refuses to return hijackers

Iraq has rejected a request from Saudi Arabia to extradite the two hijackers of a Saudi plane diverted to Baghdad at the weekend, the Iraqi state news agency, INA, reported.

"Our people ... have never handed over anyone who seeks refuge," said the interior minister, Muhammad Zimam Abd al-Razzaq. "He who comes to Baghdad is safe because Baghdad is for all Arabs," he added.
Reuters , Baghdad

Eta suspects seized in Spain

Spanish police have caught two gunmen they believe to be members of a key unit of the Basque separatist organisation, Eta. The two suspects allegedly shot and killed a military doctor in in Seville on Monday, the group's latest attack.

According to the Spanish interior ministry, the men, aged 26 and 23, formed the core of an Eta cell responsible for three assasinations and five bombing attempts in southern Spain this year.
Adela Gooch , Madrid

Schools close for fear of Ebola

Ugandan officials shut schools and banned funerals as 10 more Ebola cases were reported yesterday and the death toll from the latest outbreak of the deadly virus reached 35.

Doctors are diagnosing about 10 new cases a day, said Nestor Ndayimirije, a World Health Organisation epidemiologist in Gulu, 225 miles north of Kampala, the capital.

Ebola victims typically bleed to death within two weeks of showing the first flu-like symptoms.The virus kills 90% of those infected.
AP, Gulu

fields.headline: Carl Sigman
fields.standfirst: The first man to ring Pennsylvania 6-5000
fields.trailText: The lyricist Carl Sigman, who has died aged 91, would have deserved his place in music history for one song alone - Pennsylvania 6-5000
fields.body:
The lyricist Carl Sigman, who has died aged 91, would have deserved his place in music history for one song alone - Pennsylvania 6-5000. That first hit took its title from the telephone number of New York's Hotel Pennsylvania, and was recorded by Glenn Miller at the end of the 1930s. When it featured in the 1954 film, The Glenn Miller Story, it became a folk memory for a generation that loved seeing James Stewart on the phone to June Allyson.

Sigman's All In The Game was a hit twice for Tommy Edwards, in 1951 and 1958, a British success for Cliff Richard in the 1960s, and also for the Four Tops. In 1953, he provided lyrics for Robert Maxwell's Ebb Tide, and, soon afterwards, wrote the "riding through the glen" theme for the British television series of Robin Hood. In 1970, Sigman penned the theme song for the film, Love Story.

You would have to go back to the days of Johnny Mercer, if not Irving Berlin, to find a writer with a wider range over as long a period. fields.headline: Ana Ricarda
fields.trailText: The American dancer Ana Ricarda, who has died aged 82, was a choreographer and authority on Spanish dancing.
fields.body:
The American dancer Ana Ricarda, who has died aged 82, was a choreographer and authority on Spanish dancing.

Born into a wealthy and aristocratic San Francisco family, she studied in New York and Spain. She danced briefly with the Markova-Dolin company in the United States, but enjoyed her greatest success as a choreographer and leading dancer with the company of the Marquis de Cuevas in Europe. For them, she made Del Amor y de la Muerte (1949), a Spanish tragedy of love and death, danced to music by Granados, in which she appeared with Tamara Toumanova and George Skibine in the central roles. In 1952, she created the ballet for which she was most celebrated, Doña Ines de Castro, to music by Serra and in beautiful designs by Celia Hubbard. The story tells of the medieval Pedro of Portugal, who crowned his dead lover as queen.

After the disbanding of the Cuevas company, Ricarda settled in London and taught Spanish dancing at the Royal Ballet School. She also choreographed small ballets, always with a Spanish flavour, for the annual performances of students from the school.

Elegant, amusing and cultured, she belonged essentially to the glamorous, cosmopolitan world of the Cuevas company and the entourage of the marquis himself. Her ballets have nearly all disappeared, but they played an important part in the ballet world of their time, and should not be forgotten.

fields.headline: John Laredo
fields.standfirst: Afrikaner campaigner against apartheid
fields.trailText: Afrikaner campaigner against apartheid
fields.body:
John Laredo, who has died unexpectedly in Leeds aged 68, was one of a distinguished band of Afrikaner intellectuals, including Bram Fischer, Breyten Breyteinbach and Marius Schoon, whose rebellion against the white supremacist doctrines of apartheid led to their imprisonment.

After the 1960 Sharpeville massacre, and the ensuing repression, armed struggle seemed to many radicals an inevitability. The African Resistance Movement, formed by a mixture of liberals and socialists, undertook numerous acts of sabotage from December 1961 to mid-1964, when the special branch broke the organisation and imprisoned a score of people, most of them young and white.

That Laredo, then head of social anthropology at Rhodes University, Port Elizabeth - and a naturally gentle, easygoing and law-abiding man - should have joined such a group can best be explained by his instinctive egalitarianism and loathing of injustice. These were qualities recognised by his pro-regime mother, who said to him during a prison visit: "I cannot agree with your actions, but the Haaroffs [her maiden name] were always rebels and I know you've done what you believe to be right."

Detained and interrogated for 110 days, under the "90-day" detention clause, Laredo was jailed for five years after refusing to give evidence against his comrades. In the notorious Pretoria local prison, he was a resolute and and cheerful companion. His ability to find common ground was crucial in furthering solidarity between communists and non-communists.

Laredo was born in Pretoria. His mother was related to a former president of the Free State Republic and his father was a civil servant. His home language was Afrikaans, but he spoke English impeccably - possibly because his mother had insisted, "If you must speak the enemy's language, be sure to speak it better than they do". He later learned Zulu and several other European languages.

In 1951, Laredo went to Stellenbosch University, that incubator of so many Afrikaner nationalist theorists. Ironically, while majoring in history and native administration, he began to analyse the factors causing black poverty and subjugation - and concluded that white hegemony was to blame. Reading for a master's in social anthropology at King's College, Cambridge, between 1955 and 1957, completed his conversion to socialism.

While in Britain, Laredo married Ursula Marx, another brilliant Stellenbosch graduate, returning in 1958 to South Africa, where their daughter and two sons were born. After lecturing in African studies at Cape Town University, he moved to Durban in 1959 to undertake anthropological fieldwork in kwaZulu at Natal University, where he subsequently became a sociology lecturer. In Natal, the Laredos joined Alan Paton's Liberal party and participated in peaceful demonstrations and anti-apartheid teach-ins.

Their home became an informal locus where young South Africans - whatever their colour - could talk politics. On one legendary occasion, a somewhat xenophobic Laredo aunt arrived unexpectedly in the middle of a debate. Offered a chair by a black man, she vigorously dusted it with her handkerchief before sitting down.

In 1963, John took charge of social anthropology at Rhodes, while continuing his fieldwork. This should have led to a distinguished PhD and a secure place in the academic community, had the secret police not intervened.

After his release from prison, with his career shattered by banning orders and house arrest, Laredo came into exile in Britain. From 1970-71, he was resident visiting fellow at his old Cambridge college. He then joined the new Bradford University's sociology department, until a heart attack in 1990, and further illnesses, prompted him to retire in 1993.

Through good health and bad, Laredo worked tirelessly for various causes, including the Labour party and the Anti-Apartheid Movement, of which he was secretary through the 1980s. His marriage had broken down in 1972 but, characteristically, the couple achieved an amicable divorce, and, in 1986, John met Ailsa Swarbrick, an Open University lecturer, with whom he enjoyed great domestic happiness until the end.

Together, they celebrated the collapse of apartheid, after which they were finally able to visit South Africa. It was the only reward he wanted.

John Epaninondas Laredo, academic and anti-apartheid activist, born February 13 1932; died October 1 2000

webTitle: Ford and Vauxhall start online war

fields.headline: Ford and Vauxhall start online war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Britain's two biggest carmakers, Ford and Vauxhall, launched a cyberspace price war yesterday by offering substantial discounts to customers who use the company websites to buy their new cars.
fields.body:
Britain's two biggest carmakers, Ford and Vauxhall, launched a cyberspace price war yesterday by offering substantial discounts to customers who use the company websites to buy their new cars.

Ian McAllister, chairman and managing director of Ford Britain, promised a revolution in online car buying as he announced discounts of between 5% and 8% on cars purchased via www.fordjourney.com.

His pledge at the British International Motor Show in Birmingham came as Ford cranked up the terrestrial price war by announcing that the new Mondeo, to be launched on November 1, will cost 8.8% less than current models. A new LX, for instance, will have a list price of £14,995 - £1,405 less than its predecessor.

The internet battle between the manufacturers comes after a series of reductions in list prices triggered by the government's response to a competition commission inquiry.

The commission found that UK car buyers were being overcharged between 10% and 12% - on average £1,100 per car. Mr McAllister said the industry had since delivered price cuts worth 11%.

Vauxhall said it was extending its internet service to cover the whole of its product range and would offer an average 3.5% discount. Nick Reilly, chairman and managing director, said the extended service would offer savings of beween £300 and £800, and even more for special limited offers.

A pilot scheme, which offered retail customers a limited range of small cars, sold more than 1,200 cars last year, three times more than the average dealer's annual sales but only a fraction of Vauxhall's 300,000 annual sales.

Mr Reilly said the group would take an initial hit because of the cost of setting up the scheme and offering the discount. But he claimed that the discount would soon be offset by savings on paperwork and vehicle delivery.

Internet service would not cut out Vauxhall's franchised dealers, who would still handle the sale and delivery of vehicles bought over the internet - as well as set up test drives and establish trade-in values.

Mr McAllister admitted that relatively few customers would probably buy online even though 38% of all UK car buyers have access to the net.

"It could be 10 cars or 10,000 cars a year. We do not know. And we do not know if customers will use it less to buy and more to search," he said. "We are doing business in the dark, in a way."

In the US, the Ford chairman said, 80% of car buyers use the internet to search for their favoured model but only 3% buy online. But he insisted that Ford's new website was essential to retaining a direct relationship with customers and excluding third party dot.com traders.

The new Ford site will be running from Monday, initially offering the Focus, Fiesta, Ka and Cougar models, with the new Mondeo available from the new year.

Customers should take delivery within 10 working days of ordering, compared with the usual 15 days in a showroom.
