fields.headline: No: 1743
fields.standfirst: Loyd Grossman
fields.trailText: Loyd Grossman
fields.body:
Age: 50.

Occupation: Morsta Sherf.

You what? And Thrrrew the Keyhairl.

Oh right, that bloke on the telly with the funny voice. That's right. Loyd Daniel Gilman Grossman, who came to London from Boston in 1974, has been described as having "irritable vowel syndrome".

Can't wait to hear his dulcet tones when Masterchef returns next year. Unfortunately it will be sans Loyd.

Unthinkable! Who will be masticating and cogitating with the judges? Gary Rhodes.

But I love Loyd. No you don't and neither does much of the country. Alas, the man we love to hate - who is only slightly less irritating than David "it's over to you" Frost, his co-presenter on Through the Keyhole ("Hugh lives in a haouse like thiz?") - is quitting Masterchef because it's moving to BBC2.

What's wrong with that? Dunno, but Loyd clearly feels that after a decade of lending his golden taste buds to BBC1 he's being shoved off into TV obscurity. After all, the gastronomic guru taught himself to cook in four days. (He also ate dog food on the Big Breakfast thinking it was beef stew).

Mmm, guru you say? Well, the don of culinary aesthetics has also published a book of recipes from gastroland's great and good and retails his own range of delicious paah-sta sooor-ces, available to buy at a supermarket near you.

So what's next for Mr G? Perhaps a return to his first love: he used to be a punk rocker - Jet of Jet Bronx and the Forbidden, whose single, I Ain't Doing Nothing, reached number 47 in 1977.

I'm impressed. Maybe he could re-release a garage version? Nah, Loyd's melodious career ended when his book, A Social History of Rock, was reviewed in Rolling Stone thus: "There is not a single new idea in this pallid little volume." Shame.

Do say: "Rock on, Loyd."

Don't say: "Pedigree Chum anyone?"

webTitle: Comment: John O'Farrell on Labour's crime policies

fields.headline: Labour steals the Tories' old clothes
fields.standfirst:
Tough on crime, tough on the causes ... we've heard it all before

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Politicians from all sides have been discussing the new crime figures this week and the statistics make depressing reading. When talking about action against burglars, use of the word "tough" has increased 57%. When referring to violent crime, the incidence of politicians saying "tough" has gone up by a massive 71%. We are more likely to be assaulted by the phrase "more bobbies on the beat" than at any time in the past 20 years and millions now live in fear of the trauma of waking up to discover that Jack Straw is talking on the Today programme.
fields.body:
Politicians from all sides have been discussing the new crime figures this week and the statistics make depressing reading. When talking about action against burglars, use of the word "tough" has increased 57%. When referring to violent crime, the incidence of politicians saying "tough" has gone up by a massive 71%. We are more likely to be assaulted by the phrase "more bobbies on the beat" than at any time in the past 20 years and millions now live in fear of the trauma of waking up to discover that Jack Straw is talking on the Today programme.

Meanwhile the British Crime Survey has actually revealed that crime itself is going down. There are fewer burglaries, except in the areas where people keep leaving the house to attend Neighbourhood Watch meetings. There is a reduction in motor vehicle crime which is attributed to car alarms, while the increase in parked cars being attacked with a sledgehammer in the middle of the night is also attributed to car alarms. Apparently we are more likely to be robbed and assaulted by strangers, but this is hardly surprising - if you are going to mug someone you would have to be pretty stupid to try it out on your best friend.

Ann Widdecombe will be disappointed that the crime figures have fallen, despite all the efforts of her Conservative colleagues in getting themselves arrested on a regular basis. One of the few perks of being shadow home secretary is being able to point to the inexorable rise in recorded offences and using this to attack your opponent. But now, as she peeks out from behind her net curtains, she will realise that she too has been the victim of a crime. When it comes to the law and order issue, Labour have stolen the Tories' clothes (although the image of Jack Straw in one of Ann Widdecombe's dresses is not something you'd want to dwell upon).

While Ann's own pronouncements are greeted with stoned giggles from her colleagues in the shadow cabinet, Labour can point to solid social and economic policies that have helped bring crime down. The massive reduction of youth unemployment, for example, must surely be a factor; quite how the Tories imagine that scrapping the new deal and the minimum wage would help reduce youth crime has not been explained. Maybe Ann had an explanation for this but it was nicked from her briefcase.

Although the figures are falling, a huge percentage of crime continues to be committed by young males. There is a simple way of rectifying this imbalance: the government should introduce lots of new offences for everyone else. All sorts of anti-social behaviour continues to go unchecked in our society. For example, if you are in a long queue it should be unlawful for the person right in front of you suddenly to be joined by lots of friends. If you arrive in the cinema after the film has started, it should be an offence not to duck slightly as you walk across the front. If the film ends five minutes before last orders it should also be against the law to sit there in deep contemplation, waiting to see who was "Key Grip" while everyone else on your row has stood up and is desperate to get out and grab a swift pint.

Leaving the scene of a jammed photocopier should be a criminal offence. And a new charge of digital fraud should be used to target the makers of PCs that brazenly lie at you. "Your printer is not connected." "Yes it bloody is!" There should also be a new offence of corporate stalking. I have been stalked by British Telecom for several years now. They keep sending me letters and ringing me up when I least expect it, saying they know who my friends and family are, and then offering to change them for me.

Of course it could be argued that we don't need any new offences when there are so many crimes that are ignored already. None of the reporting on this week's crime figures made any reference to City fraud or big business tax evasion. Where are the interviews with old ladies saying how they are afraid to go out lest they should be offered a tip for some insider trading? Where are the big yellow signs in the City of London saying "Appeal for Witnesses - Fraud. Did you see anyone skimming the remainders fund, selling currency forward and then buying it spot fixed overnight? And more to the point, can you explain what this means?"

There are all sorts of reasons why crime has fallen and many voters will be alienated by anyone trying to score party political points on this issue. But before the election Tony Blair promised to be "tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime", and the latest crime figures suggest his approach is clearly working. Okay, so he nicked the phrase from Gordon. But you can't blame Labour for that; the Tories were in power when it happened.

John O'Farrell's novel, The Best a Man Can Get, is published by Doubleday.

webTitle: Accused in acid case 'went to pub'

fields.headline: Accused in acid case 'went to pub'
fields.trailText: The former partner of a hospital doctor went to the pub to drink and talk about football as the doctor was taken to casualty after swallowing sulphuric acid, Birmingham crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The former partner of a hospital doctor went to the pub to drink and talk about football as the doctor was taken to casualty after swallowing sulphuric acid, Birmingham crown court heard yesterday.

Andrew Gardner, 41, declined to accompany Karenina Longe in the ambulance to Heartlands hospital in Birmingham, where she worked, the court was told. Instead he took a taxi to the Waggon Horses pub in Yardley.

Gardner, a former laboratory technician at St Bartholomew's hospital, London, denies murdering Dr Longe, 27, by giving her sulphuric acid.

Giving evidence, Robert Pugh said he was in the Waggon Horses pub in Yardley on February 5 between 3pm and 3.30pm. He saw a tall man, said to be Gardner, enter the pub wearing a cowboy hat with silver buckles on it, and a coat, and order a pint of lager. The man "began talking about the football to whoever was in the bar".

Earlier, an ambulance technician, Tracey Walker, and a paramedic, Elizabeth Parkes, told the court they received a call at about 2.28pm that day. On arriving at the house that Gardner and Dr Longe had shared in Sheldon, they found Dr Longe moaning, "Help me, help me", on a sofa.

Ms Walker said a man said to be Gardner told them it was an accident that Dr Longe had taken sulphuric acid: he had been cleaning the drains with the acid in a mug by the sink.

The Nigerian-born doctor died in the hospital, where she had been a senior house officer, the next day.

Marlene Brown, with whom Gardner had lived in a flat in London, told the court he had phoned her. "He told me that Nina had drunk acid. I didn't believe him at the time."

The following Monday she saw on the news that Gardner was wanted for questioning about Dr Longe's death. Ms Brown said she asked him to get in touch with the police. He had been "so scared".

Asked if he was the type of man to confront problems, she replied: "No ... He would run away and try to drink the problem away."

Gardner's son John, 16, told the court that his father had told him that Dr Longe had "done something stupid", that the couple had had an argument and he had left the house, but when he returned she had drunk most of a bottle of vodka and the acid.

John went to the hospital in the ambulance. Gardner arrived later; when doctors told him that Dr Longe was unlikely to survive, he "lost it", John said. "He told me to give a message to Nina's mother and her boyfriend and his family: 'I never did it'."

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Prices too high for Sir Stanley's fans

fields.headline: Prices too high for Sir Stanley's fans
fields.trailText: Bill Myatt, a lifelong Stoke City fan, left the Britannia ground empty handed yesterday. Like many others, mostly men, most with grey hair, he had gone to the Sir Stanley Matthews auction hoping to pick up a souvenir of one of the greatest stars of English football. But the prices proved too high.
fields.body:
Bill Myatt, a lifelong Stoke City fan, left the Britannia ground empty handed yesterday. Like many others, mostly men, most with grey hair, he had gone to the Sir Stanley Matthews auction hoping to pick up a souvenir of one of the greatest stars of English football. But the prices proved too high.

"I met him a few times and I'd like to have had something to remember him by. He was a gentleman and one of the best players who ever lived," said Mr Myatt. "But I have memories and perhaps those are more important than objects."

In the auction room, within a stand at Stoke, a telephone bidder had just acquired, for £1,700, a medal inscribed with the name S Matthews by the English Schools Football Association - dated 1929 when the boy who was to become a legend, and who died last year, played against the south.

Another tiny medal up for sale served to recall the game between Angleterre et le Continent in 1938; it fetched £1,150.

Altogether there were more than 400 lots from his estate, which included vases, trophies, bowls, salvers, plaques, tureens, goblets and glass footballs, presented by admirers in Stoke (his home town), elsewhere in Britain and in other parts of the world.

The Hungarians gave him a medallion to mark the 40th anniversary of their team's 3-0 defeat of England, which sold for £90.

The sale also included personal effects from Sir Stanley's home, The Views, in Penkhull New Road - Wedgwood and Royal Doulton pottery, a brass bedstead, a trouser press, a lawnmower, and two Formica-topped tables. The books included novels by Dick Francis, James Herbert, Jack Higgins, Ed McBain and Wilbur Smith.

One hopeful buyer, Dorothy Glaze, wanted to bid for a few small items for her sons. "I only saw him play once and he never kicked the ball," she said. "The champagne glasses are not the best quality but they have his face on them."

In the end, the glasses, a paperweight and a poster - all Mrs Glaze's favourites - went without her bid, the price not being right.

Another auction-goer, John Cross from Blackpool, gained Sir Stanley's passport (identifying the footballer as resident in Malta) for £500. "You cannot get more unique than a passport," he said.

Lot 392, "a football boot belonging to Sir Stanley, possibly used in the 1953 Cup final", fetched £640. That was the match when his cross helped Blackpool snatch a 4-3 victory from Bolton Wanderers."Look," said the man from the auctioneers, "you can still see a bit of turf round the studs."

webTitle: Mekong takes its revenge for man's ravages along river

fields.headline: Mekong takes its revenge for man's ravages along river
fields.standfirst:
Vietnam floods reach new areas as deforestation and concrete riverbanks intensify effect of rains
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: More than 350 people have died in Vietnam's worst floods for 70 years. Most of the victims are young children who drowned while left unattended by their parents.
fields.byline: Owen Bennett-Jones  in  Ho Chi Minh City
fields.body:
More than 350 people have died in Vietnam's worst floods for 70 years. Most of the victims are young children who drowned while left unattended by their parents.

Hundreds of thousands of people in the Mekong delta in southern Vietnam have been forced to flee their homes, and water levels are so high that they will not be able to return until December.

Last week the floodwaters receded for the first time since July. But a new wave of sustained, heavy rain has pushed levels back up again to the point where the country's commercial capital, Ho Chi Minh City, could find itself inundated. "The flood is now reaching provinces where people are not used to seeing something on this scale," said Peter Michelson who is coordinating the Red Cross's relief effort in the delta.

Those whose homes have been submerged are living on small, muddy dykes in squalid, unhygienic conditions. Many have run out of food and rely on relief workers to bring in supplies.

Hunger and disease are not the only dangers. A number of crocodiles - not normally seen in the Mekong delta - have appeared in the floodwaters. It is believed that they were washed downstream from Cambodia or escaped from crocodile farms in Vietnam.

There is also a plague of golden snails which are breeding rapidly in the flood water. Farmers have reported seeing millions of snails' eggs. It is feared the snails will eat any rice crops that survive the flood. In the past the authorities have had to organise communal, mass culls of the snails to protect agricultural land.

Every year floods in the south cause disruption, but this time things are far worse. And in central Vietnam heavy monsoon rains have caused devastating floods for the last three years. So far this month, more than 50 people have died in flash floods well away from the Mekong. Some environmentalists believe east Asia's weather patterns are becoming increasingly extreme and dangerous.

"There's a lot more rain falling in less time. Overall the amount of rainfall isn't changing but it's coming down in very intense short bursts," said the UN's environment adviser in Hanoi, Craig Leisher.

But the problem is also manmade. The Mekong river starts in China and flows through Laos, Thailand and Cambodia before reaching southern Vietnam. All along its course, forests are being cut down, reducing the land's capacity to retain water. Downstream, the people of the delta are on the receiving end of the more extreme floods that result.

The Vietnamese authorities have tried to clamp down on illegal logging but with limited success. "Some cases have gone to court. Even so, deforestation has still happened. Some poor people still cut down trees. They need the money to make a living," said Nguyen Tuy Nien, director of flood control and dyke management.

Local newspapers have reported that there have been more than 39,000 violations of forestry regulations so far this year. Illegal loggers are turning violent when challenged by forest rangers.

Other modern practices, such as creating concrete river banks so buildings can be put up near the Mekong, contribute to the volume of water arriving downstream. And it is feared that increased damming of the river - especially in China and Laos - could compound the problem. When reservoirs fill up, dam managers release vast amounts of water, adding to the difficulties downstream.

The Vietnamese government says it wants people to live with floods rather than escape them. In recent years the authorities have extended small loans so families can build their houses on stilts. Thousands of wooden boats have been distributed so that flood victims can fish for their own food rather than rely on aid agencies. Effective early warning systems have been installed; without them many more people would have died.

But such initiatives cannot hide the fact that the number of people vulnerable to flooding is increasing. "More and more people are living in the delta, closer to the banks," said Koos Neefjes of Oxfam. "These very poor people need to fish; they need to live on the river banks."

Vietnam is one of the most densely populated countries in Asia. By implementing a policy of trying to limit children to two per family, the government is said now to have largely controlled population growth. That will ease the situation in the future but for the present, there is still great pressure on marginal land as people try to find somewhere to make a living.

The increasing numbers in the Mekong delta have resulted in new agricultural practices. The type of rice, for example, traditionally grown there can withstand most floods because it floats. But popular new strains, while more productive, cannot survive a long flood and much of this year's crop has been lost.

fields.headline: Into the unknown
fields.standfirst: Since Mile Hilton-Barber lost his sight eight years ago, he has run marathons in the Sahara and climbed some of the world's highest peaks.  Now he is training for his biggest challenge yet-to walk to the south pole.
fields.trailText: Real Lives: Miles Hilton-Barber might be loosing his sight but it hasn't stopped him going on a Himalayan expedition...
fields.body:
It was a crisp spring morning eight years ago, when, for the first time in his life, Miles Hilton-Barber suddenly felt trapped. Realising, as he stood at his open front door, that he lacked the confidence to walk the short distance into his local village of Duffield, in Derbyshire, he had no option but to retreat to the refuge of his study and start contemplating a new life.

Diagnosed 12 years earlier with the degenerative eye condition retinitis pigmentosa, he now faced the descent of blackness that he had never dared imagine. "Because I'd been losing my sight gradually, I tried to kid myself that I could still see well enough," says the quietly spoken 52-year-old. "I disregarded the inevitable, and losing all my sight was very traumatic."

As a lover of adventure and extreme sports - his CV at the time included abseiling, parachute jumps and white water rafting in the Zambezi - Hilton-Barber says that the attendant loss of "confidence, dignity and independence" hit him hard.

That these have since been so emphatically restored - and at no small risk to his life - is testament to a man who decided to dig deeper than he has ever done and found extraordinary reserves of spirit in the process. "When I was low, I'd have hidden under my bed if someone had told me what I'd be doing now."

The CV has certainly been updated over the past 18 months. In April 1999 with his close friend and sighted guide Jon Cook, he completed the gruelling Marathon Des Sables, a 150-mile race through the Sahara desert, billed as "the toughest foot race in the world".

In April this year, Cook led Hilton-Barber on a Himalayan expedition to 17,500ft in the Everest region. Three months later the pair climbed the 19,340ft high Mount Kilimanjaro, and in August, they scaled Mont Blanc (15,770ft).

Their hardest test yet, however, begins at the end of this month, when Hilton-Barber hopes to become the first blind person to walk the 730 miles from Patriot Hills, on the Antarctic coast, to the south pole. In the process they aim to raise £2.5m for the Royal National Institute for the Blind, where Hilton-Barber now works as a project manager.

"Physically it will hammer us," he says, "but the mental challenge will be even greater." Cook's respect for his friend's remarkable rehabilitation is clear. "Miles underwent a period of intense self-examination when he lost his sight. But the RNIB taught him the art of walking with sticks and gradually his confidence to try things grew."

As befits a man who, according to Cook, "is a great encourager, he has convinced me to reach for dreams," new challenges began presenting themselves and were duly overcome. Competing in a six-mile village race sharpened his appetite for half and then full marathons. But the catalyst for the pair's more recent exploits was the singular achievement two years ago of Hilton-Barber's brother, Geoff.

Having also lost his sight, by a wretched coincidence, to the same condition, Geoff remains the first blind yachtsman to have sailed solo the 4,300 miles from Durban, South Africa, to Fremantle in western Australia. "That was a real wake-up call for Miles, in terms of proving just how far you can stretch yourself," Cook explains.

"It certainly made me think again," agrees Hilton-Barber. "I could not have had a more inspiring role model." The two brothers claimed yet another world first when they completed the race in the Sahara, which comprises five-and-a-half marathons in six days in 120-degree heat. Competitors must be self-sufficient at all times, thus entailing the added burden of carrying a rucksack containing essential supplies.

Running behind on a lead attached to Cook's hip enabled Hilton-Barber to sense changes in direction and gradient. If either altered radically, Cook would alert him, slow down and offer his arm for support. "The experience with Miles certainly brought a whole new perspective to distance running," Cook says.

The mechanics of climbing together are even more demanding, and precision is all when you are hanging on to a rock face 14,000ft up. And while Cook is an experienced mountaineer, Hilton-Barber only started climbing in January in Scotland.

"I have to listen very carefully to everything Jon says," he explains. "He will tell me to reach my hand 16 inches across the rock, then up six inches, feel for the three-inch lip and grab it. Tight situations, such as falling down a crevice on Mont Blanc, do shake me up because I can't see. But Jon did pull me out." Once asked why he bothered to climb mountains when he couldn't see anything from the summit, he recalls a moment that instantly evokes the deep sense of awe and wonder he felt when he and Cook conquered Kilimanjaro.

"Jon was describing this fantastic sight. As dawn was breaking, he could see these beautiful ice fields and a huge ball of fire on the horizon. The plains of Africa were 15,000ft below us and I could feel a cool breeze. I'll never forget it." Accompanied by a British and Russian Antarctic guide, Hilton-Barber and Cook will be pushed to new and unforgiving limits by the 70-day trek to the south pole. Each will be pulling a 200lb sled of gear for eight to 10 hours a day, covering just 10 to 15 miles of bleak wasteland. They will walk side by side when the weather permits, and Cook will have a bell or a rope attached to his rucksack, so his partner knows exactly where he is.

Unless directions are being called out, the two will walk in silence to avoid wasting oxygen or breaking their rhythm. The warmest it will get is around -20 C. "At the end of every day we will have to get our gear out, put up the tent, cook, sleep, then get up and start all over again," explains Hilton-Barber. "And unless the weather confines us to camp, we're doing the same thing 70 times in a row. Mental strength is therefore essential."

"Coping with the continuous sameness will be hard for me, but Miles won't even have anything to look at," says Cook. "If we don't get on top of it and enjoy it, it will be a nightmare." Cocooned in four or five layers means that hearing or feeling anything, particularly in bad weather, becomes practically impossible. It also deprives Hilton-Barber of his two most vital senses. "But I'll deal with it," he says.

The pair are not expected home until January 30, which means missing Christmas and new year with their families. Hilton-Barber, a father of three, will try to celebrate his 53rd birthday in a tent, but will also miss his daughter Abigail's 21st birthday. "It will be very hard on them, but we hope to keep in touch by satellite phone once a week."

"My wife and two boys go through the mill when we are away," admits Cook. "But they understand what Miles and I are trying to achieve."

Hilton-Barber's philosophy is simple. "I don't expect blind people to go to the south pole. But if I can encourage someone to pick up a white stick and cross the road, that's something. Enabling and liberating people, irrespective of a disability, is what it's about." And he should know.

The RNIB Helpline: 0845 7669999.
fields.bodyText: It was a crisp spring morning eight years ago, when, for the first time in his life, Miles Hilton-Barber suddenly felt trapped. Realising, as he stood at his open front door, that he lacked the confidence to walk the short distance into his local village of Duffield, in Derbyshire, he had no option but to retreat to the refuge of his study and start contemplating a new life. Diagnosed 12 years earlier with the degenerative eye condition retinitis pigmentosa, he now faced the descent of blackness that he had never dared imagine. "Because I'd been losing my sight gradually, I tried to kid myself that I could still see well enough," says the quietly spoken 52-year-old. "I disregarded the inevitable, and losing all my sight was very traumatic." As a lover of adventure and extreme sports - his CV at the time included abseiling, parachute jumps and white water rafting in the Zambezi - Hilton-Barber says that the attendant loss of "confidence, dignity and independence" hit him hard. That these have since been so emphatically restored - and at no small risk to his life - is testament to a man who decided to dig deeper than he has ever done and found extraordinary reserves of spirit in the process. "When I was low, I'd have hidden under my bed if someone had told me what I'd be doing now." The CV has certainly been updated over the past 18 months. In April 1999 with his close friend and sighted guide Jon Cook, he completed the gruelling Marathon Des Sables, a 150-mile race through the Sahara desert, billed as "the toughest foot race in the world". In April this year, Cook led Hilton-Barber on a Himalayan expedition to 17,500ft in the Everest region. Three months later the pair climbed the 19,340ft high Mount Kilimanjaro, and in August, they scaled Mont Blanc (15,770ft). Their hardest test yet, however, begins at the end of this month, when Hilton-Barber hopes to become the first blind person to walk the 730 miles from Patriot Hills, on the Antarctic coast, to the south pole. In the process they aim to raise £2.5m for the Royal National Institute for the Blind, where Hilton-Barber now works as a project manager. "Physically it will hammer us," he says, "but the mental challenge will be even greater." Cook's respect for his friend's remarkable rehabilitation is clear. "Miles underwent a period of intense self-examination when he lost his sight. But the RNIB taught him the art of walking with sticks and gradually his confidence to try things grew." As befits a man who, according to Cook, "is a great encourager, he has convinced me to reach for dreams," new challenges began presenting themselves and were duly overcome. Competing in a six-mile village race sharpened his appetite for half and then full marathons. But the catalyst for the pair's more recent exploits was the singular achievement two years ago of Hilton-Barber's brother, Geoff. Having also lost his sight, by a wretched coincidence, to the same condition, Geoff remains the first blind yachtsman to have sailed solo the 4,300 miles from Durban, South Africa, to Fremantle in western Australia. "That was a real wake-up call for Miles, in terms of proving just how far you can stretch yourself," Cook explains. "It certainly made me think again," agrees Hilton-Barber. "I could not have had a more inspiring role model." The two brothers claimed yet another world first when they completed the race in the Sahara, which comprises five-and-a-half marathons in six days in 120-degree heat. Competitors must be self-sufficient at all times, thus entailing the added burden of carrying a rucksack containing essential supplies. Running behind on a lead attached to Cook's hip enabled Hilton-Barber to sense changes in direction and gradient. If either altered radically, Cook would alert him, slow down and offer his arm for support. "The experience with Miles certainly brought a whole new perspective to distance running," Cook says. The mechanics of climbing together are even more demanding, and precision is all when you are hanging on to a rock face 14,000ft up. "He will tell me to reach my hand 16 inches across the rock, then up six inches, feel for the three-inch lip and grab it. Accompanied by a British and Russian Antarctic guide, Hilton-Barber and Cook will be pushed to new and unforgiving limits by the 70-day trek to the south pole. fields.headline: 'This is my last hurrah'
fields.standfirst: Country veteran Merle Haggard tells  Michael Ellison why he's back on track
fields.trailText: Country veteran Merle Haggard tells Michael Ellison why he's back on track
fields.body:
'What we need is a hit record. It's important to my ego as an entertainer." The 63-year-old with bright eyes like polished coal is sitting hunched behind a table on his custom-built tour bus. If his peers, Willie Nelson and Johnny Cash, can enjoy late-career respectability, Merle Haggard is determined that his time should come again.

Best known for Okie from Muskogee, Haggard had a run of 65 hits on the country charts in the 19 years leading up to 1985. But he is rather more self-destructive, distrustful of the music industry, success and maybe even himself than today's crop of sanitised country-lite stars. And while Nashville honours its elders as an exercise in self-validation, that doesn't mean it wants to hear too much from them.

When Haggard was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1994, he appeared on the stage, live on network television, with a roll of paper containing the names of those he said he must thank. "First of all," he said after unfurling the roll, "I'd like to thank Andy Gump, my plumber. You're doing a great job keeping my toilets working, Andy."

The songwriter whose work has earned him soubriquets such as the Poet of the Common Man - Today I Started Loving You Again, for one, has been recorded by 400 artists - wants recognition, but only on his own terms. Haggard arrived at the conclusion that no record company would allow him to make the record he wanted, so he opted out for four years, though he continued to play about 150 shows every year. Then he hooked up with Anti Records, a subsidiary of Epitaph, the label that nurtures Rancid, Voodoo Glow Skulls, the Offspring and Midget Handjob.

Haggard cannot stop saying how glad he is to be on a punk label at last. The match is not as odd as it might seem, given that Anti is designed to dovetail with substantial artists from outside the mainstream: Tom Waits had the biggest-selling record of his career when Anti released Mule Variations last year.

The singer has, however, spurned other chances to give a new focus to his career. When Nelson, Cash, Waylon Jennings and Kris Kristofferson formed the Outlaws in an exercise designed to capitalise on their distance from the Nashville establishment, Haggard was invited to join in. "It got to be a cool thing to be considered a part of the outlaw community," he says. "They offered to expand it to five people. I didn't have time and the pie was too thin."

Instead, Nelson extended his audience by recording the arty Teatro with the producer Daniel Lanois. Cash achieved the same effect by reducing his music to its essence on American Recordings. Haggard's pitch to follow suit came with the release of If I Could Only Fly. Its arrangements are lightly adorned, all the instruments at the service of his genre-defining voice, the model of authority and controlled emotion. There's no need to ask who the songs are about: there is no third person in evidence here. His life is the original handbook for many of the country staples: poor childhood, father dead when he was nine, prison for burglary as a young man, divorces, drink and drugs. Haggard once told Johnny Cash how much he'd enjoyed a concert at San Quentin prison, in California. Cash said he didn't remember Haggard on the stage; that, said Haggard, was because he wasn't on the bill, but in the audience.

Haggard is a hero to the alternative country crowd, many of whose members tipped their hats to him six years ago on Tulare Dust, a successful tribute album. But he's not bothered about any of that. "I don't pay much attention to records any more. I like to see people sit down with a piano or a guitar. I still listen to [honky tonk man] Lefty Frizzell and Hank Williams. I don't believe anyone's ever outdone Lefty."

Although he's pleased with his new record, he has reservations about its likely fate. "This is my last hurrah," he says. "I think people are dying to see a high wire act without a net." At this point he mentions Hank Williams again. Later he will include John Wayne and James Dean among the individuals who have dared to put their talents on the line.

Haggard is appearing on David Letterman's TV show the following night but he is not a-quiver with anticipation. "He's not going to give me couch time." But at least he's on the show. "I guess somebody gives a shit." But there are other opportunities, even if they stopped playing authentic country on the radio years ago. "The video will probably not be played anywhere," he says. "They're not going to play me when they can play those good-looking girls. I don't blame them. Some old guy like me isn't going to take the spotlight away from them. But I'd like to sell records again."

One record that he did sell, effortlessly and controversially in 1969, was Okie from Muskogee, the most eloquent of redneck anthems and the song with which he will always be most readily associated. The song's rejection of the prevailing cultural forces in the 60s - leftish values and hippie ideals at the pinnacle of the Vietnam war - can be taken on a number of levels, and Haggard recommends that it is. Predominant among these, though, is his persistent defence of ordinary blue-collar people.

At Haggard's live show at New York's Irving Plaza that night, Okie receives the biggest cheer. Here, as the audience celebrate their lives vicariously through his short-story songs, Haggard is enjoying himself with his outstanding band, the Strangers. And from the album that Haggard says will determine the course of a near-40 year career, he plays just one song.

If I Could Only Fly is on Anti Records.

webTitle: Arts: Russia's answer to Finnegans Wake

fields.headline: Russia's answer to Finnegans Wake
fields.standfirst: A movie masterpiece
fields.trailText: No sound on the film festival circuit is as haunting as the clatter of seats flipping up as person after person walks out of a screening. I've never heard it come as thick and fast as in Cannes in 1998, when they showed the Russian film Khroustaliov, My Car!
fields.body:
No sound on the film festival circuit is as haunting as the clatter of seats flipping up as person after person walks out of a screening. I've never heard it come as thick and fast as in Cannes in 1998, when they showed the Russian film Khroustaliov, My Car!

By all accounts, Alexei Guerman's film didn't fare well in Russia either, but the film arrives here this week, via Paris and New York, where it won a reputation as a misunderstood masterpiece. Misunderstood, or just incomprehensible? There is, apparently, a coherent plot buried beneath the manic activity.

The film is set in Moscow in 1953, against the background of the so-called Doctors' Plot - an anti-semitic operation that spread the rumour that Jewish doctors were conspiring to poison the Soviet high command. The hulking baldie Yuri Glinsky, a Red Army general and brain surgeon whose chaotic household shelters two Jewish nieces is caught up in the scandal. He ends up witnessing Stalin's gruesome demise, which is where the title is explained (Khroustaliov was chauffeur to Beria, chief of the secret police).

What makes Khroustaliov such a head-spinner is the frenzied style. Guerman favours long takes and labyrinthine tracking shots but everything is an orchestrated cataclysm, like a hellish circus. Few of the thousands of characters stay still long enough to be identified. The film is a succession of chases, pratfalls and punch-ups; characters mutter to themselves or burst into song or screams; dogs, pigs, lions drown out the dialogue.

Russian cinema has its tradition of period reconstruction, but nothing quite like this. Guerman's previous film My Friend Ivan Lapshin (1982) was set just before the Stalinist purges of the 1930s. Its follow-up is a very personal project: Guerman has compared General Glinsky to his own father, a prominent Soviet writer. He actually began work on the film in the last days of the Soviet Union, but the production stretched over seven years, with funds continually running out and a year reputedly spent assembling the many ominous black cars that drive around Moscow in the film's night scenes.

It is a wonder the film was ever completed. It has been called impenetrable but it has its spaces and silence too - and the very first shot, as a dog chases a motorcycle down a snow-covered boulevard at night, is one of the most haunting images of recent cinema. Khroustaliov, My Car! resembles nothing else in cinema - although if Fellini, Tarkovsky and Tati had pooled resources to update a Gogol story, they might have matched it.

Of Freaks and Men, Alexei Balabanov's black comedy of fin de siècle porn in St Petersburg, was recently a cult hit here, which proves that British audiences are ready for the darker end of the Russian cinematic imagination. Guerman's film, however, may be Russian cinema's answer to Finnegans Wake. This month's screenings, courtesy of the micro-distributor Kino Kino!, could be the only chance you get to see it. And don't worry about the sound of the seats flipping - it all blends in marvellously with the cacophony.

Khoustaliov, My Car! is at the Ciné Lumière, London SW7 (020-7838 2144) , on Thursday; at the ICA, London SW1 (020-7930 3647), on Monday; and at the Filmhouse, Edinburgh (0131-228 2688), on October 30.

webTitle: Arts: Michael Nyman and Orlando Gough

fields.headline: Music that moves
fields.standfirst: Michael Nyman and Orlando Gough tell  Judith Mackrell  about the trials of composing for dance
fields.trailText: Composers are not always the most ardent fans of dance - particularly when choreography accompanies their own music. When Debussy saw the steps that Nijinsky had created to his 1913 score Jeux, he could barely contain his contempt.
fields.body:
Composers are not always the most ardent fans of dance - particularly when choreography accompanies their own music. When Debussy saw the steps that Nijinsky had created to his 1913 score Jeux, he could barely contain his contempt. "Among recent pointless goings-on I must include the staging of Jeux...This fellow [Nijinsky] adds up triple crotchets with his feet, checks them on his arms, then suddenly, half-paralysed, stands crossly watching the music slip by. It's awful."

British composers Michael Nyman and Orlando Gough have, fortunately, had happier dealings in the world of dance - and, as with many composers, their new work has sometimes appeared thanks to the support of choreographers. Dance is one of the most important platforms for new music, since it commissions so many scores. Even Debussy's Jeux would never have seen the light of day had it not been created for Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.

Gough admits that dance has been "a lifeline" in his own composing career and, while Nyman may reach a wider public through his film music, he too has had reason to be grateful. It is not just that choreographers, as he points out, "bugger the music around" less than film directors, but that certain dance collaborations have inspired him to create work he would otherwise never have made.

But watching their scores paired with bad dancing can be excruciating. "It makes the music sound incredibly annoying and grating," Gough says. When pushed, both composers confess to having been as disconcerted as Debussy by the maths of some of their collaborators. "You give these choreographers a beat and then they don't even dance to it," they say.

Gough and Nyman haven't crossed paths since 1976, when they were members of a mildly anarchic group of composer-pianists called Five Pianos. They have, though, composed music for several of the same dance artists and, when I got them together to compare notes, they admitted to feeling that choreographers sometimes speak a different language from musicians.

Nyman confesses that he is "a sort of literalist" when it comes to dance, and has a hard time accepting that choreographers rarely simply shadow musical structures. One of his earliest dance collaborations was with the Royal Ballet's Ashley Page. "I gave Ashley all this stuff with very fixed beats but I never saw the dancers placing their feet where the music placed its feet, so to speak. It was either very perverse or very brilliant." Gough has also worked with Page but thinks that he is far more responsive to musical beat than most. "If you give Ashley a beat he's a happy man. He hears beats in anything."

Certainly Page has always stuck far closer to the logic of Gough's music than, for instance Ian Spink (choreographer of the now defunct Second Stride). "In some of the pieces Spink and I worked on there'd be really serious friction," recalls Gough. "The music and dance would be rubbing against each other in ways that could seem totally arbitrary. I'd be wondering what on earth he was doing."

But then Gough isn't sure that absolute faithfulness to music is the right solution, either. He remembers that the first piece he saw by Mark Morris made him think: "Gosh, how flattering to the composer. Every single movement in the dance seemed to be imitating something in the music. But after a while it seemed too much of a tautology. There wasn't any friction between the music and the dance." Gough's collaborations with Spink may have been more abrasive but there were times when the collision of their separate ideas produced dazzling sparks. "We had moments that were utter genius," he says.

Siobhan Davies also tends to regard music and dance as independent entities but both Gough and Nyman have found her sensitive to the overall structure of their work. She may find her own vision in the music but it flatters, rather than hijacks, the score. Gough doesn't know how this happens but is enchanted by it. When he set out to compose for Davies's Of Oil and Water, which opens at Sadler's Wells in London tonight, he had been alarmed by the nebulousness of their common ground. "The ideas we had discussed were pretty intangible," he says. However, when he saw the piece in the theatre he realised that some new entity had been created, which he felt was all the more powerful for being impossible to describe.

Nyman agrees that good choreography can have a magically gratifying effect on the way he hears his own music. The first time he saw Stephen Petronio's new work together with his own score, he was mesmerised by "the different sense of time it gave me. There's a really interesting tension between the pace of the movement and the grouping of the bodies in relation to the music's rather stolid beat. When the choreography is strong enough to go against the plotting of the music the music flows and breaks out of itself. I can forget what I originally did and get transported."

Do they mind that the dancing usually takes precedence over their music in the theatre? It's not just that audiences tend to buy their tickets with the choreographer in mind, but that once inside the theatre, what they see on stage probably registers more powerfully than what they hear. Nyman and Gough gang up in instant, defensive accord: "That may be true for you," says Gough, "but it's not the case for us." "After all," says Nyman, "we can always just shut our eyes and listen."

Siobhan Davies's Of Oil and Water is at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020-7863 8000), from tonight till Saturday. Stephen Petronio's Strange Attractors is at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), from October 31 till November 1.

It is not just that choreographers, as he points out, "bugger the music around" less than film directors, but that certain dance collaborations have inspired him to create work he would otherwise never have made. But watching their scores paired with bad dancing can be excruciating. "It makes the music sound incredibly annoying and grating," Gough says. When pushed, both composers confess to having been as disconcerted as Debussy by the maths of some of their collaborators. "You give these choreographers a beat and then they don't even dance to it," they say. Gough and Nyman haven't crossed paths since 1976, when they were members of a mildly anarchic group of composer-pianists called Five Pianos. They have, though, composed music for several of the same dance artists and, when I got them together to compare notes, they admitted to feeling that choreographers sometimes speak a different language from musicians. Nyman confesses that he is "a sort of literalist" when it comes to dance, and has a hard time accepting that choreographers rarely simply shadow musical structures. One of his earliest dance collaborations was with the Royal Ballet's Ashley Page. "I gave Ashley all this stuff with very fixed beats but I never saw the dancers placing their feet where the music placed its feet, so to speak. It was either very perverse or very brilliant." Gough has also worked with Page but thinks that he is far more responsive to musical beat than most. "If you give Ashley a beat he's a happy man. He hears beats in anything." Certainly Page has always stuck far closer to the logic of Gough's music than, for instance Ian Spink (choreographer of the now defunct Second Stride). "In some of the pieces Spink and I worked on there'd be really serious friction," recalls Gough. "The music and dance would be rubbing against each other in ways that could seem totally arbitrary. I'd be wondering what on earth he was doing." But then Gough isn't sure that absolute faithfulness to music is the right solution, either. He remembers that the first piece he saw by Mark Morris made him think: "Gosh, how flattering to the composer. Every single movement in the dance seemed to be imitating something in the music. But after a while it seemed too much of a tautology. There wasn't any friction between the music and the dance." Gough's collaborations with Spink may have been more abrasive but there were times when the collision of their separate ideas produced dazzling sparks. "We had moments that were utter genius," he says. Siobhan Davies also tends to regard music and dance as independent entities but both Gough and Nyman have found her sensitive to the overall structure of their work. She may find her own vision in the music but it flatters, rather than hijacks, the score. Gough doesn't know how this happens but is enchanted by it. When he set out to compose for Davies's Of Oil and Water, which opens at Sadler's Wells in London tonight, he had been alarmed by the nebulousness of their common ground. "The ideas we had discussed were pretty intangible," he says. However, when he saw the piece in the theatre he realised that some new entity had been created, which he felt was all the more powerful for being impossible to describe. Nyman agrees that good choreography can have a magically gratifying effect on the way he hears his own music. The first time he saw Stephen Petronio's new work together with his own score, he was mesmerised by "the different sense of time it gave me. There's a really interesting tension between the pace of the movement and the grouping of the bodies in relation to the music's rather stolid beat. When the choreography is strong enough to go against the plotting of the music the music flows and breaks out of itself. I can forget what I originally did and get transported." Do they mind that the dancing usually takes precedence over their music in the theatre? It's not just that audiences tend to buy their tickets with the choreographer in mind, but that once inside the theatre, what they see on stage probably registers more powerfully than what they hear. Nyman and Gough gang up in instant, defensive accord: "That may be true for you," says Gough, "but it's not the case for us." "After all," says Nyman, "we can always just shut our eyes and listen." Siobhan Davies's Of Oil and Water is at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020-7863 8000), from tonight till Saturday. Stephen Petronio's Strange Attractors is at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), from October 31 till November 1.

webTitle: BMW delivers twin blow to Rover

fields.headline: BMW delivers twin blow to Rover
fields.standfirst:
Setback for engine plant hopes and £150m funding plea rejected

Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: BMW, the former owners of Rover, yesterday dealt the new management of the British car firm a damaging double blow by rejecting their plea for further funding and dashing their hopes of a quick purchase of the engine plant at Longbridge.
fields.body:
BMW, the former owners of Rover, yesterday dealt the new management of the British car firm a damaging double blow by rejecting their plea for further funding and dashing their hopes of a quick purchase of the engine plant at Longbridge.

Directors of the company, now called MG Rover, have been negotiating for a further £150m from BMW to offset the fall in the value of the stock of vehicles acquired at the time of the merger. They were also hoping to wrap up a deal to buy the engine plant by mid December.

Werner Sämann, head of BMW's UK operations, said in Birmingham that the German group saw no need to hand over any more money to MG Rover and that it was negotiating with a number of international companies over the Longbridge engine plant.

The Phoenix consortium headed by John Towers bought the bulk of Rover Cars from BMW for a nominal £10 in May. But it also received a "dowry" from the German firm estimated at about £500m.

Negotiations have been going on for some months to finalise the accounts on the deal, known as a completion agreement. Since the initial takeover deal was struck, car values in Britain have fallen sharply, prompting MG Rover to seek up to £150m more.

Senior MG Rover directors said on Monday that they hoped to reach a final agreement with BMW before Christmas. But Prof Sämann said yesterday: "We signed an agreement on May 9, transferring all the assets and liabilities to Phoenix based on their valuation on that date.

"There is no need to sign off any completion accounts. We have handed over the balance sheet and the business and that is it. If they have a problem with that, they can go to arbitration."

Prof Sämann's aides recognised, however, that it was in the interests of both groups to come to a swift resolution of their differences. But they saw no need for a hasty decision on the Longbridge engine, gearbox and foundry plant which provides all of MG Rover's power units.

Rob Oldaker, MG Rover's product design director, made plain on Monday that gaining control of the Longbridge engine facility - known as Powertrain - was critical to plans to develop a new range of sporty vehicles under the MG badge and to speed the company's return to profit by 2002 by cutting costs.

He said: "We are confident we will come to a successful outcome. We can do lots of things with this facility." The Longbridge engine plant delivers 70% of its annual output of about 200,000 units to MG Rover and the rest to Land Rover, now owned by Ford.

But Prof Sämann said reports that a deal would be concluded by Christmas were wide of the mark. "There are several renowned international companies who are interested in the business and with whom we are negotiating. Phoenix is just one of them."

BMW officials said the German group was negotiating with "less than a handful" of would-be buyers and did not expect a result for several months.

Ford, which is not interested in buying the plant, is thought to be reluctant to see it pass into MG Rover's hands.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Better late than never, the chance comes to celebrate Margaret Thatcher's 75th birthday. (By the way, readers should send liquid gifts if they choose: we don't trust gossip about a separation between the old bat and her chair during lunch with a friendly editor.) The tribute comes by way of a late postscript to the Westland affair. India has just sold its entire fleet of 19 helicopters (which Thatcher persuaded Rajiv Gandhi to buy for £60m in 1985 when Westland's crisis was at its height), for all of £900,000. The sale baled Mrs T and Westland out of trouble, but once the helicopters had been shipped to India, they proved a total disaster. Two of them crashed, while the survivors were overtly unsuited to tropical weather and needed constant servicing and repairs. In 1991 they were withdrawn on safety grounds, and have only now been sold back to AES Aerospace after spending years rotting in crates at New Delhi airport. Anyway, let's hear no more about it. Happy birthday, Ma'am.
fields.body:
 Better late than never, the chance comes to celebrate Margaret Thatcher's 75th birthday. (By the way, readers should send liquid gifts if they choose: we don't trust gossip about a separation between the old bat and her chair during lunch with a friendly editor.) The tribute comes by way of a late postscript to the Westland affair. India has just sold its entire fleet of 19 helicopters (which Thatcher persuaded Rajiv Gandhi to buy for £60m in 1985 when Westland's crisis was at its height), for all of £900,000. The sale baled Mrs T and Westland out of trouble, but once the helicopters had been shipped to India, they proved a total disaster. Two of them crashed, while the survivors were overtly unsuited to tropical weather and needed constant servicing and repairs. In 1991 they were withdrawn on safety grounds, and have only now been sold back to AES Aerospace after spending years rotting in crates at New Delhi airport. Anyway, let's hear no more about it. Happy birthday, Ma'am.

 Geoffrey Robinson's memoirs, as serialised by the Mail, are most entertaining. Any impression that Geoffrey was only tolerated in government for the champagne he served and the size of his wad but had not one whit of influence, couldn't be more mistaken. Geoffrey, in fact, was the author of policy on monetary union. "In later discussions with him [weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown], I suggested Labour should hold a referendum before we joined," he writes. "He mulled the idea over, consulted Tony Blair [note how Gordon is portrayed as boss, and Mr T the underling], and then made public our pledge to put the matter to a vote of the people when the time came." So it was all Geoffrey. Who now would dare dismiss him as a spiteful, self-deluding buffoon who wouldn't be up to being a junior transport minister in the government of Trumpton?

 That haughty siren, Baroness Jay, impresses with her effortless grasp of Labour policy. Approached recently by a party member and asked about New Labour's embarrassing inability to speed ahead towards numerical gender equality in parliament, Her Ladyship had the perfect response. "I've been thinking about that," she announced, "and am going to suggest that any short-list must have at least one woman on it. That should work." Brilliant, absolutely brilliant. It is true that under Labour rules, all short lists must already be split 50-50 between men and women, but what tedious pedant would quibble? Hats off to Baroness Jay.

 The Home Office is on top form, bombarding us with informative emails. One arrives at 10.14am from Lee Halsey, revealing that British Summer Time will end at 2am on Sunday, October 29. "Clocks Go Forward," the headline deflates. At 11.15, Lee is in touch again. "Amended Version," reads the headline this time. "Clocks Go Back." Another bloody U-turn.

 Finding a copy of the new Book of the Month, Tony Really Loves Me, by the ecclesiastic commissioner and erstwhile novelist Stuart Bell MP, proves troublesome. No one seems to have heard of the publisher, SpenView. By a particularly spooky coincidence, the register of members interests lists Stuart as a director of something called SpenView Publications Ltd, but this can't be the same firm or it would be something dangerously close to vanity publishing. Unless we can find the other SpenView today, we will be forced to pay for a copy.

 At the White House, patriotism known no bounds, whether in the Oval office or the cheapest tourist memento such as souvenir matchbooks embossed with the presidential crest. There is a little embarrassment, apparently, over the fact the manufacturer of the matches relocated the factory, and beneath the symbol of the US's highest office appear the words "Made in Canada".

webTitle: Michelin ends 74 years of tyre making

fields.headline: Michelin ends 74 years of tyre making
fields.trailText: Michelin announced yesterday that it is to end tyre making at its Stoke-on-Trent factory next year, with the loss of some 950 jobs.
fields.body:
Michelin announced yesterday that it is to end tyre making at its Stoke-on-Trent factory next year, with the loss of some 950 jobs.

The French company blamed falling profits, increased costs and the need to switch production out of Europe for its decision to cease car tyre, van tyre and rubber mixing operations after 74 years.

Truck retreads, mould and steel cord production will continue at the site which employs 2,350. The job losses will take effect in the second half of next year.

Stoke manufactures about 2m tyres a year, compared to competitors' plants which often make more than 8m.

Land Rover's manufacturing plant in Solihull, where new owner Ford plans to push through big productivity improvements to return it to profitability by 2002, was yesterday hit by a wildcat strike over holidays.

Ford, which bought Land Rover from BMW for £1.84bn earlier this year, inherited German-style working arrangements under which employees work 37 hours a week but are paid for 36. Staff can bank the extra hour as holiday, normally an extra seven days on top of five weeks' annual leave.

Some 600 staff on the Freelander night shift and paint shop walked out late on Monday over Land Rover's insistence that the extra holiday could not be taken when the workers want it. By the afternoon shift, they had all returned to work.

The company, which makes 80,000 Freelanders a year out of a total output of some 180,000 at Solihull, initially suspended talks with the unions over a new pay agreement and said the unofficial dispute had cost it around £4m. The talks are now due to resume on October 30.

Ford is committed to doubling Freelander production without employing extra staff as it prepares to launch its bestselling car in new markets, including Japan and the US.

webTitle: TV: Phil Davis is starring in Channel 4's North Square

fields.headline: Class action
fields.standfirst: He's worked with everyone from Alan Clarke to Mike Leigh, playing spotty mods and bearded bike couriers. Now in his 40s, Phil Davis is starring in Channel 4's North Square and, he tells  Mark Morris, having the time of his life doing it
fields.trailText: He's worked with everyone from Alan Clarke to Mike Leigh, playing spotty mods and bearded bike couriers. Now in his 40s, Phil Davis is starring in Channel 4's North Square and, he tells Mark Morris, having the time of his life doing it.
fields.body:
Phil Davis has a great grin. It is truly wolfish, utterly evocative of a cute animal having been recently devoured. He uses it to great effect when playing scheming barrister's clerk Peter McLeish in Channel 4's big new legal drama North Square. And it creeps onto his face when I ask him if he has ever been arrested.

"No. Everybody asks me this. It's really interesting, that's the one question everyone has asked me. But it is true to say that whenever I've been in a legal drama before, I have always been in the dock."

It's the work rather than the life: Davis has played his share of dangerous geezers. He starred in the definitive account of football thuggery (The Firm) and directed another (ID). Not to mention all the times he has appeared alongside Ray Winstone: in Face and in Births, Marriages And Deaths, just for starters. In real life, as the clean record suggests, the bespectacled Davis is both thoughtful and affable. But his acting has that edge, and it makes McLeish a memorable character. North Square, written by ex-barrister Peter Moffat, makes the useful choice of showing the chief clerk, rather than the head of chambers, as the person in control.

"I was surprised that barristers' clerks wielded so much power and influence", Davis admits. "I had no idea, I just thought they were administrative." Bobbing round the 47-year-old Davis as the barrister in the upstart Leeds chamber is a cast of (mostly) highly photogenic, posher actors fifteen to twenty years his junior, including Helen McCory, Kevin McKidd and Rupert Penry-Jones. But the camera keeps coming back to Davis, as he insists on calling all the barristers "sir" or "miss" while telling them exactly what to do. You don't need to be watching long to see that Davis is enjoying himself. "He's a fantastic character: vivid and well-drawn and appalling and funny. One would be foolish not to relish that."

On these pages, Mark Lawson has suggested that North Square is unduly concerned with class. Davis, unsurprisingly, doesn't agree. "It's only a shock to middle-class people that there is this working-class guy running things for all these middle- class, intelligent barristers. You could say that all English drama is about class to some degree, but I don't think North Square is about class predominantly: it's about law, and how it is applied. That's what is really interesting: in one scenario a woman loses her children and it's tragic, in another some nutter is stealing underpants and it's comic; that's much more like real life, with a tragedy tumbling over a comedy. Plus the career side of it: you're hoping for a plea on Monday so you can do the big fraud on Tuesday. Of course it goes on."

This is hardly the first time Davis has talked about class. Having appeared in The Who's mod melodrama Quadrophenia and worked with Alan Clarke on The Firm, he is part of the Ray Winstone/Phil Daniels generation of working-class actors so neglected during the 80s. He comes from that part of Essex that absorbed the London overspill, and his dad worked in a soap factory.

"I always wanted to be an actor, and I was indulged by my parents. I joined the National Youth Theatre, and didn't distinguish myself. I was shy, and squeaky, and about three foot six. I left school, and I was working in coffee bars and all that, and I wrote to Joan Littlewood at Stratford East. They were starting a new season, and I auditioned, and I got the job, and stayed for a year. Then I was off and running. I didn't go to drama school, and it was a real advantage working with her not hav ing trained, because Joan Littlewood worked in such a weird way - I would've had to unlearn everything immediately. It was a good start, it made me pragmatic."

Along with Littlewood, Davis's other mentor was Mike Leigh. He worked with Leigh in the theatre, and as Cyril the bearded bike courier in High Hopes. "It was like a workshop on how to make a story. And Mike was very supportive when I started writing. He'd always come and see a rehearsal and tell me very frankly exactly what he thought I ought to do." Davis has directed two films (ID and last year's Hold Back The Night), plus TV shows including Prime Suspect and Real Women. He says it has refreshed him as an actor, but he doesn't make it sound much fun.

"Directing isn't terribly enjoyable, and for me going to do an acting job after that is the life of Riley. For me, acting isn't an intellectual exercise, it's purely instinctive. When it's great, it's like surfing. Whereas directing, you have to contain a kind of algebra in your head."

He lives in Hackney these days and still supports West Ham, but not rabidly. And on the subject of football, he's aware that the first episode of North Square is up against Manchester United vs PSV. "I can't help thinking if I was launching a ten-episode, brand new series, I wouldn't put it up against the football on ITV."

He's right, of course, but if you really can't miss the dreaded Reds playing, then tape North Square. The first episode tries a little too hard (what's with all the Clash references?), but it gets better. And Peter McLeish could turn out to be a great character.

Watch for that grin.

 North Square, 9pm, Channel 4.

He lives in Hackney these days and still supports West Ham, but not rabidly. And on the subject of football, he's aware that the first episode of North Square is up against Manchester United vs PSV. "I can't help thinking if I was launching a ten-episode, brand new series, I wouldn't put it up against the football on ITV." He's right, of course, but if you really can't miss the dreaded Reds playing, then tape North Square. The first episode tries a little too hard (what's with all the Clash references?), but it gets better. And Peter McLeish could turn out to be a great character. Watch for that grin.  North Square, 9pm, Channel 4.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Exmoor
fields.body:
Exmoor

Yet more rain pours down over Selworthy Beacon as steep coastal woods to the west are blotted out by cloud pushing up the Channel. Paths through heather are transformed into streams and earthy water flows down Dean's Lane towards Porlock Vale, where plumes of mist rise from the patchwork of red arable and green pasture. Later, a succession of rainbows arch over the Holnicote Estate and we shed wet coats in the shelter of Horner's tea garden.

The day before, walking in a big loop from Porlock Weir, we passed through the varied landscape of Exmoor, with its abrupt changes from woods to pasture and open moor. Sunken lanes lead uphill, away from the quiet wave-fringed bay, past hollies loaded with berries and beeches weighed down with nuts. Then up wooded Hawk Combe with its rushing stream and ferny banks, emerging into rolling green fields with spreading beech hedges and flocks of sheep. Westwards, around Lucott Cross, expansive, more grassy moorland is broken with landmark clumps and shelter belts of beech. Sturdy horned sheep graze around Larkbarrow and, on a distant skyline, riders follow the foxhounds, observed through binoculars by followers along the road. The stag hounds are also out - towards Brendon Two Gates.

After Withycombe and Stowey, set above 1,100 ft, we drop down to Oare church. Deddy Combe leads up to the coastal ridge, pastures high above the sea. The final lap is through Culbone's dim oak woods, zigzagging down to Worthy with hundreds of cheeping, half-grown pheasants scuttling through undergrowth on the Lytton estate.

webTitle: Now it really is America online

fields.headline: Now it really is America online
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Americans' access to computers and the internet has grown dramatically over the past 20 months, with computers now in more than half of all households, according to a US government report.
fields.body:
Americans' access to computers and the internet has grown dramatically over the past 20 months, with computers now in more than half of all households, according to a US government report.

The share of households with computers rose from 42.1% in December 1998 to 51% last August - a total of 53.7m households, the commerce department found.

The number of households with internet access hit 41.5% in August, up from 26.2% in 1999.

As in past surveys, the government found a technology gap, with whites and people living in cities much more likely to have computers and internet access than ethnic minorities and those living in rural areas.

The report found that 23.5% of black households had internet access in August. While this was up from 11.2% in the 1999 survey, it still lagged behind the rate for white households of 46.1%.

The percentage of Hispanic households with internet access was 23.6% in August while Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders continued to have the largest internet penetration at 56.8%.

By state, Utah ranked first in computer ownership with 66.1% of households owning a computer, followed by Alaska at 64.8%. States with the lowest percentage of computer homes were Mississippi at 37.2% and Arkansas at 37.3%.

US commerce department site: www.doc.gov

webTitle: Accomplice of Jackal on trial after 25 years

fields.headline: Accomplice of Jackal on trial after 25 years
fields.trailText: An accomplice of the jailed terrorist Carlos the Jackal in the 1975 kidnapping of Opec oil ministers in Vienna went on trial yesterday, claiming that Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, had personally influenced him in his fight for radical leftwing causes.
fields.body:
An accomplice of the jailed terrorist Carlos the Jackal in the 1975 kidnapping of Opec oil ministers in Vienna went on trial yesterday, claiming that Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, had personally influenced him in his fight for radical leftwing causes.

Hans-Joachim Klein, 52, admitted involvement in the attack masterminded by the Venezuelan-born Carlos, whose real name is Ilich Ramirez Sanchez. Mr Klein is expected to name Libya as a country that helped to organise the operation in which three people died and several were wounded.

Mr Klein provided an insight into the revolutionary student milieu of early 1970s Frankfurt where he, Mr Fischer and the French activist Daniel Cohn-Bendit (now a member of the European Parliament), were heavily involved in leftwing politics.

"Joschka and Danny were my friends, I looked to them as my guiding lights," he told the court in Frankfurt. "We were all consumed with a burning hatred for the United States because of its role in the Vietnam war."

In Frankfurt Mr Klein was recruited into the leftwing commando unit led by Carlos which carried out the attack in Vienna on December 21. The terrorists escaped by plane to Algeria with 35 hostages who were subsequently freed.

After being on the run for more than 20 years, Mr Klein was finally arrested in Paris in September 1998. He was extradited to Germany last year.

"The 10 minutes at Opec a quarter of a century ago have ruined half my life," he said. "I have been paying for it ever since."

He is said to have told the authorities that it was Muammar Gadafy who personally sanctioned the Opec attack. This claim is likely to compromise the Libyan leader's standing in Germany where he has been given credit for negotiating the release recently of German hostages held by Islamic rebels on the Philippine island of Jolo.

Joshka Fischer's involvement in revolutionary politics in Frankfurt during the 1970s is well known. But Mr Klein's testimony could shed light on a potentially damaging allegation made about the foreign minister in a recent biography by Michael Schwelin, who claims that in 1973 police found handguns in Mr Fischer's car which had been stolen from a US army barracks.

Mr Schwelin claims that police established that one of the pistols was later used by leftwing terrorists to assassinate a Free Democrat politician, Herbert Karry, in 1981.

fields.headline: Hedging on wines
fields.trailText: The rarefied wares of the likes of Chateaux Haut-Brion, Latour, Lafitte and Margaux will soon be trading alongside December pork bellies and August Brent crude in a new futures market for Bordeaux wine.
fields.body:
The rarefied wares of the likes of Chateaux Haut-Brion, Latour, Lafitte and Margaux will soon be trading alongside December pork bellies and August Brent crude in a new futures market for Bordeaux wine.

The 30-month contract, on a case of a dozen bottles, has caused consternation among the region's more conservative growers. But the Paris international bourse, Euronext, says it will allow big buyers to hedge their viticultural risks.

"It's largely a financial instrument, of course - very few of the contracts will result in actual physical delivery of the wine," a spokesman said.

Bordeaux is home to some of the greatest chateaux in the world. Most of the region's merchants are sceptical about Euronext's initiative.

"We look upon all this with uncertainty and anxiety," said their spokesman, Francis Cruse. "Uncertainty about a world of which we know nothing, and anxiety about the effect on Bordeaux's image of being involved with a market that is generally associated with ugly raw materials and mass-production."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Commission/Where Was God?
fields.body:
After the death of 35 people in the Clapham train disaster in December 1988, the official inquiry called for the rapid installation of an automatic train protection system. Eleven years later, when a further 31 died in the Ladbroke Grove crash, there was still nothing in place. In The Commission (8.0pm, Radio 4), Nick Ross asks Will Hutton, Conor Gearty and Lady Dean what they think of such investigations. Are they just a waste of time and money, or is there some way to make them more effective?

As part of this week's Faith In The Nation series, the poet Stewart Henderson looks at how different religions cope with man's inhumanity. Where Was God? (9.0pm, Radio 2) considers the churches' response to such global horrors as the Nazis' mass murder campaigns and the ethnic slaughter in Rwanda. But it also examines the intensely personal reaction of a Somali mother of eight whose husband is being tortured in prison.

fields.headline: Wherefrom art thou?
fields.standfirst: A collection of 109 works by major artists is given to France by a mystery donor
fields.trailText: A spectacular exhibition of 109 works by some of the world's greatest painters opened yesterday at the Musée d'Orsay in Paris - but no one was prepared to say where they had come from.
fields.body:
A spectacular exhibition of 109 works by some of the world's greatest painters opened yesterday at the Musée d'Orsay in Paris - but no one was prepared to say where they had come from.

Speculation was intense about the donor who gave his collection of paintings, sculptures and graphic works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the French nation. But the directors of the Musées de France said that the individual had insisted on preserving his anonymity.

So far, only a regional French newspaper, La Provence, has dared to suggest that the donor was Philippe Meyer, son of the founder of Lazard Frères bank in New York, and a noted supporter of the arts.

Mr Meyer helped the Musée d'Orsay purchase Manet's Portrait of Berthe Morisot with a Bouquet of Violets in 1998.

However, for many critics and art lovers at the Parisian gallery yesterday, the identity of the donor did not matter. Rather, what made their hearts swell with patriotic pride was the fact that many of the paintings - including some Cézannes and Fantin-Latours, a Chardin, a Degas, a Monet, a Manet, a Matisse and a post-cubist Leger - had been returned to their native land.

"Our donor acquired practically all of his collection in Switzerland, the United States and England, and brought back these masterpieces to their own country," said Françoise Cachin of the Musée d'Orsay. "Knowing that import tax is extremely high [5% of the value of each work in France] gives us another reason for saluting his generosity."

But Ms Cachin was not prepared to say how much the collection was worth - at least not in vulgar money terms. "The remarkable thing about the collection is that it is composed of recent acquisitions - nearly all of them were bought in the past 20 years," she said.

The collection's highlights include Cézanne's Five Bathers, Degas's Chez la Modiste and Manet's Flowers in a Crystal Vase.

Many of the works are not French, however. Indeed, the title of the display, From Cézanne to Giacometti (which runs at the gallery on the Left Bank until November 19), gives that fact away.

Along with 17 Giacomettis, a Klee, a Schwitters, and a Mondrian, the collection includes 20 paintings by Tal Coat, an associate of Picasso. After the Musée d'Orsay show has come to a close, much of the collection is to be dispersed throughout France.

Fifty-seven works will stay in Paris, but the rest will go to Grenoble, Rennes, Quimper, and the Granet Museum in Aix-en-Provence. In the course of the past 15 years, the donor of these works has helped French art galleries acquire works by Renoir, Degas, Whistler, Bonnard and Moreau.
