webTitle: Firms attack plans to list staff options

fields.headline: Firms attack plans to list staff options
fields.trailText: About £2.3bn could be wiped from the value of Britain's leading computing and IT firms if they are forced to make provisions for share options in their profit and loss accounts.
fields.body:
About £2.3bn could be wiped from the value of Britain's leading computing and IT firms if they are forced to make provisions for share options in their profit and loss accounts.

The Accounting Standards Board's proposals for companies granting share options to show this as a cost in their profit and loss account would knock an average of 5.65% off pre-tax profits at each firm, according to a report published by technology corporate finance specialists Capital Strategies.

The report, Equity@work, calculates that if the market adjusted the valuation of each company to reflect the fall in headline profits their combined market capitalisations would fall by £2.3bn.

"It is clear that for most technology companies, the ASB's proposals will have a significant impact on profits," said Robert Postlethwaite, a director of Capital Strategies. "Whilst some investors favour the transparency the proposals may bring, we think that they will impact adversely on valuations, which may give them pause for thought."

Capital Strategies surveyed 88 stock market listed computer and IT services firms. It found that almost all operated extensive share option plans for employees.

Hi-tech companies in the early stages of development and where human capital is the main cost often use options as a way of attracting staff at a time when they make little or no profit. The practice is particularly prevalent in the US, where staff are offered valuable options in return for loyalty and there are less stringent limits on options.

British firms believe that the ASB's initiative would hit developing hi-tech companies particularly hard and place UK firms that operate in a global market, such as Logica and CMG, at a disadvantage.

Investors argue that the value of share options should be reflected in profit and loss accounts because options are a cost that will eventually dilute investors holdings.

Capital Strategies found that if companies continue to award shares at the same rate each year the average dilution rate over the next 10 years will be 22%.

The sum exceeds guidelines set down by the Association of British Insurers and the National Association of Pension Funds. They expect dilution of no more than 10% over a 10-year period.

At a company like Logica, where executive directors are sitting on options worth more than £15m, the dilution over a 10-year period based on the most recent share option grants could exceed 18%.

Inland revenue figures show that 4,000 companies operate share options schemes, with 2m employees taking part.

webTitle: Foes say Manila leader got payoffs

fields.headline: Foes say Manila leader got payoffs
fields.trailText: The president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, faces his worst political crisis today after allegations that he has taken kickbacks from illegal operators of the country's most popular gambling game.
fields.body:
The president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, faces his worst political crisis today after allegations that he has taken kickbacks from illegal operators of the country's most popular gambling game.

A resolution to be filed in the House of Representatives will call for his impeachment. The scandal has already led to defections from his camp, and caused the peso to fall.

Yesterday Mr Estrada suffered a new shock when Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, who resigned as his vice-president last week, said she would lead a united opposition against him.

Mr Estrada has been accused by a former political ally, provincial governor Luis Singson, of taking more than $10m (around £7m) in payoffs from syndicates which run the jueteng numbers game.

The governor has been accused of inheriting a gambling empire from a brother whose operations covered almost all of Luzon island.

Though many Filipinos are sceptical about the allegations against Mr Estrada, his critics are exploiting disillusionment with his claim to champion the poor.

Mr Estrada's son, Joseph Ejercito, accused the previous president, Fidel Ramos, and the former security adviser, General Jose Almonte, of launching a plot to unseat his father.

Jueteng is a simple game: a box containing 37 numbered bolitas or wooden balls is shaken and two balls are rolled out. The punter has to guess which numbers will appear.

Huge payoffs are made to local police and inspectors, with a large percentage passed to senior officials as high as mayors and provincial governors. A small bet may attract a large jackpot depending on the number of punters who guess the winning combination.

Mr Estrada has promised to privatise the state-owned gambling monopoly PagCor, but his critics say this will lead to private monopolies being run by gangsters and cronies. PagCor has introduced its own thinly disguised version of jueteng, which was said to be controlled by an associate of the president.

webTitle: Charity Award 2000: the heroes and heroines

fields.headline: Five-star cast
fields.standfirst: Keith Perry meets some of the unsung heroes (and heroines) of the charity world
fields.trailText: Keith Perry meets some of the unsung heroes (and heroines) of the charity world
fields.body:
Working on a shoestring budget and often struggling to get a mention in the local press, let alone the national media, the Beth Johnson Foundation faces problems typical of many small charities.

The foundation, which for almost 30 years has been developing innovative ways of promoting the status of older people, can now claim to have achieved some national recognition after being chosen one of five winners of the Guardian Charity Award 2000. "This award and the £5,000 prize money will be very useful for us," Alan Hatton-Yeo, the foundation's chief executive, said at the presentation this week.

"One of our big concerns is looking at the ways in which younger and older people can work more closely together in our communities. In the past 30 years, there's been increasing fragmentation of older people, and this award will help us look at ways of re-establishing contact between the elderly and younger members of the community."

A fellow winner, the Phoenix Community Furniture Scheme, has also proved that a large budget is by no means a vital ingredient to achieving big results. Until five years ago, no charity in Powys had taken on the role of providing the household needs of people in rural mid-Wales who were on low incomes or receiving benefits. Since then, though, volunteers have worked tirelessly from premises on a Newtown industrial estate, collecting and distributing everything from beds and blankets to washing machines and wardrobes - all donated by local people.

Receiving the award, Celia Gardiner, the scheme's co-ordinator said: "This amount is substantial in terms of the income we receive. In addition to helping us provide household items for the financially disadvantaged, it will also help us provide training opportunities for disadvantaged youngsters, a workshop and better services for our clients."

Along with three other winners - Place 2 Be, a charity providing help for pupils with emotional problems; Sunnyside Community Gardens Association, which takes an holistic approach to improving an inner city community's mental and physical health by creating "healthy" buildings and organic gardens; and Shape Ticket Scheme, a disability arts organisation providing access to cultural events for elderly and disabled people - the schemes will find some cashflow problems temporarily eased by the prize money of £5,000 each, provided this year by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the leading funder of social policy research and development.

But perhaps more importantly, recognition of their excellence and innovation may generate much-needed publicity for their causes, and trigger more help. Alan Rusbridger, the Guardian's editor, said previous winners had found they could use the award as a basis to secure other funding. With smaller charities witnessing an ever-growing gap between themselves and their bigger counterparts, the scheme had more than proved its worth in the eight years since it started.

Rusbridger, who presented the prizes at a ceremony on Monday, said: "We all read about the big charities who can look after themselves because they get the publicity and go on to get the bulk of the revenue on offer. The benefits of a £5,000 cash injection will be felt immediately by one winner - Shape London, which works with 100 arts venues and companies to provide disabled and older people with discounts of up to 50% off normal ticket prices for events such as the opera, theatre, dance, cinema and museums.

webTitle: Democracy day - elected mayor campaigns gather pace

fields.headline: Elected mayor campaigns gather pace
fields.trailText: Ministers pushing the case for radical reform of town and county halls think their campaign to create a network of elected executive mayors in England after the next general election is finally paying off. With some 14 councils, led by Birmingham, preparing to hold mayoral referendums - and a string of others poised to join them - all the signs now point to a "national democracy day" in 12 months' time.
fields.body:
Ministers pushing the case for radical reform of town and county halls think their campaign to create a network of elected executive mayors in England after the next general election is finally paying off. With some 14 councils, led by Birmingham, preparing to hold mayoral referendums - and a string of others poised to join them - all the signs now point to a "national democracy day" in 12 months' time.

The idea is to co-ordinate up to 30 mayoral referendums next October to test popular support for an elected first citizen - with full-blown mayoral polls coinciding with local elections in May 2002.

This comes as key members of the New Local Government Network, a pressure group close to Downing Street, publish the results of a lengthy research project which urges the government to be far bolder in giving councils more powers and responsibilities - and argues that policies imposed from the top without local support often fail. Significantly some of the findings of the project, Towards a New Localism, which will be discussed at a conference in London tomorrow, follow the Guardian's own agenda for local democracy, published last month in its alternative election manifesto.

The network says that the mayoral debate should light the spark for a much wider reform process, with councils developing into the champions of their areas by assuming a wider leadership role embracing the economic and social health of communities. It attacks the excessive centralism of Whitehall and calls for a new system of five-year "partnership compacts", drawn up between town halls and all local stakeholders, which would replace the panoply of government-inspired programmes. Councils selected for such compacts would get extra government cash and support.

With the network influential in parts of the government, the reaction of ministers so far has been interesting. Perhaps with an eye on the project, local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, has urged authorities to become more adventurous. "Councils don't need to wait for a lead from central government before testing new ideas," she last week told the annual conference of the Society of Local Authority Chief Executives. "I'd be very pleased to see more evidence of councils making the running with their own reform agenda."

Armstrong finally pushed through legislation paving the way for mayors and cabinet-style administrations three months ago, with her boss at the environment department, John Prescott, publicly expressing opposition to the concept.

Nevertheless, with Birmingham now on track to lead the field, it is likely that other big cities will join small authorities - such as Berwick-upon-Tweed, and several London boroughs - in quickening the pace for change. Birmingham's support rested on a knife edge. But the council's Labour leader, Albert Bore and his deputy, Andy Howell, have narrowly retained their positions after beating off opposition in the city's divided Labour group.

fields.headline: Referee Harris granted reprieve
fields.trailText: Referee Rob Harris has escaped punishment from the FA despite his embarrassing weekend mix-up at Highbury.
fields.body:
The Oxford referee Rob Harris escaped punishment from the Football Association yesterday despite his embarrassing weekend mix-up at Highbury.

Harris booked Lee Hendrie twice during Arsenal's 1-0 defeat of Aston Villa on Saturday but failed to send the midfielder off. The crowd and Arsenal players pointed out his mistake and Hendrie was then shown the red card.

Last season Harris erred in an FA Cup tie between Tranmere and Sunderland when he dismissed a Tranmere player but allowed a substitute to come on in his place.

An FA spokesperson said the official had avoided punishment this time because he had restarted the game with the correct number of players on the pitch. That was not the case in last season's incident for which he was suspended.

Graeme Le Saux also managed to avoid a fine after his weekend's misdemeanours. He apparently tried to elbow Sunderland's Kevin Kilbane during Chelsea's 1-0 defeat at the Stadium of Light. Kilbane reacted by pushing him in the chest and Jeff Winter sent them both off, which the FA deemed the necessary action. "We are happy the referee dealt with the incident," said a spokesman.

Carlton Palmer also saw red at the weekend but must wait for the FA to study a match report. The Coventry midfielder had to be restrained after he was sent off for a foul on Tottenham's Chris Perry. He faces a three-match ban for the red card but may face a "misconduct" penalty as well.

Meanwhile Marseille have announced that they are about to sign George Weah, who had left Manchester City barely 24 hours before. A club spokesman said: "The deal is about to be signed. Only a couple of details are left to be settled. But in principle both parties have agreed." He added that the 34-year-old had turned down offers from Perugia and Bologna.

Everton have completed the signings of Gary Naysmith, the 21-year-old Scotland left-back, from Hearts for £1.75m and Idan Tal, a 25-year-old Israeli midfielder, for £700,000 from Maccabi Petach-Tikva.

Crystal Palace have bought the Latvian international midfielder Andrejs Rubins from Skonto Riga for £2m.

Ferenc Puskas, one of the world's greatest-ever players, has been admitted to hospital suffering from arteriosclerosis, although his personal manager Jozsef Barkovics said that his life was not in danger.

webTitle: Fifa to hear Scottish appeal over Brown's red

fields.headline: Fifa to hear Scottish appeal over Brown's red
fields.trailText: Scotland manager Craig Brown will have to wait until the end of the month to find out whether his one-match touchline ban stands.
fields.body:
The Scotland manager Craig Brown, sent off during his side's match against Croatia last week, will have to wait until the end of the month to find out whether his one-match touchline ban stands.

An automatic ban has been imposed but Brown maintains that he did nothing wrong. The Scottish FA's assistant director of administration yesterday sent a letter to Fifa's Zurich headquarters putting forward Scotland's case.

Fifa's decision will be based on video evidence, which the world governing body has yet to receive. If the ban is not quashed, Brown will have to watch the home match against Belgium in March from the stands.

Dundee United have said that they will not begin to restructure the club until the former chairman Jim McLean, who resigned in disgrace at the weekend after an altercation with a BBC reporter, has decided how to sell his shares.

"In the present circumstances it would be imprudent and unwise to settle upon a new and permanent structure for the club," a club statement said. "It is clear that there is still a large majority of supporters who have a huge respect for Jim. The club and the board share these sentiments and want to place on record their deep gratitude for everything he has achieved at Tannadice." The vice-chairman Doug Smith has taken over as interim chairman.

The Dundee United defender Stephen Wright faces a knee operation after suffering cartilage damage during Saturday's 4-0 defeat at Hearts. The summer free-transfer signing from Bradford is expected to be out for about a month.

Kenny Dalglish, the former Celtic and Liverpool manager, has launched a new career after being named as a non-executive director of the Eye Group, a London-based sports media company. He had been out of work since leaving Parkhead during the summer. "I just don't feel comfortable with not working," he said. "It's still nice to get up in the morning with a purpose."

Aberdeen yesterday unveiled Dave Cormack as their chief executive, replacing Gordon Bennett, who resigned in August. Cormack, a life-long fan, is currently president of an American-based internet recruiting corporation.

webTitle: Boro want Boban to revive good old days

fields.headline: Boro want Boban to revive good old days
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough are set to sign Croatian midfielder Zvonimir Boban from Milan.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough are to throw more money at their mounting problems by trying to sign Zvonimir Boban from Milan. The 32-year-old midfielder, currently earning £35,000 a week in the reserves, met Boro officials in Italy yesterday and they are believed to have offered him a three-year deal at close to £50,000 a week, approaching that of his Croatia team-mate and Boro striker Alen Boksic.

Boban leapt to prominence when he attacked a policeman in 1990 after a match between Croatia Zagreb and their Serbian rivals Red Star Belgrade. He joined Milan shortly afterwards but Alberto Zaccheroni currently claims he is unfit.

Although Boban has 51 caps, his arrival may not appease Middlesbrough fans who have not seen a home win since March and have been clamouring for younger legs in the team. Their three-man midfield on Monday, when they lost at home to Newcastle, had a combined age of 93 in Christian Karembeu, Paul Ince and Robbie Mustoe.

Meanwhile Bologna are preparing a £3.5m bid for Newcastle's French centre-half Alain Goma, who scored the second goal on Monday.

Christian Panucci, on loan from Internazionale, has been released from his loan spell at Chelsea, the first victim of Claudio Ranieri's regime.

Luis Figo, who moved from Barcelona to Real Madrid in the summer, has changed his car's Barcelona number plates so that it will not be attacked by his new club's fans.

webTitle: Public access terminals to give health advice online

fields.headline: Public access terminals to give health advice online
fields.standfirst: Terminals in supermarket kiosks will link public to health information
fields.trailText: The government has launched public access internet kiosks offering NHS health information online.
fields.body:
The government has launched public access internet kiosks offering NHS health information online.

The touch-screen terminals will be linked to the NHS Direct website - the online version of the nurse staffed helpline service.

People without access to the internet will be able to use the kiosks to get basic health information and advice.

They will be situated in supermarkets, pharmacies, sixth form colleges, the Albert Docks in Liverpool and the Dover ferry terminal in Kent.

Health Minister Gisela Stuart, opening the first kiosk at an Essex pharmacy today, said that by the end of the year, more than 150 kiosks will be available and there could be more than 500 across the country by 2004.

"The new NHS Direct information points will give the public greater information about how they can look after their own health and about health services," Ms Stuart said.

"We've placed them in key public locations such as supermarkets, pharmacies and libraries because we want as many people as possible to have easy access to up-to-date, clear and reliable health information. "We are also targeting universities, sixth form colleges and popular holiday destinations."

Useful link
NHS Direct

fields.headline: Wednesday sinking fast
fields.trailText: Burnley 1 - 0 Sheff Wed
fields.body:
At least the Titanic had a band playing as it sank.

Sheffield Wednesday's famously loyal group of musicians were all that was missing as the once mighty Owls sunk to a new low at Turf Moor. Back in 1893 they lost seven games in a row but this defeat, their eighth on the bounce, plumbed new depths.

Wednesday are barely recognisable these days. Des Walker still has pace, Steve Harkness is competent, but the rest are a mix of over-anxious youngsters and to be brutal, journeymen. Manager Paul Jewell is making strenuous efforts to sign former Wimbledon striker Efan Ekoku on loan from Grasshoppers of Zurich, but you get the distinct impression only intervention from Heaven rather Efan will end their freefall.

Wednesday managed not one notable effort on goal throughout the entire first half. Fortunately for the Owls, Burnley, who had slightly surprised themselves by their results this season, were not much better.

The captain Steve Davis always looked most likely to score as he finally sparked Burnley into life with a couple of near-misses and it was no surprise when he finally did break the deadlock.

If nothing else, Wednesday were at least fighting for the point which has eluded them for so long. Bodies were put on the line, albeit usually the 18-yard line, and with their opponents lacking a truly creative edge, Jewell must have dared to dream.

He reckoned without Davis, as unfortunately did his team, failing utterly to offer any sort of meaningful challenge when he jumped for Mellon's corner. It was not as though they had not been warned.

fields.headline: Hughes finds Wolves' weak spot
fields.trailText: WBA 1 - 0 Wolves
fields.body:
West Bromwich Albion ensured the form book held sway here last night by extending their unbeaten run against their Black Country neighbours to seven games.

Despite their apparent invincibility against Wolves, Albion have finished below them in the past three seasons. But the signs are that sequence will end after this victory extended the gap between the two teams in the First Division table to 12 points.

Wolves gave a first start to Darren Peacock, who is on loan from Blackburn and has a month to earn himself a permanent move to Molineux.

Out of contract at the end of the season, Peacock will come somewhat cheaper than another central defender on Colin Lee's wish list, Hannu Tikanen of Viking Stavanger. The Finnish international helped keep England at bay in Helsinki last week and will cost Wolves £2m.

But judging by the run-around Peacock was given by Hughes, Tikanen might ultimately prove to be the cheaper option. Peacock was bypassed by Hughes when the Albion striker had the first shot of the game in the 11th minute.

That was fired straight at Michael Oakes but eight minutes later he went one better from the spot. fields.headline: Barnard rescues Barnsley's dire day
fields.trailText: Barnsley 1 - 1 Tranmere
fields.body:
Darren Barnard struck a confident 83rd minute penalty to prevent Barnsley going down to their second defeat at Oakwell in the space of four days.

Barnard was given the opportunity to level a disappointing match when Reuben Hazell needlessly fouled Bruce Dyer as they competed for a cross.

"Big Thing", said the sponsor's name on the front of Barnsley's shirts. Unfortunately, Big Nothing would have been more appropriate for large periods, particularly in the first half.

More than a quarter of the game had gone before Barnsley's Mike Sheron was responsible for the only moment of anxiety for either keeper until Wayne Allison put Tranmere into the lead shortly before the break.

Sheron, employed in midfield by his manager Dave Bassett, recalled his more erstwhile striker's duties after Bruce Dyer created uncertainty in the Rovers' defence.

Sheron thumped a volley with such authority from 18 yards that it would surely have produced a goal had it been directed anywhere except into the chest of the keeper Joe Murphy.

At least Barnsley also created earlier openings for Matty Appleby, both badly misdirected in a manner which epitomised the first-half exchanges.

Rovers could come up with nothing in comparison until Allison ended an intensely frustrating 42 minutes for manager John Aldridge with a goal they didn't deserve.

Riddled with uncertainty after four scessive defeats, Tranmere had created nothing until Jason Koumas's shot was fortuitously deflected off Sean Flynn into the path of Allison. His finish showed a crispness that was non-existent up to that point.

Barnsley suffered another setback when they lost the midfield energy of Appleby early in the second half when his fierce shot rebounded back into his face as he charged into a pack of defenders.

Appleby needed five minutes of treatment before he was stretchered off and he may not remember too much of this game. Others will just try to forget it.

The quality continued to be mediocre, although Tranmere - with something to defend - showed a new determination and should have stretched their lead in the 59th minute through Allison.

Koumas was the creator with a well-judged ball, which sent Allison clear, but the striker could only direct his shot into the side netting after rounding keeper Kevin Miller.

Reprieved, Barnsley finally discovered some attacking flair, and could have levelled twice before Barnard finally found a way past Murphy.

But the highly-rated keeper reacted superbly in the 79th minute to turn away a shot from substitute Lee Jones, the former Tranmere player.

Seconds later, Murphy beat out an angled effort from Neil Shipperley. It was later confirmed that Appleby was taken to hospital to have tests for concussion.

fields.headline: Claridge spots a winning streak
fields.trailText: Portsmouth 2 - 1 Crewe
fields.body:
Steve Claridge's good luck story continued last night when, for his second match in charge as player-manager, he again scored the winning goal.

He followed up Saturday's winner against Sheffield Wednesday with an 81st-minute penalty against Crewe and awarded for a dubious foul on Justin Edinburgh.

Claridge had to bring in Michael Panopoulos after Steve Harper went down with a calf-muscle injury in the warm-up, and the player-manager's eventful evening continued when the referee ordered him to pull up his socks after a free-kick had been awarded against him. Indeed the Lewes official Steve Tomlin refused to allow play to continue until he conformed.

To round off an otherwise unspectacular first half the player-manager earned himself a yellow card in the 41st minute for dissent, disputing a free-kick awarded against him for a foul.

Almost inevitably he was involved in the best chance of the half, too, a superb piece of control with his back to goal setting up Thomas Thogersen, who dragged his low shot across the face of goal.

The match sprung to life in the second half with a penalty award and then a sending off after Pompey had plugged away without reward for an hour. Scott Hiley brought down Mark Rivers inside the area and Shaun Smith stepped up to convert the spot-kick.

But Crewe's lead was put in jeopardy two minutes later when Paul Tait was sent off for a second bookable offence; on each occasion he had barged into the home goalkeeper. The hosts took advantage almost immediately, Thogersen scoring with a low shot from 15 yards five minutes later.
